Title: Comment from Dunnavant, Justin
Comment:
I support this nomination as the first Indigenous-led nomination of a national marine sanctuary that will advance collaborative conservation and collaborative management, protect ecological and cultural treasures, and close a biodiversity protection gap between two existing sanctuary boundaries.

This designation has the ability to set new precedent in how coastal and Indigenous communities can work together to conserve America's coastal waters and cultural heritage resources.  

We thank the Biden-Harris Administration for taking this important step to final designation that will honor California’s central coast tribes, communities, cultural and ecological resources.

Title: Comment from CHARBONNEAU, RONALD
Comment: As a California coastal resident and a volunteer Whale Watch naturalist for over 20 years with the Cabrillo WhaleWatch program based at the Cabrillo Marine Museum in San Pedro, I am very invested in the health of our coastal ecosystem.  I wholly support NOAA's proposed designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) in the waters along and offshore of the coast of central California.  Fragile ecosystems are subjected to many threats.  The establishment of a Marine Sanctuary provides a safe refuge to sustain a wide spectrum of flora and fauna.  Regulation of commercial operations, drilling, cable laying and some destructive fishing practices are necessary to preserve a fragile environment from degradation.  Sanctuary designation of an offshore coastal area that is culturally significant is the best way to ensure that future generations will be able to enjoy a wide spectrum of activities.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Dean, Janette
Comment:
I lived in California from 1984-2010 after going there to study at USC including to help work on wildlife conservation, and I still visit frequently. I also worked as a work-study student in the mammalogy and ornithology departments at the Los Angeles Museum of Natural History and enjoyed knowing the hard-working cetacean scientists there.

Wildlife habitats must be protected in the U.S so that multiple species can thrive in healthy ecosystems that indigenous populations have co-existed with for millennia. I therefore also urge NOAA to make the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
 
The designation will much better protect 134 miles of coastline and would encompass more than 5,600 square miles of water off of the Central California coast. It would also advance President Biden's "America the Beautiful Initiative," which is very much welcomed by so many of us people nationwide as it will support locally led conservation efforts across the country with a goal to conserve and restore 30 percent of U.S. lands and waters by 2030. This U.S. step would also help us meet our obligations as part of the similar global initiative. 

As we ask other countries to better protect natural habitats for wildlife and plants, we must do the same and "walk the talk." Thank you from myself and all the marine mammals and other animals and people who will benefit from this crucial and long-belated marine sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Bell, Jessica
Comment:
As a coastal resident, I strongly support the designation of a new national marine sanctuary off the central California coast.
This designation should be named Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in recognition of the past, present, and future of the Chumash people and their culture.
The sanctuary boundaries should include the full geographic extent reflected in the original proposal.
The management plan should ensure the lasting protection of the sanctuary’s outstanding ecological and cultural resources.
The sanctuary should prohibit any oil and gas exploration, development or production.
The sanctuary should prohibit seabed mining, ocean dumping and other activities harmful to the seafloor, cultural resources and marine ecosystem.
The sanctuary should protect water quality from pollution sources including cruise ships and commercial vessels.
Indigenous Collaborative Management should be applied to empower the Chumash Nation and other Indigenous Peoples to steward these invaluable resources.
The sanctuary should support and promote marine research, education, and stewardship.

Title: Comment from Haifley, Aaron
Comment:
To whom it may concern,

I am writing as a private citizen in support of the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS). 

My support for this designation is based on the following items:

•	The CHNMS will protect a unique area of consistent upwelling. This upwelling lifts nutrients from deep ocean toward surface waters, providing food and sustenance for marine life. Critically, this area of upwelling is a part of whale migrations along the west coast of the United States. The upwelling also provides nutrients to species who live in the area year-round, as well as species living across the other 4 National Marine Sanctuaries (NMS) along the California coastline. We need to protect this area of upwelling, in order to:
o	Protect the species reliant on the upwelling as a source of nutrients
o	Protect the ecosystem value of the species in the area, and across the other NMS along the California Coast 
o	Protect economic value of this coastline as an attractor of tourism – those who come out to do whale tours, sea otter tours, diving, sport fishing, etc.

•	The City of San Luis Obispo (SLO), and the surrounding area of California’s Central Coast, relies on both tourism and agriculture as primary drivers of their economy. The CHNMS will support both tourism and local agriculture:
o	The Tourism Board of SLO already leans on coastal imagery and attractions to attract visitors to the area. Protecting the waters around the region are integral to ensuring visitors have a safe and exciting tourism experience, and will provide the SLO region greater opportunities for economic development. 
o	Agriculture is key to SLO & surrounding areas economic success. Successful agriculture is reliant on healthy land & air, and existing within a stable ecosystem. We know climate change is an imminent threat to current agricultural practices, particularly in area like SLO which will become notably hotter & drier. Our marine environments are key carbon sinks, and protective mitigating factors against the threat of climate change. By protecting our marine environments, we can take a small but important step to protecting our agricultural activity and concurrent economic activity. Additionally, the immediate proscriptions against offshore oil & gas drilling associated with the CHNMS provide immediate benefits to protecting local air quality, and thus local surface water quality as well. 

•	Designating the CHNMS enables specialised teams & initiatives associated with the NMS program to operate across this stretch of coast. In particular, the Whale Entanglement Team and the Blue Whales & Blue Skies initiative.

•	Designating the CHNMS would provide a model of a collaborative framework for Tribal Governments & Indigenous Communities to work with NOAA going forward.  This is a unique opportunity to leverage collected wisdom and knowledge of local Indigenous people to collaborate on developing resources in area of research, education, and environmental protection. Additionally, designation will provide protections to ancient Sacred Sites offshore.

•	I am disappointed the Agency-preferred boundaries do not include the Morro Bay area, immediately south of the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary (MBNMS) boundary. Understanding this area is left out in order to construct undersea transmission cables for off-shore wind electricity generation, I hope & expect this area will fall under Sanctuary protection, either CHMNS or MBNMS immediately following construction of the transmission cables.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Farmer, Angela
Comment:
I am writing in support of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
Designating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is a crucial step in recognizing and safeguarding the ecological, historical, archaeological, and cultural significance of the central California coast. This designation offers a platform for heightened protection, sustainable management, and increased awareness of this precious region.
The Northern Chumash Tribal Council's role as stewards is of paramount importance. Their ancestral connection to the land and waters provides an unparalleled understanding of the area's intricate balance. Their centuries-old wisdom, cultural heritage, and commitment to sustainability make them the best custodians of the sanctuary. Their stewardship ensures that preservation efforts are infused with respect for tradition, ecological balance, and a holistic view of the ecosystem.
In a world where conservation requires a delicate blend of modern science and traditional wisdom, the Northern Chumash Tribal Council's involvement ensures a harmonious approach that benefits both nature and culture. The sanctuary designation, coupled with their stewardship, promises a brighter future for this remarkable area.

Title: Comment from B, Claudia
Comment:
Fabulous that our diverse beautiful Central California offshore area is potentially going to be a Marine Sanctuary. The Biden-Harris Administration proposal for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is extremely important. 

The comprehensive Action Plan touches on how the Marine Sanctuary will be importantly related to the Indigenous Culture of the Area, the Maritime industry, the Offshore Energy Plans which are just now in the beginning stages of how to harness the wind, and Water Quality that must be kept in its beautiful pristine state for wildlife, fisheries and tourism in the area.

Title: Comment from Winter, Jen
Comment:
I'm commenting to express my support for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. National Marine Sanctuaries protect natural and cultural marine resources.
> The collaborative management with the Chumash and Salinan tribes allows peoples with a vested interest and key knowledge in these specific cultural resources a direct role in protecting and maintaining those resources.
> Protecting the natural marine resources in the area would support continued recreation, tourism, and commercial activities supporting the local economies -- this may involve limiting access in some way, but limiting access (requiring permits, etc) is often key in protecting the natural resources (see also Girma G. Selassie & Yiannis Kountouris, 2010. "Fishing Permit Price and Wetland Conservation: A Choice Experiment on the Value of Improved Environmental Quality of Lake Awassa, Ethiopia," Chapters, in:  Jeff Bennett & Ekin Birol (ed.),Choice Experiments in Developing Countries, chapter 4, Edward Elgar Publishing. <https://ideas.repec.org/h/elg/eechap/13208_4.html>). If natural resources are not protected, biodiversity can plummet resulting in limits on recreation, tourism and commercial activities (e.g. see David Wolf, Will Georgic, and H. Allen Klaiber, 2017. "Reeling in the damages: Harmful algal blooms' impact on Lake Erie's recreational fishing industry", Journal of Environmental Management, vol. 199, p. 148-157. <https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0301479717304905>).

Title: Comment from Christensen, Ryan
Comment:
I strongly object to the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) as proposed because of the carte blanche "Prohibition on Exploring for, Developing, or Producing Oil, Gas, or Minerals" and "Prohibition on Drilling Into or Altering the Submerged Lands" included in the list of prohibited or regulated activities. America should always treasure and protect all of its resources (anthropological, biological, historical, mineralogical, and others) in ADDITION to natural resources. Safeguarding the environment should not automatically preclude or prohibit human activity in any given area. The Just and Noble cause of stewarding the world given to us by God does not have to fall into a false dichotomy of either prohibiting human activity or letting man run rampant over the earth with no checks. I believe that the history of this area deserves recognition and safeguards but this proposed rule is harsh and anti-human flourishing.
      With regard to the outright ban on Fossil Fuel exploration, development, or production, the most reliable and clean form of energy is going to have deleterious effects on the environment of the rest of the world when more energy-intensive and harmful sources of energy that have wider footprints and greater environmental impact (including solar panels and wind) are substituted in the absence of Fossil Fuel and Nuclear Energy creation that will result from this rule. Safe extraction of Fossil Fuel resources could be regulated and enforced in such a manner as to protect all other resources without a harmful outright ban. 
       The prohibition on drilling into or altering submerged lands should be removed from this rule. It appears to not apply to multiple common-sense exemptions that undermine the argument for prohibiting this activity. Cultural heritage sites should be protected but the wording in this text is too broad. The points raised above also apply to this prohibition. 
        I strongly oppose the adoption or enactment of the rule as proposed.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Belt, Annie
Comment:
As our ocean ecosystems and coastal communities face unprecedented threats from climate chaos, aquaculture, pollution, and a quickly changing marine environment, the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to protect 7,000 square miles of ocean spanning 156 miles of coastline between Cambria in San Luis Obispo for future generations offers a prudent and well planned countermeasure, and is the product of decades of stakeholder discussions.

The proposed marine sanctuary will bridge the gap between the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary and the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary, permanently protecting these ecologically significant waters from habitat fragmentation, and thereby strengthening the area's health and resilience against of climate chaos, overfishing, and ocean fish farming. 

These waters include wildlife habitat, internationally significant undersea features, and submerged Chumash sites dating back more than 9,000 years.
Unique to this region, the proposed marine sanctuary encompasses the western slope of the underwater Santa Lucia Bank at the base of the continental shelf, a 3,000-meter-deep submarine canyon, three major nutrient upwellings, spawning areas and rookeries, and feeding areas and migration lanes for 13 species of whales and dolphins.

The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would protect one of the
largest remaining kelp forests, helping to combat climate breakdown while preserving sacred Chumash cultural sites.

It has been estimated that a national marine sanctuary off the Central Coast would generate at least $23 million in economic activity and create 600 new jobs.

Designating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would strengthen
marine research, education, and conservation along the coast while incorporating
the values and traditions of surrounding Indigenous communities.

We have a shared responsibility to create certain safeguards for our oceans and coastal resources. The proposed sanctuary would help meet our shared responsibility.

Title: Comment from Garrison Miller, Melora
Comment: As a lifelong Californian who has seen the economic, environmental, and even spiritual benefits of protecting our ocean—and the devastating consequences of failing to do so—I fully support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I currently live in the Monterey Bay area, which is world-renowned in part due to the ocean conservation efforts resulting from the Monterey Bay Marine Sanctuary designation. I've also been lucky enough to spend time paddleboarding and swimming in the ocean in Avila Beach, Pismo Beach, and Gaviota, and delighting in the diverse, healthy marine wildlife there—everything from sea otters to seals to sea lions! As someone who's been personally impacted by California's wildfires, I also appreciate the value of indigenous wisdom in solving our toughest environmental problems: Just as California tribes have joined in the fight against wildfires using indigenous controlled burning techniques, so too can they help combat issues such as ocean pollution and over-fishing in the areas they know best. Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment from Barrios, Dayna
Comment:
To whom it may concern,
While I commend the work that has been done to protect our ocean waters along with our animal relatives, it is extremely important that actual Chumash voices are heard. The Northern Chumash Council does NOT have documented Chumash ancestry, this area is actually the traditional homelands of the Yak Tityu Tityu Yak Tilhini (YTT), and they have not been consulted in the ways in which they should have been. The YTT have a long-documented history of having ancestral ties to these lands and it is extremely harmful and disrespectful to not raise their voices up and prioritize their wishes and vast knowledge. Often times outsiders will talk about "not wanting to get involved with Native politics", but the government has been doing that for hundreds of years which is the reason why we are even in this situation. So yes, you should get involved and ensure the people you are working with have documented lineage to these lands. Otherwise, you are just perpetuating the erasure of true Native voices that has gone on since colonization and missionization.

Title: Comment from Spotts, Richard
Comment:
I strongly support and greatly appreciate this proposed rule for this Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary designation and management plan.

I grew up in southern California and I am familiar with this incredibly beautiful and biologically diverse marine coastal area.  I applaud the tribal members and others who have been advocating for this sanctuary for many years. 

I urge NOAA to ensure that this management plan will contain sufficiently strong required protections that will prevent any future human uses from harming or jeopardizing the marine ecosystems and species within this sanctuary area.

The climate and extinction crises are already dangerous and rapidly getting worse.  These crises pose an existential threat to humanity and the health of the biosphere.  The status quo management of the past is no longer appropriate or sustainable.  Bold and innovative solutions are urgently needed.  I believe that creating and effectively protecting this sanctuary area will be a significant positive step forward.

Thank you very much for your kind consideration of my comments.

Title: Comment from Kilcoyne, Shelley
Comment: I am thrilled to know the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is progressing toward fruition. As a Surfrider member and coastal recreation user, I strongly support the designation of a new national marine sanctuary off the central California coast. This designation should be named Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in recognition of the history and culture of the First Nation Chumash people. The sanctuary boundaries should include the full geographic extent reflected in the original proposal. The management plan should ensure the lasting protection of the sanctuary’s outstanding ecological and cultural resources. The sanctuary should prohibit any oil and gas exploration, development or production. The sanctuary should prohibit seabed mining, ocean dumping and other activities harmful to the seafloor, cultural resources and marine ecosystem. The sanctuary should protect water quality from pollution sources including cruise ships and commercial vessels. Indigenous Collaborative Management should be applied to empower the Chumash Nation and other Indigenous Peoples to steward these invaluable resources. The sanctuary should support and promote marine research, education, stewardship, recreation and tourism. Please do right by our planet and its biosphere and enact this sanctuary designation. The time is now. Thank you.

Title: Comment from Byars, Lee

To whom it may concern,

 

I am writing to support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary designation. I am an Australian citizen, who has visited the central coast of California a couple of times over the last two years while visiting my husband's family.

 

What I’ve learned of the area is fascinating. The upswelling which occurs and attracts such an abundance of marine life creates an amazing, unique, and beautiful coast line to visit. I have loved my time driving down the coast and stopping to try spotting otters, dolphins, seals, and potentially whales.

 

As a foreign tourist, I believe protecting this area adds immense value. Protected sanctuaries become places of interest, bringing in more tourists to participate in the local economy. We stayed overnight in Morro Bay and San Luis Obispo, spending money on accommodation, food, and entertainment. That local spending wouldn’t have occurred if not for the stunning coastline which attracted us in the first place. I have told many people about our visit, with several others visiting this year based on stories of our visit. 



I believe Morro Bay should also be protected by the sanctuary. 



Regards,

 

Lee Byars

Title: Comment from Kaiser, Risa
Comment: I strongly support the quick approval by NOAA of the proposed Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary on the California Central Coast.  Fred Collins and his daughter Violet have dedicated their lives to this grassroots effort initiated by their non-federally recognized tribe to conserve our ocean resources and honor the tribal presence and history in these sacred waters.  The Northern Chumash Tribe has reached out to all other tribes, to all local government and environmental groups, to fishermen, to individuals, and particularly to the Spanish speaking members of our communities.  The support of all these entities is overwhelming.  We have been eager to add our comments to this final phase, and we hope the approval will be swift enough to create a boundary beyond which off-shore wind infrastructure cannot encroach.  While we support alternative energy sources, we treasure our ocean life.  Lastly, we are thrilled to connect the two existing marine sanctuaries in California for the safe passage of migrating sea life.  Thank you for the work NOAA has done during this long process. Title: Comment from Contreras, Kevin
Comment:
Dear NOAA Office of National Marine Sanctuaries,

Thank you for all your work toward protecting another important part of California's coastal waters. I strongly support the Initial Boundary Alternative, 7,600 sq mi that links to the Monterey Bay NMS and the deep sea, rather than the NOAA preferred Alternative 2 Cropped Bank to Coast, 1,500 sq mi smaller that doesn't link north to the MBNMS or east to the deep sea. The bigger the conservation area the better in my opinion. We need to dramatically increase areas of protected waters and land to minimize the extent of the 6th mass extinction of biodiversity human activities are causing. Time is not on our side, biodiversity and ecosystems are collapsing, for only the 6th time in the Earth's 5-billion-year history. Our actions need to match the scale of the challenge. 

I recommend dealing with undersea cables and site naming concerns while protecting the full 7,600 acres. There are ways to accommodate cables and naming. On land utility easements exist through protected areas that allow that use to remain, maintained and modified in ways consistent with overall protections. I support adhering to site naming preferences by Indigenous communities and applaud the collaboration you've established with them on this and other projects.

Thank you for your consideration,

Kevin Contreras
103 Hall Rd
Watsonville, CA 95076

Title: Comment from Knight, Dr. Anthony
Comment: I strongly support the new Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  I was a member for six years of the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary Advisory Council and also served on the Sanctuary Education Team.  I am also a member of the Channel Islands Naturalist Corps.  My comments are my own, and I do not represent any of these organizations, and I list them for experience only.  The new Sanctuary should include LARGE Marine Reserves where fishing is not allowed. Fishing is destructive and disruptive to the fragile ecosystem.  Marine mammal entanglements are nearly always a result of fishing gear.  Depletion of fish stocks such as baitfish, squid, groundfish, and rockfish has a negative impact on all species that rely on them for survival.  Humans have many other economical alternatives for a healthy diet - particularly a climate-friendly, plant-based diet.  Keeping the areas pristine for marine life will enhance eco-tourism in the region.  There are countless studies that provide examples from all over the nation that demonstrate that large marine protected areas where fishing is not allowed or carefully regulated are more resilient to the effects of climate change and provide enhanced economic opportunity for people who live in or near them. There is no reason to doubt that this will not be the case in the proposed Sanctuary.  Creating the new Sanctuary is a win-win for everyone, but in particular for the marine life that is part of the complex ecosystem.

Title: Comment from Holley, Avery
Comment: The National Marine Sanctuary (NMS) network has protected and preserved ecologically, culturally, and economically valuable places and resources for years. The Monterey Bay NMS is a prime example of how protecting our coastal spaces can revitalize ecosystems, allowing commercially valuable species to thrive, open opportunities for research and recreation, enrich the lives of residents and visitors, and preserve heritage sites important to the original stewards of these lands. The Chumash Heritage NMS sets a historical precedence in potentially being the first of our NMS co-managed by the Indigenous people whose lands we occupy. This will give them a say in the sanctuary's management to continue their stewardship of these lands and waters, protect important heritage sites they have occupied for upwards of 20,000 years, and advance their sovereignty. Indigenous communities have been the greatest advocates of environmental conservation for decades and it has been proven that they are crucial to protecting the biodiversity of our planet. They are experienced ecological caretakers as their cultures are built around balancing their relationship with the land and waters. I think this NMS will be crucial to preserving our coastal habitats, which are suffering from the effects of climate change, loss of biodiversity, human encroachment and development, and pollution. The Chumash community will be excellent and capable leaders as the co-managers of this NMS. We will need their help to be able to pass down a safe, sustainable world to our future generations.

The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should be officially designated as soon as possible.
The sanctuary boundaries should include the full geographic extent reflected in the original proposal - i.e., the Initial Boundary Alternative.
The management plan should ensure the lasting protection of the sanctuary’s outstanding ecological and cultural resources.
The sanctuary should prohibit any oil and gas exploration, development or production.
The sanctuary should prohibit seabed mining, ocean dumping and other activities harmful to the seafloor, cultural resources and marine ecosystem.
The sanctuary should protect water quality from pollution sources including cruise ships, commercial vessels and agricultural runoff.
Indigenous Collaborative Management should be applied in an equitable manner to empower the Chumash Nation and other Indigenous Peoples to steward these invaluable resources.
The sanctuary should support and promote marine research, education, stewardship, recreation and tourism.

Title: Comment from Chapman, PLA, Geo
Comment:
This area of the Central Coast is uniquely resplendent with marine life because of its relative isolation. The Vandenburg Space Center, the newly created Dangermond Preserve (Jalama Ranch) and numerous State Beaches on land along this coastline makes a Marine Preserve a brilliant addition.

Please move swiftly to approve this designation/protection to honor the Chumash Heritage and marine animals alike. The Chumash culture created the transcendent story of the Rainbow Bridge. It describes how those who fall off the rainbow bridge (pass-on) are transformed into dolphins. It honors both those passed and the current marine life. A Chumash Marine Preserve would continue their legacy.

Title: Comment from Patterson, Theo
Comment: I fully support a proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (NMS), however I strongly suggest that the ORIGINAL proposed sanctuary boundary be reconsidered for approval. The original plans to have the Chumash Heritage NMS extend to the Monterey Bay NMS would vastly improve the protections for marine life and prevention of future offshore drilling on the California Coast. This original proposal secures our oceans for endangered and once-endangered animals like Sea Otters and Northern Elephant Seals, guaranteeing them a stable future by bridging the Channel Islands NMS and the Monterey Bay NMS without leaving a perilous gap at Morro Bay. It would also give indigenous leaders more power over a larger swath of the coastline and off-shore areas, which are lands and waters that still belong to them and which must be managed with the help of their generations of expertise and wisdom. If the current proposal moves forward, it will leave Morro Bay's fragile marine ecosystem open to destruction, limit indigenous sovereignty, and severely hamper interconnected conservation efforts on our beautiful California coastline.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: As a Surfrider member and/ or coastal recreation user, I strongly support the designation of a new national marine sanctuary off the central California coast.This designation should be named Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in recognition of the history and culture of the Chumash people.The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should be officially designated as soon as possible.The sanctuary boundaries should include the full geographic extent reflected in the original proposal - i.e., the Initial Boundary Alternative.The management plan should ensure the lasting protection of the sanctuary’s outstanding ecological and cultural resources.The sanctuary should prohibit any oil and gas exploration, development or production.The sanctuary should prohibit seabed mining, ocean dumping and other activities harmful to the seafloor, cultural resources and marine ecosystem.The sanctuary should protect water quality from pollution sources including cruise ships, commercial vessels and agricultural runoff.Indigenous Collaborative Management should be applied in an equitable manner to empower the Chumash Nation and other Indigenous Peoples to steward these invaluable resources.The sanctuary should support and promote marine research, education, stewardship, recreation and tourism

Title: Comment from Thompson, Bonnie
Comment: I fully support the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. It will protect California’s marine life and economy, not to mention the Chumash people’s sacred sites. At a time when alarming things are happening in oceans—recall the water off Florida hitting 101 degrees Fahrenheit—the protection of this largely unexplored marine wilderness is essential. If humanity is to have any hope of not destroying the planet, sanctuaries like this one are essential.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Johnson, MJ
Comment:
I highly support establishing the marine sanctuary, especially under the direct guidance of our native peoples. I’ve had the opportunity to study local California history as a new transplant (after I moved here over 10 years ago) and realized just how much the Chumash and Salinan tribes are the best stewards for both natural resources and ongoing economic health. Over and over we see patterns of businesses that are so focused on profits that they ignore the long-term implications of their practices, and over the decades we see how they crumble because it throws the ecosystem out of balance. Both businesses and environment suffer when short-term gains are the primary focus. However, the native communities excel at recognizing patterns, exercising patience, and knowing when to utilize natural resources and when to scale back. The methods they developed of stopping skin cancer, managing land and growth through careful planning and maintenance, using renewable materials without pollution, and knowing how to build an abundant food supply that never runs out are critical skills we need to learn from. I respect their wisdom and centuries of committed experience and I can’t think of a better investment to both our marine life and our communities (socially, economically, for respectful and incredible nature tourism, and culturally). The central coast is an incredibly special place and we need to keep it that way. This place is now permanently home for me and I want to see it flourish. Having a solid foundation and mindful, caring leadership is essential.

Thank you for all your hard work on the council and for your consideration of the marine sanctuary.

Title: Comment from lopez, crystal
Comment:
• As a concerned citizen and/ or coastal recreation user, I strongly support the designation of a new national marine sanctuary off the central California coast.
• This designation should be named Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in recognition of the history and culture of the Chumash people.
• The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should be officially designated as soon as possible.
• The sanctuary boundaries should include the full geographic extent reflected in the original proposal - i.e., the Initial Boundary Alternative.
• The management plan should ensure the lasting protection of the sanctuary’s outstanding ecological and cultural resources.
• The sanctuary should prohibit any oil and gas exploration, development or production.
• The sanctuary should prohibit seabed mining, ocean dumping and other activities harmful to the seafloor, cultural resources and marine ecosystem.
• The sanctuary should protect water quality from pollution sources including cruise ships, commercial vessels and agricultural runoff.
• Indigenous Collaborative Management should be applied in an equitable manner to empower the Chumash Nation and other Indigenous Peoples to steward these invaluable resources.
• The sanctuary should support and promote marine research, education, stewardship, recreation and tourism
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: I and my family emphatically support this proposal to create the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Sea birds are dying on South American beaches due to climate change. Not only is our seaside a tremendous tourist draw bringing in millions of dollars to the Central Coast, fueling our economy, but it is essential to preserve an ecologically healthy environment where ever possible, while much of the earth's ocean life and human life will suffer as climate change worsens. Also, the Chumash deserve to be honored as our elders who protected the land in generations past so that we are able to benefit from it.

Title: Comment from Appleton, Will
Comment: I write to urge the approval of the proposed rule establishing the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Having lived on the Central Coast for nearly my entire life, I'm extremely aware of the unique beauty of our natural landscape and ecosystems. I'm also keenly aware of the displacement of the Indigenous Chumash tribe from their ancestral lands. Approval of this proposed rule would not only safeguard this delicate and important ecosystem but would be a single step among many others to rectifying the harm done to the local Indigenous population. Additionally, this proposed rule would bolster the local economy and generate millions of dollars. With the closure of Diablo Canyon fast approaching, approval of this rule would generate much needed revenue to our municipal governments. I urge approval of this rule.

We as a community are one step closer to officially creating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary off our Central Coast.

This 5,600 square-mile sanctuary would help protect our region's unique range of marine life, prohibit future offshore drilling, and support the wide swaths of California's economy that rely on our beautiful coastlines and marine ecosystems.

And once it is approved by the federal government, this sanctuary will also be the first to be co-managed by tribal leaders and government agencies.

We the people really need your help to get these protections to the finish line! 

This is a most important step in saving our marine eco systems, wild life and sanctuary from pollution and greed currently taking over our delicate planet. We need to make this happen!
Thank you, 
I am a private citizen of Santa Barbara California and a life long resident born in California.
Santa Barbara California

Title: Comment from Haifley, Dan
Comment:
First, please accept my gratitude for your NOAA team’s effort to sort through the large volume of public comments, most in support of Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS), to develop this comprehensive set of documents meant to guide its designation. Secondly, I wish to express my support for the swift designation of the sanctuary. 

The waters off San Luis Obispo and northern Santa Barbara Counties contain Rodriguez Seamount, Arguello Canyon, Arguello Terrace, and Santa Lucia Bank. This region hosts a complex system of ocean currents, where warmer waters from the south meet colder waters from the north. The upwelling of colder, nutrient-rich deep waters towards the warmer surface nourishes marine life which migrates through five existing west coast national marine sanctuaries. For thousands of years, First Peoples got to know these waters, and the life they contain, well.

Designation of the CHNMS should be done with the Initial Boundary Alternative that was proposed at nomination, plus NOAA's excellent add-on alternative known as the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alt 5b).  The Environmental Impact Statement acknowledges that all other alternatives would reduce the beneficial effects on biological resources provided by the Initial Boundary Alternative to “moderate” or “minor” by comparison and increase the vulnerability of those resources to adverse impacts that the Initial Boundary Alternative would prohibit or mitigate. 

The Initial Boundary Alternative would protect the area that would be excluded by the agency preferred alternative from harmful activities such as offshore oil, while electric transmission cables from the offshore wind area can be permitted by the sanctuary. Such cables will already need approval from the State Lands Commission and other agencies, and can receive the type of permits offered in national marine sanctuaries for other cables that are used, for example, by communications companies. I understand that there is a marked difference between electric transmission and communications cables, nonetheless sanctuary protection in this area is important enough to warrant the extra effort needed to take care that such cables do not harm wildlife and habitats in the region. The area between Cambria and Hazard Canton Reef is environmentally and culturally significant, and deserves CHNMS protection.

I also support the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” to honor the cultural history and stewardship of California Tribal peoples. I also support the equitable inclusion of all Central Coast Tribes, both federally and non-federally recognized Tribes, in collaborative management. All sanctuary stakeholders will benefit from Indigenous input.

Sanctuary education and community outreach can partner with schools for programs on ocean ecology, and Tribal history and culture, which is multilingual, multi-cultural, and focused on underserved communities. Research programs can address the impacts of climate change and encourage community science and elevate the use of Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) to enhance ecosystem-based management; teaching the benefits of protecting our ocean and planet and promoting the spirit of stewardship exemplified by the culture and history of the original Chumash caretakers.

I support regulations to protect Rodriguez Seamount, a critical habitat for an array of marine life. Sanctuary designation is needed before offshore wind operations to its northwest are established to protect the region from its impacts. California offshore wind operation’s leasing, siting, and permitting decisions should be guided by planning and research on its potential, cumulative impacts.

I recommend the creation of a Tribal Sanctuary Council made up of all interested local Tribal Groups. The designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary will be an unprecedented accomplishment honoring the history and culture of Native Americans, the Chumash people and their ancestors who inhabited this region for more than 10,000 years. 

Thank you, again for your team’s efforts, and for considering my comments.

Title: Comment from Heller, Lee
Comment:
This comment is in support establishing a Chumash National Marine Sanctuary. This sanctuary has been years in the making and would be an important addition to protected areas along the central coast of California, where I live.

Marine sanctuaries are an important method for protecting ocean biodiversity, which is under assault from commercial fishing as well as the increasing impacts of ocean warming and climate change. Although establishing a marine sanctuary will not stop the latter, we can do everything in our power to protect special marine areas from overfishing and use, to preserve the habitats and creatures upon which our ecosystem depends.

From a cultural perspective, it’s an important acknowledgment of the Chumash peoples and their relationship to this region to both designate a marine protected area and to name it in recognition of that relationship. Native peoples have long been dispossessed despite being here before European settlers. Their historical relationship to land and ocean preservation may be important guide posts for us to follow as we try to restore what we are losing to overdevelopment and climate change.

Title: Comment from JELLISON, NORMA
Comment:
I wholeheartedly support designation of Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary
and a strong management plan that will achieve the proposed goals of Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

The waters off Central California are some of the most productive, biologically diverse and culturally significant on the West Coast. Significant features include Chumash sacred sites, feeding grounds for 13 species of whales and dolphins, major upwelling processes, sea otter population, thriving kelp forests, world class fish diversity, pinniped spawning areas and other critical marine ecosystem 

The Sanctuary and its management plan should ensure the strongest protections of the sanctuary’s outstanding ecological and cultural resources, prohibit oil and gas exploration, development or production, prohibit seabed mining, ocean dumping and other activities harmful to the seafloor, cultural resources and marine ecosystem and support and promote marine research, education, stewardship, recreation and tourism. 
Thank you for the opportunity to comment in support of this designation. Please  expeditiously designate this National Marine Sanctuary to protect this outstanding area of the Pacific Ocean for future generations.

Title: Comment from Bermingham, Ann
Comment:
I approve of NOAA's proposal to designate 5,600 square miles off the Central Coast of California north of Santa Barbara as a Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The nationally-significant natural resources, physical features and habitats, and the cultural and historical resources within the proposed sanctuary warrant long-term protection and management to reduce threats that would adversely affect their historical, cultural, archaeological, recreational, and educational value. Many threatened or endangered species, such as blue whales, snowy plovers, black abalone, white sharks, and leatherback sea turtles, rely on habitats, physical features, or prey found in the proposed sanctuary rely on habitats, physical features, or prey found in the proposed sanctuary. This area also contains hundreds of known or suspected shipwrecks of historical importance, including several on the National Register of Historic Places. Moreover, this region and its abundant resources have been home to coastal, ocean-going Indigenous tribes for tens of thousands of years, and submerged village sites may exist along paleoshorelines in the submerged lands of the proposed sanctuary. Several key threats to these natural, cultural, and historical resources include: various levels of human development and activity from: offshore energy development; decommissioning and removal of coastal and offshore industrial facilities; sound, discharges and whale strikes from vessel traffic; plastics, marine debris and pollutants from coastal runoff; and most of all, acute and cumulative impacts of climate change.
The fact this this new designation would prohibit future offshore drilling is an added bonus, and one in concert with the Biden Administration's efforts to transition the US economy to green energy. Since the disastrous 1968 oil spill the Santa Barbara region has fought to protect the environment from drilling in order to protect delicate marine ecosystems. This new sanctuary designation is welcomed by environmentalists and Chumash natives, and all who want to protect this area from destructive and irresponsible petrolium development. This is a significant site that deserves Federal protection.

Title: Comment from Dexter, Jack
Comment: I fully support the creation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  This proposal begins to redress multiple generations of abuse of our coastal resources and the systemic disenfranchisement of our native people from their cultural heritage. Upon reading the comments thus far submitted, those in opposition to the plan have a single argument: It does not support resource-extractive industries nor their profits.  I am pleased that their incautious values are so clearly stated.  It is long overdue that we, as a people in charge of the welfare of our planet, start putting the health of natural systems ahead of permanently damaging them for short-term profits.

Title: Comment from Drum , Joe
Comment:
Designating any part of the Ocean for conservation is usually a good thing for which I have advocated here and in the Northeast since 1980.
Native Americans cannot manage an Ocean, nor should they despite past rights.

Nor should any group; circumstances notwithstanding.
Nor should they be given special fishing privileges that they can exploit or assign as has happened in Oregon Alaska and elsewhere with other Tribes.
The US is the Sovereign now and the Chumash have their Casinos and left us to deal with the drunks who drive home after a night of free drinks and Home Equity Loans. Drunks who 
Killed my dog, by running over her in my front yard 
Drunks I’ve pulled from flipped cars as they hung upside down telling me to get them back into the casino so they can finish gambling even though I live near Tuckers Grove.
Let the Chumash manage their new found wealth other defeated nations never receive.
But don’t give them access or authorization over a body of water that belongs to all people, not just Native Americans who already take 36% of all west coast salmon, more than the seals. Let NOAA manage and do not give the Chumash the right to take fish, mammals or anything from the sea, nor commercial and sport fishing vessels and I own one vessel.
I’ve witnessed the sorrowful depletion of what was once an aduntant bountiful sea which needs protection! But not from all but a few who could destroy what is left, have no training in today’s restoration techniques. Two entities overseeing one body of water presents conflicts by definition so to avoid even the appearance of impropriety, please pass the Act creating a larger zone of no kill ocean applicable to all.
You are ceding rights we the US won or took 150 years ago, irrespective of the origins of our rights, they exist today for all people to enjoy the sea, Chumash included.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
As a person who spends four month out of the year in Morro Bay/Cayucos, I'm very concerned about Morro Bay wonderful Bird Sanctuary. It has been proven that Wind Turbines do not give out the electricity everyone wants them to believe they do. Wind Turbines do not belong in the same neighborhood as birds and whales. Turbine kill birds and whales not to mention other animals. Wind Turbines are not normal and Morro Bay has no need for the turbines since there will no longer be need for electricity into lithium battery storage. Lithium (batteries) cause fire when combined with water. https://firefighterline.com/how-to-put-out-lithium-battery-fire/  

Also Turbines are made by China and parts come from China. Turbines leak oil and cause more pollution than a car. https://dailycaller.com/2017/03/03/dirty-secret-behind-wind-turbines-they-need-lots-of-oil/

Replacing parts coming from China should be ruled out all together. China will withhold parts to get what they want causing energy blackouts. 

I cannot think of one good thing why Turbines should be used at all in any way. Wind Turbines have no use in a bird sanctuary except to kill birds. 

Please do your homework and do not allow Cayucos or Morro Bay to build these death turbines. There are other forms of energy. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Santuary should include Morro Bay and Cayucos. 
Thank you for your time.

Title: Comment from Lynn, Andrea
Comment:
I support NOAA's proposal to designate Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) in the waters along and offshore of the coast of central California to recognize the national significance of the area's ecological, historical, archaeological, and cultural resources and to manage this special place as part of the National Marine Sanctuary System. 

Through my research and studies of marine ecosystems I have become keenly aware of the deep wisdom necessary to manage and protect such essential, irreplaceable ecosystems as is Chumash. Blending established knowledge systems encourages complementary information outcomes as discussed in the multiple evidence base (MEB) framework (Kutz, 2021; Tengö et al., 2014). The Chumash draft management plan astutely includes "a framework for tribal and Indigenous collaborative management." Time and again, the data have demonstrated the benefits of collaborative approaches to protecting such valuable systems as this. We need only look to the Everglades for examples of the devastating impacts of ignoring Traditional Ecological Knowledge. We cannot lose thousands of years of wisdom, habitat, and history. Please, protect this place ... for all of us.

Title: Comment from Pirman, Bradley
Comment:
As a member of a local group of women and men who spearfish and sportfish, I consider myself a steward of the ocean. We're constantly picking up balloons and other trash from the water while we're out on boats, breaking up derelict lobster and crab traps, and picking up trash off the sea floor when we're diving.

I've noticed that recreational fishing isn't mentioned in the list of activities that should be promoted as part of the Blue Economy Action Plan. I want to be sure that sport fishing and spearfishing (sometimes called "underwater fishing") are included in the list of protected and encouraged activities in the Blue Economy Action Plan, and that the plan does not seek to impose any restrictions on these activities over and above any regulations that already exist.

Title: Comment from colins, Anne
Comment:
Hello, my name is Dr. Collins and I have resided on occupied Chumash land. I am writing to express my strong support for this Sanctuary and in full support of the Chumash people. As a scientist, I have dedicated my life to honoring nature's knowledge, with intentions to understand what direction we need to move in in order to be able for our lands to be habitable, for people to have resources, and for communities to thrive. This sanctuary is a vital step towards that goal. If you are in alignment with that goal, I would like to offer my recommendation to support this sanctuary. Thank you for considering information that I know might initially make us uncomfortable, but is rooted in collective protection of all people, animals, land, and water. The ecosystems that we inextricably need to thrive and I know no one needs the credentials of scientist to know this, so I know that outside of facts and information, it's clear that the heart of the communities you serve need this sanctuary. Please help do what's right. Thank you for the time and consideration and the energy it takes to care. We are loosing that lately, and it's a choice each day to care and thank you for doing that today, if you are able to.  
Thank you for you service to this land and people, 
Dr. Collins

Title: Comment from Bosold, Patrick
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel, 
My name is Patrick Bosold. I now live in Iowa. I'm a former resident of California, which I still consider my second home. I worked on the campaign to establish the California Coastal Conservation Commission in 1972. Over the years, it's become increasingly apparent that we need to protect the marine areas off of the California coast in order to ensure that the coastal experience will continue to be a good one. 
I'm SO pleased to hear that NOAA is finally considering a National Marine Sanctuary for the Chumash nation. I urge you to get this done quickly. California's near-coast waters have been under siege for decades. This needs to be stopped and reversed by establishing the proposed Chumash Nation National Marine Sanctuary and ensuring that the Chumash nation, which stewarded these waters for a thousand years and more, is given a leading voice in the establishment and management of the Sanctuary.
I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover approximately 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
Every time I've gone swimming, snorkeling, sailing or whale watching along the California coast, it's reawakened me to what a priceless natural resource this area is. I'll be doing this again in early November and it would be incredibly heartening to know that this part of the California coast has won the protections that a National Marine Sanctuary provides.
Therefore, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension - DON'T shrink it, please!!!
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries. This may sound like a no-brainer, but it must be said.
No offshore wind: there's been talk of carving out and removing a section of the proposed Sanctuary for an offshore wind project. I've worked in the renewable energy industry and I'm a passionate advocate for wind and solar. In this case, what I'd suggest is, no wind turbines in the Sanctuary area. If somebody wants to develop renewables in this area, bring it onshore. Work with the Chumash and other coastal tribes on smaller-scale, distributed solar projects. 
Once again, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary quickly. Let's allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
Sincerely,
Patrick Bosold

Title: Comment from Lilith, Ms
Comment:
As a Surfrider member and/ or coastal recreation user, I strongly support the designation of a new national marine sanctuary off the central California coast.
This designation should be named Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in recognition of the history and culture of the Chumash people.
The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should be officially designated as soon as possible.
The sanctuary boundaries should include the full geographic extent reflected in the original proposal - i.e., the Initial Boundary Alternative.
The management plan should ensure the lasting protection of the sanctuary’s outstanding ecological and cultural resources.
The sanctuary should prohibit any oil and gas exploration, development or production.
The sanctuary should prohibit seabed mining, ocean dumping and other activities harmful to the seafloor, cultural resources and marine ecosystem.
The sanctuary should protect water quality from pollution sources including cruise ships, commercial vessels and agricultural runoff.
Indigenous Collaborative Management should be applied in an equitable manner to empower the Chumash Nation and other Indigenous Peoples to steward these invaluable resources.
The sanctuary should support and promote marine research, education, stewardship, recreation and tourism.

Title: Comment from Wickham, Lyn
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel,

I am writing in support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension.

I live in Morro Bay, California.  The Pacific Ocean is essential to the economy and well-being of our community and surrounding areas.  It supports tourism, commercial fishing, recreation and solace for residents and visitors.  It is vital to keep it healthy and safe so the community can continue to enjoy and benefit from it.  

The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should include:
•	The largest possible boundary to maintain habitat and biodiversity.
•	A ban on all oil and gas development within its boundaries.  
•	Consideration for our small local commercial fishing community and other local underserved communities.
•	Outreach, education and research programs to increase knowledge and awareness of the ocean’s importance.
•	Protection for the Rodriguez Seamount to protect biodiversity.

Thank you!

Lyn Wickham
701 Anchor Street
Morro Bay, CA 93442

Title: Comment from Makes-Marks, Lou-Anne
Comment:
The Chumash Sanctuary surrounds Point Conception, which is the Chumash Jumping-Off Place for the spirits of their dead. The spirits jump out over the ocean there to go to the land of the dead, retracing the route of their original ancestral settlement voyages from early Polynesia.. As such, it is a very sacred and historic place. It thus represents the site of one of the earliest settlements on the California coast, as the Chumash settled there very early in California history. The paragraph below is a passage from my forthcoming book, "Stars on Earth: TransPacific Navigation and Settlement of the Americas," (2023) regarding the "Chumash Jumping-Off Place":
 
	The Chumash Western Gate has been interpreted as being a pathway to the afterlife for souls going to the next world. The gate was considered to be ethereal: “Traditional Chumash did not believe that there was literally a gate at Point Humqaq. It was instead known as a place of ascension, which in some literature is called a Jumping­-off Place,” a Portal for the Spirits of Chumash Dead to fly westward to the Land of Similaqsa (Anderson 2020b, 24).
	There is a Land in the west for Chumash spirits to aim toward:
"An old woman living among the Samala Chumash in the 1910s, M. S. Qiliqutayiwit, explained to John Harrington from the Smithsonian Institution the traditional funerary teachings that were handed down to her by her elders. She told Harrington that after death: 'The soul goes first to Point Conception, which is a wild and stormy place. It was called Humqaq, and there was no village there. In ancient times no one ever went near Humqaq. They only went near there to make sacrifices at a great Sawil. There is a place at Humqaq below the cliff that can only be reached by rope, and there is a pool of water there like a basin into which fresh water continually drips. And there in the stone can be seen the footprints of women and children. There the spirit of the dead bathes itself. Then it sees a light to the westward and goes toward it through the air, and thus reaches the land of Similaqsa.'” (Anderson 2020b, 23, quoting Blackburn 1975, 98)

Anderson, John M. 2020b. Kuta Teachings: Reincarnation Theology and the Chumash Path of the Dead. John Anderson Library. https://johnandersonlibrary.org/tribe/kuta-teachings/.

Blackburn, Thomas C., ed. 1975. December's Child: A Book of Chumash Oral Narratives. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press.



My PhD is in philosophy and religion from the California Institute of Integral Studies; my academic field of study is Indigenous North American religions. I am an independent researcher, writer, and activist for Indigenous American sacred Lands and Places.

Title: Comment from McMullin, William
Comment:
I fully support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The designation of the CHNMS should include the largest possible contiguous boundaries, the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alt 5b), because it would provide the most protection to this important area. We do not support NOAA’s Alternatives 2, 3, and 4 because they would not protect a critical area of coastline that contains important Chumash cultural sites, marine habitat, and local communities.

First, please support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary name. It is meant to recognize people that have lived on this coast for over 10,000 years; protect the heritage of the Chumash, an ocean-going band among the First People of the Pacific Coast; and provide a timely and appropriate reminder of the cultural origins. We support equitable inclusion of all Central Coast Tribes, both federally and non-federally recognized Tribes, in collaborative management. All sanctuary stakeholders will benefit from Indigenous input. 

It is vital that Sanctuary education and community outreach should partner with area schools to share information about sanctuary species and habitats and Chumash history and culture. Outreach should be multilingual, culturally relevant, and should focus on underserved communities.

In addition, regulations to protect Rodriguez Seamount should move forward. The seamount provides critical habitat for an extremely diverse and abundant array of marine life and deserves to be granted strong and permanent protection. The seamount has special national significance that warrants special protections through sanctuary designation. Once damaged, fragile seamount ecosystems may not recover in our lifetime.

The proposed CHNMS will protect our beloved ocean now that Offshore Wind (OSW) farms are being established off the Central California Coast. Sanctuary designation is needed before OSW and other environmental impacts affect the habitat, wildlife, and water quality. California’s first offshore wind projects must reflect leasing, siting, and permitting decisions that are guided by planning and comprehensive scientific research on the potential impacts to sensitive marine areas and species and coastal resources, including cumulative impacts.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Title: Comment from Davis, Katie
Comment:
I would like to express support for establishing the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and urge expedited action so that it can be established within the next year.

I strongly support the Gaviota coast extension as this is one of the last stretches of undeveloped coastline in California with a rich marine ecosystem.

I support offshore wind as the biggest threat to the Sanctuary is accelerated climate change and ocean acidification, and the only answer to that is rapid energy decarbonization and a variety of renewable energy sources. It would be preferable to not to leave out the Morro Bay area to allow for cabling, but rather have an expedited permit or carve out exception for all needed cables and offshore wind infrastructure so that you can still extend other Sanctuary protections to the area, while allowing offshore wind to co-exist with the Sanctuary. However, the agency-preferred boundaries would be preferable to a larger Sanctuary if the larger Sanctuary prevents or delays offshore wind development. Many environmentalists I know who are avid Sanctuary proponents would choose wind energy over a larger Sanctuary, but would prefer the larger Sanctuary AND wind energy.  

Shipping poses a significant threat to whales, including endangered blue whales. I support a speed limit in Sanctuary waters to prevent whale strikes. The Sanctuary should prioritize carbon sequestration. Every whale sequesters as much carbon as thousands of trees according to the International Monetary Fund, December 2019 "A strategy to protect whales can limit greenhouse gases and global warming"

I support marine protected areas, including areas that prohibit fishing. These areas have been proven to provide greater biomass and diversity of marine life and spill over into other areas. They improve fisheries. See, for example, June 2023 Smithsonian, "Marine Protected Areas Improve Health, Wealth of Nearby Communities" and World Economic Forum, Nov 2020, "Expanding marine protected areas could boost fish yields". They cite a study that found by expanding the world’s MPAs by just 5%, we could boost future fish catches by at least 20%

One of the biggest threats to the Sanctuary region is oil spills, particularly from Exxon's oil platforms (Heritage, Harmony, and Hondo). A May 2015 oil spill by Refugio beach that flowed into the ocean through a culvert caused huge marine damage, and an offshore spill would be far worse. The platforms have been shut down since the spill, now over 8 years ago, but Exxon would like to restart them. This has been opposed by Santa Barbara County, which denied their oil trucking plan as well as work on the corroded pipeline that caused the spill that might lead to restart. (Plains, the owner of the pipeline was prosecuted by the County and State of California and found criminally negligent in failing to maintain the pipeline.) Exxon is working on a proposal for a new pipeline over a number of rivers and streams through Santa Barbara, San Luis Obispo and Kern County to facilitate restart of these offshore platforms. However, the platforms and pipes to shore where designed to last 25 years and they are now over 40 years old. A new pipeline would propose to extend their life another 40 years, which would present a terrible on-going threat to the Sanctuary. While these platforms are indicated as "Outside proposed sanctuary boundaries for all alternatives"  DEIS Table 4.7-1, p. 169. P. 167 describes the oil and gas infrastructure within the boundaries, including the oil pipeline within the boundaries of sub-alt 5b.  Therefore, the Sanctuary should evaluate the safety of restarting this shut down pipeline within it's boundaries. It is with excellent reason that Sanctuaries prohibit new oil development, but the exception for existing oil leases should not mean that infrastructure long shuttered after a bad oil spill should automatically be allowed to restart without proof that it can do so safely and without risk to the Sanctuary. Exxon's oil processing facility on the coast was also the largest facility source of greenhouse gas emissions in Santa Barbara County, and allowing restart would increase emissions in the Sanctuary, which runs counter to the whole exercise of trying to protect this marine area.

Title: Comment from Hodin, Russell
Comment:
We stand in support of the creation of the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary. 

The special qualities embodied by this area’s pristine ocean, beaches, near shore and coastal mountains have anchored our love for and identification with California’s central coast, and San Luis Obispo county in particular.  The thought that these qualities may be preserved for future generations with the establishment of the sanctuary brings joy to our hearts. 

The gradual deepening of our respect and appreciation for these coastal lands and waters has been fostered by the integrity and dedication of certain locals of Chumash ancestry, for whom the concept of the unbuilt world as sanctuary is self-evident and visceral.  These and other dedicated individuals have tirelessly built public support for permanent protections of our coast for well over the four decades that we have resided here.  It is a honor today to stand with them in support of the sanctuary.

The sanctuary boundaries we support are the Initial Boundary Alternative and the Gaviota Coast Extension, specifically including the area from Montana de Oro to Cambria and eliminating any carveout for access to the proposed future Morro Bay wind energy lease area.

Creating one continuous sanctuary from the Gaviota coast to the waters off Cambria, coterminous with the Monterey Bay Marine Sanctuary, is the original intention of the sanctuary effort, and this must be respected.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the proposed boundaries. Your efforts towards the establishment of the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary are deeply appreciated. 

Sincerely,
Russell Hodin
Elizabeth Johnson

San Luis Obispo, CA

Title: Comment from City of San Luis Obispo
Comment:
Please see attached file(s) for the formal letter signed by the Mayor of San Luis Obispo. 

-

The City of San Luis Obispo strongly supports the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) and urges the NOAA to approve the proposed rulemaking that would designate over 5,500 square miles of waters along and offshore of the coast of central California as the CHNMS. 

The coast is vital to California. The CHNMS will help sustain biodiversity, provide recreational opportunity for the people of the state and the nation, and help sustain the economy based on tourism. As the CHNMS will fill the gap between two existing sanctuaries, it will magnify the positive effect of those existing sanctuaries and protect an area that is central to California's history and ecology. 

The Chumash and Salinan peoples have fished and gathered in the waters off the Central Coast of California for over 10,000 years. The cultural, ecological, and historical resources of this region are of national significance, and the area warrants long-term protection and management. 

The City of San Luis Obispo is particularly supportive of NOAA’s proposal to develop a coordinated, community-based management regime in partnership with Indigenous tribes and tribal organizations, and to implement a collaborative management structure to involve Indigenous communities in important management programs and initiatives. NOAA should fully honor and affirm the sovereignty of the first stewards of these waters through its Framework for Indigenous Collaborative Management. 

The City of San Luis Obispo is happy to join with the vast number of supporters in advocating for the approval the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Leupold, Ava
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

I am writing to express my support for the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative, along with the Gaviota Coast Extension. This designation aims to cover approximately 7,600 square miles of ocean in order to protect biodiversity and habitats. 

As a resident of Ojai, California, I consider the ocean to be a valuable and fragile ecosystem that is in great need of protection. Whenever I visit the coast, I take the time to explore the beach, appreciate wildlife, and reflect on the history of my ancestors who resided in Ventura and Santa Barbara counties for many generations. The ocean holds personal significance for me, as it is not only a source of recreation and spiritual well-being, but also an important aspect of community connections and economic vitality. It is essential to ensure that future generations are able to enjoy a clean, safe, and healthy ocean and continue to benefit from it.

The ocean's beauty and mystery have taught us a great deal, yet there is still much more to learn. Establishing a sanctuary would provide crucial support for ongoing research and education, serving present and future generations. Therefore, I fully endorse the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I kindly request that this sanctuary be established with the following considerations:

- The Initial Boundary Alternative, along with the Gaviota Coast Extension, to ensure the largest possible protection area.
- The name "Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary" to honor the heritage of the area.
- A collaborative management approach that includes all tribes for equitable decision-making.
- Outreach, education, and research programs that acknowledge and promote Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and facilitate access for underserved local communities.
- The protection of Rodriguez Seamount, as it plays a vital role in preserving biodiversity.
- A prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

In conclusion, I wholeheartedly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to take swift action in order to allow both current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from the many treasures that our ocean holds.

Sincerely,

Ava Leupold

Title: Comment from Heald, G

Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Gillian Heald and I support the expedited designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover approximately 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Santa Barbara, California and when I heard about this proposal, I was filled with relief and gratitude, that NOAA would be considering a proposal that could change the future of the planet and all of it's inhabitants, by starting with one 7600 square mile area--by designating it as an oceanic refuge--a sanctuary. This Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary could be a leading edge, an idea worth spreading out to more and more locations, generating more sanctuaries up and down the west coast of the United States. 

I swim regularly in the Pacific Ocean at Santa Barbara's clean beaches. I am a surfer and ride the waves. I body surf too. I walk on the shores with my husband and with my friends. I ride my bike along the path. My husband races in a Harbor 20 with his crew every Wednesday and most weekends out of the Santa Barbara Harbor. This Ocean is more than a recreation spot or even a beautiful location of the highest order of the Natural Kingdom. To me, It is a Living Spiritual Being and I am devoted to It as I am devoted to God. My devotion is to protect our beloved, sacred ocean as we would protect a baby, with fierce courage and gentle care. If we protect it now as a sanctuary, then it will serve future generations with all of it's bounty. If we do not act now, we will see further degradation of our ecosystem including pollution and harm to the biodiversity already under duress.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. and I want it to include: 
1. The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
2. The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
3. An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
4. Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
5. The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
6. Complete prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

Sincerely,

Gillian Heald

Comment:
Hello,My name is Mark Garman. I live in Cambria,CA.  I support the Initial Boundary Alternative map for the sanctuary.  Excluding the coastline from Cambria down to Point Buchon is a mistake.  We must protect entire section of coastline.  Please reconsider this exclusion.  
We are retired and volunteer with environmental and wildlife organizations in our area.  We feel strongly about protecting our coastline with a sanctuary status.  Thank you.
