Title: Comment from Conder, Ryan
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Ryan Conder and  I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Los Angeles, California and to me, the ocean is where I spend most of my time with my two boys surfing , diving and exploring. I enjoy seeing the native plants and animals as well. 
It’s such a beautiful refuge living in the city that everyone can enjoy 





I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Ryan Conder

Title: Comment from Dorfman, Nicole
Comment:
My name is Nicole Dorfman and I live in Morro Bay, CA.  I urge you to swiftly approve the designation of the CHNMS with the initial boundary lines that cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean, and completes the connection between the existing Monterey and Channel Islands sanctuaries.  Removing the Morro Bay area from the sanctuary will create negative conditions for my hometown, leading to an industrial highway in the ocean that will threaten marine life and leave the waters off the coast of Morro Bay vulnerable to oil and gas drilling in the future.  

While I support the original boundaries and scope of the proposed CHNMS, I do request that the name be changed to an inclusive designation that recognizes other indigenous tribes and their importance in this area.  Perhaps something like California Indigenous People’s Marine Sanctuary?   

Thank you for your serious consideration of this vital matter.

Title: Comment from mascarenhas, julie
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
   My name is Julie Mascarenhas, a coastal California resident.  Please rush to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and our precious marine habitats.
   I live on the Monterey Bay, and as a student was involved in the original designation of the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary back in the 1990s, which has been essential for our local coastal protections.  My kids have grown up on the water; my family and I frequent the coastal access areas and beaches, river outputs, estuarine systems, watch wildlife, and swim and paddleboard frequently.  They are connected to nature through our California ocean. We support the thriving local seafood economy, made safer by national marine sanctuary designation. 
   I am a marine ecologist working throughout the California Current ecosystem from Baja California, Mexico up to Vancouver Island.  The marine transition zone waters around Point Conception and up to Morro Bay are a critical area in need of protection in the CA Current system – plankton, krill, forage fish and top predators including large fish and sharks, seabirds, pinnipeds, dolphins and whales congregate in this zone.  We need protected areas as ecological climate refugia as climate change intensifies, particularly preventing damaging oil and gas extraction. 
   The Chumash marine waters are so important to their tribal culture and livelihood, which historically has largely been stripped from them.  They are marine stewards, largely prevented from carrying out their ongoing cultural task of protecting the marine waters where they live and striving for balance.  
   The ocean is also spiritually important for me personally – I have always lived on the ocean, and it is painful each time humans despoil the coast and ocean.  
Therefore, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, including:
•	Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
•	Sanctuary Name: “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
•	Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management and decisions from the outset, not after-the-fact
•	Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that highlight both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities, in multiple languages and multiple platforms to promote equal accessibility
•	Protection of Rodriguez Seamount: The inclusion of this important location to protect critical biodiversity and trophic transfer
•	Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, and urge the Administration to act swiftly on a comprehensive designation to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 Sincerely,
Julie Mascarenhas

Title: Comment from Osborn , ChrissyAnne
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is ChrissyAnne Osborn and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Los Osos, California and to me, the ocean is essential to keep healthy and protect our ocean families, the ocean is their home. The ocean helps keep the earth’s biorhythms steady for all living beings. 

	•I have been Sailing 
in this magical Pacific Ocean since I was five years old, for 55 years now. I love watching Mama and baby Humpback Whales feeding and playing with the dolphins in the ocean in Morro Bay and Cayucos. 
I want to absolutely make sure the Humpback Whales are protected when they migrate to and feed along the ocean coastline in Morro Bay, Cayucos and Cambria every summer and fall to feed before they migrate back to Mexico and South America. 
I want protection for the migrating Gray Whales along the coasts 
We also have the Morro Bay Harbor Porpoises that are unique only to Morro Bay and there are only a small number of them left. During the 
PGE seismic testing, marine biologist’s research has shown that the Morro Bay Porpoises were trying to escape the blasting and went into Bottle Nose Dolphins territories and some of them were killed. 
That was caused by man made seismic testing noise and normally would not have happened, 
as the Morro Bay Harbor Porpoises only stay in a small area. Because their numbers are small their biodiversity can be jeopardized and they may not be able to recover. 
When I go to the coast, 
I go with my family sailing, kayaking, wading in the surf, surfing, explore the beach and watch the wildlife. 
	•	The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.
	•	I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community and the wildlife, Dolphins, Humpback and Gray Whales can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
	•	The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. 
A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 
I ask that this marine sanctuary includes: 
	•	Biggest Possible Boundary: 
The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
	•	Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
	•	Tribal Collaborative Management: 
An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
	•	Outreach & Education: 
Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
	•	Rodriguez Seamount: 
The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
	•	Ban Oil & Gas: 
A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries, ban seismic testing. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 
I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 Thank you ! 
Sincerely,
ChrissyAnne Osborn

Title: Comment from Schaefer, Linnea
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Linnea Schaefer and I want to express my unequivocal support for the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I grew up in San Luis Obispo county, and have pursued education and a career in biology since moving away from the central coast. California’s coastline is one of its most precious places and ecosystems. The Pacific ocean houses immense biodiversity and wonder and means so much to those of us who have had the chance to experience it. I go to the coast to watch birds and wildlife, swim in the water, walk along the dunes in Morro Bay, explore the tide pools at Montana de Oro, or canoe and kayak across Morro Bay. Some of my earliest memories are from days along the coast. It is so important to me that the ocean and coastline are protected from resource extraction to benefit the communities and wildlife who use it, including many endangered and threatened wildlife species to whom this represents critical habitat in the road to recovery.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that the sanctuary lines honor the original boundary proposed by the Chumash, and include the areas offshore of Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria under its protection. Morro Bay provides critical habitat for migratory shorebirds and recovering populations of sea otters, San Simeon is home to the once nearly-extinct Northern elephant seals, and Cambria holds some of the coasts’s healthiest intertidal invertebrate communities. In addition, Morro Bay and the surrounding area hold great cultural significance for the Chumash who inhabited and stewarded the unceded land and ocean we now live on.  


I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
* Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria areas 
* Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
* Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
* Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
* Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
* Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
* Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures. Furthermore, I wholeheartedly support Indigenous stewardship of this sanctuary and recognization of the rightful inhabitants of this coast in the name of the sanctuary. 
 
Sincerely,
Linnea

Title: Comment from Davalos, Camaray
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Camaray and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I am an enrolled member of the Pechanga Band of Indians from Temecula, California, which is not too far from the proposed area. Our Native people are ocean people, as well as valley people. The ocean has always been a special place of connection for us, and vital for our traditional ways, and mental, physical, and spiritual well-being. I know that it is the same for the Chumash; This is a deeply spiritual place, where we conduct ceremony, utilize its natural resources for our traditional foods, regalia, and other utilitarian arts, and where we connect and maintain healthy relationships with human and non-human relatives. Being around a clean, healthy ocean, feels good, to put it simply. Being in close proximity to the ocean boosts our mental, emotional, and spiritual well-being.

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community and the Chumash communities can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

I know I've given you alot to think about. Please, above all, keep the Chumash people and ocean flora and fauna in your minds as you make this significant decision; Their good health and longevity depend on it.
 

Sincerely,

Camaray

Title: Comment from MiniNature Reserve
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Diego Magaña. I am speaking on behalf of the organization MiniNature Reserve and our volunteers.  We support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

We are a 501c3 based in the coastal city of Oxnard, CA. Through the work of volunteers, we grow native plants from seed and plant them throughout the city. We are grateful for the ocean. We are grateful for the marine layer it produces that creates our precious year-round temperate climate (something that we might lose due to climate change) which in turn creates our unique coastal sage scrub, dune, lagoons, and alkali meadow habitats. 

We support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. We support the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension. We want it to be named the “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.” We ask for an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management. We want to see outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities. This should include paid internships for students of the communities. The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity. There also needs to be a complete prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
We support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. We urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
Sincerely,
Diego Magaña
MiniNature Reserve | President

Title: Comment from Garman, Susan
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Susan Garman and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and the Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about  7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Cambria, California; to me the ocean is our wilderness and holds our hope to protect an ecosystem, indigenous coastal history and native wildlife from destruction.

I spend considerable time along the coast on a daily basis, enjoying the natural beauty, recreating, removing litter and rescuing wildlife in distress. I actively volunteer with numerous local nonprofits and do all I can to protect our coast and help mitigate any damage inflicted by human interactions.

Failing to retain the Initial Boundary Alternative by excluding Cambria, Cayucos, Morro Bay and part of Montano de Oro from this sanctuary is a mistake. It places this richly biodiverse area in a very vulnerable position, surrounded by protected areas and yet not itself protected. Failing to afford these unique coastal areas the same protections as the rest of the Central Coast leaves them more vulnerable to exploitation which will surely threaten sea life in the area and subject this area of the coast to an increased risk of future spoilage.
 

Thank you for protecting the coast for everyone!

Susan Garman
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Leighton, Barbara
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Barbara Leighton.  As a Unitarian Universalist person of faith and a grandmother, I wholeheartedly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, as quickly as possible.  I urge adoption of the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
In my life, I have appreciated the beautiful wonders, resilience and life sustaining nature of protected spaces.  I have also witnessed the degradation, pollution, and impoverishment of sacrifice zones and unfettered development.  Destruction is easy.  Repair is difficult and sometimes impossible.  Maintenance takes commitment and care for the long term.
I believe we need to do all we can to protect healthy environments that sustain many future generations of life including all precious grandchildren.
The Chumash preserved this area since ancient times and deserve to be part of the sanctuary name as well as participate in collaborative management.  We need to codify preservation of this area, including protection of the Rodriguez Seamount.  We need to ban oil & gas development in this area.  We can do this by committing to the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and educating future generations to care for and preserve ocean life for posterity.
Sincerely,
Barbara Leighton

Title: Comment from Salminen, Elina
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
I'm writing in support of the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I work in Goleta and live part-time in Santa Barbara and I've come to appreciate what a huge presence the ocean has and always has had on the region. Currently, it draws in the tourists that make Santa Barbara more vibrant than other small seaside town; UCSB students love the campus location close to the sea. But from visiting local museums and learning about the Chumash Sanctuary initiative, I've also come to appreciate that the ocean's meaning is much deeper for the tribes who have lived on the coast for centuries.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I know there are many requests being made by different individuals. For me, especially the below seem like important priorities: 

The sanctuary should be named “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” to honor the traditional custodians of the area
All local tribes - and I hope non-federally-recognized tribes as well - should be involved in managing the sanctuary collaboratively
Outreach programs in the sanctuary should include education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
As a sign of California's commitment to a sustainable future, new oil and gas development in the sanctuary should be banned

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,
Elina Salminen

Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Katie McKendry Grove

Title: Comment from Merriam, Karen
Comment: I am a long-time resident of the Central Coast of California and live just five miles from the Pacific Ocean area to be included in the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  Since 2005 I have been actively involved, through the Santa Lucia Chapter of the Sierra Club, in active public education regarding the benefits that the Marine Sanctuary will bring to the this part of the Central Coast, both in the waters and on land.  It is my considered opinion that the broadest possible boundaries for the Sanctuary should be selected. In addition, through my environmental work and local public contact, it is my opinion that it is essential to maintain the tribal designation "Chumash Heritage" not only in the title but also in the agreements for joint management of the Sanctuary. In this way history will inform and enrich the environmental protections and enhancements as well as honor the history in all public education.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Parks, Andrew
Comment:
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the NOAA Agency-Preferred Boundary Alternative (Cropped Bank to Coast plus Gaviota Coast Extension) proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I grew up in Sacramento, California but my parents would regularly take me and my sister to the Central Coast and stay with my grandparents in Pismo Beach. Some of my fondest childhood memories are exploring this region of the coast, from rocky tidepools to sandy beaches. This stretch of ocean has been so special to me and my family, and I want to see the federal protection of it to ensure that my children and grandkids will have the same opportunities as me.  Of course the rich history of the Chumash tribe in the area also provides a great opportunity for preservation of the native heritage and cultural values of the people that have lived here for thousands of years. Additionally, some of California’s most unique biological heritage thrives here, as the annual grey whale migration passes through this region, and our largest and most endangered bird, the California condor, has been making a comeback along these coastlines.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. In the interest of facilitating California’s transition to green energy, I would like to see the boundary cropped to allow for the planned undersea cables of the Morro Bay Wind Energy Area. However I ask that this sanctuary includes protection of the biologically significant Rodriguez Seamount and that the boundary stretches eastward to the Gaviota Coast. I want to see a strict prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries. I strongly advocate for an equitable approach to include all Tribes in collaborative management, and that the name of the sanctuary reference the Chumash heritage: “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”. I would like to see this management strongly focus on outreach, education, and research, implementing both a scientific approach and a Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) approach. 

Thank you for considering my comments.

Sincerely,
Andy P.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Social Justice Ministry, Live Oak Unitarian Universalist Congregation of Goleta, CA
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

On behalf of the Social Justice Ministry of the Live Oak Unitarian Universalist Congregation of Goleta, CA, I am writing to support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

We live in Goleta and Santa Barbara, CA and so preservation of this central coast is very important to us. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our health. Care of our ocean is in keeping with one of our religious principles: Respect for the interdependent web of all existence of which we are a part.
We support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, and we are pleased with the proposed partnership with the Chumash people of our community.

Sincerely,
Carolyn Chaney, chair

I submit a comment of strong support for the proposal to designate a National Marine Sanctuary off the coast of Central California in waters stewarded by the Chumash and other Indigenous peoples of this area. Title: Comment from Patton, Gary
Comment: I am submitting a very brief comment - but one that is truly heartfelt. I was formerly an elected member of the Santa Cruz County Board of Supervisors (for twenty years, from 1975 to 1995). During that time, the federal government approved the creation of the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary - and chose the "largest" boundary designation suggested. The impacts on the entire Monterey Bay Region have been immensely positive - in terms of marine protection, and in terms of our local economy. I STRONGLY URGE that NOAA Our all-important ocean upwelling and the Pacific Current Ecosystem will not be protected by the artificial and inadequate boundaries recently dictated by the offshore wind industry. Just tell NOAA “close the gap” and adopt the Initial Boundary Option for the proposed Chumash Marine Sanctuary. PLEASE don't lose this opportunity to extend the benefits of the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary program further south. Thank you!

Title: Comment from Lovett-Adair, Melissa
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. It is vital that we do all we can to protect the marine ecosystem to the largest extent possible.  
My name is Melissa Lovett-Adair and I am a resident of the county and city of San Luis Obispo. We still have much to learn about the ocean, and as our climate rapidly changes, we can waste no time in protecting it. We must protect the largest possible area, including the originally proposed boundary and the Gaviota coast extension. 
Having participated in one of the excellent informational presentations, I understand the proposed exclusion of Morro Bay is due to two main concerns. First is the issue of the undersea cables needed for off shore wind energy.  I support wind energy and do not believe these uses are incompatible. I understand that permits can be issued which will allow the undersea cables to be built.  The sanctuary designation and permitting process will provide assurance that the work is done with the highest level of protection for the marine ecosystem.  This is appropriate and acceptable.  We can move forward with renewable energy while caring for the environment. 
The second concern I heard is that the Salinan people object to the Chumash name. I respect the concerns of the Salinan people, but this should not be allowed to create gaps in the protection of the ocean.  The Chumash people have put decades of work into this proposal and have offered ways to resolve their concern including changing the name.  The important thing is to get the protection in place with the largest possible boundary.  Indigenous traditional lands overlap in many areas. Internal conflicts arise within and between groups. The process for shared management with Indigenous people includes opportunities for involvement and council from multiple tribal groups. This shared management structure is a vital new understanding of our shared responsibility and commitment to undoing past wrongs. The sanctuary protection must be continuous from the Monterey Bay Sanctuary to the Channel Islands Sanctuary. 
Thank you for the opportunity to express my support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  
Melissa Lovett-Adair

Title: Comment from Cole, Carole Ann

Title: Comment from Gallo, Paul
Comment:
September 19, 2023

The proposed boundary change to the CHNMS is outrageous and tantamount to a gerrymandering of the California coastline. It is clear that NOAA has disregarded the National Significance Criteria, as well as the Management Considerations, that were satisfied during the Nomination process and served as the foundation of the Initial Boundary. This ill conceived carve out of our precious coastline is a betrayal to those of us who have supported the establishment of this sanctuary for many years.

Just today, I witnessed an amazing display of humpback whale activity in Estero Bay right offshore from Morro Bay. Estero Bay, which has been eliminated from the current proposed map, has an abundance of marine life and bird life year round. This area serves a vital access point to visitors from all over the world who observe, learn, and engage in this unique marine environment. It is one of the very few places on the California coast where the endangered Southern Sea Otter can be closely observed right from the shoreline. Furthermore, this area is a regular destination for school field trips from throughout this region. Morro Rock with its amazing presence and relevance to indigenous peoples should be the heart of this sanctuary, not excised from it.

I implore you to designate the boundaries of the proposed National Marine Sanctuary as follows: The Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension ( Sub-Alt 5b); additionally, the waters offshore of Point Buchon, Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria should be included. This is essential to create the largest possible contiguous sanctuary boundaries for protection of the California coastline.

Title: Comment from Love, Sarah
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Sarah Love and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension

Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Title: Comment from Miyakawa, Minh

My name is Minh Miyakawa and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the largest possible boundaries to better protect 7,600 square miles of ocean area off of California’s Central Coast.

I live in Sacramento, California and to me, the ocean is is beatiful and deserves protection. My own son is name "Ocean".
The ocean is personally important to me and my family.

Title: Comment from Aist, Kari
Comment:
I am in favor of designating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary which could provide improved protection for 7,600 square miles of ocean to protect biodiversity and habitats. The sanctuary designation has the potential to protect ocean and coastal ecosystems and contribute to climate and biodiversity goals in an area that extends from Gaviota to Morro Bay. Scientific research shows that this area already is experiencing climate change impacts, such as ocean acidification, at a rate twice that of the world’s oceans and it MUST be protected!
 
Designating the sanctuary would also advance the first Tribal-nominated national marine sanctuary designation in the U.S., setting a precedent for elevating Indigenous perspectives, cultural values in ocean conservation, and Indigenous collaborative management that includes all Central Coast tribes equitably.

I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Please do the right thing by the earth and the people.

Title: Comment from Hewitson, Jennifer
Comment:
I am a lifelong resident of Coastal California, and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. That sensitive and biodiverse habitat MUST Include Morro Bay, and must not sacrifice that sensitive habitat for Wind Farms under the guise of GREEN Energy!! There is NOTHING green in that proposed wind farm on the ocean but the DOLLARS it represents for businesses that will build and run it. NO to sacrificing Morrro Bay for the ABUSE by our state's needs for energy and the LIE that it is safe for the wildlife that FILLS this area and relies on that nearly pristine habitat for survival. 

I live in Encinitas on the coast of Southern California, but my son is in San Luis Obispo, my extended family is in Morro Bay, and I spend time at many beaches and lagoons along our coast. I value this coastline, the ocean, and the fact that we all rely on these waters for survival! There is NO OTHER more important or less disturbed habitat on earth!  This is one of the most biodiverse, well -preserved, and beautiful coasts in the state and we cannot allow it to be exploited or invaded and ultimately destroyed by US, for the performative and false narrative of GREEN ENERGY!! Stop the lie, and preserve ALL of this proposed sanctuary from any development. 
Sensitive species, Humpback Whales, Dolphins, countless fish species, otters, seals, and thousands of birds are at risk! 

The ocean is our life support system. As the daughter of a biology teacher, I understand our dependence on the ocean for food, climate stability, recreation,  spiritual well-being, economic health, and our own survival!
I want to protect this stretch of ocean so we all can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean filled with diverse wildlife upon which WE DEPEND!
 A sanctuary will mean long-term protection, important ocean research opportunities, and environmental education for present and future generations!
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, but I want it to include the:
Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension, and INCLUDE MORRO BAY.
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” but with the addition of other tribal names in sections of the sanctuary if possible.
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management, along with qualified dedicated marine scientists.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries.
Prohibition of WIND FARMS or any development detrimental to wildlife within sanctuary boundaries.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow the strongest preservation for the delicate balance of sensitive habitats supporting fish stocks, wildlife within and above the sea, and the majestic beauty of this nearly pristine ecosystem.


Sincerely, Jennifer Hewitson

Title: Comment from Lawrence, Charles
Comment:
Dear NOAA Administrators:

My name is Charles Lawrence and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the largest possible boundaries to better protect 7,600 square miles of ocean area off of California’s Central Coast.

I live in Ventura, California and to me, the ocean has been a home and center of recreation for most of my time on the central coast.

As a resident of Ventura Harbor for over 15 years as a live aboard, sailor and fisherman, I have experienced all of the wonder, bounty and beaty of the area despite human and commercial encroachment. The area still provides enough marine health to support some of the few commercial fish and squid fleets left on the California coast. More encroachment on the natural environment is sure to impact all of these uses.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

The largest possible boundary to maximize protection of ocean habitat and wildlife
A prohibition on oil and gas exploration or development
Water quality protections
Seafloor protections for the Rodriguez Seamount
Collaborative management that includes all interested local Native American Tribes
Education and community outreach that is multilingual, multicultural, and focused on local underserved communities.
Recreational use provisions to encourage future generations ability to experience including diving and fishing
“Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” as the official name of the sanctuary.
I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Respectfully,

C Lawrence
Ventura, CA

I live in Ojai and my work is in researching and creating artwork inspired by kelp. Our kelp forests are a superpower and need to be protected. Kelp forests provide habitat for hundreds of species, filter the water, hold the shoreline from erosion and sequester more carbon than any forest on land. My wish is  to protect this stretch of coastline as kelp forests are among the most productive ecosystems on earth and need to be protected for present and future generations.

Title: Comment from Brown, David
Comment:
It is vital that the CHNMS cover the largest possible contiguous boundaries. I support the designation of the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alt 5b). Including the waters offshore Point Buchon, Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria will close the California Central Coast’s biodiversity protection gap between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This will protect the only eelgrass bed in a 300-mile stretch of coast; many historic Chumash sites, including Lisamu’ (Morro Rock); numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds; the highest population of Southern sea otters on the California coast; several State Marine Conservation Areas; and the kelp forests and rocky intertidal habitats considered to be some of the most diverse and abundant in the world.

No other proposed sanctuary alternative is adequate. The Draft Environmental Impact Statement acknowledges that all other alternatives would reduce the significant beneficial effects on biological resources provided by the Initial Boundary Alternative. All other alternatives would increase the vulnerability of those resources to adverse impacts that the Initial Boundary Alternative would prohibit or mitigate.

I specifically support the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” to honor the cultural history and stewardship of California Tribal peoples. The name will recognize Peoples that have lived on the California coast since time immemorial and protect the heritage of the Chumash, an ocean-going band among the First People of the Pacific Coast. We want to honor the late Chief Fred Collin’s nomination and vision for the sanctuary and the 10 years of work that the Northern Chumash Tribal Council
did to campaign for the sanctuary.

The CHNMS is an opportunity to advance environmental justice efforts. We ask that you keep the sacred connection between our ocean and community at the heart of this effort. The Sanctuary should teach the benefits of protecting our ocean and planet and promote the spirit of stewardship that is exemplified by the culture and history of the original Chumash caretakers.

I support equitable inclusion/representation of all Central Coast Tribes in the collaborative management of the CHNMS. By being equitable and inclusive, all sanctuary stakeholders will benefit from broad Indigenous input and TEK informing management.

Equitable collaborative management must be open to all Tribal groups interested in participating. This can best be accomplished with a Tribal Sanctuary Advisory Council made up of interested Tribal Groups. NOAA’s Tribal collaboration should be facilitated by a qualified Tribal Liaison.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Agredano, Hector
Comment: Members of NOAA and the public, my name is Hector Agredano and I am a geography professor at Pasadena City College in Pasadena, California. I am writing in support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary because it is time to recognize and make amends for the historic and ongoing dispossession of indigenous lands and resources in California. As a geographer, I always stress to my students the importance of human and nature relationships and the need to be better stewards of our environment. This campaign would be a great example of sustainable cultural and social development as Chumash peoples are able to reconnect with their historic lands and help preserve them for future generations as they bring traditional ecological knowledge to these landscapes. A marine sanctuary of this kind would make history as a "land back" initiative and would usher more initiatives like it across North America. Through this sanctuary, NOAA is in a position to begin making amends on behalf of the Federal government for centuries of dispossession and genocide. Do not shrink from the historic meaning of this opportunity. Do what is right and give the Chumash people an opportunity to show us new forms of land, water and life stewardship. In solidarity, Hector Agredano, PhD.

Title: Comment from Hather, Robert
Comment:
In 2005-2009 I served on the Marine Interest Group, an advisory board to government agencies and policy makers.  During that time I co-founded the Central Coast Fisheries Conservation Coalition.  We raised the seed capital in conjunction with the World Wildlife Fund to fund Cal Poly’s rockfish assessment which is still on going.  I was later appointed by the governor to advise the Blue Ribbon panel for the development of the Central Coast Marine reserves. 

The Marine Interest Group was comprised of 32 community leaders consisting of government reps, and environmental groups, recreation and commercial fishing groups.  The MIG was not in support of the Chumash Sanctuary.

If the goal of the proposed sanctuary is to prohibit mineral extraction and recognize the Chumash, just leave it at that which would likely reduce controversy.

But do not grant any authority.

We already protect our resources with the:

Regional water Quality Board
California Coastal Commission
Pacific Fisheries Management Council
California Fish and Wildlife
CEQA
Army Corps of Engineers

Any further oversight would result in wasted money and resources and could potentially interfere with dredging permitting that keep our harbors safe and usable.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Williams, Steven
Comment:
I live in Morro Bay.  I support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary initial boundary alternative FIRST or alternative 1, bank to coast SECOND. The historic Chumash tribal land includes Morro Bay and Morro Rock. There are sacred Chumash sites included in the above mentioned area that should remain protected by their tribe.  

The 7,600 square miles of waters protected by the Initial Boundry or the 6,100 square miles of Alternative 1, Bank to Coast should be left  untouched for the existing diverse marine life.  No wind farm and no oil exploration. 

Financially the wind turbine industry is in jeopardy.  Inflation is erasing potential profits.  Eight multinational companies in three states are backing out of their contracts or attempting to renegotiate their contracts.  Beyond Shell (ticker: SHEL), they include BP (BP), Denmark’s Orsted (DNNGY), Norway’s Equinor (EQNR), Spain’s Iberdrola (IBDRY), Portugal’s Energias de Portugal (EDPFY), and France’s Engie (ENGIY) and state-owned Electricite de France.  If not for the $23 per megawatt-hour federal Production Tax Credit for wind power and state mandates requiring the use of renewable energy, plans for offshore wind turbines would come to a halt.

Respectfully, 

Steven Williams
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Lewis, Cindy
Comment:
September 25, 2023

Dear Paul Michael,

My name is Dr. Cindy Lewis and my husband is Mr. Jeffrey Lewis, living in Templeton, CA. We strongly support establishing the largest possible Chumash Heritage National Sanctuary. 

I have a unique perspective about the Chumash Heritage Marine National Sanctuary (CHNMS), having grown up in San Luis Obispo in the 1960’s. My second year SLO High School biology class had weekly field trips to Montana de Oro, which was not even a State Park in 1965. My teachers inspired me to major in Marine Biology at Cal Poly, having taken courses with hundreds of hours of field trips up and down our beautiful coast. I saw intertidal black abalone and sand sharks in tidepools. Indeed, our coast was, and is, magical. I became a Marine Biologist, teaching and doing research for over 20 years.  

Between land development, pollution, global climate change which is warming and acidifying our oceans, and the overfishing of such animals as native abalone and oysters, our coastline is severely degraded. We MUST protect what we have NOW!

My husband and I attended the first NOAA presentations of the CHNMS in Morro Bay 8 years ago. We joined the Marine Protected Area Otter Watch program for years to gather data to protect our local otters. 

We support the largest possible contiguous boundaries as seen in the Initial Boundary Alternative combined with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alternative 5b) because it provides the most protection to this crucial area. We do NOT support NOAA’s Alternatives 2, 3, or 4 which reduce the size and protection of the sanctuary by some 2,000 square miles, eliminating connectivity with the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary, leaving out crucial cultural sites, including Morro Rock which is habitat for 2 endangered Peregrine falcon nesting pairs, and removing critical protections for marine habitat and species, including the threatened Southern sea otters. 
This largest proposed boundary ensures a contiguous buffer of ocean protection while directing offshore wind development to more suitable areas further offshore where wind energy is optimal and ecological and cultural impacts are reduced. The sanctuary will also allow for robust monitoring and research needed to understand the long-term impacts of offshore wind, including by Cal Poly Marine Biologists and their students.  Any offshore wind transmission cables proposed for this area as part of future offshore wind development should require permits from the National Marine Sanctuary Program to ensure that they are planned and sited in a thoughtful, consolidated manner to minimize impacts to the ocean. 

We support the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” to recognize people who have lived on this coast over 10,000 years, protect the heritage of the Chumash, an ocean-going band among the First People of the Pacific Coast and honor the late Chief Fred Collin’s nomination and vision for the Sanctuary and the 10 years of work that the Northern Chumash Tribal Council did to campaign for the Sanctuary. 

We oppose the proposed projects off Vandenberg based on serious environmental, cultural and permitting-process issues. The projects are irresponsibly sited too close to the shore, in a uniquely biodiverse location, with highly significant fisheries and unacceptable impacts to critical cultural sites. 

We support Sanctuary water quality programs and regulations that reduce pollution, by preventing harmful discharges and excessive runoff of sediments, oils, nutrients, pesticides, and pathogens. 

Do not carve out the Morro Bay area which includes one of the only functional tidal salt marshes left in California and our iconic Morro Rock that has ecological and cultural significance.  Instead, designate our CHNMS to be “complete” so Sanctuary administration oversees energy production and ecological impacts, rather than letting energy drive this system. 

This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to protect such a jewel of ecosystem diversity that provides fishing, recreational, research, cultural and educational prospects for future generations!  Who will protect our oceans if not us?

Sincerely,
Dr. Cindy Lewis and Mr. Jeffrey Lewis

Title: Comment from Kay, Suzanne
Comment:
I am submitting a comment to NOAA-NOS-2021-0080.  
I am writing to support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The designation of the CHNMS should include the largest possible contiguous boundaries, the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alt 5b), because it would provide the most protection to this important area. We do not support NOAA’s Alternatives 2, 3, and 4 because they would not protect a critical area of coastline that contains important Chumash cultural sites, marine habitat, and local communities.

First, please support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary name. It is meant to recognize people who have lived on this coast for over 10,000 years; protect the heritage of the Chumash, an ocean-going band among the First People of the Pacific Coast; and provide a timely and appropriate reminder of the cultural origins. We support equitable inclusion of all Central Coast Tribes, both federally and non-federally recognized Tribes, in collaborative management. All sanctuary stakeholders will benefit from Indigenous input. 

It is vital that Sanctuary education and community outreach partner with area schools to share information about sanctuary species and habitats and Chumash history and culture. Outreach should be multilingual, culturally relevant, and should focus on underserved communities.

In addition, regulations to protect Rodriguez Seamount should move forward. The seamount provides critical habitat for an extremely diverse and abundant array of marine life and deserves to be granted strong and permanent protection. The seamount has special national significance that warrants special protections through sanctuary designation. Once damaged, fragile seamount ecosystems may not recover in our lifetime.

The proposed CHNMS will protect our beloved ocean now that Offshore Wind (OSW) farms are being established off the Central California Coast. Sanctuary designation is needed before OSW and other environmental impacts affect the habitat, wildlife, and water quality. California’s first offshore wind projects must reflect leasing, siting, and permitting decisions that are guided by planning and comprehensive scientific research on the potential impacts to sensitive marine areas and species and coastal resources, including cumulative impacts.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Title: Comment from Coats, Francis

Further there is no fair basis for giving a very small heredirltarilly defined group preferential influence in decision making over a public land and water. Title: Comment from Dias, Jessica
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Jessica Dias and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Goleta, California and to me, the ocean is an important treasure and one of the greatest resources we have on this planet.  We must protect it and it’s the creatures that live in it.  There is nothing more I love better than wandering among tide pools, exploring and seeing the sealife, and playing in the surf.  I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.  The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
•	The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
•	The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
•	An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
•	Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities.
•	The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity.
•	A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,
Jessica Dias

Title: Comment from Weisman, David
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel:

I am a photographer living in Morro Bay, California, and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. That includes the entire sanctuary as originally envisioned by the applicant, and not the current alternatives proposed which truncate the southern border of the sanctuary and carve out wide corridors that interrupt the continuity of the sanctuary.   It is important to establish a contiguous sanctuary that connects with the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary in the north.  A key goal is to prevent any oil or gas drilling off the coastline.  An accommodation can be made for cables necessary for offshore wind power, should those proposals come to fruition, that does not require bisecting the original plans.

With photographer Arthur Tress we are currently editing a book, "100 Views of Morro Rock" and what emerges is a portrait of a region that thrives in the area around "Lisamu" as the Chumash call the site. Its definition means "place of great abundance, or source of great abundance for life around it" and as the photos demonstrate, the sea life around the area thrives.  This needs to be protected as well, and "Lisamu" (Morro Rock) needs to be included in the protected area as well.

Thank you for allowing me to register my support of the project as the applicants originally envisioned it and for the full protection of this exquisite marine environment.

Yours truly,
David Weisman

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I am in support of the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary! 


Please designate the sanctuary as it was originally proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), as well as the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b), so that there is protection for the waters between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. 


This sanctuary offers the opportunity to elevate Indigenous perspectives and cultural values, honoring the history and culture of the Native Americans who have inhabited this region for more than 10,000 years.
﻿

This sanctuary should protect the area from harmful oil and gas development and reduce water pollution in Sanctuary waters by preventing excess runoff of sediments, oils, pesticides, nutrients, and pathogens.




The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should ensure that Offshore Wind operations and construction are completed through the guidelines of the new Sanctuary. These projects should be planned and authorized in a way that avoids and mitigates impacts to sensitive marine areas, species, and important cultural areas.

Title: Comment from Shannon, Eleanor
Comment:
Comment on Draft of Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary
To: Paul Michel, Policy Coordinator at NOAA Sanctuaries West Coast Region
From: Eleanor Shannon

Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Eleanor Shannon, and I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live south of the proposed sanctuary in Ojai, CA, and the reason I moved there was to be near the ocean. It is a priceless resource—a foundation for mental health, physical health, community, and simply knowing from its vastness how small human beings actually are and how much we depend on an eco-system bigger than we are. 

I fully support of the designation of the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary. I have read the draft plan and agree with the statement that is expanded and explained in pages 6-12:  that this is an"... opportunity to raise public awareness of Indigenous cultures, incorporate traditional knowledge into sanctuary management, and protect resources essential to these cultures, was a core motivation in the nomination and ultimate designation of the sanctuary." 
I am not a Chumash, but I volunteer for and support their activities, including the tomol canoe project, started by a group near where I live. This Sanctuary would have a direct positive affect on tribal groups but up and down the coast of California, and it would also center their knowledge and cultural heritage in a way that we can all benefit from in this era of Climate Change. It is impressive to read in the document about all the ways the Sanctuary will involve and support indigenous culture and know how through the various Action Plans, especially the first and second. 

I ask that:
. 
-	The sanctuary include the biggest possible boundary with the Gaviota Coast Extension. 

-	Be named, Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary because these areas are historically important to the Chumash tribes and the natural resources within them remain critically important to tribal heritage.

-	Include all Tribes in Collaborative Management

-	Create outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge and access for local underserved communities. 

-	Protect Rodriguez Seamount as an essential way of protecting biodiversity

-	Prohibit new oil and gas development within its boundaries

In sum, I assert my full support for the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge you and the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations of Americans and Californians to enjoy, protect, and benefit from the ocean as a multi-faceted resource—and one whose importance cannot be overstated. Time is of the essence. 

Sincerely,

Eleanor Shannon

The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should ensure that Offshore Wind operations and construction are completed through the guidelines of the new Sanctuary. These projects should be planned and authorized in a way that avoids and mitigates impacts to sensitive marine areas, species, and important cultural areas.

Title: Comment from Sletteland, Holly
Comment:
As a longtime resident and coastal advocate in San Luis Obispo County, I have been following the proposal for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) for many years. I am a former board member of the Morro Bay National Estuary Program (MBNEP), SLO County MPA Watch Coordinator and SLO County Coastal Cleanup Coordinator.  I am now happily retired and have more time to enjoy kayaking, swimming and just strolling along the beach. 

I am so excited that we are nearing the finish line and an official sanctuary designation is close to becoming a reality. I can’t thank you enough for all of your efforts to move this process forward.  I am especially pleased with the decision to honor the Chumash people that have called this coastline home for over 10,000 years by including the tribe in the name of the sanctuary.  The Northern Chumash Tribal Council has also worked tirelessly to shepherd the sanctuary nomination to completion and deserves recognition for their efforts.  I sincerely hope that NOAA will continue to collaborate with both federally and non-federally recognized Central Coast tribes in the ongoing management of the sanctuary. 

I’m also very supportive of the proposed regulation of activities within the sanctuary, including the creation of a special Rodriguez Seamount Management Zone.  Restrictions on activities are essential for ensuring that the sanctuary fulfills its primary purpose as a refuge for the incredibly diverse and abundant marine life found within its boundaries, allowing them to thrive and flourish in perpetuity.  I would actually have preferred stronger regulations, such as restrictions on fishing and speed limits for ships, but realize those are more controversial.  

I do have one major reservation about the final proposal, however.  I strongly support the initial boundary that was submitted with the nomination which would protect 7,573 square miles of ocean and close the gap between the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary.  I do not support the agency-preferred alternative of reducing the size of the sanctuary by almost 2000 square miles by leaving the area between Cambria and Montana de Oro unprotected.  This alternative offers insufficient safeguards for the many migratory species that pass through this area, including birds, whales, fish, turtles and marine mammals.  Uncontrolled activities in that area, such as drilling, mining or dumping, could seriously undermine threaten marine life and the adjacent sanctuary.  I understand the conundrum posed by uncertainties associated with the development of the offshore wind farms.  If the wind energy corridor was already in place, it could be grandfathered in.  I understand the reluctance to create a precedent by allowing a wind energy cable corridor to be created after the sanctuary is established.  Nonetheless, I would urge you to continue to pursue a solution that will accommodate both the protection of the entire coastline and the successful implementation of the wind farms.  Protecting biodiversity and slowing climate change are the two biggest challenges of our time and we can’t afford to sacrifice either one. We must succeed at both.

Second, although they state the proposed regulations they will impose, no oil drilling etc., once given control, nothing can stop them from imposing more restrictions like eliminating sport fishing, scuba diving, etc. in the oceans that belong to all of us.  Finally, I am getting tired of groups of people getting together and creating some excuse to take away our rights to our lands, oceans, and beaches, as if they have some favored ownership or higher knowledge of how to control and regulate those assets

Title: Comment from Smith, Peter
Comment:
As a follower of Jesus, I'm excited to see a proposed draft management plan for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. We need clear and meaningful management and implementation of the sanctuary. Given that the Chumash tribe, among other tribes, have been the primary keepers and sustainers of these waters and the lands that are along the coast, we must first look to them for comment and input on this draft management plan and future management plans. It is so important that we preserve God's unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. I ask that you respect the Northern Chumash Tribal Council requests regarding sanctuary boundary, the sanctuary name, tribal collaborative management, outreach and education, Rodriguez Seamount, offshore wind and water quality. Thank you for your work on this immediate need to preserve and steward God's creation.                                                                                                              

Sincerely,  
Peter

Title: Comment from Valle, Victor
Comment:
My name is Victor Valle, a Cal Poly San Luis Obispo emeritus professor and recreational fisherman residing in San Luis Obispo. I am writing here to support the creation of the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary because California's network of Marine Protected Areas (Marine Reserves, Parks, and Conservation Areas) have already proven themselves ecologically successful, most notably in the Channel Islands Marine Protected Area (MPA) and the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary, where most fish stocks have increased in variety, biomass and size. Another report (cited below) indicates the same trend for several other commercially and recreationally fished species.

"Generally, baseline monitoring results show that California's MPAs are “on track” and that some species are already responding to protection.33 This is especially true in older MPAs that pre-date the MLPA planning process. 

"For example, mature fish including cabezon (Scorpaenichthys marmoratus), lingcod (Ophiodon elongatus) and black rockfish (Sebastes melanops) are more abundant in some Central Coast protected areas than in similar fished habitats, according to five-year findings.34 The endangered black abalone (Haliotis cracherodii)—which has not been harvested legally since 1993— increased in size inside Central Coast protected areas during the same time period.35 The North Central Coast baseline monitoring results show increased abundance of lingcod and several species of rockfish inside MPAs after five years.36 Additionally, red abalone (Haliotis rufescens) populations in the North Central Coast's Sea Lion Cove SMCA, which was designed to curb poaching and protect abalone, experienced a “sharp increase” in the first five years after the MPA was established in 2010.37,38"

https://montereybayfisheriestrust.org/stories/2019/9/19/cowcod-declared-rebuilt
 
But the ecological benefits to the proposed sanctuary will not be fully realized without also closing it to future oil and gas exploration. This crucial component of the sanctuary will not only prevent the kind of environmental degradation that occurred in the Santa Barbara oil spill of 1969, of which our coastline is only now recovering, it will have affirmative effect of giving the federal and local governments the tools to address the problem of ocean acidification while supporting California's plan to meet its climate change goals. Expanding fossil fuels exploration along California's most pristine and picturesque coastline would undermine my state's authority to fulfill its climate change agenda through future environmental regulation, while creating the sanctuary would respect our state's authority to protect our extremely sensitive coastline for future generations, as well as recognize our local Chumash community as the original stewards of our coastline and waters.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Cruz, Tatiana
Comment: I’m writing as a concerned resident of the central coast (Santa Barbara County). The designated sanctuary must have connectivity along the coast. I do not support carving out an area for energy infrastructure and instead urge you to designate the sanctuary as it was originally proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), as well as the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b), so that there is protection for the waters between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. I am so grateful the Chumash representatives spoke on this issue and I want their voices to be heard because for so long the government has not respected their cultural knowledge through meaningful legislation. This sanctuary offers the opportunity to elevate Indigenous perspectives and cultural values, honoring the history and culture of the Native Americans who have inhabited this region for more than 10,000 years. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should ensure that Offshore Wind operations and construction are completed through the guidelines of the new Sanctuary. These projects should be planned and authorized in a way that avoids and mitigates impacts to sensitive marine areas, species, and important cultural areas and be reviewed and permitted as such.

Title: Comment from White, Kim
Comment:
I am in full support of the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and NOAA moving forward with the Agency-Preferred Alternative.  The proposed regulations for the sanctuary take into consideration the importance of protecting natural resources and the marine ecosystem from harmful oil and gas development and pollution as well as preserving indigenous groups’ heritage and culture while balancing the need for economic development, clean energy alternatives, and recreation. It offers a sustainable plan for future needs and advances President Biden’s America the Beautiful Initiative.  
I appreciate the plan to incorporate indigenous knowledge in sanctuary management and the plan to raise public awareness of indigenous cultures and I believe it is crucial to create new opportunities for scientific research, education, and responsible recreation and tourism.  I am in full support of the proposed goals and strategies.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Fistanic, Kevin
Comment: Please create the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Marine sanctuaries have been proven to be extremely beneficial to local fish populations, which is good news for conservationists, recreational anglers, and commercial fisheries. It will also honor the indigenous Chumash people, who have relied on these waters long before the existence of this nation. It is important that ALL of the proposed areas are protected in this sanctuary, including the offshore waters that connect this marine sanctuary to both Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. Providing these corridors for fish and other marine wildlife will guarantee that all three of these sanctuaries will significantly increase in species richness, diversity, and total biomass. This is critical as our oceans continue to be overharvested and bare the brunt of the impacts of climate change. For the sake of the oceans, the Chumash way of life, and the continued enjoyment and dependency on our beautiful oceans, I humbly request that this undersea paradise be protected indefinitely as the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Thank you for your time.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Crockett, Meg
Comment:
This Marine Sanctuary is the first of it's kind to be designated as a marine sanctuary by a tribe of indiginous people, and to be overseen by them. As such, it should not be limited or compromised by cutting out the very heart of the area so near and dear to the Chumash people: Morro Bay and Morro Rock.  These are sacred to the Chumash people, and Morro Rock is also sacred to the Salinan people, another indiginous group in our area.

There can be no value in cutting this area out of the proposed National Marine Sanctuary.  Please do not do this to what will otherwise be such an amazing and wonderful area for the presurvation of the ocean on the Central Coast of California.  The predominant white race in the Americas have done enough damage to the land and sea, and to the indiginous people who lived here first, it is time to honor the land and sea and the peoples who sought long before us to keep all of it safe and pure, and to honor the plants and animals which we never saw as our sisters and brothers. But as our science gradually enlightens us to the possible affinities and intelligence in these other life forms, we should be open to the possibility that indiginous people had truths we never gave the crediance they deserved,and to try to understand why the whole area originally requested should be granted protection.

Thank you for your consideration of this matter.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Bennett, Tim
Comment:
I've lived in San Luis Obispo for more than two decades. I have taken my children and grandchildren on countess boating trips to view whales and other incredible creatures off of Morro Bay. I feel so wedded to this area that I plan to have my youngest son deposit my ashes after my death in Morro Bay. 

I purchased 60 acres of land atop nearby Prefumo Canyon and have honored the Chumash heritage by never having touched any of the artifacts of the Chumash Indians, preserving them for future generations—artifacts like serpentine rock impressions where grain was pulverized for cooking purposes.

I think it's critical to preserve the entire coast from Monterey--including Morro Bay--from windfarms and degrading development for generations to come. Thank you for listening, understanding and appreciating feelings from the heart.

Title: Comment from Romo, Alina
Comment: After reading about the narrowing of the  marine sanctuary’s boundaries, I am writing to advocate for returning to the original boundaries that expand through Morro Bay and connect to the  Monterrey Bay Sanctuary. Besides caring deeply about preserving the largest portion of our coast possible, I find it rather short sighted to limit the sanctuary largely to appease the possible development of wind turbines off this pristine coast. This wind energy project should not have been entertained  in the first place. The wind project is an atrocity. Limiting the sanctuary so that cables can run through otherwise very special waters, which its original inclusion in the sanctuary actually highlights, is ethically suspect.

Title: Comment from vitale, tammy
Comment:
I support the biggest possible boundary for the proposed marine sanctuary in Central California - specially the boundaries urged by the Chumash tribe. 
 I support their participation in the management of this sanctuary and education about the diversity of this area (especially the protection of the endangered otters).
I think of my grandchildren and what they and their grandchildren will have left if we keep treating our oceans and coastlines as indefatigable profit centers.

I urge you to reconsider your current claim that there is o support for the larger boundaries.  We are all busy and most of us don't know anything until it is too late - certainly it hasn't been on my horizon through any regular media means, which tells me the administration hasn't done it's outreach, the kind it expects local citizens to do.  

Become a legend in your own time.  Do something different - put the land and the peoples of the land ahead of profit.  Yes, wind farms are good, but they have their place and it is not here - the otters (endangered list since 1977 and finally starting to make a comback...and a income generator for those who find them enchanting and want to come watch them...and the whales...always an income generator.  One day we human species realize how ignorant and selfish we have been when it comes to the other species we share this smaller and getting smaller planet with.  Make a difference.  Expand the boundaries.

Sincerely
Tammy Vitale
