Title: Comment from Frey, Madeline
Comment:
Hello,
I am a resident of Ventura and would like to see the greatest possible boundary for the Chumash marine sanctuary be approved. I am excited for the first ever tribally led sanctuary to be designated on our shores. As a biologist, I understand the pressing need for more protections of our coast, but realize the balance required to support local communities. Title: Comment from Even, Elizabeth
Comment:
I agree that there is a need for a National Marine Sanctuary in this area and appreciate the thoroughness of the work, thus far, of NOAA to make this happen.  I am dismayed and concerned, however, that the designation does not include Morro Bay.  I want clean energy, such as wind, to be the rule rather than the exception, but not at the sacrifice of our marine ecosystems and Indigenous traditional ties to the area.  The protection of Morro Bay, by including in the proposed sanctuary, should take precedence over the BOEM concerns.  There needs to be proper management of the Morro Bay area so infrastructure for the offshore wind farms does not destroy the very planet we are trying to save -- and inclusion in this proposed marine sanctuary would provide such management.
Although I am currently in North Carolina, I am a third generation Californian and particularly concerned about the protection of the Pacific Ocean coast.  I just moved here from San Diego and saw how the marine sanctuary off the shore of La Jolla protects the area.  I want to see this happen for Morro Bay.

Title: Comment from Green, Rebecca
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Rebecca Ravenoak and I support  the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundaries extending up the Gaviota Coast. That 7,600 square miles of ocean is precious habitat for the whales, the otters, and countless other marine species.

I live in Alameda county and I grew up in Orange County, near the beach. I got married at the beach. I spend every weekend I can at the beach, or fishing with my in-laws off the Monterey coast, or admiring the sunsets you can only find here. The land is both beautiful and rich, teeming with life in the kelp forests and the rocky bottoms. We must preserve it for the future.

The Chumash people have been stewards of this land for much much longer than any white people have even known about it. They are the rightful caretakers. Listen to them and heed their advice. The impacts of underwater noise and construction must not be underestimated, and progress for California can't come at the expense of her coasts. A wind farm off the coast would be ruinous for all of us. 

Thank you
Rebecca Ravenoak
San Leandro, CA

Title: Comment from Hughes, Lori
Comment: I fully support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. This is one small but vital step in restoring the balance of sea life. It is a step towrd saving all life on the planet. We have spoiled enough. It is time to rehabilitate the sea beds, the source of our food, clean air and comfortable climate. Tell big oil NO MORE and begin the process of saving ourselves!  Thank you!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Fuss, Teddy
Comment: As a native Californian, I have enjoyed the coast for its beauty, serenity, and as home for trillions of unrepresented life forms so vital to the health of our environment.  Why has NOAA chosen to exclude this one particular portion of the wild California coastline?  And why has the Chumash indigenous tribe been excluded - after years of highly valuable fact seeking and commentary - been excluded now from the preparation of NOAA's report?  It is simply wrong and very questionable.  The area in question is no doubt of great interest to Pacific Has & Electric Company whose Diablo Canyon Nuclear Power Plant may be impacted, oil and mineral exploration corporations, and who knows what else may be able to dominate this fragile part of environmentally active California.  As a native Californian, I demand that NOAA expose all corporate interests in their proposal to exclude the subject portion of the coastline from protection and reinstate the Chumash tribe to full commentary rights on it.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Kunce, VR
Comment:
That section of California coast is near and dear to me, I was just there visiting as I do on a regular basis, the area absolutely
needs to be protected from wind farms, big oil, or any other form of destruction.  It's crazy but not a surprise that it was omitted. 
Most likely money/greed is at the core of that decision.  I support the Chumash people, and others 100% in this fight to save the coastal environment.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Dyerly, Jeff
Comment:
As a life long native of California and an avid sportsman I wholeheartedly DO NOT support another assault on my rights to enjoy our natural coastline.   Enough is enough!  Half of the California coastline is already under some form of restriction from use. If you move forward with the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary then the last remaining open area along the Central Coast will be closed to recreational activities.  I am out on the ocean once a week and never get tired of watching the sun rise, seeing the sea life wake up and enjoying the variety of weather conditions.  I simply can’t image life without this rejuvenating weekly experience.  
I also fail to see how giving stewardship of this area to a band of natives that feel comfortable living off the hard earned wages of gamblers is acting responsibly and in the best interest of California and its varied citizens.  
I implore you to step back and look at the best interests of ALL Californians before taking away what so many of us love.  Respectfully, Jeff Dyerly
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Stewart, Nick
Comment: Thank you for proposing this marine Sanctuary. However, I encourage NOAA to expand the proposal to include the entire area identified by the Chumash tribe. Our indigenous peoples have been key to preserving a reverent connection to the natural world that is now under such dire stress. I trust in their ancient wisdom regarding the ecosystems in their home territory, and the need to protect the fragile environment along the entire central coast, particularly from the ravages of marine development projects. Wind farms are certainly a great contribution to creating a green energy system, but the destructive impact of their construction in an area with endangered species such as the sea otter should not be allowed. That is one of the purposes for demarking a marine Sanctuary along the central coast. Please follow the lead of the Chumash people and include their entire proposed area in the Sanctuary. In hope of your wise reconsideration of this issue, Nick Stewart (life long California native along our coastline and former mayor of Sebastopol)
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Lang, Benjamin
Comment: I support the creation of the Chumash marine sanctuary with the widest possible borders, including Cambria, Morro Rock, Morro Bay and the Gaviota coast. I believe we should be deferring to the wishes of the tribes in this matter and doing what we can to help them preserve their culture and sacred lands. However, I think that a widened marine sanctuary would benefit all people who currently live on their lands by allowing us and our descendants to experience the beauty of the natural world and its protected wildlife. Creating offshore wind and a clean energy economy does not and should not have to come at the expense of Indigenous culture and lands or the devastation of the natural environment.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Reinhardt, Teresa
Comment:
To: Paul Michel

My name is Teresa Reinhardt, and I support designating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension, cover ingabout 7,600 square miles of ocean in order to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Corvallis, OR and lived in Santa Barbara, CA in the early 90s; so I remember the oil blob-polluted beaches and the stench well. I believe protecting the ocean is one of our last chances of preserving what's left of Nature as it used to and is supposed to be. Human impact has been bad enough already (found just this week: DDT, dead whales...), and it's high time we put a stop to degrading it further. Please remember that the genie cannot be put back into the bottle: much too often, we have waited too long (e.g., the effects of mining, oil exploration, sonar effects on animals....). Let our AND YOUR legacy for future generations include ay least some last-ditch efforts to prevent further damage. All of the potential energy produced cannot make up for the environmental destruction in the path of generating it.

There is also a factor of social justice involved; we have trampled on indigenous/native lands, our treaties with tribes ,and their rights long enough.
Let's put a stop to that in a meaningful way: ensuring a healthier future for as much of the CA coast as possible. Centuries, or probably already decades from now, doing so will be seen as prescient and wise, and the right thing to do, at a time when this area may well be one of the last healthy places to live for a large portion of US population. Please remember that we owe our kids and grand kids to do as much as is in our - YOUR - power to protect what is not only logical, but also irreplaceable, and last, but not least, sacred to so any who live there.

I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary be as large as suggested by the local/regional tribes, and that all types of industrial exploitation (oil, gas,...) be prohibited there.
In doing so, the Administration will allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and sustainably benefit from the Pacific’s many treasures without destroying it.

Thank you for any efforts to make this come true.

Sincerely,

Teresa Reinhardt
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from McGuinness , Stephanie
Comment: As a resident of California’s Central Coast, I strongly advocate for Chumash Heritage National Sanctuary and condemn the use of Morro Bay as an offshore wind farm. We need to preserve the regions biodiversity for the well being of all the people and animals of the Central Coast and to properly awknowledge the rights and desires of the native Chumash people. We need to place people and the environment over profits !
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Burnett, Susan
Comment:
Dear NOAA Administrators:
I am a resident of Washington State but I am writing in support of the Chumash Heritage Sanctuary.  I was so disappointed to read that NOAA had deleted this stretch of coast from the proposed sanctuary.  Trust me, I see a need for reducing our dependence on fossil fuels. Perhaps we can have wind farms and also protect the environment? If there are to be wind farms, measures can be made to protect the sea otters and other life of this area.  There would need to be strict regulation backed by science, but that and careful oversight might be able to make it work.  I encourage you to take a hard look at the issue and to see how both sides may be, at least, given some victory here. So much of the time, it isn't either/or but AND.  Make it happen, please.  We have lost so much already due to intransigence from the corporate side.  I am thankful that the Chumash are attempting to save what so many are willing to sacrifice.  Please do your best. The eyes of the future are on you to protect what is under assault. Regarding off shore mining-the industry hasn't advanced enough to take the risk. Any thoughts that they have are premature!!   Respectfully, submitted.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Individual, Anonymous
Comment:
I am a Californian by birth, and have lived next to the ocean most of my life. The coast is the place where I go when I need to seek peace and tranquility. It is a place where I see the abundant life of the coast from human to crustacean and avian. It lifts my heart. The ocean is our partner and has mitigated some of our worst excesses of pollution and an overheating climate. It is up to us to protect the ocean and see that it is not over exploited and further trashed by our activities.  In the case of this proposed marine sanctuary,  we also have the opportunity to partner with Indigenous Tribes of California to steward a piece of our coastline. 

To that end, I support the creation of this sanctuary in it's originally proposed configuration: linking the Monterey Bay Sanctuary to the Channel Islands in one continuous reserve. I support the name "Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary". I support and encourage the partnership of Indigenous tribes and NOAA to administer and steward this area. I would like to see this area protected from future oil and gas development and seafloor mining.  On the issue of potential offshore wind development - I would like to see this happen in some form. We need to replace fossil fuels, but the development has to happen with the highest possible standards to prevent harm to organisms which live here including migrating whales, without harm to sacred sites, to the livelihood of fishers or detrimental impact on land. 

In light of the proposed floating wind farms off Morro Bay, I don't think this is a good reason to cut out a portion of the proposed sanctuary. If NOAA doesn't know what the effects of such a wind farm will be, why aren't we consulting with European Countries to see what effects they are seeing? Yes, it's in a different place in a different ocean, but it is likely to be similar equipment, so what can they teach us? This consultation should be done in conjunction with any planning for a wind farm, instead of doing this piecemeal and cutting a piece out of the proposed sanctuary because we don't know what will happen. 
Thank you.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Bor, Valerie
Comment: It is time to do wha is right, and listen to the original care takers of these lands we inhabit.  The environmental impact to  humans , Marine life, aviary and land animals will be detrimental and we will not be able to undo it. But we can prevent it. Add Chumash territory and protect  our future.

Title: Comment from Flanders, Gail
Comment: We must end our environmental destruction. Our lives depend on it.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Tedder, Anne
Comment: I live in Sonoma County where vineyard growth has exploded over the last decade, taking out massive numbers of native redwoods. This has dramatically disrupted our hydrologic cyles which replenish aquafirs. Many grape growers are digging deeper wells and draining essential water needs for people and wild life. When we suffered the wildfires in 2017 which destroyed 5500 homes, our water needs were taxed to an exceptional degree. Having just emerged from a horrific drought, this hasn't curbed vineyard growth which is expanding to the coast. While I've been supportive of a strong local economy - I'm opposed to coastal growth. We must set limits on growth which negatively impacts ecological habitat and drains vital water needs. The central California coast is a miracle of nature which, if tampered with, will become a black hole of more development. In times of climate change, we must make every critical decision to protect nature for generations to come. Preservation over energy expansion must take precedence.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
While I agree that some of the West Coast should be a sanctuary, energy extraction should not be precluded.

Climate change will destroy all that you seek to preserve. It is an existential threat, not just to the marine life.

We must stop and reverse climate change. For the sake of everyone and everything we hold dear.

I applaud the efforts of indigenous people in protecting the natural environment. 

But I feel that wind, current, tides and wave energy are too important to be sequestered. The stakes affect, not just costal inhabitants, but all of us.

Title: Comment from Kelly and Family, Lisa Ann
Comment:
As a Santa Barbara native of nearly 70 years, it makes my heart sing  to know that steps will be implemented to protect the habitat and welfare of our marine animals. This action is long overdue and has been a long time coming.
Over the years, I have watched friends and acquaintances make their livings and sometimes even fortunes by contributing to the overfishing and, sadly,  often irreparable damage done to our local marine environment. It is time for strict regulations to be put in place so that the fish, lobsters, urchins and other marine life can recover and thrive.
I look forward to seeing the area from San Luis Obispo to Naples designated as an official Marine Sanctuary.  And I give thanks to The Chumash for all of their hard work in making this sanctuary a reality. 

My family feels the same as I and so I sign this for us all.

Sincerely,

The Kelly Family:
Lisa Ann
Chad
George and 
Sergei

Title: Comment from McCambridge, Elizabeth
Comment: I understand the need for wind energy and I support the development. But not at the cost of endangered species like the sea otters or in total disregard for the Northern Chumash people who have worked so hard to designate this area as a marine sanctuary. I was a middle school teacher for 30 years. Since retirement I have been a volunteer tutor with the Minnesota Literacy Project, individually tutoring 2 adult Somali women. I am a frequent lobbyist at the Mn Legislature for legislation I believe in strongly. I unequivocally support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS), with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean, in order to protect ocean biodiversity and to advance environmental justice through collaborative ocean management. Water is life. What will we leave for our children and grandchildren? I urge the NOAA Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures. Do it because it is the right thing to do. Thank you. Elizabeth McCambridge
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Fechner, Jennifer
Comment:
I am writing to support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to protect biodiversity and species habitats.  I believe it is important that the sanctuary include the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension. 

I live in Berkeley California and have been a California resident and tax payer since 1978.  The California coastline is near and dear to my heart.  Degraded ecosystems risk the survival of species, the balance of the systems, and even human health.  As ecosystems are degraded the risk of future pandemics increases.

The establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should be based on an equitable approach to include all tribes in collaborative management. The Rodriguez Seamount needs to be protected.  And a prohibition on oil and gas development in sanctuary boundaries is critical.

Thank you for your careful consideration.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Kovick , Karen
Comment:
I feel a strong desire to speak up to support the desires of the Chumash Tribe to have the stretch of coastline which includes their tribal lands included in a marine wildlife sanctuary plan. This is necessary to protect and respect their history, culture and religion, but also to protect the environment. Wind farms can be located elsewhere to leave this area protected. The farms are not benign, but would rather require underground cabling to a centralized base at the shore in order to dispatch the energy. It is unknown how the turbines and cabling will affect migratory patterns of whales and other species, but Noaa has highlighted the developments could increase ocean noise, change existing habitats, affect life cycles of fish, change species survival rates, and release contaminants that could be absorbed by marine life.
Since the US government took this land from the Chumash many years ago, it is unconscionable to leave it out of a sanctuary plan now. Are they still the only ones whose voices will not be heard today?
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Hirsch, Kristen
Comment: Please reconsider the marine area to be protected and extend it so it includes Morro Bay and the area the Chumash people have been fighting for. While offshore wind farms are understandably a priority for non-fossil fuel energy generation, the damage they can inflict on marine areas should not be dismissed or overlooked. Protecting the ocean habit, in this case for sea otters amongst other creatures, is important enough to extend the sanctuary’s boundaries. We are stewards of our natural resources and to be good stewards we must extend protections to creatures and habitats that cannot protect themselves.

Title: Comment from Corey, Cindy
Comment: I have family who live in Santa Barbara county, and I go out there on a regular basis. I have been out to the channel Islands and I have driven up the coast from there to Monterey. I am still struck by the beauty of this area of California's coastline. I was so happy to hear that the indigenous Chumash tribe were involved in the creation of a marine sanctuary but now I understand a key part of the sanctuary from Cambria to Morro bay will be left out. I am dismayed that the tribes guidance has not been listened to, and that, for other reasons which I presume is the development of a wind farm, this prime part of the coast line is not going to be included. It is so bio diverse and important and I am of the strong opinion that wind farms or a hub for wind farms should not be developed in this area. It's so full of whale and other marine life that should be protected at all costs, they are already so threatened. Please reconsider and include this important part into the marine sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Tian, Martha
Comment: Please include Morro Bay, Cayucos and Cambria as part of the protected sanctuary! My husband and I got married in Cayucos and we love that stretch of the central coastline.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Elliott, Pamela
Comment:
Paul Michel,

In order to maintain the quality and quantity of the California coastal and near shore ecosystem the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should run from the existing Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary to the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary and include a small number of floating windmills for ancillary industrial power on the shore.

A limited number, approximately 190, floating windmills could be considered for operation within the entire combined National Marine Sanctuary. Off shore floating windmills will endanger sea life with sonic pollution, while the attending cables will be a navigation hazard to all sea life that migrates within the combined National Marine sanctuary. A large number of off shore floating windmills will not address the need for green energy in the region. Solar power and batteries on individual buildings and properties will. 

A disturbed ocean and near shore environment will leave a non-natural barren ecosystem causing local heating and die-off of ocean species. Leaving the California coast and near shore environment in a natural state will decrease the effect of climate change by allowing the ocean to absorb much of the excess heat and some of the CO2 emissions caused by climate change. 

Creating the combined National Marine Sanctuary - from the existing Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary to the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary - will be a decisive step towards reducing the effect of climate change on the California coast.


Pamela Elliott
Santa Barbara, CA
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Louie, Maribel
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Maribel Louie and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Hermosa Beach, CA. The ocean is an important natural resource that must be preserved for current and future generations. Climate changes impacting the coast of California are increasingly ever-present. Careful stewardship of the land and in this case it’s surrounding waters is best done with the collaboration of the indigenous communities that have been stewards of the land and who have intimate knowledge of its needs and how to care and restore it for the benefit of all Californians. 

I understand that a portion of the originally mapped area has been left out of the preservation are with the intent for it to be used for a wind farm. I would urge you to reconsider the approach to this project and find a way to work collaboratively with the Chumash people to protect the most land possible. We have many urgent environmental needs, including more sustainable energy sources, but California must be at the forefront of finding solutions that prioritize the environment and it’s people first.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Title: Comment from Simon, Rosanne
Comment:
I believe that the Chumash Heritage Sanctuary should be approved.

The ocean stores 50 times more carbon dioxide than the atmosphere, and much of that is held in wetlands and seagrass beds such as are found in the Chumash area. This expanded sanctuary will help us heal the Earth, safeguarding this incredible biodiversity, and keeping ocean wildlife out of harm’s way. Sanctuary status also provides funding for research and better co-management of the area's key ecosystems with the Chumash people.

Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment from nelson, eric
Comment:
I am writing to express my heartfelt support for the establishment of a wildlife sanctuary off the beautiful coastline of Morro Bay. As a native Californian, born in this magnificent state, I have always held a deep reverence for the diverse natural wonders that grace our region.

Last year, upon returning to California after many years away, I embarked on a memorable journey along Highway 101. The mesmerizing sights and the profound connection I felt with the land reignited my passion for environmental conservation and underscored the critical need to safeguard our delicate ecosystems.

I firmly believe that preserving our environment should take precedence over any economic interests. Indigenous tribes have an inherent, time-tested understanding of sustainable coexistence with nature, and their wisdom should guide our decisions regarding conservation. Their ancestral knowledge, coupled with modern scientific expertise, can pave the way for responsible and long-lasting stewardship of our precious ecosystems.

Morro Bay, with its rich biodiversity and unique coastal habitats, deserves to be preserved for future generations to admire and cherish. Establishing a wildlife sanctuary in this area would not only protect the flora and fauna but also provide an opportunity for educational enrichment, research, and responsible tourism.

I urge you to consider the lasting benefits of creating a wildlife sanctuary off Morro Bay, informed by the collective wisdom of indigenous communities and driven by a sincere commitment to the environment. Let us join hands to preserve the natural heritage that makes California truly extraordinary.

Thank you for your attention and consideration.

Sincerely,
eric nelson

Title: Comment from Langridge, Ruth
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel,

I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension. This will cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean that will ensure greater protection for biodiversity and ecological habitats.

I am a researcher at the University of California, Santa Cruz. My current research focuses on land use, water sustainability and climate change on California’s Central Coast. An additional area of interest is Native American environmental policy reflected in my 2003 dissertation as well a 2008 paper, “The Right to Habitat Protection,” published in Public Land & Resources Law Review. The Central Coast is a unique region, close to very large metropolitan areas, yet with many undeveloped areas that we need to cherish and protect from inappropriate development. 

As such, this sanctuary should encompass the largest possible boundary  (the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension), the name should be  “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” in honor of the Chumash efforts to sustainably manage the region for future generations, and oil and gas development should never be allowed. 
 
Sincerely,
Ruth Langridge

Title: Comment from Nguyen, Ava
Comment:
Dear Paul Michael,

My name is Ava Nguyen and I am writing to support the designation and extension of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I was born and raised in California, have lived here my whole life, and wouldn't leave for anywhere else in the world. I especially love our ocean and all the organisms that dwell inside it. I recently graduated from UC Santa Cruz, where I majored in Ecology & Evolution. Every day I saw the beautiful Monterey Bay while walking to the dining hall. Many of the courses I took were located at the Coastal Science Campus, located at the edge of Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary, our nation's largest marine sanctuary. One of my fondest memories was walking with my friends in between classes to the overlook point, where we'd see sea lions, whales, and all manners of seabirds. The diversity of wildlife I saw amazed me; as a Southern Californian, I was unused to seeing many of these animals in the wild. The beach I went to as a kid and still frequent to this day, Seal Beach, has very seals left. Actually, I have never seen one there, despite looking for years. I therefore strongly advocate for marine sanctuaries that protect as much biodiversity as possible.

I also support the Chumash, a tribe that I actually did a report on in elementary school. Throughout the years I've kept reading on them; I remember in particular a heartbreaking Los Angeles Time article about how many of their buried artifacts are being lost to increasing sea levels due to climate change. I urge you to allow the Chumash to take part in fairly and equally managing their ancestral lands. I ask that this marine sanctuary not only protect our precious wildlife, but uplift communities and be used to educate all. Lastly, I support the ban of oil and gas development within the sanctuary. Thank you for reading!

                                                                                                        Sincerely,
                                                                                                      Ava Nguyen

Title: Comment from Moore, Karen

As a Veterinarian who has spent decades involved in protecting our wildlife and their habitat, I believe the area of our coastline from Cambria to Morro Bay is so extraordinary in so many aspects, it truly deserves the special recognition as part of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 
 Not only is Morro Rock sacred ground to the Chumash, but the surrounding waters and the bay afford a safe haven to birds, sea lions and notably, the sea otters. After nearly becoming extinct, the otters have reestablished themselves there. Current research has highlighted the importance of sea otters benefitting the ecosystem in all tiers. Their uniqueness also serves as quite an economic draw for the surrounding communities, who  depend on tourists wishing to observe them as well as other marine wildlife. 
 While I recognize the need to invest and promote renewable energies, the wind farms should not displace the inestimable benefit of this invaluable area. It is a true wonderment that should be protect    .

Title: Comment from brown, joshua
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

As the world grapples with the existential threats posed by climate change and environmental degradation, the call to protect our marine ecosystems reverberates with increasing urgency. The proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, covering the 'Alolkoy' (Initial Boundary Alternative) and the 'Shalawa' (Gaviota Coast Extension), stands as a testament to this urgency. This sanctuary is not merely a delineation on a map; it is a living, breathing entity that encompasses approximately 7,600 square miles of ocean, a sanctuary for life and Earth Mother's vital habitats.

The National Marine Sanctuaries Act (NMSA) serves as the foundational legislative framework for the establishment and management of marine sanctuaries in the United States. It grants the Secretary of Commerce the authority to designate areas of special national significance and mandates the preparation and periodic updating of management plans for each sanctuary. However, the NMSA is not an isolated piece of legislation; it exists within a complex web of laws and international agreements that shape our interaction with the ocean.

The United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) provides a comprehensive international legal framework for the governance of the world's oceans. In 2023, the global community reached an agreement on a High Seas Treaty, an instrument added to UNCLOS, aimed at protecting marine biodiversity in international waters. This treaty sets a global precedent that amplifies the importance of marine sanctuaries and provides an international context within which the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary can be understood.

The Antiquities Act, another pivotal piece of legislation, has been instrumental in the designation of marine monuments like Papahānaumokuākea. It sets a federal precedent for the protection of marine resources and offers a legislative pathway that could be emulated for the Chumash sanctuary.

But what sets the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary apart is its profound connection to the indigenous Chumash people. The United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP) establishes a universal framework of minimum standards for the survival, dignity, and well-being of indigenous peoples. It elaborates on existing human rights standards as they apply to the specific situation of indigenous peoples, including their relationship with their ancestral lands and waters. The sanctuary thus becomes not just an environmental imperative but also a matter of indigenous rights, aligning with the principles laid out in UNDRIP.

The sanctuary should, therefore, be designed to honor this intricate web of relationships. Its boundaries should be expansive, in line with both the NMSA and the global commitments under UNCLOS. The name "Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary" should be retained to honor the indigenous peoples and their deep-rooted connection to these waters. An equitable approach to management should be adopted, integrating traditional ecological knowledge with modern scientific understanding, as per the guidelines of UNDRIP and the NMSA. Outreach and education programs should focus on making the sanctuary accessible to local underserved communities, democratizing oceanic knowledge and stewardship. The protection of unique geological features like the Rodriguez Seamount is crucial, aligning with the NMSA's objective to protect unique habitats. Finally, a stringent prohibition on new oil and gas development within the sanctuary boundaries should be enforced, as authorized by the NMSA and in alignment with global commitments to reduce fossil fuel extraction under various international agreements.

The urgency to act is now. The designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is not merely a policy decision; it is a commitment to future generations, ensuring that the ocean remains a treasure for all to explore, appreciate, and benefit from. It is a commitment to the indigenous Chumash people, whose heritage is deeply intertwined with these waters. And it is a commitment to the world, signaling that we are ready to take the steps necessary to protect our planet for the generations to come.

The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has been at the forefront of global conservation efforts, advocating for protected areas that are effectively managed and fairly governed. The IUCN's World Commission on Protected Areas emphasizes the importance of recognizing the roles and custodianship of indigenous peoples and local communities in conservation efforts. This aligns seamlessly with the sanctuary's objectives, as it aims to integrate Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) in its management practices.

The sanctuary's proposed designation also resonates with the principles of the Marseille Manifesto, which calls for an ambitious, interconnected, and effective site-based conservation network. 

Sincerely,
Joshua W.J. Brown

Title: Comment from Hildebrandt, Ziporah
Comment:
I am writing in general support of the creation of marine sanctuaries, and specifically in support of extending the current draft to include a larger area of the proposed Chumash sanctuary.
 I feel it is extremely important to protect the specific area of Morro Bay from offshore windfarm development until such time as more is understood about the impact of offshore wind and its infrastructure on sea creatures, especially mammals, especially sea otters.

The original proposal from the Chumash tribe included Morro Bay, which has rich biodiversity including a population of endangered sea otters. It is also a significant area to the tribe. 
The exclusion of this area from the proposed sanctuary is not only unfortunate for the wildlife and ecology there, but a slap in the face to the people who have worked for years towards its creation.
I am certainly in favor of sustainable energy production. However there must be ways found to generate electricity without the environmental destruction that has accompanied oil and gas drilling, coal mining,  dam building and deforestation for solar farms.
As I see it, there is a prevalent myth that because lots of electricity is needed, lots of big machines and big installations must be employed to produce it. In reality, electricity is constantly produced all around us, by natural forces as well as by life itself.
These myriad generators haven't yet been harnessed in the numbers needed. Nor has there been any incentive to decentralize the power grid to include multiple smaller electricity sources, which would create a grid with vast resilience instead of the vulnerability we have currently. Imagine every home, every roof, every highway median, every office building and parking lot creating, gathering and contributing electricity. This is possible, the technology exists. It is sustainable. It destroys none of the increasingly scarce habitat remaining for the millions of other species that share our only home, Earth.
In the meantime, it is imperative that precious places, animals and habitats be protected from development that would compromise them further by intruding devices, equipment and materials into sensitive habitat without any idea what impacts it could have.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Ferrasci, Fred
Comment:
Dear NOAA Administrators:
My name is Fred Ferrasci and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the largest possible boundaries to better protect 7,600 square miles of ocean area off of California’s Central Coast.

I live in Oita, Japan and to me, the ocean is essential to the survival of all plants and animals.  In particular, the oceans provide nutrients to fish which I enjoy eating.  Also it absorbs carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases and thus mitigates global warming.  

When I go to the coast, I (take my kids, surf, kayak, fish, swim, wade in the surf, explore the beach, watch the wildlife, etc.).
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes as much of the California coastline as possible and to maximize protection of ocean habitat and wildlife.  It should also include a prohibition of oil and gas exploration or development, water quality protections, seafloor protections for the Rodriguez Seamount
Collaborative management that includes all interested local Native American Tribes, education and community outreach that is multilingual, multicultural, and focused on local underserved communities, and   “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” as the official name of the sanctuary.

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Respectfully,

Fred Ferrasci

Title: Comment from Sullivan, Patrick
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

I am writing to you to express my wholehearted support for the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension, covering approximately 7,600 square miles of ocean. As a resident of San Luis Obispo, California, the ocean holds a special place in my heart. Whenever I visit the coast, I cherish moments kayaking, exploring the beach, and observing the vibrant marine life. As a surfer, sport fisherman, kayaker, diver, and outrigger canoe paddler, the ocean is not just a playground for me, but a sanctuary that enriches my life and strengthens the bonds within my family.

The ocean is our shared heritage, a source of endless wonder and joy for my family. It's where young people learn the importance of nature, conservation, and respect for all living beings. Preserving this stretch of ocean is not just a choice; it's an essential responsibility. It's about safeguarding the legacy we pass on to our children and the generations that follow. Each wave I catch, every fish I reel in, every stroke of my paddle, and every dive beneath the surface reminds me of the delicate balance of our marine ecosystems. It reinforces the urgent need to protect and nurture these waters, ensuring that the vibrant life they hold continues to thrive.

I wholeheartedly endorse the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the following key components:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.
Sanctuary Name: Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
Tribal Collaborative Management: An inclusive approach that incorporates the wisdom of all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Robust programs promoting Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and ensuring access for underserved local communities.
Rodriguez Seamount: Protection of Rodriguez Seamount, crucial for preserving biodiversity.
Ban Oil & Gas: Prohibition of new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.
I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary promptly. This sanctuary will not only be a haven for present generations but also a vital resource for future ones, fostering enjoyment, protection, and benefit from our ocean's invaluable treasures.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Bondy, Sharon
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Sharon Bondy and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. However, I strongly suggest that the ORIGINAL proposed sanctuary boundary be reconsidered for approval. The original plans to have the Chumash Heritage NMS extend to the Monterey Bay NMS would vastly improve the protections for marine life and prevention of future offshore drilling on the California Coast. This original proposal secures our oceans for endangered and once-endangered animals like Sea Otters and Northern Elephant Seals, guaranteeing them a stable future by bridging the Channel Islands NMS and the Monterey Bay NMS without leaving a perilous gap at Morro Bay.

I live in Irvine and the ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our health.
I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and to extend to the Monterey Bay NMS. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
* Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension and extend to the Monterey Bay NMS
* Ban Oil & Gas: A total prohibition on oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries
* Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity

This sanctuary should protect the area from harmful oil and gas development and reduce water pollution in Sanctuary waters by preventing excess runoff of sediments, oils, pesticides, nutrients, and pathogens.

The Marine Sanctuary should ensure that Offshore Wind operations and construction are banned to avoid and mitigate impacts to sensitive marine areas, species, and important cultural areas.

This original proposal secures our oceans for endangered and once-endangered animals like Sea Otters and Northern Elephant Seals, guaranteeing them a stable future by bridging the Channel Islands NMS and the Monterey Bay NMS without leaving a perilous gap at Morro Bay. It would also give indigenous leaders more power over a larger swath of the coastline and off-shore areas, which are lands and waters that still belong to them and which must be managed with the help of their generations of expertise and wisdom. If the current proposal moves forward, it will leave Morro Bay's fragile marine ecosystem open to destruction, limit indigenous sovereignty, and severely hamper interconnected conservation efforts on our beautiful California coastline.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary including an extension to Monterey Bay NMS. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 
Sincerely,

Sharon Bondy

Title: Comment from Schenk , Emily
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

I wholeheartedly endorse the swift establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, encompassing the Initial Boundary Alternative and the Gaviota Coast Extension. This designation would safeguard approximately 7,600 square miles of ocean, preserving its biodiversity and vital habitats.

Whenever I visit the coast, I am awed by it's beauty. When I learn about ocean life, I'm amazed by the uniqueness of all the different creatures and life forms that reside within it.  

Without protection, the biodiversity of the ocean is at risk.  Sea otters, whales, dolphins and more could be disturbed, deafened and killed by disruptions caused by deep sea mining or offshore wind cabling, which could increase ocean noise, change existing habitats, affect life cycles of fish, change species survival rates, and release contaminants that could be absorbed by marine life.
 
The ocean's beauty and mysteries never cease to amaze me. It's a boundless source of knowledge, both in what we've discovered and the vast potential for future generations to explore. 

I am committed to safeguarding this coastal stretch.
I stand firmly behind the establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, with the following key elements in mind:

1. Largest Possible Boundary: Embrace the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension.
2. Sanctuary Name: Bestow the name "Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary."
3. Tribal Collaborative Management: Foster equitable Tribal participation in Collaborative Management.
4. Outreach & Education: Prioritize outreach, education, and research programs that elevate Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and expand access for underserved local communities.
5. Rodriguez Seamount: Ensuring the protection of Rodriguez Seamount is vital for preserving biodiversity.
6. Ban Oil & Gas: Advocate for a prohibition on new oil and gas development within the sanctuary boundaries.

I fervently support the establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to grant this designation, allowing both current and future generations to cherish, protect, and benefit from the ocean's incredible treasures.

Thank you for reading,
-Emily

Title: Comment from Howe, Jeanette

Dear Paul Michel,

I live in San Antonio, TX, which is a few hours drive from some coastal waters, and to me the ocean is our source. We live on the only planet known to have stable bodies of water on its surface. Though I am not near the same ocean coast, because we are all interconnected and dependent upon the ocean, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the biggest possible boundary, inclusive of the Gaviota Coast Extension, protection of Rodriguez Seamount to protect biodiversity, prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries, the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”, an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management, and outreach, education and research programs that provide both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary as outlined above.

Title: Comment from Heischman, Nancy
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel,

I am writing in support of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sancturary. I understand that the boundaries of the future sanctuary, as proposed by NOAA, exclude the area specifically targeted for protection by the Chumash people. I am very concerned about this, because NOAA's stated reason for excluding this area is to accommodate wind farms. NOAA itself has acknowledged that wind farms and related developments could "increase ocean noise, change existing habitats, affect life cycles of fish, change species survival rates, and release contaminants that could be absorbed by marine life." (The Guardian, "Indigenous Tribe reels after exclusion from US Marine Sanctuary," 10/1/23)

I am very fortunate to live on the Monterey Bay (in Aptos, CA). In the years since this area was protected as a marine santuary we have seen the many benefits, including a rebound of the sea otter population and reduction in human activities that adversely affect the marine ecosystem. Tourists flock to the Monterey Bay Aquarium to marvel at the wonders of ocean life in this area, and many are inspired to become involved in efforts to protect it. These newly made commitments are a bare shadow of the Chumash people's milennia of stewardship of their traditional lands. I urge you to include the lands they have targeted for governmental protection in the new Marine Santuary.

Thank you for your consideration.
Nancy Heischman

Title: Comment from Paul, Cailyn
Comment:
My name is Cailyn Paul and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Washington but have enjoyed the Californian coast and to me, the ocean is much more than a natural resource. The clean air and natural beauty makes me hopeful for our future and would love to see as much of the coastline protected as possible so our future generations are able to enjoy it as we have been able to. Many cultures have a deep spiritual or religious bond with the ocean and protecting the coast is just one way we can respect the indigenous peoples who have worked so hard to make this sanctuary a possibility.

I ask that this sanctuary includes: the largest possible boundary as outlined in the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension,
collaborative tribal management, education and research programs that improve both Traditional Ecological Knowledge and access for local communities, protection of Rodriguez Seamount, which is essential to protect biodiversity, and a prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries. 

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures before it is too late. To ensure the greatest impact, please reconsider the initial boundary alternative with Gaviota Coast extension.

Title: Comment from Sharp, Royce
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Royce Warner Sharp, member of the Osage Nation, and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. I am very, very upset that the coastline between Morro Bay and Cambria is not included in the final proposed area of the NMS, in spite of the insistence of the Chumash Nation that this land should also be protected. I have spent a lot of time in this area for someone who lives so far away, and there are few places I have been in this great country of ours that are more deserving of protection. 

I would like to see the protection of the biggest possible boundary (The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension and protection of Rodriguez Seamount) with the Chumash Tribe able to fully cooperate in the sanctuary’s management. 

Do what is right. Protect these sacred waters and the diverse (and endangered) species that exist here, so that future generations will get to experience, appreciate, and learn from such a beautiful and important place.

Thank you for your time,
Royce

Title: Comment from Kvaas, Robert
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Robert Kvaas and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Goleta, CA. and as a scientist, we know the ocean is now one of the most critical factors in slowing global climate change.  I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community is doing its part in maintaining our regional section of ocean environment.  The Marine Sanctuary will help protect the balance of physical and biological diversity which still exists in this region of the coast.  There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.  Several campuses of the University of California and City Colleges like that at Santa Barbara have excellent marine focused degrees and research programs which will benefit from the proximity of this Sanctuary.

As a supporter of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, I would like to see this sanctuary include Tribal Collaborative Management to take advantage of the traditional knowledge possessed by the nearby Native American tribes who have lived in this region for thousands of years.  The sanctuary should focus on education and research programs to help us understand how the natural flora and fauna are maintaining the ecological balance of the region.  And finally, I would like to see the largest possible boundary (Initial Boundary Alternative) with the Gaviota coast Extension.  The Rodriguez Seamount inclusion is essential to protect biodiversity and help us understand the unique role these features play in ocean dynamics.  It goes without saying that a prohibition on new oil and natural gas development within sanctuary boundaries is also essential.

To sum up, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many life sustaining properties.

Sincerely,

Robert Kvaas
Goleta, CA

Title: Comment from Leach, Nicky
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Nicky Leach, and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension, to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I now live in Santa Fe, New Mexico, but am a former longtime resident of Santa Barbara, California, and still an annual visitor to the Central Coast around Morro Bay and Big Sur. To me, the ocean in this still wild area is special, not only for its beauty, wildness, and coastal and marine life but because of the area's rich indigenous history. The two are intertwined here in a unique way, and it has given me great joy to know that the Chumash tribe have been working hard for a long time now to protect resources in this region for all. 

Every year, I travel two days by car to get to this stretch of coast - an 18-hour journey - just to walk Morro Bay Beach from Morro Rock on a daily basis, enjoy its sweeping beauty, crashing waves, sandy beach, and the birdlife onshore and off, the otter family in the harbor, the fishing boats, fresh fish, and the tranquil views of the Pacific. It is a place of physical and spiritual renewal that I look forward to having every year, and indeed need for my health, as I am living with a chronic health condition that benefits greatly from access to the beach and ocean. 
It is unimaginable that it could in any way be impacted by offshore development. That is already an issue in the Santa Barbara Channel, with so many oil platforms spoiling that channel and oil patches on the beaches. Although a cleaner energy, the density of wind farms would certainly ruin the viewshed of the Central California coastline, as it has in many parts of Europe and Scandinavia. 

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so we can all continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean. The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.

For all these reasons, I wholeheartedly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Nicky Leach

Title: Comment from Bui, Jonathan
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Jonathan and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I am a lifelong resident of California living in Los Angeles, and I have a great love for our California coastline. California has an awe-inspiring natural beauty rooted in the unparalleled biodiversity of our ocean and the marine life that calls the California coastline home. As a child I was fascinated by the sea life I could see exposed in tide pools, and as I grew older I realized there was a wealth of incredible life just off the coast, home to kelp forests, migratory whales, sea otters, and so much more. As climate change heats our oceans and acidifies the water, I believe we must preserve the full range of habitats that nature has gifted to us. A sanctuary will be an important part in protecting our ability to learn and inspire this generation and the next.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the biggest possible boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension, including Morrow Bay. I also ask that proposals for offshore wind development in this area be critically evaluated to have little to no impact to the marine life that calls this stretch of coastline home. Human development has long-term generational impacts on pristine marine habitats that I believe should be eliminated if at all possible. There are other stretches of the California coast that have already been heavily affected by human activity, and I believe that industrial projects should seek to avoid disturbing the beautiful marine habitats that would be covered by the largest possible boundary for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

Jonathan Bui

Title: Comment from Lu, Flora
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Flora Lu, and I work as a professor of Environmental Studies at the University of California, Santa Cruz. I write you today in enthusiastic support of the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

As a scholar, my work centers Indigenous stewardship and sovereignty, issues at the heart of this matter. We know that settler colonialism and racial capitalism are the root causes of climate change and environmental degradation. We cannot protect or preserve the ecological systems upon which our lives depend without recognizing how issues of equity and justice are integral to environmental policy. I was disheartened to learn that NOAA had left out the stretch of coastline from Cambria to Morrow Bay as part of the marine sanctuary. This area, part of the traditional lands of the Chumash, should be off limits to oil drilling, deep sea mining, and wind farm development. NOAA must demonstrate its commitment to partnering with Indigenous peoples and forge a respectful co-management relationship with the Chumash, which begins with honoring their wishes for the territorial designation and acceptable uses of the coastal ecosystem. 

Specifically, I strongly urge you to support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
    Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
    Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
    Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
    Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
    Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
    Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

Sincerely,
Flora Lu
Professor of Environmental Studies, UC Santa Cruz

Title: Comment from Jensch, Kristine
Comment: “One of the tribe’s driving factors for establishing the sanctuary is to protect the area from the offshore “windfarms slated to be built along the coast. Morro Bay, an area of rich biodiversity – including part of the country’s last remaining population of endangered sea otters – would become a hub for offshore wind if the sanctuary’s boundaries do not extend to include it.”  The Guardian, 10/1/2023.  I am standing with the Chumash. You have known for many decades of the importance of this area to them. And of the importance of the area to environmental diversity. It is a very sad comment that a tribe of Native Americans have to fight for protection of land that they honor and have protected for many years. And then to watch as your decision strips them of agency and of respect. Refusing to protect this bay is tantamount to giving in to political issues, no matter how helpful a wind farm may seem Please extend the boundaries of the marine sanctuary. Please remember that your mission is the protection of our natural resources, not political interests, nor economic development. Thank you.

Title: Comment from McKeough, Kathleen
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension, to cover the approximately 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

It is very important to me that this sanctuary includes the largest possible boundary, which means the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension and the protection of Rodriguez Seamount, which is essential to protect biodiversity. The wealth of sea life in this stretch of coastline, if protected in the ways the indigenous tribes would protect it, will serve not only Californians, but will have benefits for sea life and the environment far, far from here, benefiting countless beings, and life everywhere. 

Indigenous wisdom always takes the longest view for the broadest benefits for all life, and if we honor and follow that wisdom, I believe we have the very best chance possible of healing the climate crisis before it is a complete climate catastrophe. Protecting our deep cold waters in a warming world can make it a place of refuge for species of all kinds, especially seabirds and ocean plant species, from the tiniest phytoplankton to the tallest kelp. Kelp are some of the most effective carbon sinks we have, and can do far more for the environment than offshore wind farms, which will cause unconscionable harm to wind-dependent seabirds and the many roles they play in fertilizing ocean plant life and maintaining biodiversity. It is also absolutely essential to prohibit new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries if any of these goals are to be met. 

In honor of all they’ve done to bring about the creation of this sanctuary, I would strongly support naming it the “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.” And drawing on their wisdom once again, I support using a tribal collaborative management model, an equitable approach that would include all tribes in collaborative management. We will all benefit from this. In that same vein, outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge and access for local underserved communities will benefit all of us too.

The designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary gives me great hope for the future. Please do all you can to make this happen for the health and wellbeing of current and future generations, and for the earth itself.

Title: Comment from M, S
Comment:
I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. 

The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would protect the ecosystems and species important to the beauty and ecological functions of the region. The sanctuary would also protect the cultural heritage and traditions of the Chumash tribe.

The Chumash tribe are the traditional custodians of their area, including the sea. Their role in Tribal Collaborative Management must be honored and valued. The exemption of a key stretch of coast that has great cultural value to the Chumash tribe does the opposite. Environmental and social justice in establishing the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary means drawing the largest possible boundary of the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension, genuine participation through Tribal Collaborative Management, Outreach & Education programs, protection of the Rodriguez Seamount, and Banning Oil & Gas exploration and development within sanctuary boundaries. These inclusions and conditions of the sanctuary will support the valuable ocean ecosystem that supports biodiversity and key species. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our oceans.

Title: Comment from Noar, Raphael
Comment: I am writing in strong support of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. It is important that we prioritize environmental conservation and protection. Therefore, it is vital that we give the lands and waters that were historically under the protection of the Chumash people back to them. Environmental justice is intertwined with Indigenous rights and sovereignty. We cannot combat environmental degradation without uplifting Indigenous wisdom and rights with regards to environmental care. The Chumash people have been protectors and stewards and guardians of these lands and water ways. It is a step towards justice and environmental protection to place all of the areas that the tribe has proposed under their care and jurisdiction. For too long the US has treated our Indigenous communities beyond poorly so let us take this step toward mending the hurt that we have caused to the environment and to the Chumash people by ensuring all of the land and water areas that they have proposed as part of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary are rightly returned to the jurisdiction and stewardship of the Chumash tribe and peoples.

Title: Comment from Young, Jamaal
Comment: In its public release of the draft management plan for the proposed Chumash National Marine Sanctuary (NOAA-NOS-2021-0080), the agency emphasizes the history-making components to the plan. Once established, this will be the first marine sanctuary to have been nominated by an American Indian tribe. It will also represent a shared approach—wherein both federal and tribal government will be explicitly included in the management of the site—the first such arrangement ever. Undoubtedly, this is an important win for the cause of Native American tribal sovereignty. However, in  the draft management plan, the agency throws very cold water on the hopes that the federal government will honor its promise of shared decision-making. The stretch of ocean territory the agency would include in the sanctuary is remarkably shorter than the area proposed by the Chumash nation. The reason given: the area proposed—and fought for by the tribe for 15 years—would conflict with a wind energy project. Under this logic, all an energy company would need to do to limit the federal government’s authority to conserve American land and water would be for it to have a proposed project that may be built to completion at some point in the future (ocean-based wind projects are often abandoned as the true financial costs of deployment begin to outstrip the potential benefit of the energy to be produced). The agency would have the public lose forever the chance to properly protect a truly unique ecosystem (of tremendous cultural and spiritual significance to American Indians and non-Indians throughout California and across the nation—for the possibility of a wind farm, whose backers admit they have not answered key questions regarding the impact that the transmission technology will have on the surrounding ecosystem. The agency sets the troubling precedent that it is the sanctuary that conflicts with the wind project—and not the other way around. It thus gives primacy to corporate interests at the expense of the stated preference of the Chumash. What’s more, the agency asserts that it did not find the arguments for the tribe’s proposed boundaries compelling. These perspectives are the opposite of partnership. By dismissing the perspective of the Chumash, who have more experience and knowledge of the region and the sanctuary project than any other stakeholder, the agency undermines faith that the federal government will actually heed tribal positions in the future. If the government opts to pursue this plan, it will be a departure so far away from tribal wishes that one wonders why even name it for the Chumash. American Indian nations are not brands whose name should be slapped onto a development project if that project conflicts with tribal intent in supporting said project. I am disappointed that yet once again the federal government appears to be backtracking on its promises to tribes—and in doing so, making it that much harder for all Americans to hold faith in government. Please revisit the area to be protected, as the proposed plan is wholly inadequate for the task at hand and may actually harm federal-tribal relationships, which would deny the nation the chance to enjoy the expected benefits and improved ecological outcomes that make this such an important project in the first place.

Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Tashina Vavuris, I am a doctoral candidate at UC Santa Cruz in the Environmental Studies department, and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Aptos, CA, and to me, the ocean is a lifeline. My family and I live on the coast, my children live in the water, and my son is a talented surfer. Therefore, the ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, spiritual well-being, community connections, and economic health. I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community and future generations can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean. The ocean is beautiful and a learning tool, as there is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension

Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”

Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.

Outreach & Education: Outreach, education, and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities

Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity

Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Tashina Vavuris 
[UC Santa Cruz Ph.D. student, Department of Environmental Studies]

Title: Comment from Klepacki, Anya
