Title: Comment from Watson, Sheri
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
I wanted to take this time to write to you regarding the sanctuary status which was not included for the MORRO area that is special to the Chumash people. The exclusion of the Morrro area threatens more than just a casual impact. A lot of sensitive areas cannot sustain wind farms for birds in the air,, Or underground structures interfering with interference for  sea life, and these structures will also leak toxic chemicals. So the sanctuary status is so necessary for the sensitive area, that I wish you would reconsider designating this as a sanctuary. It is not easy to go against the majority when a position such as yours. But I’m sure you would be able to find the strength to weather the storm, perhaps, of unpopular views on this very very importantt marine area.  Wind farms create so much damage irreparably, and any other further considerations use for non-environmentally compliant and unsafe environmental practices, which are iffy to begin with should be taken to heart. It takes a lot of courage to go against the green, and I urge you to please take some time to weigh all the options. I was really hate to see this area industrialized. Not withstanding the impact. Any non-sanctuary status would mean Chumash people would lose out, historically, culturally, and sacredly. What of these colonized people that we have destroyed so totally? The past has woman itself into the present, and the present will leave itself into the future. L is it really worth it  for this rather small area to be ruined? Please please be a pioneer for this environmental status and protection of this vital area. So many reasons to define the status quo and leave a brilliant mark environmentally. You won’t regret it. I encourage you to take the time you need to save the MORRO area And designated a marine sanctuary. Thank you very much for your time. Sincerely, SHERI. WATSON, Lincoln, Ca.

Title: Comment from Erkiletian, Amber
Comment:
My name is Amber Erkiletian and I strongly oppose the exclusion of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary from the proposed marine sanctuary. The Chumash people have lived with and studied this region of ocean. The Chumash scientists and cultural historians are more completely informed about the nature of this region than those who are examining the benefits of wind farms on the state economy. It does not make sense to destroy a region of such diversity in order to develop clean energy. 
California is known for its tourism. Tourism is an incredible boon to the state economy. Clean fish, clean waters, and the natural environment are much better for the lives of people living in California. 
I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I study ocean flora and fauna for my work. The interrelationship of all of these organisms is necessary for my understanding of the world. During the pandemic I witnessed the disruption caused by recreational motors on a protected ocean inlet in Maine: the eagles didn’t raise their young, the herons didn’t come, the terns, lions and cormorants didn’t nest. There were no osprey in this heritage region because of the noise. The mussel and oyster lines were damaged and this affected local people’s livelihoods. The horseshoe crabs, a critical component of our medical vaccine and blood testing industry, were driven away. Without sufficient horseshoe crabs we lose our ability to make medicine for injectable antibiotics and other protections again pathogens. All this lost just from the noise people made in one 4 mile stretch of protected ocean during the summer of 2020. The ocean needs greater protections than we have given it. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
Most sincerely,
Amber Erkiletian

Title: Comment from Sullivan, Shannon
Comment: The Chumash people as is true of all CA first people's were as recently as the early 1900s been subject to government sponsored extermination at the state level. They were not only dispossessed of their tribal lands but had a bounty upon their heads.  The central coast including Morro Bay are central to the identity of the people's.  It is not only appropriate but imperative that the fragile ecosystems  be fully protected. Additionally, the proposed sea based wind for profit projects should not be allowed in these critically important waters that are a last refuge to endangered sea otters and whales.  Further failing to protect and preserve the health of these areas as originally proposed by the Chumash in light of increasingly destructive climate change is at best irresponsible and at worst an act of systemic genocide.  Have we not learned that choosing profit from windfarms over our long term survival is foolish?   Please reconsider including the entire originally proposed designation area as protected.  Please do not allow destructive wind farms in this critical habitat
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Mohning, Laurie
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
I support the prompt designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctury with the original proposed boundary (Initial Boundary Alternative) and the Gaviota Coast Extension (sub alternative 5b) to protect the largest possible area of the ocean and coastline and the marine biodiversity and habitats included in those areas.  
I live in Lompoc, California and I moved to the Central Coast area specifically to get involved in marine conservation.  Our oceans are dying and we humans are the ones killing them.  Supporting the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is a major step in protecting the ocean, the marine life and their habitats.  I frequently do solo beach clean-ups at Surf Beach, Ocean Beach and Jalama Beach and besides the trash that I pickup, the amount of tar on the beaches from the existing off shore oil rigs is astounding.  By enacting the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, we need to ban any new oil or gas development within the sanctuary, which is why we need to make the boundaries as large as we possibly can!  I would prefer that we decommission the existing oil rigs, but that is a topic for another day.
Alternatives 2, 3 and 4 reduce the size of the sanctuary, and the protections it would provide, by roughly 2,000 square miles.  They eliminate the connection with the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary, opening up that area to damage, particularly from offshore wind development.  It also removes sanctuary protection for the threatened species of Southern sea otter.  While I support investigating offshore wind as an alternative to fossil fuel energy, it needs to be done in a way that least impacts the marine biodiversity.  There are multiple species of whales and other marine mammals that migrate along the central coast and these off shore wind platforms and transmission cables pose a threat to their migration, both in the Morro Bay 399 Wind Energy Area and ones proposed off Vandenberg SFB, right here in Lompoc.  The proposed Vandenberg sites are too close to shore and would impact marine biodiversity, fisheries as well as off shore cultural sites.  Additionally, removing Morro Bay from the sanctuary boundary excludes Lisamu’, also know as Morro Rock, which is a significant part of the Chumash cultural heritage.  As an ocean going people, the ocean is their mother and they have lived in this area for estimates of over 10,000 years and Lisamu’ is a sacred site for the Chumash.
I urge NOAA to retain the name of Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  Yes, there are other tribes in the area, but the Northern Chumash have spearheaded this effort for over a decade.  The late Fred Collins and current Chairwoman Violet Sage Walker have tirelessly worked to bring this sanctuary to fruition.  To name it anything else is an affront to their efforts and to the Chumash nation.  Furthermore, I find it offensive that NOAA is stating that it must work only with “federal recognized” tribes.  It is a slap in the face to Chairwoman Sage Walker and the Northen Chumash, who have spearheaded this effort, simply because they do not have a federal tribe designation.  And to my knowledge the Santa Ynez Chumash have not been involved in the process at all so to now bring them in as a titular nation is insulting.
If renaming the sanctuary would eliminate issues with the Salinen tribe then I have a suggestion.  Since most of the existing sanctuaries have geographic names (Monterey Bay, Channel Islands, etc.) why not make the name geographic as well.  I would like to suggest the Lisamu’ Central Coast National Marine Sanctuary as the name.  By including Lisamu’ (Morro Rock) in the sanctuary as outlined in the Initial Boundary Alternative this satisfies the desires of the Chumash people and allows NOAA to recognize the cultural significance of Morro Rock to the Chumash people as well as other tribes.  By naming the sanctuary after a geographic area (Morro Rock) but using the Chumash name – Lisamu’, you are also recognizing the Chumash heritage without naming any particular tribe.  But you would have to include Morro Bay and Morro Rock within the sanctuary boundaries.

Additionally, I do support the Tribal Collaborative Management so that ALL INTERESTED tribes can participate in the management of sanctuary.  In my UC Climate Stewards course, we learned a great deal about TEK (Traditional Ecological Knowledge) and how we can use it to restore the land.  Using the sanctuary for outreach and education will further the use of TEK to protect the land as well as marine habitats.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and I urge NOAA and the administration to designate the sanctuary to protect our coast for future generations to come.
Thank you.

Title: Comment from Lane, Belden C
Comment: As a Christian, I'm excited to see a proposed draft management plan for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. We need clear and meaningful management and implementation of the sanctuary. Given that the Chumash tribe, among other tribes, have been the primary keepers and sustainers of these waters and the lands that are along the coast, we must first look to them for comment and input on this draft management plan and future management plans. It is so important that we preserve God's unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. I ask that you respect the Northern Chumash Tribal Council requests regarding sanctuary boundary, the sanctuary name, tribal collaborative management, outreach and education, Rodriguez Seamount, offshore wind and water quality. Thank you for your work on this immediate need to preserve God's creation.

Title: Comment from Meeks, Mark
Comment: As a Christian, I'm excited to see a proposed draft management plan for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. At this critical time in our history we must enhance our efforts to preserve and protect all of the natural vitality that remains in our natural environment.  Much is now threatened by human impacts, and now is the time to reverse the history of exploitation for a better future of preservation and sustainability.  That future will be even more open o us the more we collaborate with Indigenous peoples who have for a far longer time lived as stewards of the earth's vitality.   Given that the Chumash tribe, among other tribes, have been the primary keepers and sustainers of these waters and the lands that are along the coast, we can look to them for comment and input on this draft management plan and future management plans. It is so important that we preserve God's unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. I ask that you respect the Northern Chumash Tribal Council requests regarding sanctuary boundary, the sanctuary name, tribal collaborative management, outreach and education, Rodriguez Seamount, offshore wind and water quality. Thank you for your work on this immediate need to preserve God's creation.

Title: Comment from Preciadl, Judtih
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
I am a supporter of the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect marine habitats.
I am a retired teacher from Vallejo, California, and I feel a deep connection to the ocean.  I feel a responsibility to protect this stretch of ocean for the sake of the community and for the protection of marine life. I also believe that ocean research is important for educating present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.  I also urge you to include all the tribes who are culturally connected to that area in collaborative management. Outreach, education and research programs should include both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and should be accessible to local underserved communities.
The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity.  New oil and Gas development should be prohibited within sanctuary boundaries
I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to benefit from the protection of our oceans.

Title: Comment from Shipman, Shireen
Comment:
Hello,
I think that the Chumash Heritage NMS should be revisited and added to the MPAs identified by NOAA.  As a SCUBA diver in Southern California, I have seen how beautiful and special the areas proposed are.  I have seen the impact and abundance of sea life within MPAs.  It is an absolute shame to lose out on this piece of California's coast for offshore windfarms.  I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 

I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
Thanks for your time!

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Although I approve of most details of the plan in general, I don't understand NOAA's position regarding the waters near the town of Morro Bay. 

The bay in general, and Morro Rock in particular, is not just a historically-sacred place, it is still held sacred today both by the Chumash and Salinan peoples. Its sacredness to these groups is so well-established that they have an ongoing dispute with one another about whether the rock should ever be climbed, with the Salinan climbing it twice per year to celebrate the solstices, and the Chumash believing that it should never be climbed. Moreover, archeology near Morro Bay establishes that the Chumash, at least, had been living in the area for over 3000 years, only a few thousand feet from the Rock.

When NOAA claims that "The preferred boundary also allows NOAA to focus its management on key areas historically important to the Chumash tribes and natural resources important to their heritage," it seems like a bizarre claim. The agency is not primarily run by Chumash people, so we don't have any reason to think that NOAA's position reflects any insider knowledge about what's important to the Chumash. And the Chumash themselves have asked repeatedly for protection of the waters off this site, so it seems clearly just plain false to say that it's really for their sake that NOAA is ignoring this part of their request.

But I don't understand which other stakeholder either, that the exclusion is supposed to benefit. I don't see how it can possibly actually be the stated wind-farm-related concerns about "subsea electrical transmission cables and substations from the Morro Bay Wind Energy Area to shore". Those concerns do not seem applicable to Morro Bay, because the wind energy area is closer to Cambria than it is to Morro Bay. Laying the cables from the turbines all the way to Morro Bay at all would take several extra miles of undersea cables. It seems more efficient to onshore at Cambria, or perhaps further up the road.

Nor do I understand the ecological rationale. NOAA's plan has already shown at Graviota that the protection of coastline is an important goal of the sanctuary; deliberate choices in this boundary have been made to include the waters off other state parks, in the Marine protected area. And that makes very good sense: by protecting an adjacent pair of waters and the lands, a larger overall protected zone is created, each side supporting the other. Well, this applies directly to Morro Bay; there's a state park already right there in it, called Morro Bay State Park. I can see it right there on Google Maps. There's an otter-viewing pier and a State Marine Reserve, so there's clearly wildlife to protect... but apparently, it is the position of NOAA that none of this wildlife is worth protecting? Or that the adjacent wildlife is not worth protecting, as a support for the state reserves? I do not understand the intent.

It is heartening, though, that this sanctuary is happening at all.

Title: Comment from Harrington, Eileen
Comment: Priority of Indigenous Peoples and Sanctuaries in the face of Climate Change's devastating effects on marine life: That's it in a nutshell. The government should only be in the business of mitigating the farm caused by corporate greed and environmental devastation to peoples and animals and wildlife such as marine life. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary honors the people who were wiped out by the US government, church and greedy people. Marine life continues to be harmed by corporations (and corporate power). the US government, and greed. While we are all in favor of "wind farms", respect for the Chumash people and their wishes as well as acknowledging the fact that all marine life is in critical danger from Climate Change as well as human behavior along the CA coast. FIND ANOTHER WAY that doesn't harm marine life, respects indigenous rights, and protects the environment. There is always another way--smart people who want to protect vulnerable people and the environment have always known this.

Title: Comment from Kirks, Susan
Comment:
Support the Chumash Heritage Sanctuary

Paul Michel, NOAA Sanctuaries West Coast Regional Office, 99 Pacific Street, Building 100F, Monterey, CA 93940

Dear Paul Michel,

I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Sonoma County and am a Naturalist and long-time conservationist, very familiar with our California coast and waters.

Honoring the Chumash tribal request is most important.

The ocean is also personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.
I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. This designation will protect one of the most sensitive and beautiful areas of the world with exceptional sea life and ocean features.

The sanctuary should include the Chumash proposed full sanctuary and be named “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” - with Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.

For Outreach & Education, I support programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities

Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity

Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries is critically important.

In summary, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

This designation will be one of your agency's most important. We must seek renewable energy solutions that do not negatively impact our California coast and we must make decisions to prioritize equity and fully protect our oceans, sanctuary areas and the fragile lives struggling to survive there

Sincerely,
Susan Kirks

Title: Comment from Edwards, Catherine
Comment:
October 2, 2023

Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Catherine Edwards and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Santa Fe, NM, but grew up in California. The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health. Leaving this stretch of coast without protection may mean the destruction of habit for endangered sea otters and affect California tourism. For example, wind farms in this area will be a blight on the beauty of the drive up CA 1 and will kill thousands of sea birds, which already are under terrible strain from avian flu. Tourists will not wish to visit places with windfarms. They completely mar the beauty of the coastline. Another example that could blight the area are oil platforms which pollute the surrounding waters, leave tar on the beaches and leak, causing devastation to wildlife. It is important to protect this stretch of ocean to protect the health of the planet, whales, dolphins, birds and sea life that depend on a healthy ocean for survival.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension; the sanctuary name: “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary"; as well as Tribal Collaborative Management and outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities. I also support the protection of Rodriguez Seamount which is essential to protect biodiversity; and finally a ban on oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,
Catherine Edwards

Title: Comment from Zilmer, Roxi
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Roxi Zilmer and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Palos Verdes, CA and to me, the ocean restores my energy. I walk and hike near the ocean, my family sails and paddle boards in the ocean. We enjoy sustainable caught seafood and heals our soul! 

I support the largest proposed boundary, the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alternative 5b), to ensure a contiguous buffer of ocean protection while directing Offshore Wind development to more suitable areas further offshore where wind energy is optimal and ecological and cultural impacts can be reduced. The sanctuary will also allow for robust monitoring and research needed to understand the long-term impacts of Offshore Wind. Any Offshore Wind transmission cables proposed for this area as part of future offshore wind development should require permits from the National Marine Sanctuary Program to ensure that they are planned and sited in a thoughtful, consolidated manner to reduce and mitigate impacts to
the ocean. 

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely, Roxi Zilmer

Title: Comment from Simon, Paula
Comment:
I live on the Central Coast and have had the pleasure of being able to really get to know this incredible area that needs your protection. There is so much diverse wildlife, migrating, whales, and birds that frequent the coast at different times of the year. There is such a diverse and pristine, marine life system as well as the largest and last remaining healthy kelp forests.  In the area between Cambria and Morro Bay, there has been an incredible rebound of the endangered otter species. I think it’s incredibly important that the original border is considered and adopted for the sanctuary, making it contiguous with the Monterey Bay national Marine sanctuary. In addition, Morro rock, and the areas around it are very sacred to the native peoples of the area. Even in Cambria, there are sacred sites. The border must start where the Monterey Bay National Marine sanctuary border ends. 

Please include the area from Morro Bay North to Cambria. It is my opinion that it’s worth saving. The wind farm and all of the operations needed to maintain it can be located south near Santa Barbara area. It makes sense because naturally there are already structures and ports for oil wells, etc. in the area. There’s no need to bring that kind of industry this far north. I realize this can create a conflict between two government agencies, but the otters need a voice as do all of the other marine animals that live in this area peacefully.  Thank you for your time and reading my comment. I hope you do the right thing and include the areas originally proposed by the Chumash tribal council. Please respect  their sacred sites. 

Respectfully,
Paula Simon

Title: Comment from Simon, Reed
Comment:
I live on the Central Coast and I think it’s important that the original border proposed by the Chumash Tribe is considered and adopted for the sanctuary. It should connect to the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary. In addition, Morro Rock, and the areas around it are very sacred to the Native Peoples. The border must start where the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary border ends. 

Please include the area from Morro Bay North to Cambria. It is my opinion that it’s worth saving because of the migration of so many sensitive species AND its significance to The Native Peoples. 

Thank you for your time and reading my comment. I hope you do the right thing and include the areas originally proposed by the Chumash tribal council as the preferred border. 

Thank You, 
Reed Simon
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Barron, Tiobe
Comment: Hello, I am writing (from unceded Chumash territory) to voice my support for the Chumash Heritage marine sanctuary. The Channel islands are unique, with many endemic (& vulnerable) species. They deserve protection, especially from extractive fossil fuel industry, especially in the face of dramatically worsening climate chaos (as I write to you, Ojai is in the middle of a 20-degree jump over 24 hours, from 70s to 90s). Marine life, HEALTHY marine life, produces more oxygen (that we need to breathe) than trees. Anything NOAA can do to protect them, they should. Even the in the face of entrenched monied interests; money is a human construct, not actually real, not actually enduring on a geological scale, whereas our actions very well may be (& certainly the rising cases of asthma, wildfires, etc that our families are enduring are all too real). Be as bold as you can be, for our lungs, our lives, our oceans. Thank you.

Title: Comment from Barnett , Mike
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Michael Barnett and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in San Diego, CA and to me, the ocean is an incredibly important resource that we need to protect. 

The ocean is personally important to me. I have spent so many hours, especially with my children, at the ocean. We have hiked, camped, kayaked along the shore. Most importantly, we have found a deep connection to life and our planet by spending time there.

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

Mike Barnett

Title: Comment from Marx, Jan
Comment:
Dear Paul Mitchell,
I am writing in support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with borders as originally proposed, including waters off of Cambria and Morro Bay. I have been a supporter of this nationally significant project for decades and, as then Mayor of the City of San Luis Obispo, have traveled to Washington DC to voice that support to then Congress member Lois Capps and her successor, Salud Carbajal.  I am also a strong supporter of off shore wind farms and battery storage at the old Duke power plant in Morro Bay, and believe that these projects, with environmental and engineering expertise, could be accomplished without reducing the borders of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  Attached you will find letters demonstrating the support of the San Luis Obispo City Council which I signed as Mayor in 2015. Our City's support remains strong.  We urge you to revise your recommendation to include the original borders of the Sanctuary.  Sincerely, Jan Howell Marx, present City Council Member City of San Luis Obispo.

Title: Comment from Preston, Mel
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Mel Preston and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I have lived most of my life near the coast of California. The ocean is at the heart of our culture. As a child, I spent my summers boogie boarding and body surfing, and as an adult I go to the ocean often to walk with my dog and find some peace and quiet at the end of the day. As an ecologist, I have a strong connection to, and understanding of, how important the oceans are. I have lived and worked near coastal ecosystems for over a decade. I've been on boats to see blue whales, humpback whales, and albatrosses. I've spent many an hour tide pooling to see octopus or abalone, which are getting rarer and rarer. I've witnessed the collapse of fisheries and the crab season because the ocean's ecosystems are deeply imperiled and they need protection. I've witnessed the decline of shells, kelp and other natural material washed up on the beach, replaced by microplastics and trash. When a community bands together to protect what they love, and what gives them life, they should be supported. This is one of the richest coastal ecosystems in the world. If we don't follow the leadership of the Chumash people and stand up to protect and cherish this ecosystem now, it WILL be gone for the next generation. Many drastic changes have already happened, but with a strong commitment to the well being of this coastal ecosystem, we can encourage marine life to recover and even flourish. The Chumash National Marine Sanctuary needs our support.

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
 I ask that this sanctuary includes:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,
Mel Preston

Title: Comment from Kretz, Georgia
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Georgia Gayle Kretz and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Brooklyn, NY and have always loved and wanted to preserve the beauty of the ocean. I know what it’s like to live near one of the most toxic rivers in the nation—the Gowanus Canal—and to see beaches despoiled with trash and industrial waste. On your coast, the ocean is not only enjoyed by all people, but particularly sacred to the Chumash, who deserve the right to help steward it and who will be able to contribute greatly to its conservation with their knowledge and care for it. Excluding them at this step is a terrible mistake that will only add to the list of broken promises made by the US government to Native nations. You have an opportunity to do the right thing for once, and the power I only wish I had to make things right. Please don’t squander it.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes an equitable approach to include all Tribes in collaborative management.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Georgia Gayle Kretz

Title: Comment from Jacobs, Don
Comment: Several years ago a panel of California congressman and the president of the Santa Barbara Chumash met to discuss water usage in California. The Chumash usage of water per capita was far better than any other community in California. At the end I asked the question to the Chumash official: "Did your Indigenous worldview have anything to do with such success?" He replied: "It was the main driver." I just presented at the UN Biodiversity Summit on how Indigenous worldview is "proven sustainable." (See ProvenSustainable.org). The UN Biodiversity Report of 2019, the largest study ever done with 15,000 peer-reviewed papers, 450 researchers and 50 countries, revealed that where Indigenous worldview is operating such extinction rates are absent or severely reduced. (See my article in The Nation, "The Media Missed A Crucial Message in the UN Biodiversity Report."  80 percent of all biodiversity is on the 20% of the planet managed by Indigenous Peoples.  I raised money and helped direct efforts to create the first Category II Marine Sanctuary on the Costelgre coast of the Pacific in Jaliso Mexico, so I well know how important this issue is.  NOAA says within one generation there will be no sustainable fisheries if we do not get 10% of the ocean into NTZs. Less than 2% is now protected.  I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary as an effort to do far more than just preserve a part of our ocean for future generations. This is about survival of all species on Earth. Respectfully submitted, Wahinkpe Topa (Four Arrows), aka Don Trent Jacobs, Ph.D., Ed.D.

Title: Comment from Hebberger, Jo Anna
Comment:
As a Christian and an Ecologist, I'm excited to see a proposed draft management plan for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. We need clear and meaningful management and implementation of the sanctuary. Given that the Chumash tribe, among other tribes, have been the primary keepers and sustainers of these waters and the lands that are along the coast, we must first look to them for comment and input on this draft management plan and future management plans. It is so important that we preserve God's unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. I ask that you respect the Northern Chumash Tribal Council requests regarding sanctuary boundary, the sanctuary name, tribal collaborative management, outreach and education, Rodriguez Seamount, offshore wind and water quality. Thank you for your work on this immediate need to preserve God's creation.                                                                                                              

Sincerely,  Jo Anna Hebberger, PhD

Title: Comment from Sanchez, Laura
Comment:
Dear Mr. Paul Michel,
I am writing I am in support of the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Please designate the sanctuary as it was originally proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), as well as the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b), so that there is protection for the waters between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This sanctuary offers the opportunity to elevate Indigenous perspectives and cultural values, honoring the history and culture of the Native Americans who have inhabited this region for more than 10,000 years. This sanctuary should protect the area from harmful oil and gas development and reduce water pollution in Sanctuary waters by preventing excess runoff of sediments, oils, pesticides, nutrients, and pathogens. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should ensure that Offshore Wind operations and construction are completed through the guidelines of the new Sanctuary. These projects should be planned and authorized in a way that avoids and mitigates impacts to sensitive marine areas, species, and important cultural areas.

Thank you for your consideration,
Laura Sanchez

Title: Comment from Connett, Joe
Comment:
Conversation with Bard
profile picture
Improve the following to make it more professional and persuasive:  My name is Joe Connett and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Ventura CA where I spent my career as a civilian supporting the United States Navy  and to me, protecting the ocean is vital for our future. I have spent 1000s of hours appreciating our coastal beauty on the shore and diving in our coastal waters. Please protect our ocean flora and fauna and by protecting them protect humanity. 
View other drafts




























Dear Sir or Madam 

My name is Joe Connett, and I am writing to urge you to swiftly designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension, covering approximately 7,600 square miles of ocean.

As a 35 year resident of Ventura, California, and a former civilian supporting the United States Navy, I have a deep appreciation for the importance of protecting our ocean and its resources. I have spent countless hours enjoying the coastal beauty of our region, both on the shore and in the water.

The CHNMS would provide a vital refuge for marine biodiversity and habitats, including kelp forests, rocky reefs, sandy beaches, and unique offshore geologic features. It would also help to address the global biodiversity crisis and accelerate nature-based solutions through inclusive partnerships and collaboration among federal, state, and local governments, and California Native American Tribes.

In addition to its environmental benefits, the CHNMS would also create new opportunities for scientific research, education, and economic development, including responsible recreation and tourism.

I urge you to support the swift designation of the CHNMS. It is a critical step towards protecting our ocean and ensuring a healthy and sustainable future for all.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Cowans, Diana
Comment:
My name is Diana Cowans and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Bradenton, Florida, on the Gulf Coast and the ocean represents life to me. I am so fortunate to live on the coast of Florida, having grown up on the east coast and now living on the west coast.  I do all that I can to help preserve the oceans. All life on this planet needs water, clean water. Humans have not done enough to preserve the oceans but I believe we can do much better.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary include: 
•	The Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension. This will help us do more to preserve our environment.
•	Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
•	Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management. Indigenous peoples know more than many non-indigenous peoples about how to preserve the land. They respect and live in it, as we all should.
•	Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
•	Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity. Biodiversity feeds and preserves our systems. We must acknowledge and support these systems. 
•	Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries. This is merely common sense. We need to be quickly moving away from fossil fuels. Creating this sanctuary assumes that we will not destroy it by drilling for gas and oil.  
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Title: Comment from Hart, Danny
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Danny Hart and I live in Los Osos, CA.   I moved to this area in support of the natural beauty and wild life that the central coast offers.  I have been "Ocean" active all my life.  As a Master Dive instructor, Merchant Marine holding 100 tonnes Master License,  former USCG AUX coxwain, I have seen what marine sanctuaries can and can not do.   I have witnessed the come back of many endangers species in my life all due to a marine Sanctuary in the channel islands.   Yes there was the push back, fishermen/ and divers alike didn't like the restrictions, but after a few years, nearly all of them have seen the benefit.

I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
I understand the need green energy and that Morro Bay is situated in a unique position, but there are other viable solutions.   We do not have to destroy more.  Our lifestyle on the central coast is already impacted by the Diablo Nuclear power plant.   The Chumash tribe has give up alot for that.
Let's give them back their way of life in a small way.  Let's give them part of the ocean to be as it was intended to be.  sacred and natural 
 

Sincerely,

Danny Hart Los Osos, CA

Title: Comment from Ruiz, Salvador
Comment: The cost for implementation and maintenance has increased drastically. Noaa has highlighted the developments could increase ocean noise, change existing habitats, affect life cycles of fish, change species survival rates, and release contaminants that could be absorbed by marine life.The construction and installation of offshore wind turbines will cause a significant underwater disturbance, affecting marine species' behaviour and migration patterns. During operation, the wind turbines emit an electromagnetic field that interferes with the ocean's natural electromagnetic fields. Republicans in Congress and some environmental groups claim the turbines would disrupt marine wildlife, especially whales. Military officials object that proposed sites would interfere with their operations. Please reconsider the plan for this project as it will be counter productive, expensive, and improperly placed.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Farhar, John
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

I strongly support the timely designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the original Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.  The Agency-preferred Alternative excludes the most significant portion of the original proposed Initial Alternative and the focus of much of the original discussions surrounding the plan from the beginning. The segment between Morro Bay and Cambria must be included to preserve the intergrity of the original concept as well as the regional protection and safeguards needed for success. The explanation that there is a need to prohibit the protection in case there is possible wind energy industrial development corrupts both this review process based upon speculative considerations and future review processes by predisposing the approval of a separate project and thereby prejudicing future decision making, contrary to the objectives of NEPA. Further, excluding this narrow stretch of coast will invite uses inconsistent with the adjacent preserves and protected areas that might not otherwise be considered. This cannot be overstated that this is an impact of the Agency-preferred Alternative that requires identification and mitigation. 

This section of coastline was and continues to be as significant if not most significant from a Native American cultural perspective as evidenced by the Northern Chumash Tribal Council championing this cause for many years at the local level. Their dedication and focused efforts are responsible for the impetus for the vital plan that now fails to accomplish the original objective.  Please honor the work of the NCTC and approve the original Initial Boundary Alternative.

I have lived on the central coast since 1982 and haved a strong reverence for our coastal resources. I have volunteered for the Marine Mammal Center in Morro Bay and seen how fragile this ecosystem is for all of the wildlife. Any proposal for offshore development must be sensitive to all of these resources most notably the Federally listed and protected sea otters concentrated around Morro Bay as well as nesting Peregrine falcons who utilize Morro Rock and forage in the surrounding area. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and ask that this sanctuary include:

The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities.
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity.
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.
 

Sincerely,

John Farhar
Atascadero, CA

Title: Comment from Horvath, Robert
Comment: I fully support your proposal to EXCLUDE the zone from Morro Bay to Cambria from the proposed marine sanctuary. You know very well you will be inviting lawsuits to oppose offshore wind development along the central coast if it is all part of the marine sanctuary. You need to be looking to the FUTURE, not the past, in your decision. We need to protect our marine resources for the future of everyone, but not arbitrarily reflecting the viewpoint that no development is acceptable because the area is sacred, or that marine life is so delicate that all disturbance will bring the end of the world. Human resources must also be considered in the balance, and offshore wind power will be critical if we want to slow the damage caused by climate change. I doubt that even the Chumash or Salinans want to preside over the destruction that will follow from short-sighted decisions on our global future.

Comment: I stand in support of the Chumash heritage national Marine sanctuary this is long overdue and much needed. The proposed sanctuary should extend south all the way to Carpinteria as over the years I have been very concerned with various extraction threats made along the California coastline from the fishing, minerals,military, oil and wind industries. There appears to be no oversight over these industries whether they are the trawlers methods that are like hunting jack rabbit with a bulldozer, the oil folks using the Cory corset to tow 18 Volkswagen size speakers guaranteed take the hearing of marine mammals close to them or and unaccountable nuclear industry that kind dump with impunity not only putting the world at risk for cancer but possibly disrupting the DNA of all planet life. The indigenous people have been here far longer than we have and have the insight to keep ecosystems in balance not irresponsible practices of our present Big Ag. When I was younger any morning you could see up to 25 bottlenose dolphins along the California coast and now if you're lucky you'll see three maybe as many as five together these things are disappearing right before our eyes but the whole world comes here to enjoy things like whale watching and the amazing the diverse ecology, so again I request that you let the Chumash and other affiliated tribal nations be the stewards we need.

Title: Comment from Maxwell, Ann
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Ann Maxwell, and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I was born, raised, and currently live in, Santa Barbara, CA and to me, the ocean is an integral part of my family’s life. We spend our weekends at the beach with our children and try to explore the Gaviota Coast whenever we can. Protecting biodiversity is a critical part of our children’s future. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the biggest possible boundary and includes the protection of Rodriguez Seamount, a key area of biodiversity.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,
Ann Maxwell

Title: Comment from LaFuente Jr., Frank

Dear NOAA Administrators:
My name is Frank LaFuente Jr. and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the largest possible boundaries to better protect 7,600 square miles of ocean area off of California’s Central Coast.
I live in Nipomo, CA and to me, the coast brings me joy.

When I go to the coast, I (take my kids, surf, kayak, fish, swim, wade in the surf, explore the beach, watch the wildlife, etc.).

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Dear NOAA,
My name is Andy and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Seattle, WA, but I grew up on the East Coast. Part of what drew me to the West Coast was the rugged beauty of the coast and the peace I find on the coast. It’s a place to go  hiking, kayaking, and spend time with friends and family, but most importantly it’s a time to reconnect with the land and ground myself in what’s important. Like so much of the US, the coast has been stewarded by the tribes since time immemorial and I think it’s important to honor their relationship to these places. This can be done both by bringing greater awareness to sacred places and by working with the tribes to make sure these places are there for future generations. 
This is why I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the  the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension, and that tribes are consulted in the naming, designation, and management of the sanctuary. This could include:
* Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
* Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
* Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
* Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
* Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,
Andy

Title: Comment from Agnor, Leah
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Leah Agnor, I am native to California and lived in the Monterey Bay area for many years. There, I developed my love and appreciation for the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary. It's important to me, and for future generations, that more areas are protected in the same way. To that end, I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I understand the need for alternative energy sources; but, I believe there are alternative ways for achieving those aims while simultaneously creating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Creating a sanctuary covering 7,600 square miles of ocean in the name and honour of the Chumash people; would be an incredible act of restorative justice that would bring us hope for the future. 

I ask that this sanctuary includes the largest possible boundary (i.e. the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension). I ask that this sanctuary be called the “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.” I ask that the Chumash tribe be included in the management of the the sanctuary. I ask that outreach, education and research programs are created that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities. I ask that the sanctuary includes the protection of Rodriguez Seamount, to protect biodiversity. I ask for the prohibition of new oil and gas development/exploration within sanctuary boundaries. And, if possible, I ask for the prohibition of commercial vessels and commercial fishing within the sanctuary.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

Leah Agnor

Dear Paul Michel,
My name is JoAnne Clarke and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

Title: Comment from Mason, Tamara
Comment:
I strongly support creating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and encourage NOAA to so. The National Marine Sanctuary system is a great way to preserve and protect our vital natural and cultural resources. We don't want these areas to be lost or destroyed. They are national treasures, irreplaceable places of learning, enjoyment and thriving communities of people, animals and plants. These places encourage bio-diversity and healthy ecosystems. And who knows what we will discover in these places. The CHNMS would be an outstanding addition. Honoring the Chumash, an important part of California history - and American history - by creating a new National Marine Sanctuary is an important step. Nurturing a thriving underwater ecosystem, especially in a changing climate, is critical. By preserving this space we are doing the right thing to help foster knowledge of our past which in turns makes for a better present and future. 
While it may be too small for some, it is too large for others. These concerns must be considered and when they are, the positives of creating this proposed new Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is of benefit for all. When a Marine Sanctuary is created we know many species thrive in these protected areas. And many humans thrive too, being outside, experiencing and learning about the inhabitants and our history at that special location - even if some of us consider the sanctuary too small (or too big). This proposed Marine Sanctuary area is a beautiful and special location. I've had the privilege of being near and around this stunning stretch of California coastline. To know it is protected and preserved as the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would make it a more beautiful place to be near. I look forward to visiting CHNMS soon! 
Thank you, Tamara Mason
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Anderson, Beth
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Beth Anderson and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Carpinteria CA and to me, the ocean is a fundamental system to the earth that is abused by human systems that use it as a limitless resource. The science shows us that the earths closed systems holds and recycles pollution that human activities put into the water, atmosphere, and land. I try to make life choices that have the least impact on harming the environment. I support positive legislation to regulate and protect the environment. I feel our capitalistic structure, and lack of regulations supports corporations, in rampant and huge scale, use of earth’s resources to develop products, many of them unnecessary, for capital gains, bloated through manipulations both commercial and political, while leaving resultant destruction and pollution. In the best-case scenario this leaves the tax payers and private efforts to clean up a small portion of the harms they levy en masse to the earth and life on earth.
Living on the coast, I realize I have a heightened awareness of nature and the environment because I see it every day: the creeks, estuaries, beach, ocean, flora and wildlife. I think this also yields more awareness of the impacts of environmental degradation as I've seen over decades: changes in the" density of ocean wildlife I see in tidepools, poisons effecting ocean life as see neurological symptoms in seabird and sea mammals, as well as health concerns I have for food sources such as fish and what eventually cycles into our drinking water. 
The ocean is personally important to me and I know important to human life on earth. Although knowledge of that importance exists very few folks in human society have the daily awareness of our dependence on the ocean to ensure necessary consideration of actions and effect choices that support the health of the ocean.
I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations. To grow the awareness and actions, to build on a model of improved stewardship necessary to effect change. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s.
Sincerely, Beth Anderson

Title: Comment from Goodfellow, Sharie
Comment: I recently became aware that NOAA modified it draft plan to exclude Morro Bay in the designated Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary proposal due to proposed and planned wind turbine devices to be installed in the ocean in the Morro Bay Area.  I recently became aware that the endangered sea otter population would be further endangered by this exclusion.  Is it inconceivable that the planned wind turbines built to generate electricity could be relocated further out in the ocean from Morro Bay or relocated to land so as to be able to include Morro Bay within the protected Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary area?   I am very concerned that our Pacific Ocean's mammals and sea creatures receive this most necessary protection to their migration routes, their necessary food supplies, and their ultimate health and protection by all means necessary.

Title: Comment from Marine Conservation Science Institute
Comment:
The proposed boundaries of the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary will protect some very unique marine ecosystems, including the southernmost mainland northern elephant seal colony and a recently discovered adult white shark hotspot. The region is very remote with very little commercial and recreational pressure, so the opposition will then be muted since it is will not impact very many people. So this can be an easy "win" for marine conservation. To be fair, one could also argue that the region is so remote and relatively pristine, that the taxpayer burden for the administration and enforcement of the sanctuary is unnecessary.

One segment of the population that will be negatively impacted, ironically, is the research community that studies the flora and fauna of this specific region. Above I mentioned the fact that the proposed sanctuary includes a newly discovered adult white shark hotspot. How do I know that? My research team discovered it. I have lead a team of researchers that has been tracking the movements of the white sharks that visit this site. Our results are largely unpublished because the work is in progress, but the public has become aware of the site through some television documentaries we have released, the most recent being Counting Jaws on the National Geographic Channel. I have been studying white sharks for nearly 25 years, and I have had to obtain permits from the State of California, the Mexican government, and from one of the National Marine Sanctuaries off the California coast. I can say without hesitation that the extra level of permitting and restrictions that come with a Sanctuary permit are actually a hindrance to research. Many of the restrictions have no scientific data to justify them, and they sometimes unwittingly make the research more dangerous to both researchers and the species we are studying. 

If this Sanctuary becomes a reality, I encourage the new administering staff to work closely with researchers when considering research restrictions. We already must have our research reviewed and permitted by the State of California, and the work has proceeded smoothly with a track record of excellent results. There is no reason to impose additional, heavy handed restrictions that do nothing more than hinder important research. Already there is language drafted to prohibit the attraction of white sharks via chumming. Without the ability to chum for white sharks our research become too difficult to continue. I understand that regulators may want to prohibit the development of a cage diving industry, but that should not hinder research. In fact, the few studies that have been published regarding provisioning (chumming) and its impact on white sharks have shown that it does not have a negative impact on the sharks.

Regards,
Dr. Michael L. Domeier
President
Marine Conservation Science Institute
www.MarineCSI.org
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Markson, Craig
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Craig Markson.  I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Santa Barbara, CA and to me, the ocean and how we treat it is one of the most important issues in my life.

My wife is a specialist in the behavior of cetaceans and I have been an advocate for protecting our oceans for almost 50 years, first as a Greenpeace volunteer in the 1970s.  The ocean and its inhabitants are of prime importance to us

As you already know, the ocean is severely affected by people and their behavior towards our environment.  One only has to walk along our beaches to see the untreated storm drain runoff into the ocean, notice all the trash getting into the ocean when doing Coastal Cleanup Days, learn about the huge island of man-made plastic and the amount of plastics found in practically all marine life, learn about the affect of ocean warming and the death of thousands of marine mammals from algae blooms and the bleaching of coral, the effect of naval testing on underwater communications of cetaceans, and the list goes on and on.  People have been terrible stewards of the world's oceans.

People are literally killing the oceans and the addition of floating wind turbines for the benefit of people and the detriment of birds and marine life will be just one more example of environmental decay.

The section of the ocean under review is vitally important to me and to the Chumash.  It is one of the most beautiful sections of California's coastline and how this proposal will affect the various seals, sea otters, dolphins and whales, and other marine life is totally unknown. A sanctuary will allow research and education and beauty for generations to come.      
  
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

    Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
    Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
    Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
    Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
    Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
    Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

Craig Markson

Title: Comment from Courtway, Jon
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Jon COURTWAY and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Sanctuary, the sooner the better.  It should cover 7,600 square miles so as to protect the biodiversity and habitat therein. 

I live in  Sacramento CA and volunteer at the Cosumnes River Preserve that was once home to the Miwok people. Native CA Indians were targeted for extermination by our first Governor, Peter Burnnet in an address to the State legislature. Then CA passed a multi year bond greater than $1 million dollars to pay for that extermination.  

The designation of this sanctuary as “Chumash Heritage …” would help repay a great wrong. Tribal collaborative management would give them an an equitable voice over their traditional territory.

The ocean has much to teach us and future generations and this sanctuary is a huge step in that direction.

Title: Comment from Else, Robert
Comment:
I am writing in support of the the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I agree 100% with the EDC's three major points, as follows:

1. Please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries.

2. This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.

3. Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.

Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary!

Comment: I am writing as a 52 YEAR resident of the Central Coast of California in  STRONG SUPPORT of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and the Environmental Defense Center's request that NOAA designate the largest santuary possible, SIMILAR TO THE AREA ORIGINALLY PROPOSED BY THE NORTHERN CHUMASH TRIBAL COUNCIL, which would establish important connectivity between two existing National Marine Santuaries in Monterey Bay and the Channel Islands. Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary!
Please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries.
This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.
Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.
Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Shields, Susan
Comment: As a resident of the City of Santa Barbara and a supporter of environmental justice I fully support the establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Amongst my concerns relating to the protection of this body of water is the increasing presence of cruise ships that stop in Santa Barbara, thereby sending pollutants into the air and water.  I also believe it is vital to protect the fishing sources while at the same time allowing the commercial fishing industry to make a decent living. Furthermore, we must protect the whales who swim up and down our coastline and who are threatened by modern dangers such as undersea noise and tankers and freighters. Recreational activities should also be regulated and monitored, as well as the safety of both humans and animals and birds. This sanctuary will be an environmental benefit.

Title: Comment from All Good
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Caroline Duell, I am Founder and CEO of All Good, a Morro Bay based business,  and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

The wellness of the ocean, particularly around the Central Coast of California is central to our business.   I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Caroline Duell
