Title: Comment from San Luis Obispo Beaver Brigade
Comment:
Paul Michel
NOAA Office of National Marine Sanctuaries
99 Pacific Street, Suite 100F
Monterey, CA 93940

Dear Paul Michel:

My name is Audrey Taub and I am the founder of the San Luis Obispo Beaver Brigade.  We are a local organization in San Luis Obispo County dedicated to supporting our watersheds by supporting the beavers and their natural process of building dams, creating wetlands, and defining an entire ecosystem in their role as a keystone species.  We  enthusiastically support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the inclusion of the coastal waters of Morro Bay and Cambria, which will form a contiguous sanctuary from the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary to the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary.

As noted in the Global assessment report on biodiversity and ecosystem services of the IPBES of 2019 (Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services), “the territories of Indigenous peoples and local communities contain 80% of the world’s remaining biodiversity and intersect about 40%1 of all terrestrial protected areas and ecologically intact landscapes”.  

It is well-known that the practices of indigenous people have, for thousands of years, focused on conservation and renewal of resources, even while the modern world has produced climate change and loss of biodiversity.   Traditional Ecological Knowledge is more and more being recognized as essential for incorporating into policy and natural resources management, especially in decisions relating to climate change.  The US Fish and Wildlife has produced a Fact Sheet to encourage crossover between TEK and Western Science, and there is a wealth of resources supporting the use of TEK.

One of the Key Messages from the 2019 IPBES Summary for Policymakers,

D5. Governance, including customary institutions and management systems and co-management regimes that involve indigenous peoples and local communities, can be an effective way to safeguard nature and its contributions to people by incorporating locally attuned management systems and indigenous and local knowledge.  The positive contributions of indigenous peoples and local communities to sustainability can be facilitated through national recognition of land tenure, access and resource rights in accordance with national legislation, the application of free, prior and informed consent, and improved collaboration, fair and equitable sharing of benefits arising from the use, and co-management arrangements with local communities.
And
D7.  Sustaining and conserving fisheries and marine species and ecosystems can be achieved through a coordinated mix of interventions on land, in freshwater and in the oceans, including multi level coordination across stakeholders on the use of open oceans.  Specific actions could include, for example, ecosystem-based approaches to fisheries management, spatial planning, effective quotas, marine protected areas, protecting and managing key marine biodiversity areas, reducing run-off pollution into oceans and working closely with producers and consumers.

In addition to the full support by the San Luis Obispo County Beaver Brigade of the designation of  the entire Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary as it was originally proposed, including Morro Bay and Cambria,  we are in support of this proposal adhering to the suggestions outlined in the 2019 IPBES for including Indigenous peoples in the management of our oceans.  

From Volume 4, Issue 7, 23 July 2021, Pages 907-909, Indigenous peoples proven to sustain biodiversity and address climate change: Now it’s time to recognize and support this leadership author Steve Nitah writes, “Indigenous peoples sustain nature because we know we are a part of nature. We realize that trying to bend nature to our will would harm us as well as the animals, plants, and ecosystems we all depend on. Instead, Indigenous peoples have a reciprocal relationship with our territories. We know that if we take care of the land, the land will take care of us. And so, we honor our cultural responsibility to be careful stewards. When these relationships are respected and when the rights and responsibilities of Indigenous peoples are recognized and supported, the entire planet will benefit.”

We strongly urge NOAA to lead the preservation of an ecological and cultural treasure by approving the entire Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary including Morro Bay and Cambria with the greatest possible boundary,  maintaining the name of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and utilizing tribal collaborative management..  

Sincerely,
Audrey Taub
On behalf of the SLO Beaver Brigade

Title: Comment from Save Our Shores
Comment:
Offshore of San Luis Obispo and northern Santa Barbara County lay the Rodriguez Seamount, Arguello Canyon, Arguello Terrace, and Santa Lucia Bank. This region hosts a complex system of ocean currents, where warmer waters from the south and colder waters from the north converge. The upwelling of colder, nutrient-rich waters from the deep brings nutrients to the surface for primary producers and phytoplankton - this supports an important and complex marine food web that is crucial to the health of our oceans. This area attracts marine species that migrate through five existing west coast national marine sanctuaries, including the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary (MBNMS). For over ten thousand years, the Chumash people have stewarded these waters, and the biodiverse life these waters support. In 2015 the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) accepted the Northern Chumash Tribal Council’s nomination for sanctuary status, and we encourage you to register your support for the largest, boundary option, as requested by the Tribal Council. Now is the time to stand with Indigenous leadership together.

Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) would be the fifth national marine sanctuary off California and sixth off the continental west coast. This new designation would increase the protection of ecosystems from Mendocino County to southern Santa Barbara County. It would fulfill national marine sanctuary program protection goals, facilitate research, outreach, education, and maritime heritage objectives by protecting sacred Chumash cultural sites. NOAA proposes to collaborate with federally recognized Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Indians to access Indigenous knowledge and stewardship. The Northern Chumash Tribal Council supports tribal organizations and governments throughout the region having equal opportunities to collaborate - this also means tribes that are not currently Federally recognized by the United States government.  True equity would be equal opportunities, across the board, for all tribes.

This is the first tribally nominated sanctuary to have made it this close to designation, and the goal is to finalize the status designation by 2024.  There is still time to influence Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary’s boundaries and we need the public’s input. NOAA’s draft plan has an agency-preferred boundary alternative covering 5,600 square miles over 134 miles of coastline. That boundary alternative doesn’t connect to the southern boundary of MBNMS, as its nominators proposed. Instead, NOAA proposes a northern boundary at Hazard Canyon Reef, south of Morro Bay to accommodate electrical transmission cables from an offshore wind energy area outside the sanctuary. NOAA’s proposed changes imply that Morro Bay would not be part of the new sanctuary designation. The Chumash Tribe has voiced how important it is to include that area within the new sanctuary boundaries due to the significant cultural significance the area represents. We encourage you to support the Northern Chumash Tribal Council’s originally nominated boundary which protects 7,600 square miles over 156 miles of coastline, for continuous protection, including Morro Rock. Under sanctuary status, electric transmission cables can be permitted while other activities, such as offshore oil development and dumping, would be prohibited. Additionally, there are no new fishing regulations proposed in the designation. Can we make the commitment to truly listen to indigenous voices, to stand behind their requests, and give them the ownership they should have always had?  We know we can - let's make it happen together. The time to act is now!

We all have an opportunity to support an Indigenous-led Sanctuary, to help protect this region by shielding it from harm from new offshore oil drilling, terrestrial runoff from land, dumping of waste, seismic testing, and other negative impacts of climate change by supporting the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Ballantine, Lydia
Comment:
I am writing to express my support for the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative). Marine sanctuaries preserve and protect the delicate and unique ecosystems of California's central coast, and can also bring financial benefit and physical protection to Californians. Healthy marine ecosystems, especially kelp forests, help slow shoreline erosion and act as carbon sinks, which help slow and mitigate the problems cause by climate change. The original boundary protects more area against oil and gas development, while still allowing for offshore wind development and the passage of the necessary cables through the sanctuary. This will be both a step towards protecting the marine ecosystems and a push away from climate-destroying fossil fuels. 
I am also so excited to see collaboration with the Chumash and that indigenous knowledge will be incorporated into the management of this sanctuary. Tribes have been caring for this land for thousands of years, and have important knowledge and a vested interest in preserving and protecting coastal ecosystems, which is beneficial for everyone.

Title: Comment from Williams, Deborah
Comment:
Dear NOAA,

Dear NOAA,
Thank you for seeking, reviewing and carefully considering public input on the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
As a resident of Goleta, California; as someone who is very familiar with the area in question; and as a Lecturer who teaches "Public Lands and Waters -- Law and Policy” in the Environmental Studies Department at the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB), I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative, plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b).
At stake is the protection of not only critically important public marine waters, but also of equally important public submerged lands. These lands and waters are significant for so many reasons, including biodiversity, climate change mitigation and adaptation, endangered species protection, tourism, and their sacredness and cultural significance to the Chumash peoples. 
To achieve 30x30, we need to protect as much of our nation’s lands and waters as warranted. The Initial Boundary Alternative, plus the Gaviota Extension is warranted. This full area contains an exceptional marine environment, irreplaceable cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, historic shipwrecks, and sensitive submerged lands, all of which deserve protection.
The Secretary of Commerce certainly has the authority to allow offshore wind transmission cables when establishing this National Marine Sanctuary and can specify how offshore wind transmission cables will be accommodated in the regulations governing the Initial Boundary Alternative plus the Gaviota Extension. There is no need to exclude these areas from the Sanctuary boundaries because doing so would (1) not be consistent with 30 x 30 and (2) would not provide these excluded areas with all of the other crucial protections that Sanctuary status confers under the National Marine Sanctuaries Act. It is very important to permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters; in addition to the benefits of being part of the Marine Protected Areas (MPA) system.
This is an exceptional opportunity for this Administration to (1) use all authority available to it to protect sacred Tribal (submerged) lands and waters, (2) to help advance 30 x 30 as fully as possible, (3) to get the full advantage of National Marine Sanctuary status and MPS status, while accommodating wind transmission cables; (4) to promote biodiversity, climate change adaptation and mitigation, and ecosystem services. 
Thank you for protecting our nation’s public submerged lands and waters off of California’s Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary – and specifically with the Initial Boundary Alternative, plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b).
With appreciation,
Deborah L. Williams, J.D.
Lecturer, UCSB, Environmental Studies Department

This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection. Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters. Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Rada, Michael
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Michael Rada and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Concord, California and to me, the ocean has always been a place to become mentally, spiritually and physically renewed. It is where I hold some of my fondest memories with my family and friends. It is also a place for recreation where I go to take my dog to run on the beach. It is not only important to me but also to our wildlife that depend on humans to be good stewards of the sea. The descendants of the original stewards of California must also have a direct role in managing the marine sanctuary. To keep this area protected will continue to show California as a global leader in conservation while also being one of the greatest economies in the world. In the face of climate change it is imperative that we protect as much of the ocean we can for present and future generations. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 Sincerely,
Michael Rada

Given that the Chumash tribe, among other tribes, have been the primary keepers and sustainers of these waters and the lands that are along the coast, we must first look to them for comment and input on this draft management plan and future management plans. Title: Comment from Sissiton/Wahpeton Sioux, Lake Traverse Reservation
Comment:
My name is Colby C. Crotzer, I am an enrolled member of the Sisseton/Wahpeton Sioux tribe (enrolled # 347 000 13238). I am writing to thank you for proceeding with the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and for explicitly requesting comments from tribal members. 
I am requesting that you to make a contiguous sanctuary which connects the several existing sanctuaries by including the ocean waters between Point Buchon and Cambria as proposed in the Initial Boundary Alternative as originally proposed in 2021.
I am also a native Californian born in Santa Monica, so naturally have loved and cared for the Pacific coastline since I was a child. Born in 1946, I watched Santa Monica Bay become desolate from pollution, followed by decades of efforts to clean it up again. 
When I moved to Morro Bay in the late 1980’s I became active in municipal politics, elected to serve two 4-year terms as Councilmember in 1992 and in 1998. I was a constant advocate for marine protection during my 8 years in office.
Finally after all those years of working for a Marine Sanctuary off the Morro Bay coast, we have come to the brink of success!
As an indigenous grandfather my greatest obligation is to protect a viable world in which my progeny can thrive. The threat of human-induced climate change is real, and the situation is dire! Moving away from fossil fuels to produce energy is essential to reverse this existential challenge, so the efforts being made by California and the Federal Government to create alternative energy sources such as the off-shore wind project is essential. That effort and the protection of the ocean is not in conflict, but must be achieved through genuine, creative cooperation, as has been done in other sanctuaries. The conduit cable routes should be grandfathered in since the existence of the already-leased wind farm sites naturally assume the necessity of cables to the on-shore electric grid. Once in place, they would offer no significant detriment to marine life or commerce. 
Therefore I am writing to encourage you to include Morro Bay in the proposed new Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Quinn, Ross
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Dr. Ross Quinn. I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary as originally proposed, and with Gaviota Coast Extension.  This is necessary to protect ourselves, and the biodiversity and health of our oceans.
I now live in Victorville, California, but I grew up in the beach city of Ventura.  To me, the ocean is a deep part of my being.  I grew up body surfing its waves, walking is beaches, and fishing its waters, both from the Ventura Pier, and from charter boats going out to the Channel Islands.  Santa Cruz and Anacapa Islands were the ocean’s background every day, especially at sunset. This Chumash coast lives within me, even while I live inland, in the desert. The Pacific Ocean seems now more precious to me in its absence, than it was when I lived by it.
Importantly, I have personally seen the improvement of the ocean’s and shore’s health after the establishment of the Southern Chumash Marine Sanctuary, the establishment of the Channel Islands National Park, and the purchase of Santa Cruz by the Nature Conservancy.  The ocean became cleaner.  Fish catches increased. Discharges from land into the Pacific decreased.  People became able to visit the islands, and to get to know them. And the Chumash museum opened in Ventura, financed by their inland casino, for better or worse.  For the best, however, it has been a focal point for dissemination of the Chumash knowledge and culture, and their millenniums-long conservancy of these precious lands and waters. 
So again, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in central California. I urge that the Sanctuary be established to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures… As we have benifitted in Southern California from the Southern Chumash Marine Sanctuary.
Excluding both the Chumash people from its management, and excluding the full extent of the Sanctuary, because it is incompatible with off-shore electricity generation, is just terrible policy.  I think there are still way too many unknowns re the multiple impacts that this power generation could wreak on our Pacific Ocean’s eco-system. And for sea creatures, finding suitable areas for feeding, breeding, and migration will undoubtedly become MUCH more difficult, and these areas will become much more limited in their extent, given the severe climate changes we are experiencing.  In my opinion, we urgently need to greatly increase roof-top solar generation and battery systems on all existing buildings on land, and NOT risk our ocean.  Worse is the great risk of eco system fragmentation:  Whales and fish do not respect mankind’s artificial boundaries. Even if 90% of their territory is protected, if their migration paths cross the 10% where they are not protected, they can still be threatened, and become critically endangered, or worse, go extinct. 
For all these reasons, I feel it imperative that that we approve the full extent of the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary as originally proposed, and that the Chumash Tribe name and role in the Sanctuary’s management be fully adopted and protected.  It is vital that we immediately and permanently ban oil and gas drilling here, and any ocean floor mining.  And we must greatly increase educational outreach, so that the population at large can better understand the need to do all this, and how we will all benefit from taking these critically needed actions.

Title: Comment from Gelsey, Katherine
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Kat Gelsey and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, INCLUDING Morro Bay.

Morro Bay has historically been decimated by poor resource management practices, which led to the decimation of key species such as abalone and sea otters. 

I live in Lake County, California, around 100 miles from the Mendocino Coastline.

Morro Bay has historically been destroyed by extractive, unsustainable forms of natural resource management. Offshore wind projects proposed there are not sustainable if they impede protection for Morro Bay's endangered and unique wildlife. In addition to being home for some of the last remaining sea otters in the country, Morro Bay is also a refuge for hundreds of marine species at risk of extinction from decades of mismanagement. Don't let the same mistake be made again in Morro Bay. Include it in the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary.

Sincerely,
Kat

Title: Comment from Felice, Richard
Comment:
To the Office of National Marine Sanctuaries, of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the Secretary of Commerce regarding the Proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary:

As a lifelong resident of California and a current graduate student studying Environmental Policy and Management with a focus in Natural Resources Management, I was excited to learn of the Proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) and its trajectory to become the first National Marine Sanctuary that resulted from direct involvement with Indigenous peoples. I applaud the Office of National Marine Sanctuaries (ONMS) and National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) for moving forward with this designation and providing opportunities for the Central Coast’s First Peoples, specifically the famously seafaring Chumash, to collaborate on management of this culturally significant area. 
I was dismayed, however, at the amendment to the Initial Boundary Proposal (IBP) and exclusion of the portion between Morro Bay and Cambria. While I recognize the need for developing offshore wind power, it is my understanding that the area excluded in the Agency-Preferred Alternative (APA) could also potentially be targeted for seabed mining and oil and gas developments.
It is also my understanding that there are mechanisms in place to both designate this area a Sanctuary and allow for some offshore wind development, while prohibiting more harmful activities associated with seabed mining ad fossil fuel developments specifically, both of which pose a real threat to our already-strained ocean ecosystems. As NOAA notes on their National Marine Sanctuaries website page concerning wind power development in the CHNMS, “given that certain concentrations of this infrastructure may not be compatible with a national marine sanctuary depending on the number of cables and disturbance that could occur”. I have italicized the key parts of that statement, which further obfuscate the purpose of eliminating this region from the APA, as limited wind development or development stratified through a larger area of the Sanctuary could still meet Sanctuary standards as defined by NOAA and the ONMS and avoid large impacts to the environment. The reduction of the nearly 2,000 square miles of ocean protection and 18 miles of coastline also diminishes the congruence with President Biden’s America the Beautiful Initiative’s goal of conserving and restoring 30% of our land and waters and would necessitate new designations to achieve the same amount of conservation as the IBP, which would be a costly and time-intensive process. 
As a student of Natural Resources Management, I find the APA to greatly diminish the overall potential positive impact of the CHNMS for the reasons noted above and I stand with the Surfrider Foundation and the Chumash peoples in calling for the IBP to serve as the blueprint for the Sanctuary’s boundaries, and considering keeping the addition of coastline next to Gaviota found in the APA. 
Sincerely, 
Richard Felice of Los Angeles
Steward of the Environment and Concerned Citizen

Title: Comment from Christophe, Amanda
Comment:
Hello, 

My name is Amanda Christophe. I am a San Luis Obispo resident and an environmental professional. I am writing to express overwhelming support for the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary. As the first tribally-nominated sanctuary, I believe that it is important that local Tribes play a central and collaborative role in the decision-making, implementation, and management / governing bodies of this Sanctuary. For this reason, I am advocating that the Proposed Sanctuary incorporate the boundaries that were proposed by the Chumash Tribe, including the Gaviota Coast Extension. This stretch of ocean is critical to ocean wildlife, and if protected would provide connecting pathways to Monterey Bay. If not protected, it would be subject to offshore wind, oil, and gas, which would have a negative impact on wildlife. While I understand that offshore wind is an important endeavor, the larger boundary still allows for this. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is a wonderful opportunity to further protect our oceans, build relationships with Tribes, and educate communities on the importance of oceanic ecosystems! Thank you!

Title: Comment from Beckman-Lau, Mari
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Mari Beckman-Lau and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

It is so important to preserve our oceans and to continue and expand research and conservation efforts to protect its ecosystems.  According to the World Wildlife Fund, "Although they comprise less than 5% of the world population, Indigenous peoples protect 80% of the Earth's biodiversity in the forests, deserts, grasslands, and marine environments in which they have lived for centuries."  Therefore in my opinion, the more land stewardship we can put back in the hands of Indigenous tribes and nations, the better for the planet and everyone who lives on it.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and hope that it includes the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension; the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”; an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management, outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities; and a prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,
Mari Beckman-Lau

Title: Comment from Campbell, John
Comment:
Hello Friends at NOAA -
Thank you for all the important work you are doing.  
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary!
    Please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries.
    This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.
    Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.
    Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.
This is very important for our future and for our children.
John C.  A lover of our coast

Title: Comment from Hoegh, Payton
Comment: As a faith leader with the Episcopal Church and the Center for Spirituality in Nature, I'm excited to see a proposed draft management plan for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. We need clear and meaningful management and implementation of the sanctuary. Given that the Chumash tribe, among other tribes, have been the primary keepers and sustainers of these waters and the lands that are along the coast, we must first look to them for comment and input on this draft management plan and future management plans. It is so important that we preserve God's unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. I ask that you respect the Northern Chumash Tribal Council requests regarding sanctuary boundary, the sanctuary name, tribal collaborative management, outreach and education, Rodriguez Seamount, offshore wind and water quality. Thank you for your work on this immediate need to preserve God's creation.

Title: Comment from Dunson, Debra
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
I am a scientist and frequent visitor to the central coast of California.  I am writing to ask you to protect this area by designating this area as a marine sanctuary.  Specifically, I ask that you swiftly finalize the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean.  This area is one of the most profoundly beautiful and biologically diverse regions in the world. 
The Marine Sanctuary would contribute to studies of the effects of climate change on marine environments, while providing as much protection as possible to the area's biodiverse species.  Furthermore, the incorporation of Tribal ecological knowledge of the Indigenous Chumash people will help to build resilience along the Pacific coast.
As an adult, I have been thrilled to revisit the Pacific Coast of my childhood, especially the beaches off San Luis Obispo and northern Santa Barbara Counties.  My deep love of this area moves me to advocate for strong protections.  These waters create an incredibly productive feeding ground that attracts a menagerie of marine wildlife. The vulnerable species living and migrating within this critical habitat deserve our protection from development and exploitation. I remind you that areas within the Central Coast waters, which teemed with native marine wildlife decades ago, have shown an alarming decline in species and populations.
Furthermore, the Central Coast of the Pacific Coast benefits families, visitors, and communities.  I was blessed as a youngster, because my family spent leisure time along the central coast of California.  When I interacted with this environment, it benefited me in the following ways:
I learned about marine wildlife, which prompted me to explore science.
I developed physical strength as a paddler in the Pacific Ocean currents.
I appreciated the beauty of the Pacific Ocean, which prompted me to write poetry and essays about it, which grew my literary creativity.
It is urgent to protect this treasured coastline and waters by finalizing the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and fulfilling the following: 
Provide effective protections by creating the largest boundary possible: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.
Honor the Leaders and Members of the Northern Chumash Tribal Council: Adopt the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”.
Fully adopt Tribal collaborative management: Utilize a fair system that will include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Promote effective outreach, education, and research programs: Focus on programs that will incorporate Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and provide access for local underserved communities.
Ensure full protection of the Rodriguez Seamount: Its biodiversity is essential to the regional ecosystem.
Effectively prohibit all oil & gas development within sanctuary boundaries.
Please quickly designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary for the benefit of marine wildlife, people, and the climate.

Title: Comment from Hayes, Rick
Comment:
The draft plan does not ban or regulate Motorized Personal Water Craft (MPWC) at this time. 
Page 52 of Draft Environmental Impact Statement:
"NOAA lacks sufficient information on existing MPWC use and/or localized threats to marine resources to
identify whether MPWC regulation is warranted or to structure any such proposed regulation."

Once this Marine Sanctuary has been approved, they will then add an amendment regulating/banning Motorized Personal Water Craft.
The coastline of Gaviota, Bixby, Vandenberg, Point Sal and Diablo Canyon are only accessible by boat and jet ski's. If they pass a law that no launching of boats or jet ski's are allowed then they are cutting off any possibility of public access for surfing, hiking, diving, fishing, etc.
They could also implement a rule of no traveling or anchoring within a certain distance (1 mile) of land. With offshore winds this would be extremely dangerous to all recreational boaters. 
This coastline is very inaccessible in its current state. We do not need to add more laws making this coastline even harder to access.
Vandenberg has already cut off 42 miles of coastline to the public, lets not make it 152 miles.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Crotzer, Sharon (Shoosh)
Comment:
I am writing in favor of including Morro Bay, as in the original proposal, in the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
When my husband (Colby Crotzer) and I moved to Morro Bay in 1998, we became active in our community politics. We decided that one of the most important ways we could help to provide our grandchildren with the same quality of life we have enjoyed here would be to work to get our coastline included as part of a National Marine Sanctuary on the West Coast.  In the late 1990s and early 2000s, our goal at that time was to try to get a new sanctuary or to add our central coastline to the already existing Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary. We spent years on this project.  I have letters I wrote to NOAA in 2006 along with comments I made at various public meetings, etc. all in favor of being included in this expansion.  Most of our community had not even realized that the oceans along our coast were still susceptible to having oil wells off of our coast or by having the Central Valley’s agricultural waste salts and pollutants such as selenium dumped here.  Besides affecting the quality of ocean waters, since Morro Bay is a tourist town, this would be detrimental to attract the visitors who the city needs to sustain our tourist economy. Who would want to come here only] to see oil wells and a coastline depleted of sea life?
For years, there has been a discussion of what to do with contaminated wastewater produced by San Joaquin Valley agriculture.  Morro Bay has long been considered one of the choice locations for this dumping.  Selenium is highly toxic to fish and wildlife and has been implicated in both fishery declines and the deaths of thousands of shorebirds and waterfowl (San Francisco Chronicle, Nov 1, 2005 article by Glen Martin).  Sierra Club Santa Lucia Chapter Director Andrew Christie summed up our perspective perfectly in an article in New Times SLO on September 21, 2023.  He quotes State Sen. John Laird (D-Santa Cruz):  "Whatever the pathway, I implore NOAA to find a creative solution to ensure the protection of an unfragmented stretch of the Pacific Ocean between the Monterey Bay and Channel Island sanctuaries, while also enabling the successful implementation of offshore wind energy." 
Director Christie continues: 
            "There's something missing in NOAA's agency-preferred alternative version of the map that was submitted with the sanctuary nomination. The initial boundary alternative would fill the gap between Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary and would protect 7,573 square miles of ocean. But the agency's preferred boundary includes a cut-out of San Luis Obispo County waters of approximately 750 square miles between Cambria and Montaña de Oro and reduces the total boundary by nearly 2,000 square miles.
            The problem: The shipping and undersea cables serving the future offshore wind farm will pass through that area, and NOAA does not want to regulate that industrial development in a national marine sanctuary. And the Salinan tribe also includes that coastal area as part of its historic lands and have let it be known they would not appreciate a marine sanctuary there dedicated to Native American cultural heritage that omits their name.
            The solution: NOAA's concern is basically the timing—i.e., if the area is designated as a marine sanctuary and then the cable and shipping infrastructure are allowed, that sets a precedent. But if the cables are laid and then the marine sanctuary is declared, no problem. National marine sanctuaries include any number of preexisting features that would not have been allowed if they were proposed to be constructed after the marine sanctuary was created. (Case in point: The proposed Gaviota Coast extension for the Chumash sanctuary includes the existing oil pipelines from the offshore rigs to the onshore processing plant.) Wind energy companies must submit maps of their cable routes for federal certification. Once the routes are certified, the cables become a preexisting fait accompli, and the marine sanctuary could then include the Point Buchon to Cambria region, which could also be designated as a special treatment area of the sanctuary, with a name acceptable to the Salinans."
This sums up my perspective completely and we hope that you will vote to INCLUDE Morro Bay, as we have been working to do for decades.

Title: Comment from Pedersen, Laura
Comment:
Hello, 

As a former surfer, active Surfrider SLO member, and recently certified and exploring SCUBA diver, I strongly urge NOAA to address the following concerns in regard to the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary: 

1. Adopt strong regulation and management plans to ensure sufficient protections for the region’s sensitive habitats, cultural resources, and sustainable Human Resources. I have seen what other marine sanctuaries locally (e.g. Monterey and Channel Islands) have done to help repopulate and conserve precious ecosystems that are not only essential to oceanic survival but also to human survival. Without a thriving ocean, we as humans cannot survive which has been proven time and time again. The power and protection that comes with the establishment of marine sanctuaries have done just that; provided power and protection to a critical resource to human and animal survival alike. 

2. Include the full geographic extent reflected in the Initial Boundary Alternative, in addition to the Gaviota Coast Extension (5B). When it was discovered that the Initial Boundary Alternative did not include my home county from Point Buchón up to Cambria where the edge of the Monterey Marine Sanctuary begins, I was intially worried. Worried for the thriving kelp beds, the otters and urchins who live there. Worried for the pristine untouched tide pools and open natural areas surrounding it to be negatively impacted and/or destroyed by man made operations. Worried for my favorite local surf spot being compromised due to pipes, and my favorite local dog beach to be shut down to my two pups who love to run freely on the coastline like so many of us. Worried for our infamous elephant seals who pup near Hearst Castle annually. I worry about not just the marine life, but also the continuation and production of excess carbon that is destroying our planet and removing the only protection we have against excess carbon; the ocean and natural elements found within it that help absorb carbon safely and effectively. 

3. In the enabling regulations, include special permits for the transmission cables needed for anticipated offshore wind project development and operations in the Morro Bay Wind Energy Area. There is no shortage of concern regarding renewable energy, but the movement of the energy from the offshore wind needs to actually be moved to land for human use so we can decrease the use of gas and oil that ultimately will damage and create more chemical destruction. This is one small way to address the energy crisis and without this approval, more and more oil will be extracted and exploited that could have been avoided. 

This marine sanctuary proposal (and extension 5B) has so many projected benefits from ecological safety, conservation, climate change impacts, economic gains from increased tourism economies, and support to the already limited resources available to our local indigenous peoples. Please consider our concerns in the development in this plan for the benefit of so many human and non-human animal alike. 

Thank you for your time, 
Laura Pedersen, PsyD
(She/her)

Title: Comment from Balaban, Susan
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Susan Balaban and I am writing on this Indigenous Heritage Day to express my absolute and unwavering support for the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Wilmette, IL, but even though I'm landlocked, well, Lake Michigan is hardly landlocked, but you know what I mean, the ocean, any ocean, is a source of wonder, natural miracles, beauty and life for its inhabitants as well as all of earth's. 

I've spent summers in Cape Cod going on dozens of whale watches and marveling at their grace and enormity. My children grew up on those boats learning to appreciate and treasure our oceans and take care of them. We've been lucky enough to be on the west coast also and to marvel at its beauty and diversity of wildlife and habitats. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary include every proposed educational and conservational designation and program support. Including the biggest possible boundary, the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension, an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management, outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities, the protection of the Rodriguez Seamount, which is essential to protect biodiversity and finally, but certainly not least importantly, without a doubt there must be an absolute and total prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Susan Balaban

Title: Comment from Venegas, Juan

To whom it may concern:

I am in support of the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. This designation is of utmost importance due to the ecological value of the area in question. As you well know, this area is teaming with a wide diversity of marine animals and plants that are irreplaceable. Title: Comment from Grace, Amy
Comment: There is no question the region that is being proposed to be included in a new National Marine Sanctuary is pristine and unique. But I would argue that the creation of a new sanctuary to celebrate this area is not, at this time, fiscally responsible. The US government's annual budget exceeds tax revenues by trillions of dollars. Where is the funding of this sanctuary going to come from? Will it be paid for by private foundations? I doubt it, which means adding to our national debt. The natural resources in this area are not under any threat, and the sanctuary is not proposing any restrictions to commercial or recreational fishing activities, so why do we need to spend the funds to create the sanctuary? In fact, the presence of SpaceX is a major conflict. Rockets are not currently allowed to fly over the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary, so how can we create a new sanctuary on the doorstep of such a major rocket launch facility? Since the proposed sanctuary will not be bringing any new resource management to the region, it will simply be an impediment to scientists that are already working there, on land and in the ocean. If there were natural resources under serious threat, this would be a different conversation.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

Hello, my name is AJ, and I'm a voting California constituent from San Leandro, Alameda County. I'm writing to support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I ask that this sanctuary includes, at minimum, the following: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

AJ Cho

This message was sent as part of a public marine conservation campaign by the Chumash Heritage Sanctuary. I am not affiliated or employed with this organization, simply participating as an individual advocate.

Title: Comment from M, Rachael
Comment:
I have lived on the Central Coast and loved this stretch of coastline for many years, and have spent years studying the unique and irreplaceable marine ecology of this region. In response to the draft designation documents, I support the following actions per category:

Sanctuary Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension Sanctuary

Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”

Tribal Collaborative Management: An inclusive approach to all Tribes in Collaborative Management & a NOAA Tribal Liaison.

Outreach and Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities

Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount

Offshore Wind: Thoughtful planning of adjacent Offshore Wind farms to protect ocean life

Water Quality: A prohibition on new oil & gas development within sanctuary boundaries

It is especially important for the CHNMS to cover the largest area possible, specifically connecting the Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries to create a safe corridor for species passage throughout the entire stretch of coastline from Rocky Point to the Channel Islands. This larger designation is imperative to fully protect many of the region's species, including eelgrass beds, Southern sea otters, and an abundance of intertidal species. It has been well-documented that MPAs are more successful when they are connected to one another through MPA networks, allowing migratory species more protection. I think that the CHNMS is no exception, and we have a very special opportunity to connect three very important marine sanctuaries and thus supercharge the benefits of each of them.

It is also very important that there is tribal collaborative management, as this sanctuary is an opportunity to advance environmental justice efforts, have overdue indigenous representation in the management of our natural environments, and learn and be guided by those who have successfully managed and regenerated these ecosystems for millennia. Traditional Ecological Knowledge should be elevated through outreach and education programs, teaching the importance of ocean stewardship, Chumash tribal history, and the ways in which we can move forward as a community to heal these sacred waters. 

This sanctuary is an incredible opportunity to champion, learn from, and honor the Northern Chumash who have stewarded these lands and waters since time immemorial. It is a crucial step in truly respecting and honoring the sacred sites of the Chumash and showing appreciation for their millennia of stewardship. While there is direct ecological benefit for tribal co-management of this sanctuary, I think it is important to also highlight the stand-alone importance of protecting this area for the sake of the Chumash peoples, who have strong cultural ties to this area, ancestors who have lived and died here, and a deep reverence for their original homeland. We owe it to the Chumash to protect this stretch of sea while we still can. I believe this sanctuary can serve as a guiding light forward for other indigenous communities around the world to reclaim their rightful positions as stewards of their lands and waters, and this is a massive step towards a world in which we live more harmoniously with both nature and each other.

Title: Comment from Tewell, Jason
Comment:
As an avid coastal recreation user on The Central Coast for over 40 years, I stronlgly urge NOAA to do the following in regard to the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS)

Adopt strong regulations and a robust management plan, (WHICH MUST include a plan for maintenance and cleanup ) to provide sufficient protections for the region’s sensitive habitats, cultural resources and sustainable human uses. Too often have we seen abandoned Wind projects left to become rust and rubble in sensitive areas.  I still advocate that a WIND project should only be considered on land and not ocean in attempt to preserve the ocean.
Include the full geographic extent reflected in the Initial Boundary Alternative, as well as the Gaviota Coast Extension (5B).
In the enabling regulations, allow for personal sea crafts usage for Surfing , Snorkel/dive in the Sanctuary for recreation and personal usage, and include special permits for the Wind project to be relocated from Ocean site to a land site of their choice.

Title: Comment from Velte, Wayne
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel, 

My name is Wayne Velte and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. 

I live in Morro Bay and to me, the ocean is a place of healing and rejuvenation.


• When I go to the coast, I surf with my son, kayak with my wife and kids, wade in the surf, explore the beach, watch the wildlife, etc. 

• The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health. 

• I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean. 

• The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:  

• Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension 

• Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” 

• Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management. 

• Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities 

• Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity 

• Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures. 

  

Sincerely, 

Wayne Velte

Title: Comment from Wu, Katherine
Comment:
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary!
Please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries.
This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.
Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.
Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Gordon, Chris
Comment:
Hello- I am writing in favor of establishing the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. This larger area is necessary to protect the migratory routes of whales, dolphins, sea lions, sharks and numerous bird species, not to mention all the tiny organisms below the surface. Protection of the rich biodiversity of this area is crucial for the survival of these species that are already dealing with the effects of: a warming and acidifying ocean due to climate change, a noisy ocean caused by shipping traffic, and the decline in populations due to overfishing. It would close the gap between the Monterey Bay and Santa Barbara sanctuaries. 
The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” is appropriate and it would indicate the desire for an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management. Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge and access for local underserved communities would also be a great benefit.
This designation would not rule out the possibility of allowing some regulated shipping through the sanctuary;  other sanctuaries
live in harmony with shipping traffic, and the added oversight and planning provided by a sanctuary can provide a
balance between industrialization, fishing, recreation and sacred use. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension, to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
Thank you for your consideration.

I live in Irvine, CA and to me, the ocean is perhaps the most important source of climate regulation and biodiversity that exists on the planet. I visit the beaches here in Southern California on a regular basis and the cleanliness of these beaches along with a priority to disturb the balance that exists in nature as little as possible are very important to me. They are values that are ingrained in most of us who regularly visit the beaches and swim or surf or sail in the ocean for recreation.

When I go to the coast, I often ride my bike. I sometimes take my dog and we play in the water and on the sand and are so very grateful for living in this beautiful region where we have regular access to the Pacific coast. Title: Comment from jackson, jasmine
Comment:
Dear NOAA, 

The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is vital to protecting California’s Central  coastline, however the proposed boundaries for the site drafted by NOAA deny the Chumash and surrounding communities the ability to provide meaningful input where the development of off-shore wind is concerned. Renewable energy sources are essential to providing power to the coastline and relieve Californians’ dependence on harmful fossil fuels, but such development must remain under the custodial eye of the Chumash peoples who are the original caretakers of this land.

According to Paul Michel the NOAA has completed no environmental analysis on the impacts that offshore wind will have on the region. Under the protection of the CHNMS, offshore wind farming will still be possible, and can be effectively planned and implemented in ways which protect the coastal ecology, the safety and preservation of human, animal, and plant life on and offshore. 

Through this reasoning I hope that NOAA will be compelled to honor the boundaries of the site created and proposed by the Chumash Northern Council.

Sincerely, 
Jasmine Jackson
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Harrison, Abigail
Comment:
To whom it may concern, 
I am writing in support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 
Growing up on the Central Coast, the Chumash were the only Native Americans I was ever provided context for. I recall molding model Chumash villages from clay in 3rd grade, and visiting a model of their village around that same time. 
Now I work for a Urban Indian Health Organization in the Central Valley. We serve many populations and tribes, including Chumash who have relocated to the area. 
As any Central Coast born person would attest to, the beauty and diversity of the coastline is unlike any others in the world. Furthermore, the Chumash were the original stewards of this land, which has been completely stolen from them, sold, and tourist-ified. To provide sanctuary to this section of California would give honor to the beliefs of the descendents of the original people. Furthermore, biologically the opportunity to reduce human impact on the diverse population of species along the coast would be beyond crucial for serving generations to come.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Cameron, Jean
Comment: As I have been reading information put out there during October's Indigenous People Month and learning more about the very positive role Indigenous People have played in environmental preservation, I feel compelled to support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  And, having lived in a coastal state myself (I have lived in Florida for 72 years) I feel a great connection to their goal of creating this important marine sanctuary. In the 72 years of loving and feeling protective of our Florida beaches, our surrounding waters and the precious sea life, I have been angered and heart-broken at the irresponsible actions of man and the resulting deterioration and disrespect of our shores. Our beloved manatees are starving and dying because of what man has done to the water they depend on for food and a safe habitat. In the Gulf our endangered Rice Whales (the last in the entire world) are struggling to survive because our political leaders insist on drilling for fossil fuel in their little bit of water and have failed to control speeding vessels in the area. In the news this morning I read where 100's porpoises were found dead because of the warming waters. In the 72 years I have lived in this state I have witnessed terrible pollution of the waters, over-fishing, unregulated use of large sea nets and gillnets indiscriminately drowning sea turtles, porpoises and other precious sea life, over-development and erosion of our beaches and the disappearance of so many once plentiful species. If any of these destructive environmental influences can be averted in the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary on our West Coast it is worth all the support we can possibly offer!

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean. The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Kim Flores

Title: Comment from Steenwyk , Elizabeth

Dear Paul Michel,

Title: Comment from Agranovich, Amelia
Comment:
Dear NOAA, 

My name is Amelia Agranovich, I am a Masters student from Maryland and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I first heard about this Marine Sanctuary Proposal through Mission Blue - an organization founded by the world renowned marine biologist, Sylvia Earle. I believe that it is vital we protect our oceans, and maintain indigenous rights. The ocean is perhaps the greatest reason that we are not feeling even more extreme effects of climate change, and the biodiversity found within is astounding. It is crucial to protect as much of the ocean as we can, as this is how we protect ourselves for generations to come, and the wildlife within deserves to have spaces free from exploitation. Therefore, I am a big supporter of the proposed Marine Sanctuary. 





I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary has the largest possible boundary -  The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension. I ask that it is named the “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”. I ask that it is managed equitably with indigenous people through Tribal Collective Management. I ask that outreach, education and research programs are created that elevate Traditional Ecological Knowledge alongside Western-based Science. I ask that local underserved communities can have access to the Sanctuary. I request also that the Rodriguez Seamount is strictly protected. My final request is that no future exploration for oil and gas is allowed within the sanctuary boundaries, and that if there is any current exploration/extraction - it is prohibited with the sanctuary's creation. 

Sincerely,
Amelia Agranovich

Title: Comment from Ulloth, John

MAXIMIZE THE SIZE
1. ADD THE GAVIOTA COAST EXTENSION to the largest Initial Boundary proposal: (Sub...5b)

Title: Comment from Cotten, Greg SeaLion
Comment:
The Chumash, for many thousands of years, have been the primary stewards of this most extraordinary stretch of Ocean. While it may or may not look like it, that hasn’t changed. 

They deserve the acknowledgment and full rights to their territory both on land and off. The US government should fund and follow their leadership in these waters. It is their territory from which they are informed by hundreds of generations of knowledge and relationship. This is an exciting time to recognize this Indigenous leadership, wisdom, compassion, and rights. As a marine biologist, underwater photographer and educator, this is the missing presence in our Ocean culture. 

We are so grateful for the past work of the Chumash ancestors, the current work of the Chumash, and we are honored with their future leadership. Please return the greatest rights, privileges and territory possible in this most important realm.

I can already hear the gratitude from the future generations. Thank you.

Title: Comment from Wrenn, Dr. Rosemary
Comment:
Please approve Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Sub-Alternative 5b.

I have lived in what is now called Shell Beach since 1993 and am grateful every day to the original and current caretakers of this land and ocean, the Northern Chumash, for their stewardship which has preserved the beauty and well being of the place I call home. I am an ally and supporter in favor of designating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary based on the Initial Boundary Alternative including Morro Bay as proposed in the sanctuary nomination combined with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub Alternative 5b). 

Since I met Violet Sage Walker in 2015, I have been a supporter of the proposed sanctuary. She has patiently cultivated my learning about the relationships we have with the land and water and in particular the profound spiritual, cultural, and practical ties that bind the Chumash and the Central Coast. I am very grateful to see the significant progress the designation has made to date. However, the boundary excluding Morro Bay being put forth by NOAA at this time would gravely diminish its impact. By NOAA’s own report, the, “initial boundary alternative would have the greatest number and magnitude of significant beneficial impacts” of all the possible options. None of the other boundary options - including the one preferred by NOAA - would have the same level of significant beneficial impacts. 

These significant impacts are 

Cultural - Morro Bay to the north and Point Sal to the south are critical elements of Chumash and other Indigenous peoples’ cultural beliefs, rituals, and practices. Removing Morro Bay from this designation severely undermines the goal of the original nomination by leaving Morro Bay exposed to potential further damage. It was just in the last century that developers deemed it appropriate to blast significant portions of Morro Rock, desecrating a sacred space to be used as material for road beds, buildings, and breakwaters. Keeping it within the sanctuary boundary protects it from further destruction.


The impacts are logistical - creating a contiguous line of marine sanctuaries from Point Arena to the Gaviota Coast. CHNMS Connects the Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries - mitigating the loss of effectiveness seen at the borders of sanctuaries.

The impacts are ecological - Connecting the sanctuaries along the coast mitigates what a study in the journal, Nature Ecology & Evolution.calls the “edge effect” the result of Human impacts on the ocean ecosystem close to the edges of marine protected areas that causes damage within the protected area. 

Finally, including Morro Bay has significant economic impacts
Since the sanctuary supports sustainable use of the oceans to encourage further economic development in commercial and recreational pursuits for the community. In regards to the Wind Energy development underway, Including Morro Bay will ensure a contiguous buffer of ocean protection, while directing Offshore Wind development to more suitable areas further offshore where wind energy is optimal and ecological and cultural impacts can be reduced. The sanctuary will also allow for consistent monitoring and research needed to understand the long term impacts of Offshore Wind. 

Any Offshore Wind transmission cables proposed for this area as part of future offshore wind development should require permits from the National Marine Sanctuary Program to ensure that they are planned and sited to reduce and mitigate impacts to the ocean.
Including Morro Bay in the designation invites meaningful collaboration with tribal leadership and the broader community; conservation and marine protection from the in-progress renewable energy efforts; and supports the original intent and purpose for this proposal.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Wrenn, Dr. Rosemary
Comment:
Please approve Original Boundary Alternative and include Sub-Alternative 5b to mitigate damage to ocean and shore from Offshore Wind.

Please approve the boundaries as originally proposed for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in order to protect ecologically and culturally critical areas of the Central Coast in advance of planned future development of Offshore Wind farms in the region. While Offshore Wind may prove an important source of renewable energy, it will also result in a range of environmental impacts to ocean habitat, wildlife, and water quality. Through careful planning, the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary can help ensure that adjacent Offshore Wind farms avoid critical ecological and cultural resources.
The Initial Boundary Alternative, which is the largest proposed boundary, will ensure an unfragmented buffer of ocean protection, while directing Offshore Wind development to more suitable areas further offshore where wind energy is optimal and ecological and cultural impacts can be reduced. The sanctuary will also allow for robust monitoring and research needed to understand the long term impacts of Offshore Wind. 
Any Offshore Wind transmission cables proposed for this area as part of future offshore wind development should require permits from the National Marine Sanctuary Program to ensure that they are planned and sited to reduce and mitigate impacts to the ocean.
I ask for meaningful collaborative Indigenous management with conservation and marine protection from the in-progress renewable energy efforts.

Title: Comment from Anderson , Brooks

Dear National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, 
My name is Brooks Anderson of Santa Rosa, CA, and I completely support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. The ocean, to me, is our last frontier, as Jacques Cousteau would call it. I am a full-time professional artist, and I visit the Central California coast whenever I can. I believe in the Chumash Nation trying to protect the ancient and historic waters that once was theirs. They have, for thousands of years, been at-one with the sea, fishing in those waters on their tomols (canoes); and now, they are doing all they can to protect it and all sea life from destruction. Please pass legislation to protect the largest possible area of Central California ocean, an important part of biodiversity and habitats, for ocean research and education for present and future generations to come. It would be most fitting to call it the “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.” Let's follow their lead -- a lead which has lasted for thousands of years. They knew how to protect the ocean; let's finally give back and help them please.
Thank you very much, 
Brooks Anderson

I live in Santa Barbara and to me, the ocean is life.
