The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.
I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Sandra S. Mezzio
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Hispanic Access Foundation Por la creacion
Organization Name: Hispanic Access Foundation Por la creacion
Comment:
Buenas tardes, my name is Juan Rosas, I’m speaking on behalf of the Hispanic Access Foundation Por la Creación Network. Today, I want to express our strong and unwavering support for the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

This proposed sanctuary, encompassing the Initial Boundary Alternative and the Gaviota Coast Extension, is a vital step towards protecting approximately 7,600 square miles of ocean along the Central Coast of California. It's not just about conserving natural resources; it's about preserving biodiversity, critical habitats, and the rich cultural history of our Indigenous communities.

As a faith leader and a member of our community, the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary holds a special place in my heart. It's where we come together with our families and our church communities on the beach, where we participate in and observe baptismal ceremonies. The ocean has always played a crucial role in our lives, providing recreation, spiritual fulfillment, community bonding, and economic well-being.

But it's not just about us. It's about ensuring that future generations can benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy marine environment. It's about granting marginalized Latino communities and other local communities equitable access to a clean and safe ocean and coastline for recreation, livelihoods, and culture.

We envision a future where wetland, coastal, reef, and underwater ecosystems are protected and restored, enhancing coastal resilience against rising sea levels, flooding, and other effects of climate change. We dream of an ocean free from pollution and plastics and free from the threats of offshore drilling and mining that harm not only local communities but also the global climate.

Latinos are among the fastest-growing demographic groups living by the ocean and coast. We are the new recreational fishermen, boaters, and outdoor enthusiasts. However, our communities are also among the most vulnerable to an ocean overburdened with declining natural resources. Protecting the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is a significant step towards addressing these challenges, promoting equity, and enhancing the well-being of the Central Coast region of California.

Furthermore, the ocean's beauty and mysteries have always captivated me. It's not just a source of recreation; it's a wellspring of knowledge and inspiration. It's an invaluable resource for both present and future generations. Establishing this sanctuary will be pivotal in advancing California and Federal 30x30 priorities and the Biden Administration’s Justice 40 Initiative.







I wholeheartedly endorse the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, and I urge you to consider the following key points:

1. Sanctuary Boundaries: We support the largest possible contiguous sanctuary boundaries, specifically the Initial Boundary Alternative combined with the Gaviota Coast Extension 

2. Offshore Wind: While we recognize the importance of Offshore Wind as a source of renewable energy, we also acknowledge its potential environmental impacts. The sanctuary's Initial Boundary Alternative will help guide Offshore Wind development to suitable areas, minimizing ecological and cultural disruptions. 

3. Vandenberg Offshore Wind Projects The projects are sited too close to the shore, in a uniquely biodiverse location, with highly significant fisheries and unacceptable impacts to critical cultural sites.

4. Sanctuary Name: We endorse naming the sanctuary the "Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary" to honor the heritage of the Chumash people and recognize their enduring connection to this coastal region.

5. Tribal Collaborative Management: We support equitable, collaborative management, inclusive of all Tribal groups culturally affiliated with the proposed sanctuary area. 

6. Water Quality: We advocate for sanctuary water quality programs and regulations that prevent pollution, including runoff of sediments, oils, nutrients, pesticides, and pathogens. Collaborative local programs, such as the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary's Agricultural Water Quality Stewardship Program, should serve as models.

7. Outreach and Education: The sanctuary's outreach and education efforts should be multilingual, multicultural, and focused on underserved communities. Partnering with Tribal groups, local schools, community organizations, and educators is vital to disseminating knowledge about marine science, conservation, Chumash history, and culture.

8. Rodriguez Seamount: We support regulations to protect the Rodriguez Seamount, given its importance as a critical habitat for diverse marine life. Permanent protection is necessary to preserve this fragile ecosystem.

In conclusion, we urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, safeguarding our ocean's treasures for the well-being and enjoyment of current and future generations

Title: Comment from Van Fleet, Alicia
Comment:
Dear NOAA Team,

I am writing to express my strong support for the Proposed Chumash Marine Sanctuary and to request the incorporation of Morro Bay to Ccambria into this sanctuary, connecting it to the Monterey Marine Sanctuary. It is my belief that our beloved coastal towns have much to gain from the protection and preservation of our ocean and coast, and there is too much at stake to exclude these areas from the sanctuary.
The northern San Luis Obispo County coastline is a unique and ecologically significant stretch of coastline. It boasts an array of biodiversity, from marine mammals to various fish species and seabirds, making it a critical part of our region's ecosystem. By extending the Chumash Marine Sanctuary to encompass this area, we have a remarkable opportunity to conserve and protect these invaluable marine resources for generations to come.

Here are a few reasons why I believe it is crucial to include Morro Bay to Cayucos within the proposed Chumash Marine Sanctuary:

1. Ecosystem Preservation: This region features diverse habitats such as kelp forests, rocky shores, and sandy beaches, which support an array of marine life. Protecting these habitats is essential for the overall health of our ocean.

2. Economic Benefits: The coastal towns in the region, such as Morro Bay and Cayucos, heavily depend on tourism and recreational activities. A well-preserved marine sanctuary can boost local economies, create jobs, and sustain the livelihoods of those who depend on coastal resources.

3. Education and Research: The inclusion of Morro Bay to Cambria in the sanctuary would provide opportunities for research, education, and public awareness programs. It would help people understand the importance of marine conservation and foster a sense of responsibility toward our natural environment.

4. Climate Resilience: Marine sanctuaries serve as natural laboratories for studying the effects of climate change and ocean acidification. By expanding the Chumash Marine Sanctuary, we can better monitor and mitigate the impacts of these global challenges.

Incorporating Morro Bay to Cayucos into the Chumash Marine Sanctuary would not only benefit our local communities but also contribute to NOAA's mission to protect, conserve, and manage the nation's coastal and marine resources. I urge you to consider the broader implications and the necessity of safeguarding this pristine coastal area for current and future generations.

I appreciate your dedication to marine conservation and look forward to seeing the Proposed Chumash Marine Sanctuary expanded to connect the sanctuaries. Our coastal towns and the environment we cherish depend on it.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
Alicia Van Fleet

Title: Comment from Dills, David
Comment: I am strongly against this proposal.  The Chumash tribe does not have the education to manage a sanctuary with NOAA. In fact, this entire idea seems to be based on using the tribe as a means to obtain the sanctuary designation.  A sanctuary designation will end up imposing severe regulations on any and everything anyone now does along the coast. Is the next story going to be that the Chumash need a casino on the coast to raise money for the sanctuary? This entire idea is unnecessary. Nothing is stopping the NOAA from studying the coast, and nothing prevents the Chumash from educating people about their history.

Dear NOAA,
Please support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary(CHNMS). Designate the largest sanctuary possible, as originally proposed, in addition to the Gaviota Coast extension. This will provide full protection for these waters and establish important connectivity for waters between Monterey Bay & Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary. Title: Comment from Pfeiffer, Tiffany
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Tiffany Pfeiffer and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in California, and to me, the ocean is imperative to a healthy and balanced life for all humans. Every day I visit the ocean to fill me with purpose. I am a surfer, swimmer, a naturalist for the Greater Farollones Association, and a volunteer with the Marine Mammal Center. As a surfer and rescuer of marine mammals I see and experience changes in the ocean’s health up close. In college I learned the health of the ocean is the starting point for the health of planet earth. I’ve been making efforts to care for the ocean ever since. 

I work a stressful job. When I go to the coast, my stress decreases. When I go to the coast I feel like a species in harmony among other species just living on this beautiful planet. I feel grounded.

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean. The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
-Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
-The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
-Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
-Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
-Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
-Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,
Tiffany Pfeiffer

Title: Comment from Balder, Wendy
Comment:
A ACCIÓN
La oportunidad
La biodiversidad marina —la variedad de vida en nuestros océanos— sustenta la salud del planeta y nuestro bienestar social y económico. El océano, donde se encuentra el 99 por ciento de todo el espacio habitable de la Tierra, hace posible la vida.
Durante más de 40 años, líderes Cchumash, miembros de la comunidad local y funcionarios electos a lo largo de la costa central de California, han abogado por el establecimiento de un nuevo santuario marino nacional para proteger de mejor manera el área oceánica a lo largo de la costa central de California. Las características únicas de esta área — que incluyen un hábitat intermareal rocoso, un cañón submarino y corrientes de agua de mar fría rica en nutrientes— están repletas de vida marina, incluidos enormes bosques de algas marinas, nutrias marinas, focas, ballenas, delfines e importantes colonias de aves. Pero esta área vulnerable está amenazada por el desarrollo petrolero en alta mar, la contaminación y el cambio climático. El propuesto Santuario Marino Nacional del Patrimonio Chumash ayudaría a proteger los ecosistemas oceánicos y costeros biológicamente productivos y diversos, y promovería la Iniciativa América la Bella de la Administración Biden-Harris, la cual apoya los esfuerzos de conservación liderados localmente en todo el país.
La Oficina Nacional de Administración Oceánica y Atmosférica (NOAA) ha abierto el proceso de comentarios públicos para el Santuario Marino Nacional del Patrimonio Chumash propuesto, y está recopilando opiniones del público, hasta el 25 de octubre de 2023, sobre un borrador del Plan de Gestión y el borrador adjunto de la Declaración de Impacto Ambiental.
La amenaza
Los recursos ecológicos y culturales frente a la costa de California están amenazados por el desarrollo del petróleo y el gas. Cualquier derrame de petróleo significativo en la región Cchumash amenazaría un área desde la Bahía de Santa Mónica hasta Santa Cruz, poniendo en riesgo casi la mitad de las aguas costeras y playas del estado. Incluso sin derrames, el continuo desarrollo de petróleo y gas en alta mar en esta región también causa contaminación del aire que afecta a las comunidades terrestres, y socava los objetivos y políticas de cambio climático de California. Las investigaciones científicas muestran que el área propuesta para protección por el Santuario Marino Nacional del Patrimonio Chumash ya está experimentando impactos del cambio climático, como la acidificación de los océanos a un ritmo que duplica el de los océanos del mundo. Los recursos naturales, históricos, arqueológicos y culturales de importancia nacional del área se beneficiarán de una gestión integral basada en la comunidad y los ecosistemas.
Dígale a la NOAA que apoyas el Santuario Marino Nacional del Patrimonio Chumash
El 9 de noviembre de 2021, la Oficina Nacional de Administración Oceánica y Atmosférica (NOAA) y la Administración Biden propusieron formalmente designar el Santuario Marino Nacional del Patrimonio Chumash. Durante el primer período de comentarios públicos, que cerró el 31 de enero de 2022, más de 30,000 personas expresaron su apoyo. Ahora que la NOAA ha completado un análisis exhaustivo de esos comentarios, el borrador del Plan de Gestión is open for a final round of public comment. está abierto a una ronda final de comentarios públicos. Su retroalimentación influirá directamente en la forma final del Santuario Marino Nacional del Patrimonio Chumash propuesto.
La NOAA organizará reuniones virtuales y presenciales para recopilar opiniones en septiembre y octubre de 2023. La información detallada sobre las fechas, horarios y lugares de las reuniones públicas está disponible en su y se indica más adelante. Participe en una de estas reuniones de comentarios, o envíe un comentario por escrito y exprese su apoyo al Santuario Marino Nacional del Patrimonio Chumash. Los comentarios públicos sobre la designación de santuario propuesta están abiertos hasta el 25 de octubre de 2023. Se espera una acción final sobre la designación a mediados de 2024.
Cada santuario es único, creado para satisfacer las necesidades de la región, por lo que la participación local es vital en esta última fase. Sin embargo, todas las voces, desde locales hasta globales, son bienvenidas a comentar; todo el mundo tiene un interés en nuestro océano.

Title: Comment from Bakula, Marcelle

Title: Comment from Bockmon, Julia
Comment:
My name is Julia Bockmon and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary! I am very concerned, however, that the Sanctuary boundaries identified as the agency preferred alternative omits the waters between Cambria and Point Buchon, that is the waters in vicinity of Morro Bay. This area includes eel grass beds, historic Chumash sites, numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds, the area with the highest population of sea otters on the California coast, several State Marine Conservation Areas, and rocky intertidal marine habitat considered to be one of the most diverse and abundant in the world. 
I live in San Luis Obispo and the ocean in this area and its marine life is very special to me. We frequent the beaches and other places along the coast. A member of my family is involved in ocean research in the Morro Bay estuary, which is tidally influenced by the omitted area.
I support the development of wind energy in the most environmentally and culturally responsible manner; the Sanctuary boundaries as proposed appropriately omit the waters of the offshore wind leases where the Morro Bay wind turbines will be sited. But excluding the waters of the Morro Bay region generally from the Sanctuary designation is unacceptable when, as I have read, options are available that would allow for the permitting of the subsea electrical transmission cables even if within the national marine sanctuary. 
I urge NOAA to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension.

Title: Comment from Duke, Kristi
Comment: Hello, I am writing to request that the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration fulfill the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  I see creating the sanctuary as an honor -  acknowledging that oceans and water belong to the earth and all its creatures -  and that we as people have power to recognize this gift.

Title: Comment from Murphy, Lisa
Comment:
I am Lisa Murphy, resident and homeowner in Cambria, CA
I am a naturalist, natural resource educator, retired NPS ranger, sea kayaker and boogie boarder, ocean enthusiast, and recent convert to regenerative agriculture. 
I support our local fishermen by buying wild caught directly from them, and support our local farmers buying most of our food through CSAs and the local farmers markets.

The most important points for me:
•	Original proposed boundaries.   Contiguous protection (no gap between Monterey Bay NMS and Chumash Heritage NMS) and largest area including the edge of the continental shelf
•	Yes on Gaviota Extension
•	Defer to Morro Bay National Estuary Program re: Morro bay extension.
•	No Oil, gas, mineral exploration of the coast of CA – protected by NMS
•	No seismic mapping - protected by NMS
•	Boat requirements: Cleaner fuel, Speed regulations to protect marine mammals.
•	Protect the Rodriguez Seamount (very specialized habitat)
•	Swift approval.  Get this approved as a new NMS!!!!!
I am Especially adamant about the inclusion of the area of the coast from Cambria to Los Osos to be protected as NMS – adding more protection offshore of the existing small MPA’s we have in place and NMS protecting a contiguous NMS chain (Farallones, Cordell Bank, Monterey Bay, Chumash Heritage (including Gaviota ext.), and the Channel Isl.
I’d like to see the grant/ funding opportunities for farmers – aiding in the shift to regenerative agriculture practices which will has been shown to reduce nitrogen and chemical run off, as well as helping with carbon sequestration, water absorption, and higher nutrients in our food and forage.  This would help our coastal areas deal with the extreme weather events as well, with healthier soils we have less runoff and less erosion.
I reiterate – original proposed boundaries.  This is necessary to protect our coast and our local economy here in Cambria.  Our economy is based in our coastal location, the moderating effected the ocean has on our climate, access to the ocean, ocean recreation and of course delicious seafood.  
If you exclude Cambria to Los Osos, you are funneling all detrimental activity into our area.   And by claiming this as a naming issue – you are blaming this exclusion on the tribes.  That is very problematic and disrespectful.
On this – I think all tribes with historic and current connection should have seats at the table, not just the one federally recognized tribe. And I believe there can be a special management area named for the Salinan tribe to alleviate the naming issue.
In addition:  I teach climate change and feel we need to switch from fossil fuels to renewable energy swiftly.  However,  I am skeptical about the proposed off shore wind farms – as a naturalist I am aware of the issues wind farms cause in the migratory routes of birds, bats, and pollinators.  Because of the lack of studies off shore (Motus towers are very limited of their reach to this far off shore, and don’t work well with fog – which we have a lot of here on the central coast) and the difficulty to get an accurate idea of the #s of species in the air and in the water that will be effected.  This would be a massive windfarm in an extremely important area of the coast (world biodiversity hotspot)  I think off shore windfarms off the coast of California will prove to be very problematic, and very damaging to migratory corridors in the marine environment (in water and in air).  
To that point, I think it’s absurd to exclude this area (Cambria through Morro Bay) from protection under the NMS because of federally leased rights for a project that has not been designed and has certainly not been vetted through the environmental protection lens.
For the love of God and all that is sacred!  Utilize the original boundaries plus the Gaviota extension for the broadest area of protection possible under this designation.   And let the tribes figure out how to effectively deal with the naming issue, but don’t let this hold up the process of designation.  Designate this swiftly – by summer of 2024.
In gratitude, 
Lisa Murphy
Cambria, CA

Title: Comment from 3rd District Santa Barbara County Supervisor Joan Hartmann
Comment:
See attached file(s)

Mr. Paul Michel
West Coast Region Policy Coordinator
NOAA Sanctuaries West Coast Regional Office
99 Pacific Street, Building 100F
Monterey, CA 93940

RE: Support for Designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary - To Connect and Protect an Unfragmented Region Stretching from the Monterey Bay to the Channel Islands Sanctuaries

Dear Mr. Michel:

As the County Supervisor who has the privilege of representing the Gaviota Coast in Santa Barbara County, I write to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to offer my support for the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I respectfully request that you take prompt action to finalize this designation and implement the new sanctuary, to protect an unfragmented stretch of ocean and marine habitat from the southern border of the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary through the entirety of San Luis Obispo County, to the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary and the Gaviota Coast.

On December 14, 2021, the Santa Barbara County Board of Supervisors unanimously adopted a non-binding resolution in support of the nomination of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to the Office of National Marine Sanctuaries and NOAA and this request is consistent with that action.

In addition to the biological importance of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary area, this region holds deep cultural significance for the Chumash people. Native Americans have lived along the California coast for at least 13,000 years, and the relationship between the Chumash and the sea during that time has been profound.  Historically, the Pacific Ocean provided the Chumash with maritime resources that supported life, including food, shells for fishhooks, beads, and ornaments.  Numerous areas within the proposed sanctuary are significant Chumash sites, including Point Conception.  This point was a sacred place for ancient Chumash, as it was regarded as the gateway for the souls of the departed to exit earth and enter the heavens.  It is only appropriate that areas as culturally valuable as this one be protected within a sanctuary that holds the Chumash name. 

I specifically support the inclusion of Gaviota Coast in the southern portion of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary boundary. The creation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would provide resource protection and allow the Chumash Nation and local communities to work together in the future to preserve the treasured resources along California’s coast.  

One key aspect of NOAA’s current proposed designation gives me great pause: the boundary of the “Agency-Preferred Alternative.” This boundary is about 2,000 square miles smaller than the Initial Boundary Alternative proposed last year, and excludes the ecologically rich north-boundary coastlines and oceans of Morro Bay and Cayucos.

Furthermore, per recent review by a noted marine biologist, this excluded region is a biodiversity hotspot and would be a significant obstacle to the long-term protection of Central Coast marine life, including whales, sea turtles, sea lions, seals, sea otters, dolphins, sharks, and fish.

The designation documents suggest that the north-boundary exclusion is primarily intended to accommodate the infrastructure needed to support the adjacent Morro Bay Wind Energy Area. It appears, however, that the “Agency Preferred Alternative” throws the “baby out with the (ocean) water.” There is ample precedent for allowing sanctuaries to accommodate cables and other infrastructure. Also, there have been discussions about allowing the offshore wind industry sufficient time to identify its infrastructure needs, and then lay the sanctuary protections on top of those, thereby grandfathering in such infrastructure. Whatever the pathway, I implore NOAA to find a creative solution to ensure the protection of an unfragmented stretch of the Pacific Ocean between the Monterey Bay and Channel Island sanctuaries, while also enabling the successful implementation of offshore wind energy (which is critical for our carbon-free future). Thank you for your consideration; let’s seize this unique opportunity to protect the Central Coast – all of it.

Joan Hartmann
Third District Supervisor
Santa Barbara County

cc: 
U.S. Congressmember Salud Carbajal
Northern Chumash Tribal Council Chairwoman Violet Sage Walker

Title: Comment from Thompson, Carole
Comment:
12 October 2023



To Whom It May Concern:

I see no reason why the proposed Chumash ocean sanctuary must preclude future wind or solar offshore facilities.  I believe, given the size of the sanitary, both could exist and benefit one another.

In addition, I believe the governance of the propose Chumash sanctuary would benefit by including non-Chumash in the form of ocean & marine biologists or other concerned academics from UCSB or other nearby, concerned colleges and universities.  

Otherwise, I applaud the creation of another marine sanctuary on our beloved coast.

Sincerely,


Carole Thompson
707 Chiquita
Santa Barbara, CA  93103

Title: Comment from Ruiz Fritz, Amy
Comment:
My name is Amy Ruiz Fritz and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Sacramento, CA and I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.

As a descendant of the Chumash people, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.

The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”

A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Title: Comment from Dutton, John
Comment: I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary! Please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection. Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters. Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Keily, Galen
Comment:
Hello,

My name is Galen Keily and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I live in Los Osos, CA and enjoy the beauty of our ocean coast daily as I call this place home. I am a fisherman, paddleboarder, and diver- these activities connect me with the ocean, an ocean that I want to be healthy, safe, and clean. The connection I feel to this place pales in comparison to what I imagine members of indigenous cultures feel who have called this place home for hundreds or thousands of years. For this sanctuary to bear the Chumash name and include co-management with modern day indigenous groups has me very excited to support this designation. 

I am strongly in support of the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension to preserve connectivity with the Monterey Bay NMS, and protect cultural sites and natural resources that would otherwise be left out. I wish for the sanctuary to be called “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” in honor of the great Chumash cultures that have called these seas home since time immemorial. I am strongly supportive of the emphasis of tribal co-management and the strategies defined in the Indigenous Cultural Heritage Action Plan.
I also support a prohibition on oil and gas development, as well as protection from invasive wind energy projects within the sanctuary boundaries.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

Galen Keily

Title: Comment from Hewitson, Jennifer
Comment:
i am a life long resident of coastal California down in Encinitas, but spend time and have family in Morro Bay and San Luis Obispo. I’m also an illustrator and 
the daughter of a biology teacher and environmentalist. I have grave concerns about the fate of the California coast.

I commend NOAA for helping to put forth this Chumash National Marine Sanctuary in a place that indeed needs protection from human degradation.
However, I am strongly against excluding Morro Bay, which is no less important than any other location on the Central Coast, if not more so.
SAVE MORRO BAY along with the rest of the wildlife rich central coast, and STOP the destructive development of OFF SHORE WIND FARMS!!
The rare otter population, the plethora of sea birds, the humpback whales, countless fish species and delicate balance have NO BOUNDARIES!. 
They will be disturbed and destroyed by Wind-Farm exploration, construction, cable laying, constant maintenance and NOISE produced during the installation and FOREVER! That constant drone of multiple turbines reverberating through water will deafen, inhibit communication and navigation, and drive away whales, porpoises and seals, boat strikes from increased traffic will kill them! Thousands of sea birds will be slaughtered in those massive blades of the many turbines and NO ONE will know how extensive that destruction of species will be. 
NO WIND POWER BUSINESS should be on our ocean, especially in a rare habitat like Morro Bay!! Morro Bay has been hacked out of the sanctuary map for the sole purpose of EXPLOITATION” 
There has been no research as to the adverse impacts and no proof of a safe way to install and operate offshore wind farms.
This is a moneymaking scheme under the guise of "GREEN ENERGY” and the only GREEN here are the dollars that will flow into the power industry pockets.
What they and now you are suggesting is DESTROY the planet to SAVE the planet! It is nonsense and INEXCUSABLE.

Our government has lost its way, and big power companies stand to make billions. They promise jobs and money to get these destructive projects accepted by communities, but there is NO amount of money that can compensate for the environmental degradation they will cause! The amount of wildlife, beauty, cherished ocean and unspoiled beaches are priceless, and impossible to replace once spoiled. SAVE Morro Bay from being the sacrificial lamb of power industry greed, and our government's performative actions they claim will save us from climate change...it is the BIG LIE!!
We must say NO to destroying our habitats under the guise of saving ourselves and the climate! 
Include Morro Bay in the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary as designated in the original map, or Alternative 1 map plus 5-B supplemental map.
The largest possible boundary is preferred, including the Gaviota Coast Extension and Morro Bay with oil, gas and wind farm construction being banned from the area.
There are better and less destructive ways to both conserve and produce power. Don’t allow the energy industry to exploit and abuse our last vestiges of wilderness and preserved habitats.
Our oceans are our life support system, and that system, including its wild inhabitants, deserves respect and protection from detrimental human exploitation. 

Sincerely and respectfully, Jennifer Hewitson

Title: Comment from Russell, Tammy
Comment:
My name is Tammy Russell, I’m a marine ecologist at Scripps Institution of Oceanography in San Diego, CA and I research habitat use of and climate change impacts on marine predators in the California Current Ecosystem. I’m commenting today in support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS), as well as to recommend that the sanctuary boundaries include the entire Santa Lucia Escarpment, part of which was cut out in the updated proposed boundary lines. 
The area of the proposed CHNMS captures a unique transition zone between the warm southern waters and cooler waters in the north. Along with the effect on wind and mixing from Point Conception, this results in productive foraging habitat for a diversity of marine predators. Through my research, I’ve found that the density and diversity of seabirds here is higher than outside of the originally proposed sanctuary boundaries. The unique location of this sanctuary would capture that warm-cold water transition zone and the variety of species that use the coastal and offshore habitats in this region. In addition to the important coastal habitat, the original boundaries captured a high proportion of offshore habitat, which is extremely important for migratory species that use these waters as their non-breeding feeding grounds. In total, I’ve found that 73 seabird species use this habitat, with 81% of the birds recorded here being migratory species. Protecting these important foraging grounds are critical for these highly vulnerable species. 
I especially want to highlight that within the section of the northeast corner of the original boundary, over the Santa Lucia Escarpment, I have identified it as an ecological hotspot. Our data shows there is a high abundance of seabirds and marine mammals that use these waters, which is likely due increased ocean mixing from the complex seafloor. We will also be conducting a focused Santa Lucia Escarpment research cruise in May 2024 to further explore this ecological hotspot. The newly updated boundary goes right through this productive and important habitat. This change would result in a tremendous loss of opportunity by excluding this unique habitat, and I ask that this be more thoroughly, ecologically evaluated. To include this in the CHNMS would help protect this rare productive offshore habitat for multiple species, many of which are federally and/or internationally protected. 
Because of these reasons, which show the ecological importance of this region, in addition to the cultural significance for the Chumash People, I continue to support this designation. I hope that the boundaries will be further evaluated, not only based on wind energy plans, but on the underlying marine ecosystem. As of now, our evidence only supports that the offshore waters in the northeast section capture a biological hotspot and will be a missed opportunity to protect this unique region.

Title: Comment from Arrighi, Dean
Comment:
I urge NOAA to select the Initial Boundary Alternative, along with Sub-alternates 5a (Morro Bay Estuary) and 5b Gaviota Coast Extension). I disagree with NOAA selecting the Alternative 2 Proposed Boundary. Moving the northern boundary of the originally proposed Initial Boundary Alternative will creating a 10 mile gap between the existing southern boundary of the Monterey Bay NMS and the originally proposed northern boundary. I would like to address some of the NOAA justifications for making this boundary change:
(1) The name of the proposed NMS has been rejected by the Salinas tribes, who have historical cultural ties with the coast between Cambria and Morro Bay, because the proposed name does not include them. I think the best way to address this controversy is not by excluding this area from the proposed NMS. Instead, simply add the name Salinas into the proposed name to read "Chumash and Salinas Heritage National Marine Sanctuary". Surely the proposed NMS can be inclusive enough for all Indigenous tribe stakeholders, including the name.
(2) Alternatives 2-4 adjust the originally proposed northern boundary southward to create a 10 mile corridor outside of the originally proposed NMS. This change would allow the future installation and maintenance of approximately 30 electrical power cables to take place outside the proposed NMS. These electrical power cables are planned to go from the ocean wind turbine farms to the Morro Bay coastline, where they can be connected to existing power grid infrastructure. Although this boundary adjustment would potentially simplify the permitting process for the project proponents, a detailed, lengthy NEPA review process would still have to be completed. And the actual environmental impacts caused by these electrical power cables would be the same, regardless if it happens within the proposed NMS or outside of the NMS. As stated in the paragraph Offshore Wind Development - Federal Waters on page 173 of the DEIS, there is an existing permit process that ONMS can use to authorize the installation and maintenance of these electrical power cables within the proposed NMS. This same process has already been used for installing fiber optic cables within a NMS. Considering the unique importance of the already planned ocean wind farm projects, I think the electrical power cables can be installed within the boundary of the Initial Boundary Alternative. 
(3) As stated in Table 5-1, the Initial Boundary Alternative has Significant Beneficial Impacts for physical resources, biological resources, commercial fishing and aquaculture resources, cultural heritage and maritime resources, DoD and Homeland Security activities. I believe all of these Significant Beneficial Impacts should not be overlooked for the temporary conveniences afforded to NOAA and future developers by avoiding the NMS naming controversy and future developer permitting issues.
(4) I have additional concerns with the 10 mile gap along the northern boundary of the Initial Boundary, as proposed by Alternative 2. I believe the Draft EIS does not adequately address the future adverse impacts that could be created from the 10 mile gap. If Alternative 2 were to be selected for the proposed NMS, then the ocean area with this gap between NMSs would not have the protections offered by a NMS. Cetaceans and other wildlife who migrate along the California coast within the Monterey and proposed NSMs would have a lapse of protections once they entered the 10 mile gap area. This situation could potentially harm migrating wildlife in this area. It could also harm local fish populations over time. The original idea of the Initial Boundary Alternative is to have a shared boundary from the Monterey NMS to the proposed NMS. This allows for the uninterrupted protection of all migratory species within these NMSs. It is for these reasons that I think it's a bad idea to change the original northern boundary as presented in the Initial Boundary Alternative.
Alternatives 1- 4 moves the original westward boundary further eastward, away from the continental shelf's edge. I read the purpose of this boundary change is to reduce the size of the proposed NMS, making it more manageable to oversee. I don't know if any potential adverse environmental impacts that could be caused from this boundary change was adequately addressed in the DEIS? Would migrating ocean fauna within the western areas left out of Alternatives 1-4 be impacted by not being included within the proposed NMS? 
Considering my above comments, my preferred boundary alternative is the Initial Boundary Alternative.
Thanx for considering my comments.

Title: Comment from Grajeda, Monique
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Monique Grajeda and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in San Luis Obispo, CA and to me, the ocean is the life blood to our planet and existence as well as a spiritual and universal conduit to our connection with what is beyond .

We as humans go to the ocean and stare because we are drawn to its power and purpose. It is a world of its own and should be our true focus and priority.
We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.
I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Monique Grajeda

Title: Comment from Keyes, Kelsey
Comment:
The designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would be a valuable and important achievement. This sanctuary would honoring the history and culture of Native Americans, the Chumash people, and their ancestors who inhabited and care for this region for more than a 10,000 years. It would also honor the oceans, we all rely on for our very existence, while providing a safe refuge for the plants and animals who call the ocean home. Given the crisis we are all suffering from right now, it seems this project has too many benefits not to move forward. I love the ocean. At this time in my life with the drama of recent years, the climate crisis, and the economy, I have been unable to visit the ocean in quiet a while. However, when I need to bring myself to a state of peace it is still the place i picture. I envision myself looking out over a vast expanse of blue, listening to the waves on the beach, imaging the sand supporting my body and the breeze and sun on my skin. I am sure I am not alone, in using this exact scene to calm my nerves and steady my mind to face the challenges of my day or prepare myself to slide into sleep at night. Please support protect this valuable resource and honoring the work the Chumash have done to care for this region.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Title: Comment from Adams, Case
Comment:
As a naturalist and scientist, and resident of Morro Bay, CA, I support the designation of a marine sanctuary for this coastline. This is a sensitive habitat for many species. However, in my opinion, NOAA has mistakenly carved out and abandoned the area between Morro Bay and Cambria. This will effectively open these waters up to not only the proposed windfarm, but to oil drilling platforms, the latter of which could ruin the entire coastline including the sanctuaries north and south.

I do understand the consideration of NOAA regarding cables from a proposed windfarm. However, cables the lead out to a floating windfarm could easily be permitted or excepted from the sanctuary requirements, given the reality that a move to alternative energy sources would effectively help preserve all of our oceans from a carbon standpoint, making such a wind farm appropriate for a marine sanctuary.

Therefore, I respectfully request that NOAA approve the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Alternative 1 with Sub-Alt 5b); which includes the waters offshore of Point Buchon, Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria as well as the Gaviota extension. 

If we are going to do this, let's get the job done please.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Zhu, Daphne
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Daphne Zhu, and I am in 11th grade at Lynbrook High School in San Jose, CA. I am a Youth Commissioner for Santa Clara Valley Water District and a student leader in Silicon Valley Youth Climate Action. I strongly support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

As a Bay Area resident, the ocean has always been a place like no other where I find beauty, peace, relaxation, and a valuable connection to nature. I love going kayaking, or laying down on the beach, or watching the egrets and pelicans and cormorants, or feeling the breeze on my face and the waves around my ankles.

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean. In addition, a sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,
Daphne

Title: Comment from Miller, Michael
Comment: Thank you for consideration of my comments in your decision on the current NMS boundary. I fully support including Morro Bay and Cayucos in the bouderies. It is not a guarantee that the wind farms will be placed of the Morro Bay and Cayucos coast. It may not be cost effective or environmentally sound for that project. I have lived in Los Osos since 1971. I have been hoping all these years that we could have the coastal waters locally protected and added to the Monterey NMS. It would be terrible loss to our beautiful coastal waters to loose this protection. Thank you for your consideration in this monumental and prudent decision you are about to make.

Title: Comment from Paule, William
Comment: I do not understand why commercial fishing regulation is excluded from this rule. The rule seeks to protect important national resources, specifically citing particular animals and plants  it is well known the oceans are overfished and our local fisheries in decline. These are not opinions but historical fact evident from a visit to any local maritime. I don’t understand how a rule that does not further limit commercial fishing will make any noticeable difference.  I hope this rule is a step in that direction.

Title: Comment from Korchek, Becky
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel;
I am so grateful to learn of the proposal for the  Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  The plan could truly complete the important safeguards necessary to protect the California coastline.  However, I hope your committee will enhance the current proposal and eliminate the open corridor for shipping near the Moro Bay area.  Such a gap in the sanctuary would permit shipping that could harm the sea life in the area, harm migration of animals, and harm kelp forests.  Please consider making  the sanctuary a continuous protected area of coastline.  
Thank you,
Becky Korchek
Carmel Valley, CA Resident
Point Lobos Docent
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Kennemer, Jody
Comment: We are URGENTLY requesting that the entire PROPOSED CHNMS be protected. The new boundary proposed by NOAA cuts out the waters between Cambria and Point Buchon which need the very most protection. This is a very sensitive environmental area which includes numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds, the highest population of sea otters on the California coast, a marine habitat considered to be one of the most diverse and abundant in the world, and many historic Chumash sites. People from all over the world visit here throughout the year to view and enjoy all of the wildlife, sealife, and natural beauty that surrounds these specific waters. Of all of the California coastal areas to be cut out of this Marine Sactuary, this area needs the most protection because of its biodiversity and sensitive marine habitat! Thank you for reconsidering the originally proposed CHNMS that guarantees the protection of these rich waters, sealife, marine mammals and coastline. We are highly concerned residents of Morro Bay.

Title: Comment from Wilson, Wendy
Comment:
Dear NOAA Administrators:

My name is Wendy Wilson and I support the early designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the largest possible boundaries to best protect the 7,600 square miles of ocean area off the central coast of California.

I live in San Diego and to me, the ocean is a part of our creation story including the balance of life on the land and sea.

The ocean is personally important to my daily life.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Wrenn, Rosemary
Comment:
I have lived, worked, and raised a family in Pismo and Shell Beach on the Central Coast of California since 1993. I have learned a great deal about our relationship to the land and water from members of the Northern Chumash Tribal Council and other local Indigenous Peoples who have all been and continue to be stewards of our land and ocean. I urge you to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with its originally proposed boundaries adding Sub Alternative 5b to also protect the. Gaviota Coast.

I support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) name. It is meant to recognize people that have lived on this coast for over 10,000 years; protect the heritage of the Chumash, an ocean-going band among the First People of the Pacific Coast; and provide a timely and appropriate reminder of the cultural origins. Leaders and members of the Northern Chumash Tribal Council initiated, sustained, and continue to lead the effort on this designation, in part due to their historic and current presence on this part of the coast. While they are not a Federally recognized tribe, their claim to this space is valid. (Federal recognition is a structure set upon Indigenous peoples that does not acknowledge indigenous ways of knowing and being.) I support equitable inclusion of all Central Coast Tribes, both federally and non-federally recognized Tribes, in collaborative management.

As an educator and teacher educator, I know it is vital that Sanctuary education and community outreach should partner with area schools to share information about sanctuary species and habitats and Chumash history and culture. Outreach should be multilingual, culturally relevant, and should focus on underserved communities.

I support regulations to protect Rodriguez Seamount. The seamount provides critical habitat for an extremely diverse and abundant array of marine life and deserves to be granted strong and permanent protection. The seamount has special national significance that warrants special protections through sanctuary designation. Once damaged, fragile seamount ecosystems may not recover in our lifetime.

With plans for future Offshore Wind (OSW) farm development off the Central Coast, the proposed CHNMS will help protect important habitats and cultural sites and direct OSW development to less sensitive areas of the Central Coast. California’s first offshore wind projects should be done smartly and reflect leasing, siting, and permitting decisions that are guided by planning and comprehensive scientific research on the potential impacts to sensitive marine areas, species, and coastal resources, including cumulative impacts.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage NMS. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage NMS to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Thank you, 
Rosemary Wrenn, Ed.D.
Shell Beach, CA.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Lazarus , Brian
Comment: As a resident of Cambria community I would like to support the Chumash tribe.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Duncan, Mary
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Mary Mackenzie Duncan.  I live in northern Santa Barbara County and I am a mother, educator, and artist.  I was born in Syuxtun and some of my earliest memories are of swimming in the ocean with my mother.  When I was in middle school, our science teacher took us to Refugio State Beach and I went snorkeling in our local waters for the first time.  I remember my awe at the forests of kelp and all the creatures living within them.  I do extensive outdoor education work and I can attest that strong and life-giving natural ecosystems, and meaningful connections with them, are what our children need for a hopeful future.  
I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I work with young people now, and they are very aware that many humans are living out of balance with nature.  They notice with sadness and anger the wasteful and destructive attitudes towards the body and spirit of our home planet earth.  They need hope and true leadership that demonstrates a care for all people including fish people, plant people, and bird people.  The Chumash people have the generational knowledge to lead the way back towards a relationship with our waters that sustains life.   I wholeheartedly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

 
Sincerely,
Mac Duncan
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Conrad, Kalea
Comment:
Hello,
I was an Environmental Sciences and Management student for both my undergraduate and graduate degrees at Cal Poly. I express my full support for the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Any potential name changes in the interest of incorporation of the Salinan people must center and elevate the presence of the indigenous stewards of the coastline--including the Salinan peoples. The original proposed boundary should be respected in accordance with the recommendation of the Chumash peoples to incorporate as much of California's precious coastlines as possible-- extending from Cambria past Gaviota to ensure that all of the coastline between the Monterey and Channel Islands Sanctuaries are protected to the maximum extent possible from all future oil and gas related perturbations. The management of the sanctuary must incorporate the voices of all indigenous groups on the Central Coast who have stewarded the land and water for millennia to prioritize restoration and the maximum preservation of marine life from seismic testing, overfishing, and additional threats to ecosystem vitality. California's marine ecosystem is amongst the most biodiverse in the world; no part of the Central Coast should be excluded from Sanctuary protections. In a time with unprecedented extinction, endangerment, and threatening of species, consider the critical role that this complete sanctuary will play for centuries into the future. I look forward to the final approval of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary! Best,

Kalea Conrad
Environmental Sciences and Management 2024

Title: Comment from Hostetler, Sandra
Comment: As a Christian, I'm excited to see a proposed draft management plan for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. We need clear and meaningful management and implementation of the sanctuary. Given that the Chumash tribe, among other tribes, have been the primary keepers and sustainers of these waters and the lands that are along the coast, we must first look to them for comment and input on this draft management plan and future management plans. It is so important that we preserve God's unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. I ask that you respect the Northern Chumash Tribal Council requests regarding sanctuary boundary, the sanctuary name, tribal collaborative management, outreach and education, Rodriguez Seamount, offshore wind and water quality. Thank you for your work on this immediate need to preserve God's creation.

Title: Comment from Hand, Laura
Comment:
My name is Laura Hand, and I urge the NOAA to adopt the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension.

I am lucky.  Some would be surprised to hear that if they saw me. More than 30 years ago, my own car inexplicably popped out of gear in my own driveway and ran over me.  It severed my spinal cord in six different places, and the engine block ended up resting on my face, scalding half of it. But soon after I started my new life from a wheelchair, my husband and I bought a house in Morro Bay.  From our front deck, we watch the peaceful, beautiful ocean of Estero Bay; from our kitchen window, we can see whales pass by on their migration to and from northern and southern climes; from the state park below us, I can use an accessible beach chair to get to the beach and watch otters frolic and dolphins play.  How lucky I am.

I am also lucky to be alive at a time when the NOAA appears close to establishing the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  What a gift this sanctuary will be to the species that occupy that portion of the ocean and to the people who visit and/or live near it. Thank you, thank you to the NOAA for its diligence and incredibly hard work throughout this designation process. I urge you to complete the process as quickly as possible.

On the flip side, I am disheartened by the possibility that NOAA will adopt an alternative that does not protect the coast from Cambria to Morro Bay.  I urge NOAA to adopt the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension. Excluding any part of the 2,000-square-mile section of ocean between Cambria and Morro Bay will be devastating to marine species that do not recognize the proposed human boundaries and will suffer from the disruption and pollution that would be allowed in an area that, despite the exclusion, will still be habitat to many threatened species. 

The agency-preferred alternative states that the Point Buchon/Morro Bay-Cambria area must be omitted because of the proposed wind-energy development. 
However, knowing that offshore wind farms may be a part of the sanctuary environment, NOAA could establish a process for permitting the proposed wind-energy activities. Adopting the Initial Boundary Alternative plus extensions and including wind energy as a potential use would protect the entire region from climate-destructive activities such as oil and gas drilling.  

Designating the sanctuary with the largest possible boundary would lead to multiple benefits. The Initial Boundary Alternative would connect the new sanctuary with the existing Channel Islands National Marine and Monterey Bay National Marine sanctuaries to offer contiguous protection of most of the California Coast from oil and gas drilling and other damaging uses. Creating a sanctuary with the largest boundary would most effectively protect local Indigenous communities’ cultural history, including Morro Rock. Using the largest boundary, including both extensions, would leave the character of the Central Coast and its waters intact. Selecting the Initial Boundary Alternative and extensions would support the recovery of endangered and threatened marine species and environments. This alternative would protect the only eelgrass bed in a 300-mile stretch of coast; many historic Chumash sites, including Lisamu’ (Morro Rock); numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds; the highest population of Southern sea otters on the California coast; several State Marine Conservation Areas; and the kelp forests and rocky intertidal habitats considered to be some of the most diverse and abundant in the world.

The agency-preferred alternative states that the Morro Bay-Cambria area must be omitted from the sanctuary because local Indigenous people cannot agree on a name for the area. I’m sorry – what??!!!??  We cannot afford to leave a 2,000-square-mile stretch of ocean unprotected because of a dispute over the name.  Please.  This is not the time for NOAA  to throw up its hands and give up on the idea that there is a naming solution that satisfies all tribes.  Please continue to work on such a solution. One option: the stretch in question could be named as a subset of the Sanctuary. Great minds have been working for years on the designation of this Sanctuary.  Surely, these great minds can reach a solution amenable to all stakeholders. Please do not leave a huge stretch of ocean unprotected because of a dispute over what it shall be named.
In summary, I commend NOAA and its partners for proposing the new Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, and I ask you to designate the sanctuary as soon as possible. I strongly urge NOAA and its partners to select the Initial Boundary Alternative, plus both extensions and strong protection for the Rodriguez Seamount, to afford the best long-term protection for this diverse and fragile environment. Thank you for all you have done.  Please don’t exclude the Morro-Bay-to-Cambria section of this miraculous sanctuary.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from River, Aurelea
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Aurelea, and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Pittsburgh, PA now, but I grew up on the West Coast and I have a deep relationship with the Pacific Ocean. I want to see it protected and I believe that Indigenous people are the best stewards of the land and the sea.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the largest amount of ocean possible: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension, be named "Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”, be managed by local tribes especially the Chumash, and have a focus on outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities. The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity. I also ask for a prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

Aurelea River

Title: Comment from Gardner, Sherrill
Comment:
As a lifelong coastal recreation user; I care deeply about our central coast ocean, preserving and managing indigenous cultural sites as well as overall environmental protection and management. My concerns are as follows:
1. Include the full geographic extent reflected in the Initial Boundary Alternative, as well as the Gaviota Coast Extension (5B).
2. Adopt strong regulations and a robust management plan to provide sufficient protections for the region’s sensitive habitats, cultural resources and sustainable human uses. 
3. Insure equitable managment to include all Tribes in Collaborative Managment.
4. In the enabling regulations, include special permits for the various proposed/planned transmission cables needed for anticipated offshore wind project development and operations in the Morro Bay Wind Energy Area. This will allow the currently shown preferred boundary with the 'gap' at the Morro Bay Esturary area to be eliminated.
5. Prohibit any new oil and gas development within the sanctuary boundaries.
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this very important proposed designation.

Title: Comment from Rico, Mary Ellen
Comment: I support the Initial Boundary Alternative and the Gaviota Coast extension as the sanctuary boundaries in order to fully protect all the marine species that live in or migrate throughout area.  Cutting out this area from the sanctuary dooms marine life in other parts of the sanctuary instead of protects them.  Please do the right thing and protect this area for them and for future generations.  Thanks for listening.

Title: Comment from Ravinale, LeAnne
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
I wholeheartedly support the swift designation of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension.
The oceans are integral to our survival, especially due to acidification and other crises due to climate change. The more designations and encouragement for the public to be be engaged in protecting the oceans, the better of we'll all be. I live on the MBNMS and I also know how our area benefits from educational and experiential tourism due to this designation, and the contiguous protection for our ecosystem is only a positive thing for present and future generations.

I support the designation as well as the specific naming of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, with the largest possible boundary, including the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension. I ask for the Tribal Collaborative Management, TEK Outreach and Education, including access for local underserved communities to this NMS.

Please include protection of the Rodriguez Seamount to protect biodiversity and prohibit new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

Thank you for this enduring legacy of marine and human protection.

Title: Comment from Schulz, Carlee
Comment: This sacred and biologically important land must be preserved, in its full form from the initial proposal. Cutting corners will never work when preserving vital waters and lands!

Title: Comment from Lomeli , Joseph
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Joseph Lomeli and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Cambria, CA and to me, the ocean is a very sacred and special place.
* The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.
* I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
* The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:
* Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
* Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
* Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
* Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
* Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
* Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,
Joseph Lomeli

Title: Comment from Kremer, Rory
Comment:
As a California archaeologist with over 20 years of experience working in the area of the Central Coast I must ask for disapproval of this proposal.
There is no strong evidence that the people who call themselves Chumash controlled or were the majority group of native people who occupied the Central Coast of California.  In actuality, The Salinan people may well have held this position.  With this in mind I believe that unless the Salinan people are included in the proposal and process this is a hollow and I'll informed proposal.
Rory James Kremer
Senior Archaeologist
Morro Bay, CA
805-806-1610

Comment: Please support this landmark legislation to preserve this critical marine habitat.

Title: Comment from Gallo, Frances
Comment:
I am alarmed that your agency has revised the boundary for the proposed Chumash National Marine Sanctuary off the coast of Central California. I live along this area of the coast and it has many unique features not found in other areas of the California coast. Morro Rock is an incredible landmark and a sacred location for the indigenous peoples who have called this area home for thousands of years.  Additionally, Morro Bay and isolated areas along the Initial Boundary provide critical habitat to the Southern Sea Otter. Moreover, Morro Bay and the beaches to the north, including Cayucos, are popular destinations for tourists from all over the world. 

A decision by your agency to leave Morro Bay,  as well as onshore and offshore Estero Bay, outside of the proposed sanctuary unprotected flies in the face of the National Marine Sanctuary Act. I ask that you restore the boundary for the sanctuary to the original map you previously proposed.

Title: Comment from Tomchin, Cheryl
Comment: I am in support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary effort to protect 6,000 square miles of the Gaviota Coast as well as the proposal of an additional 2,000 square miles of permanent protection connecting Monterey and the Channel Islands. As an avid ocean swimmer and philanthropic environmentalist (as well as supporter of women and children's health and education). We ALL need to help those who have no voice heal themselves and the planet in order to flourish and turn the tide of despair.  Best, Tomchin Family Foundation

Title: Comment from Ackley, Sharon
Comment:
I am in support of the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
Please designate the sanctuary as it was originally proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), as well as the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b), so that there is protection for the waters between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. 
This sanctuary offers the opportunity to elevate Indigenous perspectives and cultural values, honoring the history and culture of the Native Americans who have inhabited this region for more than 10,000 years.
This sanctuary should protect the area from harmful oil and gas development and reduce water pollution in Sanctuary waters by preventing excess runoff of sediments, oils, pesticides, nutrients, and pathogens.
The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should ensure that Offshore Wind operations and construction are completed through the guidelines of the new Sanctuary. These projects should be planned and authorized in a way that avoids and mitigates impacts to sensitive marine areas, species, and important cultural areas. Thank you for protecting earth and humanity, Sharon Ackley
