Title: Comment from Gray, Monica
Comment: I oppose the placement of wind farms on California's central coast, due to the possible impacts to wildlife, harm to the environment due to so many things that the companies are experimenting with, while accepting contracts and a bunch of money to do things they aren't even sure they can and will accomplish, by building those things. Having these giant, untested structures floating around and being built in  areas where whale and bird migration happens will also impact those creatures, and could affect tourism if it hurts those creatures bad enough and they "go away." Reading the environmental impact report gives you an idea of the possibilities and "what ifs," and the speed with which these contracts, agreements and boundary redraws is happening makes me.wonder who is paying someone off to quiet dissent and why there is such a rush to push it through, when decisions made in haste and under time sensitive pressure often result in poor environmental outcomes, and failed endeavors. The environment needs protection, but not by way of ill conceived "projects," with hefty price tags, untold environmental impacts and people who admit they don't know what they are doing cashing the checks and demanding everyone just accept it as a "savior solution. " This is not akin to arguing over where the fire extinguisher gets hung up during a fire; this is asking us to accept a conceptual idea that has already been producing conditions that correlate with more dead whales where they're built, with agencies denying any correlation. Asking the dox to guard the henhouse is never a good idea, and asking agencies that get money for allowing things to go on whether they cause harm or not, is not a.good.way to ensure integrity and reporting the negative aspects likely won't be done if it goes against their objectives and what will allow them to continue their activity.  I want to help protect the environment, but after watching the malfeasance at every level and the self serving ways people vote when approached by the right suit, they'll change their tune and allow what they've been bribed to. Protect the Central Coast. Once we.ketbthem.do their not so little experiments in the name.of "saving the planet," they'll come up with more ill conceived ideas that will be approved and funded before tested, and that could hurt our planet worse than ever before.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from G, Rachel
Comment:
I urge the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary within the borders of the Initial Boundary Alternative as originally proposed, along with the Gaviota Coast Extension.

Including the waters between Point Buchon and Cambria will close a biodiversity protection gap along the California coast. This will protect the only eel grass bed in a 300-mile stretch of coast, many historic Chumash sites, numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds, the area with the highest population of sea otters on the California coast, several State Marine Conservation Areas, the kelp forests of the Santa Barbara Channel, and rocky intertidal marine habitat considered to be one of the most diverse and abundant in the world.

Excluding any of these waters is unacceptable when multiple options are available that would allow for the permitting of the cables and infrastructure needed for the adjacent offshore wind area and would not require the permanent exclusion of 2,000 square miles of ocean from sanctuary protection. The National Marine Sanctuary Program should work closely with state and federal partners, OSW companies, Tribes, and community members to ensure off-shore wind is developed in the most environmentally and culturally responsible manner.

No other proposed alternative is adequate to this purpose. The Environmental Impact Statement acknowledges that all other alternatives would variously reduce the significant beneficial impacts on biological resources provided by the Initial Boundary Alternative to “moderate” or “minor” by comparison and increase the vulnerability of those resources to adverse impacts that the Initial Boundary Alternative would prohibit or mitigate. The alternatives that truncate the Initial Boundary Alternative would impact the many species that migrate through the unprotected areas, impacts that would go far beyond the wind farms' cable corridors.

I urge you to recognize your obligation to future generations and secure full protection for the irreplaceable ecosystem and cultural heritage of this vital marine region.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Costello Duran, Anna
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Anna Costello Duran and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in San Luis Obispo, California, and will be directly impacted by the sanctuary, benefitting from cleaner ocean, increased research and educational funding, and the collaborative local and indigenous management of our water ecosystems. The ocean and gorgeous Central Coast beaches are some of the most iconic and beloved parts of this area. We locals love leisure, recreation, and fishing in the beautiful ocean! It is imperative that we protect our ocean from toxic waste, offshore drilling, and ocean mining, which will prevent future generations from benefitting from these important natural resources. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
* Timely Completion: Please complete this sanctuary designation as swiftly as possible and by next summer 2024 in order to ensure protection of our oceans in a bipartisan manner.
* The Largest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension in order to prevent offshore drilling and continuity with other nearby ocean sanctuaries. With small gaps in continuity, the “edge effect” will damage the protection of the entire sanctuary ecosystem as a whole.
* Sanctuary Name: It is important to listen to and take action to address the needs and concerns of all indigenous peoples to cultivate inclusion. Sub-names would be a great solution if there are alternate name suggestions for specific areas of the sanctuary that are offered by different Tribes.
* Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management. It is important to allow for participation from non-federally recognized tribal peoples to honor the wisdom and rights to this land of the first peoples.
* Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities. These must be in multiple languages and address unique cultural understandings with factual education.
* Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity!
* Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries is imperative so we might begin investing in a livable future in light of global warming and the non-renewable nature of fossil fuels. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Thank you, Paul Michel, for your work to hear from community members who are deeply invested in this sanctuary designation. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

In gratitude,
Anna
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Huelga, Brandon
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I was born and raised in Monterey, CA, and I have had a strong connection with our local and global ocean my entire life; from my first childhood memories of waddling around my parents’ dive shop, to my current passions of scientific diving through Reef Check California, underwater photography and divemaster instruction.

When I am not diving, I am reading books like The Brilliant Abyss by Helen Scales, tidepooling at Asilomar State Beach in Pacific Grove, kayaking in the Elkhorn Slough of Moss Landing, attending ocean art exhibits and celebrations at local forums or taking invigorating cold plunges at San Carlos Beach in Monterey. To say that our beautiful ocean nourishes my whole being is an understatement.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the following: 

- Ensuring the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension is critical. I had the wondrous experience of conducting Reef Check surveys out of Morro Bay down to Montaña de Oro and Point Buchon. This is a stunning beautiful area and deserve the most protection possible.

- The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”

- Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities. Diversity and expanded awareness is key to stoking public interest, passion and therefore good decision making with regards to the ocean

- The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity. Seamounts are treasure troves of life that further study would allow scientists to make breakthroughs in medicine, geology and more.

- A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries. Allowing this development within the area is antithetical to the base purpose of the sanctuary.

The Earth is in a state of crisis, and we know, as a scientific fact, that the best way to save our home and ourselves is to aid nature’s incredible self-healing by sanctifying areas to enforce the natural symbiotic connection that we humans have with it. The Chumash people embody this connection, and supporting the tenets above are critical in recognizing and uplifting this. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Rousseau, Mark
Comment:
I support the creation of the proposed CHNMS, and applaud NOAA including Chumash members in the process of defining and governing the Sanctuary.  
Given the facts of climate change and the overwhelming impacts it has, including in this area on the ocean life;  I do not think it would be prudent to exclude  potential wind energy development within CHNMS (including cables that may need to pass through the area).   I feel that these two uses (Sanctuary creation and off shore wind) are not mutually exclusive.  There can be both.  While there may be minor impacts to the Sanctuary from off shore wind energy development, it far outweighs the impacts of continuing to burn fossil fuels to create energy.  
Please write the rules for the CHNMS to allow for off shore wind to be developed within it's boundaries.  
Thank you, and many generations to follow us will thank you in the future.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: It is disappointing that the people are being required to argue in favor of preserving our valuable coastline. I work for utility companies as an environmental monitor and I feel so blessed to wake up everyday and go to work protecting the natural resources we were graced with in California. Please don’t let the idea of “money” or “productivity” cloud your judgement in what you know is best for the wildlife and cultural resources of the land and water here. Think of what you could assist in leaving your children; the world you want them to inherit. Please protect everything you can. We are the planet’s only hope for survival now.

Title: Comment from Schumann + Adams, Klaus +Jay
Comment:
We strongly urge you to adopt the Initial Boundary Alternative and the Gaviota Coast Extension as the sanctuary boundaries.
This alternative is the only option that would connect the two existing National Marine Sanctuaries in Monterey Bay and the Channel Islands, providing contiguous protection for whales and other species that migrate along the California Central Coast.
Thank you for your attention to this extremely important matter.
Dr, Jay Adams and Klaus Schumann

Title: Comment from Esposito , Dan
Comment: As a Christian, I'm excited to see a proposed draft management plan for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. We need clear and meaningful management and implementation of the sanctuary. Given that the Chumash tribe, among other tribes, have been the primary keepers and sustainers of these waters and the lands that are along the coast, we must first look to them for comment and input on this draft management plan and future management plans. It is so important that we preserve God's unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. I ask that you respect the Northern Chumash Tribal Council requests regarding sanctuary boundary, the sanctuary name, tribal collaborative management, outreach and education, Rodriguez Seamount, offshore wind and water quality. Thank you for your work on this immediate need to preserve God's creation.

Comment: As a Christian, I'm excited to see a proposed draft management plan for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. We need clear and meaningful management and implementation of the sanctuary. Given that the Chumash tribe, among other tribes, have been the primary keepers and sustainers of these waters and the lands that are along the coast, we must first look to them for comment and input on this draft management plan and future management plans. It is so important that we preserve God's unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. I ask that you respect the Northern Chumash Tribal Council requests regarding sanctuary boundary, the sanctuary name, tribal collaborative management, outreach and education, Rodriguez Seamount, offshore wind and water quality. Thank you for your work on this immediate need to preserve God's creation.

Title: Comment from Williams, David
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is David Williams and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Los Angeles, California, and to me, the ocean is vital

* When I go to the coast, I am soothed by observing the the natural ecosystems in the ocean.
* The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.
* I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
* The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
* Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
* Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
* Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
* Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
* Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
* Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,
David Williams
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Vanvakaris, Suzanne
Comment:
I am in support of the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary!
 Please designate the sanctuary as it was originally proposed (Initial Boundary  Alternative),  As well as the gaviota extension sub alternative 5B so that there is protection for the waters between Monterey Bay and channel islands national marine sanctuaries. The sanctuary offers the opportunity to elevate indigenous perspectives and cultural values, honoring the history and culture of the native Americans who have inhabited this region for more than 10000 years. This sanctuary should protect the area from harmful oil and gas development and reduce water pollution in sanctuary waters by preventing excess runoff of sediments oils pesticides nutrients and pathogens. The too much heritage national marine sanctuary should ensure that offshore wind operations And construction are completed through the guidelines of the new sanctuary. These projects should be planned and authorized in a way that avoids and mitigates impacts to sensitive marine areas, species and importance cultural areas. Thank you.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Campos, Brynn
Comment:
Hello! I, Brynn Campos, am in support of the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
Please designate the sanctuary as it was originally proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), as well as the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b), so that there is protection for the waters between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. 
This sanctuary offers the opportunity to elevate Indigenous perspectives and cultural values, honoring the history and culture of the Native Americans who have inhabited this region for more than 10,000 years.
This sanctuary should protect the area from harmful oil and gas development and reduce water pollution in Sanctuary waters by preventing excess runoff of sediments, oils, pesticides, nutrients, and pathogens.
The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should ensure that Offshore Wind operations and construction are completed through the guidelines of the new Sanctuary. These projects should be planned and authorized in a way that avoids and mitigates impacts to sensitive marine areas, species, and important cultural areas.

Title: Comment from Lessard, Joanne
Comment:
I strongly support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) to protect ocean biodiversity and to advance environmental justice through collaborative ocean management.  Environmental preservation is a desperate issue since so much beautiful and important land and ocean is being lost so easily and quickly.

 It is vital that the CHNMS cover the largest possible contiguous boundaries. I support designation of the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alt 5b). Including the waters offshore Point Buchon, Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria will close the California Central Coast’s biodiversity protection gap between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This will protect the only eelgrass bed in a 300-mile stretch of coast; many historic Chumash sites, including Lisamu’ (Morro Rock); numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds; the highest population of Southern sea otters on the California coast; several State Marine Conservation Areas; and the kelp forests and rocky intertidal habitats considered to be some of the most diverse and abundant in the world.
Offshore Wind. While a source of renewable energy, Offshore Wind (OSW) farms will have environmental impacts on habitat, wildlife, and water quality. California’s first OSW projects adjacent to the sanctuary should be planned and sited to avoid or mitigate impacts to sensitive marine areas and species and important cultural resources. The National Marine Sanctuary Program should work closely with state and federal partners, OSW companies, Tribes, and community members to ensure future OSW is developed in the most environmentally and culturally responsible manner.
Water Quality. The CHNMS should prohibit oil and gas exploration, development and production; phase out existing fossil fuel infrastructure and leases; reduce land and ocean-based pollution; and partner with the local communities to improve conservation of the Central Coast.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Dziak, John
Comment:
I am writing to express strong support for the proposal to 
designate and protect the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
I care very much about ocean ecosystems and wildlife and am very
worried about the threats they have been facing and the 
inadequate protection they have received in the past. 
Kelp forests and whale habitat are especially important to me.
I am delighted that this action is being considered to help protect
the vital and highly threatened ecosystems of our Pacific coast,
and also that it is being done in conjunction with Native American 
tribal authorities in order to protect sacred cultural and religious
sites from desecration.  Thank you very much for your consideration 
to protect these sacred and beautiful places, as well as the ecological, 
environmental and economic benefits they provide, from harm.

Title: Comment from SLO Climate Coalition
Comment:
SLO Climate Coalition supports the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The waters off Central California provide critical habitat for whales, otters, shellfish, and many other species. These waters are highly vulnerable to human impacts, and this threat is heightened by climate change. Protecting biodiversity in the ocean is essential for storing carbon dioxide, providing oxygen, and regulating our climate and weather patterns. The establishment of a sanctuary will halt the threats of offshore oil expansion, acoustic testing, and provide funding for local marine research.
The SLO Climate Coalition supports:the largest possible contiguous boundaries as seen in the Initial Boundary alternative combined with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alternative 5b). This would provide the most protection and provide connectivity with the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary;equitable collaborative management that includes all interested local Tribal groups; andoffshore wind development further offshore where wind is optimal and ecological and cultural impacts can be reduced.SLO Climate Coalition urges the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to protect the ocean for the benefit and enjoyment of current and future generations.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from San Luis Obispo Mothers for Peace
Comment:
San Luis Obispo Mothers for Peace supports the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The ocean waters off the Central Coast of California provide crucial habitat for a great variety of species. These waters and living creatures are highly vulnerable to human impacts, and this threat is heightened by climate change and the operation of Diablo Canyon Nuclear Plant. 

Protecting biodiversity in the ocean is essential for storing carbon dioxide, providing oxygen, and regulating our climate and weather patterns. The establishment of a sanctuary will halt the threats of offshore oil expansion, acoustic testing, and provide funding for local marine research. Once Diablo Canyon is shut down, the sanctuary will help mitigate the tremendous damage caused by decades of operation: thermal pollution, impingement and entrainment, discharge of toxic materials, and the very large impacts from decommissioning. 

Mothers for Peace supports:

the largest possible contiguous boundaries as seen in the Initial Boundary alternative combined with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alternative 5b). This would provide the most protection and provide connectivity with the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary;

equitable collaborative management that includes all interested local Tribal groups; and

offshore wind development further offshore where wind is optimal and ecological and cultural impacts can be reduced.

Mothers for Peace urges the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Wolfe, Shaun
Comment: Although I have moved away, I am still a frequent coastal recreator on the central coast and I strongly support the designation of a new national marine sanctuary off the central California coast. This designation should be named Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in recognition of the history and culture of the Chumash people. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should be officially designated as soon as possible. The sanctuary boundaries should include the full geographic extent reflected in the original proposal - i.e., the Initial Boundary Alternative - as well as the Gaviota Coast Extension (5B) boundary option. The management plan should ensure the lasting protection of the sanctuary’s outstanding ecological and cultural resources. The sanctuary should prohibit any oil and gas exploration, development or production. The sanctuary should prohibit seabed mining, ocean dumping and other activities damaging to the seafloor, cultural resources and marine ecosystem. The sanctuary should protect water quality from pollution sources including cruise ships, commercial vessels and agricultural runoff. Indigenous Collaborative Management should be applied in an equitable manner to empower the Chumash Nation and other Indigenous Peoples to steward these invaluable resources. The sanctuary should support and promote marine research, education, stewardship, recreation and tourism.

As a resident I strongly believe Morro Rock and it’s vicinity is a unique and cherished part of America that needs protection and should be included in the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Please, this decision is greatly important to the protection of Morro Rock and the significant and abundant animal species and specifically the land area at Morro Rock.

Title: Comment from Brown, Marty
Comment:
My name is Marty Brown and I have lived in San Luis Obispo County for 55 years.  I am writing this for my grandchildren and their future families. It is essential for us here today to protect our beautiful coastal waters. There are many threats to sea life, wildlife and water quality and our economy including but not limited to oil drilling and other resource mining. The cultural heritage of the Native People who have lived on our Coast for thousands of years must be preserved.
Additionally, scientific research could bring grant money for study on climate change, medicine, habitat loss, wave energy and much more. The sanctuary would be compatible with commercial and recreational fishing, protecting our water quality and sustainability. San Luis Obispo's coastline provides essential habitat for everything from shorebirds to aquatic animals like dolphins and migrating whales to hundreds of fish species including salmon, rock fish, cod, sole and swordfish.
The local economy would thrive with millions of dollars brought in by tourism, jobs, recreational and educational opportunities
in many languages.
It is essential that in managing the Sanctuary that all local tribal groups who want to be are invited to be involved in collaboration 
with a NOAA Tribal Liaison. 
Please designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. This is the Dream of the large majority of Central Coast residents and a positive move on all fronts. Future generations will be thankful.

Title: Comment from Bennett, Tim
Comment:
When I moved my family here two decades ago and built a home on top of Prefumo Canyon with views of Morro Bay, I was told I could not build on certain areas due to Chumash artifacts.

I honored those relics and was proud to point out to guests how the Chumash used serpentine rocks to grind grain for food. 

Today, I feel the same way about honoring the marine sanctuary and continuing the legacy of environmental stewardship.

I support the Initial Boundary Alternative and the Gaviota Coast Extension as the sanctuary boundaries.

Thank you,

Tim Bennett

Please designate the sanctuary as it was originally proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), as well as the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b), so that there is protection for the waters between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. 
This sanctuary offers the opportunity to elevate Indigenous perspectives and cultural values, honoring the history and culture of the Native Americans who have inhabited this region for more than 10,000 years.
This sanctuary should protect the area from harmful oil and gas development and reduce water pollution in Sanctuary waters by preventing excess runoff of sediments, oils, pesticides, nutrients, and pathogens.
The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should ensure that Offshore Wind operations and construction are completed through the guidelines of the new Sanctuary. These projects should be planned and authorized in a way that avoids and mitigates impacts to sensitive marine areas, species, and important cultural areas. 

In a time when so many choose profit over the planet, please sustain this environment for the future.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Wellspring, Andy
Comment: Dear NOAA staff, I am writing to express my support for the creation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I think the name is important to include Chumash because it honors the people who have tended this area the longest, and it is still their area today. I believe that co-management with Tribes, or collaborative management, whatever the Tribes want and whatever they want to call it, should be implemented because CA Tribes have the most knowledge of the waters and lands and have proven to the world that they know how to take care of it better than the industrial California/United States society which has only polluted and overfished it. The Traditional Ecological Knowledge of tribal people is real and it is beyond time for our society to respect it and the people who hold it and wish to use it in the ecosystems again. I support the creation of this marine sanctuary because I have grown up and lived in California in the Bay Area and now Mendocino County, in Fort Bragg. I have always appreciated the beauty of the CA coast and have never moved away! I grew up visiting friends in Santa Barbara and I learned about the history of oil spills there and the threat that more offshore oil drilling may be added there, and I support this sanctuary as a way to protect the ocean and coastline from more pollution than it has already experienced. Oil and gas development must be fully excluded and banned from the sanctuary, or it will just be a false sanctuary. I urge you to adopt the largest possible boundary for this sanctuary, including the Gaviota Coast Extension under consideration, because the more ocean and seamounts we can protect the better. Animals need habitat to survive, and they need as much as possible given how much has been tainted and damaged by the United States/California society. The Rodriguez Seamount in particular is one I have read about, please include it in the sanctuary because it is such a crucial location for supporting biodiversity within this ocean ecosystem. Thank you, Andy Wellspring
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Moir, Megan
Comment: The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is a vital step toward preserving the rich biodiversity and cultural heritage of California’s coastline. This area is home to a remarkable diversity of marine life, including whales, dolphins, sea otters and countless species of fish and seabirds. These waters also hold immense cultural significance for the Chumash people, whose ancestral connections to the ocean stretch back millennia. I support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in its original design as it was proposed by the Chumash people. Thank you.

Title: Comment from Shore, Richard
Comment: I grew up in the desert in California and as a youth visited the coastline of this proposed protected area for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. When I later studied at marine stations in California and North Carolina I came to understand even better that protecting the oceans is extremely important to all of us even those of us living far from the ocean.  We need clear and meaningful management and implementation of the sanctuary. Given that the Chumash tribe, among other tribes, have been the primary keepers and sustainers of these waters and the lands that are along the coast, we must first look to them for comment and input on this draft management plan and future management plans. It is so important that we preserve these unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. I ask that you respect the Northern Chumash Tribal Council requests regarding sanctuary boundary, the sanctuary name, tribal collaborative management, outreach and education, Rodriguez Seamount, offshore wind and water quality. Thank you for your work on this immediate need to preserve this treasure.

Title: Comment from Andrews, Betsy
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Betsy Andrews and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Brooklyn, NY and to me, and I am a poet. My second book, The Bottom, was written on California's Central Coast, and it is about the coast. I have a deep love of and history with the area that would be covered under the sanctuary, and as a scuba diver diving regularly in the Channel Islands (our family keeps a boat on the coast to go out there), I have seen the Pacific change so much over the years. I know that marine sanctuaries work, and I want to see the ocean healthy. I am also a food writer, finishing up a manuscript with chef Scott Clark from Half Moon Bay's Dad's Luncheonette. It is called Coastal, and it is an homage to the Central Coast of California, an area we would like seen protected forever.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension under the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”; an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management;
outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities; the protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity; and a prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,
Betsy Andrews

Title: Comment from Bettles, Sean
Comment:
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary!
Please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries.
This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.
Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.
Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from DeVries, Cameron
Comment:
I live on the Central Coast of California and I am happy that this plan is going forward, however I feel very disheartened that the coasts bordering Morro Bay and Los Osos (roughly 2,000 square miles of ocean along a 30 mile stretch of coastline) are not included in the proposed NOAA marine sanctuary plan.  As Violet Sage Walker, chairwoman of the Northern Chumash Tribal Council, says: “There is so much biodiversity and critical habitat in that area."  

I often visit Morro Bay and Los Osos, an area that is rich with natural beauty and abundant wildlife.  This area is among the most beautiful stretches of oceanfront land in the world and it is home to many, many people who are actively concerned with protecting the environment and the oceans.  I personally feel that it would be highly beneficial to include the coastline near Morro Bay in the final plan for the NOAA marine sanctuary.  This is an area that is treasured for its unique, diverse, and stunning natural beauty, and it deserves to have its coastal areas placed under official protection for years to come.  In my opinion, adding the 30 mile stretch of coastline, including the areas bordering Morro Bay and Los Osos, to the marine sanctuary plan, would be an important gift to future generations; a symbol of respect to a natural environment that is both beautiful and vital to the sustaining of many types of wildlife.  

Please consider adding the Morro Bay coast to the proposed marine sanctuary plan.  
Thank you!

Title: Comment from Starr, Lisa

My name is Lisa, long time resident of Santa Barbara. My 2 main concerns are: 
1. Increased human impact upon opening up this area for visitors. I would prefer to have the fewest number of people in this area as possible. As we all know, human foot traffic, boats of any kind, powered by people or motors, and sunscreens in the water due to swimming (to name a few), greatly and negatively impact the natural order and balance of ecosystems. 
2. Oil drilling, spills and seepage. I would like to be guaranteed that no deals will be made, and no exemptions to protective federal laws related to drilling or oil exploration or any marine mammal protection acts etc.

Title: Comment from Madeja , Jamy
Comment: This comment supports the final designation of the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary to cover the largest possible contiguous boundaries, including the designation of the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alternative 5b), also inclusive of the Morro Bay Estuary (Sub-Alternative 5a).  I am an Adjunct Professor at Northeastern School of Law and an environmental attorney in Boston.  The upwelling feature off of Morro Bay is of worldwide ecological significance. The nutrient and food source present are essential to marine life sustenance and the health of California National Marine Sanctuaries, UNESCO International Biosphere Reserve, and the network of State Marine Protected Areas. The only eelgrass bed in a 300-mile stretch is where villager seedlings emanate from, for example.  The largest boundary would close any gap otherwise allowing marine electrical transmission cables and hydrogen and ammonia pipelines, ruining the purpose of the Sanctuary given the constancy of leaks.  No peer-reviewed science can be identified by NOAA that supports any gap. The Chumash heritage culture of protection and co-existence at this highly revered sacred site, for thousands of years of Chumash Peoples, makes this an especially significant environmental justice decision to designate as broad and contiguous an area as possible.

Title: Comment from Hauer, Erin

I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
* Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
* Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” is incredibly important because it recognizes those who’ve been here for the longest and who’ve been the greatest stewards of our earth. It will also serve as an inspirational reminder to us all.

I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
A concerned and caring resident,
Erin Hauer

I am sure working for NOAA you realize as much as anyone that this is the correct course to take in preserving the coastal waters and land of California. Title: Comment from Wolny, Stacie
Comment:
As a resident of Campbell, California, I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, specifically the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.

After several centuries of horrible extraction and pollution, our ocean and shores need some serious and dedicated protection, for the respect and recovery of the diversity of sea life that remains, which also supports human life both directly and indirectly in so many ways. This is why the Sanctuary should have the largest possible boundary, which would provide a critical link between the Monterey Bay and Channel Islands Sanctuaries. 

Meanwhile, it is long past time that we begin the process of reparations with the Tribes whose land and waters were stolen and exploited to create this country. The most important thing to me about this marine sanctuary is that it not be in name only, although naming it after Chumash (and Salinan?) is very important. There must be true collaboration and partnership with Chumash and other involved Tribes, them leading the way with their millennia of experience stewarding this area, fully supported by us and all related government agencies. Their sacred sites must be honored, and visitors educated about the deep history and wisdom between people and place, which can help us all get on a much more connected, and sustainable, path for the future.

Also, if this is indeed a "sanctuary", it seems obvious that no oil and gas development should be allowed within its boundaries (really, no new oil and gas development should be allowed anywhere), nor should acoustic testing/pollution be allowed, which does great harm to underwater resident communication. If wind energy is located in the vicinity, it must be done in such a way that it does no harm to the seafloor or other features and creatures. I also completely support the prohibition of introducing or otherwise releasing an introduced species into the sanctuary, and there should be no exemption for striped bass. There should also be no exemption for DoD activities, they are already one of the greatest polluters and destroyers in the world, and we must finally stand up to them and force them to change their ways. In general, Tribes should be the ones deciding which activities are appropriate within this Sanctuary, to ensure the rebalancing and thriving of these ecosystems into the future. 

Thank you for moving this proposal forward, and committing to the future of Tribal co-management, which is critical for our healing as a nation.

Title: Comment from Ober, Holly
Comment:
I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

Title: Comment from Coronado , Robert
Comment: I fully support NOAA making permanent the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. By designating this area a marine sanctuary will preserve from development and pollution California’s Central Coast’s marine ecosystems. By NOAA permanently designating this area as a Federal marine sanctuary will improve the quality of the marine environment for generations to come, improve the health of fishing areas within the sanctuary, and save marine and cultural diverse features of the area from human-made threats. California’s Chumash people have been caretakers of the marine and land ecosystems for millennia. By naming this marine sanctuary in their honor will be recognition that is long overdue. The adverse impact by designating this as a National Marine Sanctuary will be minimal on marine industries, especially the oil and gas extraction industries.

Title: Comment from Gallardo, Rebeka
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Rebeka "Bii" Gallardo and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Los Angeles, California, and to me, as an Indigenous youth, the ocean is my relative. I am Yaqui born and raised in Tongva territory and throughout my life I lived also in Chumash territory. The west coast will always be my home, in this lifetime, and ancestrally. The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:
- Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
- Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
- Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
- Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
- Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
- Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

Rebeka "Bii" Gallardo

Title: Comment from Altman, Rachel
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Rachel Altman and I am the administrator for the Santa Barbara Standing Rock Coalition. I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Santa Barbara, CA and to me, the ocean is an important resource for relaxation, exercise, beauty and a way to connect with nature. I often meet friends to walk or swim on one of our treasured beaches. When my daughter and granddaughters were young, we would take them frequently so they could delight in the beauty and the spell cast by the ocean. It was a way to foster a healthy respect for nature in them.
The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our tourism and fishing industries rely on the ocean for their economic health.
More importantly, the ocean has been a source of food and sacred rituals of the Indigenous Chumash who were here long before the rest of us came. I want to protect this stretch of ocean so our entire community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
 A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,
Rachel Altman
1383 Sycamore Canyon Road, SB, CA 93108
raltmansb@gmail.com

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I first moved to santa barbara in 1967 and began surfing here in 1968. 
The proposed plan would NOT support ocean dependent economies; it would only protect fishes, etc. So I am NOT for this plan. With 50 tribal members worth way more than $150 million, they do not need the money as they are running a casino daily. They do not need the publicity either as people are well aware of Native Americans in the area. The tribe should give back money to the community that surrounds it.
Thank you.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from McKaughan, Gaelila
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Gaelila McKaughan and I support the quick designation of Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I’m a student at UCSD studying marine ecology at the Scripps Institute, and I’ve seen firsthand the importance of community involvement in ocean conservation. People want clean safe and lively oceans, preserving the biodiversity of the seas that support and enrich their local communities.

For the sanctuary, I support the Gaviota Coast Extension of the boundary, involvement of local tribes in collective management, and prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries. It’s so important, now more than ever, to protect our oceans biodiversity and ensure clean oceans for generations to come. This has to be a collective effort with the peoples that live and care for these environments the most, in order for this to be a sustainable and long lasting agreement. 

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Best,
Gaelila McKaughan
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Brajkovich, Troy
Comment:
I’m am a native of Cayucos, California. I would like to thank you for the opportunity to comment on the Chumash Heritage NMS. It’s very important to me that these waters are protected. As a surfer and diver who has been influenced deeply by these waters I express my support for the Sanctuary designation. I have also come to learn about the designated area has been re-drafted to redact the area of Morro Bay, Cayucos and Cambria. I would like to beg that you reinstate this area as part of the sanctuary. It’s the most important area for peregrine falcons, whales, sea otters, and Morro rock is sacred to the Chumash people. Not including this area in the sanctuary is clearly a decision made for industrial and political benefit, and must not be allowed. It will be a shame on NOAA for allowing influence from industry determine the fate of an environmentally important region. 
I support the naming of the sanctuary: the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Leaders and Members of the Northern Chumash Tribal Council have campaigned for over 40 years to establish the proposed Chumash Heritage NMS. Let’s keep the rich natural phenomenon that is this coast pure for future generations. The ocean is already in peril. Please protect what remains. 

Thank you,
Troy Brajkovich

Title: Comment from Curtis, Kathleen
Comment:
As a resident of the central Coast, I support the designation of the largest possible area for the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean. The proposed marine sanctuary is critically important for the future of our Central Coast region, which is rich with marine life and cultural significance.  However, the boundary of the sanctuary will most benefit our region and wildlife if contiguous with the southern border of the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary.  The ocean area between Point Buchon and Cambria is a critical habitat and migration corridor for many species that will only thrive with the same protections as sanctuary areas to the south. The attached letter details my concerns. and proposed solutions. Thank you for the opportunity to comment and for your actions in support of this important initiative.  
Kathleen A. Curtis
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Baikie, Heidi
Comment: I support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and urge NOAA to adopt the Initial Boundary and the Gaviota Coast Extension as the sanctuary boundaries. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sancturary (which the above boundaries) would create such a vital protection area as our oceans face rapid warming and acidification. Our oceans are key in the fight against climate change--this sanctuary would do that as well as protect many species and protect an area of cultural significance for the Chumash people. This area has been important to the Chumash people for much longer than any of us Europeans have been around on North America. It's time to steward the land and oceans and other waterways like our Indigenous citizens have for millennia. We can fully reverse climate change--and every step we take to slow the heating of the planet, the degradation of the waterways, and extinction of species is a positive step. By making sure this is a larger Marine Sanctuary, we can protect more and have a more positive impact environmentally and culturally. Thank yoiu, Heidi Baikie

Title: Comment from Sinker, Mary
Comment:
The proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would extend a corridor of protection between Monterey Bay and the Channel Islands for seabirds (both resident and migratory) and marine mammals like southern sea otters and endangered blue whales.

Several species of albatross, Western Snowy Plovers, and Brown Pelicans are just a few of the birds using these kelp rich waters, coastal dunes, and adjoining wetlands. 

Together with the Northern Chumash Tribal Council, NOAA can make this proposed new National Marine Sanctuary a reality.

Title: Comment from Twigg, Lindsey
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Lindsey Twigg and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I currently live in New York but was born and raised on the Southern California coast. To me, the ocean is a vital living relative. When I visit the coast, I visit a vast grandmother whose wisdom, comfort, and vastness is crucial to the vitality of our way of life. It is my sincere desire that we, as proud Californians, learn to live in right relationship with both land and sea. For me, that means protecting the vast ecosystem that is currently under threat by further development.

I vigorously support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge NOAA to honor the original plan to include biggest possible boundary (The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension). I ask that it be properly named the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary so as to honor our land and sea defenders who have worked tirelessly to protect their ocean relatives. I also as that an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management so that present and future Chumash members may restore their relationship to the ocean, and by extension, perhaps teach us how to better be in right relation with Mother Ocean. Perhaps most importantly, I also urge you to prohibit new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries. New developments of fossil fuels would effectively nullify the purpose and name of sanctuary, effect further harm upon the Native Tribes involved, and render this project effectively useless.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Lindsey Twigg

Title: Comment from Nathanson, Christine
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Christine Nathanson, a graduate of Westmont College, and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I’ve lived near the California coast my entire life, whether north, south, or somewhere in between. To me, the ocean is a precious life-giving source that Indigenous peoples in most cases have been unfairly and unjustly severed from.

When I go to the coast, I explore tide pools for tiny creatures, play ukulele on the warm sand for my friends, or simply listen to the crashing waves in meditation. The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Christine Nathanson

Title: Comment from Kaiser, Channing
Comment:
To whom it may concern:

I am writing in regard to the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

I live in Morro Bay and work as an outdoor education director up in Cambria. When the proposed boundaries for the Sanctuary were released, I was surprised and disappointed that the area between Morro Bay and Cambria--two places I know and value dearly--was not included. 

As an outdoor education director, I oversee programming that reaches approximately 2,000 kids a year. Some are local and some are coming from landlocked states such as Colorado to see and experience the California coast. Something we discuss at length in our programming is sustainability and the importance of healthy ecosystems. We talk about overhunting and the enormous decline in abalone populations, we discuss ochre stars and their importance as a keystone species, we have students reflect on why it's so important to experience wilderness and care about it. We try to give our students hope for a vibrant and ecologically rich future in the face of so much climate change.

Something we also discuss is how western scientists and settlers frequently try to implement ideas with good intentions, and then sometimes how they go wildly wrong. Like ice plant, for example, a plant that was introduced to help curb erosion and is now a spreading disaster up and down the coast. People genuinely believed that introducing this plant would be helpful, but it turned out to be detrimental to the ecosystem and native species.

I worry that this is also true of the proposed wind turbine area off the coast, which is the primary reason stated that the stretch from Morro to Cambria was not included. None of the research or details released by any organization convinces me that we know enough about the turbines to confidently say that no harm will come to the ocean and the ecosystem. We've seen enough oceanic and environmental disasters, and we should be thoughtful about proceeding cautiously. From the back deck of our dining facility, guests and staff often sit out with binoculars to watch the whale migration. What about the whales? We have absolutely no idea what the turbine field will do to their migration patterns, a natural ritual that humans only loosely comprehend.

Besides ecological concern, I am deeply disappointed that NOAA did not heed Indigenous concerns. Both the Chumash and Salinan tribes, the native peoples of these lands, have expressed support for the Sanctuary and concern about the wind turbines. Our nation has an ugly history of ignoring native concerns and stripping the once rich land of resources. In 2023, it is embarrassing, insulting, and racist to completely dismiss these people's concerns. Governmental agencies have a sordid history of performative inclusion, often only consulting or including native voices when it benefits them and when native tribes aren't asking for too much. Why are we continuing to do this? To only uplift native people when it is helpful for our own agenda, to only listen to them when it's convenient for us and when it already aligns with our plans? The United States of America has a gross and violent history with indigenous peoples, and it is hard to fathom that we are still acting out of hubris and individualism despite all of the devastation we've caused. Will we ever learn?

This feels like an incredible opportunity to celebrate native voices and ecological diversity, to act in ways that people don't expect of the government and other national agencies. In this political climate, there is so little hope and good news, and it feels like the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary is a proposal that could unite and protect communities and ecosystems. What an opportunity to listen and learn from past mistakes.

I hope NOAA will consider the boundaries of the sanctuary to respect indigenous voices and to prevent future ecological disasters.

Sincerely,
Channing Kaiser

Title: Comment from Punch, Betsy
Comment:
Dear Esteemed NOAA folks,

I am writing to ask that the Chumash Marine Sanctuary be enshrined in as large an area as possible, to reflect the coastal regions where the Chumash and other native groups have made their homes for millennia. This is of such great importance for both conservation and for taking a significant step towards repair of the harm that was done, over centuries, to those indigenous inhabitants. Please honor the wishes of the descendants of the first nations people of the central coast! As a 40 year resident of the Monterey Bay area, and an admirer of the enormously significant work that NOAA does, I am grateful for your time and have high hopes for the enlarged Chumash marine sanctuary.

Kind regards,

Betsy Punch
Pacific Grove

Title: Comment from Walters, Alta
Comment: And they call it the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. After decades of tribal efforts to protect the marine environment of their native land, NOAA, having worked with the tribe, now turns its back on those efforts and leaves the very area the Chumash sought to protect outside of the boundaries of the Marine Sanctuary which will bear their tribal name. It's a betrayal--and a failure to truly work with the tribe and others to maximize the benefits of the proposed Sanctuary. Most gallingly, the failure to include this sacred shore will result in even more persistent efforts to exploit it--including efforts at oil and gas development. No one disputes the need to maximize alternative energy in a climate changing world--and that appears to be the crux of the problem--the area is slated for off-shore wind development. But we need not trade one problematic form of energy for another, and we certainly don't need to do that on the backs of our indigenous neighbors. This proposed map represents a failure of consensus. It is, apparently, a nod acknowledging that the environmental safety of off-shore wind farms has not been proven. What will the effect be on the endangered otter population? What about migrating whales? The California Coast is a veritable highway of migrating marine life, you cannot carve out one area to exploit and pretend it does not have an impact on the remaining sanctuary ecosystems. The solution is more science, more study and finding engineering solutions to make renewables truly the 'safe' energy we all desperately need. This proposed carve-out, leaving the Chumash concerns on the cutting room floor, while using their name as if these boundaries really addressed their concerns, is a slap in the face and a continuation of centuries of betrayal of the indigenous people of this continent. There is an easy fix--do the work. At a minimum, grant the disputed area protection from oil and gas development, make off-shore wind facilities do the science and mitigate their negative impact. Certainly we cannot exploit the Chumash name, and their decades of effort, without protecting the very concerns that brought them to the table in the first place.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Cheek, Sandy
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,		
						 
My name is Sandy Cheek and I spent twenty years working in water quality for the California State Water Resources Control Board. I fully support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension. I know intimately the fragility of our ecosystems, and it is with that background that I strongly urge protection of Rodriguez Seamount as essential to protect biodiversity.
We must include the North Coast and Cambria south through Morro Bay. During the previous presidential administration, our former leader halted new designations and wanted to take an inventory of resources, proposing oil leases off the central California coast. At that time, my colleagues and I found the only way to utilize NOAA’s public comment site was to access it in the wee hours of the morning, because during any other time the site would fail. This experience had an almost sinister feel back then, leaving many unable to exercise their collective voice. In the shadow of this, we request the Initial Boundary Alternative with a prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

Without sanctuary protection, these North Coast waters are left vulnerable to industrialization that will impact the environment and further impact the character of this special area. Think for a moment about what your children and grandchildren’s experience of the North Coast might be twenty years from now. I find it interesting that when speaking with locals, many informed fishermen want Morro Bay to be included. They are concerned about potential damage to their livelihood. 

I have studied the Tribal engagement issue and believe it is necessary and certainly appropriate to include the nominators (and other tribes and tribal organizations) in the collaborative management of the sanctuary. I believe the proposed name, Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, is appropriate considering the 15,000-years that the Chumash people lived on land that is now submerged beneath the waters of the proposed sanctuary, and the work of Tribal Chair Fred Collins, the original sanctuary nominator who tirelessly campaigned for over 40 years with other members of the Northern Chumash Tribal Council to establish this sanctuary, until his passing in 2022.

I live in Arroyo Grande, CA, was born and raised near the Pacific Ocean, and feel a deep connection to these waters. My free time is usually spent in, on, or around the water, as an avid kayaker, beach goer, sailor, and ocean swimmer. Just the other day, I swam with dolphins and seals off the central coast, while watching whales breach in the distance. I am blessed to say that this is something I experience relatively often. We need to protect our North Coast waters, species migration routes, and all ocean beneficial uses for present and future generations.

Sincerely,

Sandy Cheek
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Zegarra, Terence
Comment:
As a coastal recreation user, I strongly support the designation of a new National Marine Sanctuary off the central California coast. In my opinion, this designation should be named the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in recognition of the history and culture of the Chumash people.
The size, location and other features of the sanctuary should be consistent with the official proposal submitted to NOAA by the Northern Chumash Tribal Council in 2015. Sanctuary designation will empower the Chumash Nation and local communities to work with federal and state partners to protect this vital stretch of coastal and marine waters. The designation will also stimulate marine research, education, stewardship, recreation and tourism. 
The proposed Chumash Heritage NMS is essential for the protection of the heritage of the Chumash, an ocean-going band among the First People of the Pacific Coast, and submerged Chumash Sacred sites ranging from villages to solstice alignments. 

Please follow through with your mission statement and help conserve and manage coastal and marine ecosystems and resources.

Title: Comment from R, J
Comment:
To Whom it May Concern,
I am writing to express my support of the proposed Chumash marine sanctuary that would connect the protected waters of Northern and Southern California. As someone who grew up in San Luis Obispo County, this proposed sanctuary has been on the back burner far too long. Let me be brief. 
The Monterey sanctuary and the Channel Islands sanctuary have already shown that creating a marine sanctuary increases the health of the ocean in those areas. Additionally, people who rely on the ocean for income prefer regulated waters because it ensures stable populations of fish and marine life. The stretch of coastline between Ventura and Monterey is home to many iconic forms of wildlife that deserve protection from human intervention.
Furthermore, the Chumash people were stewards of this land far before colonial settlers upended their way of life. The colonization of Native Americans caused the erasure of their cultures. This proposed sanctuary would be a step towards visibility for the Chumash and other Native Nations— a way to show that Native people still exist and they are still trying to protect the home that was taken from them.
In conclusion, I am in support of the creation of Chumash heritage marine sanctuary because it would benefit the health and livelihoods of not just marine life but human life as well. 

Sincerely,
A concerned citizen

Title: Comment from Parsons, Nancy
Comment: I support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary(CHNMS) in it's entirety.  I live in Pacific Grove next to the Monterey Bay National Marine Sactuary. I have witnessed personally the remarkable comeback of the bay after the poluting canneries left and the bay became a sanctuary.  Once the bay was protected I saw the return of whales, sea lions, dolphins, and otters.  Seabiards have come back such as oystercatcher, pelicans, cormorants, etc. Adding the CHNMS would close the 7,000 square miles of ocean gap between the Monterey and Santa Barbara coasts, thus providing protections for the sea life that lives there and migrates through. Please honor the Northern Chumash Tribal Council by protecting their ancient home-land and allow them to co-manage the sanctury.  Please do the right thing and approve this sanctuary in it's entirety and DO NOT shrink it for an industrial corridor.  Thank you for your consideration,  Nancy Ponedel Parsons

Title: Comment from Manfredini, Rebecca
Comment:
My name is Rebecca Manfredini and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension.
This option would cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean and best protect biodiversity and fragile marine habitats.
Last year, I moved to Cambria, where I hike along the ocean on a daily basis and began volunteering as a docent with Friends of the Elephant Seal. My husband and I cherish the natural beauty of the Central Coast and strongly encourage the full protection of this globally significant ecological area.
To best protect the coast, I ask that this sanctuary ban oil and gas development within these delicate waters. I also strongly encourage that Traditional Ecological Knowledge is employed as part of a collaborative management approach with the Indigenous peoples of this area.
Furthermore, I encourage more comprehensive studies of any potential impacts on air quality and wildlife within the sanctuary area from offshore wind power development, both during the construction and operational phases of the project. My fear is that this part of the coast could essentially be industrialized without fully understanding the impacts, and, that by leaving a large gap in the National Marine Sanctuary system along the California coast, this area between Cambria and Point Buchon will be vulnerable to a variety of harmful development activities. 
I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to help protect this area so that future generations can also enjoy the natural beauty, abundant wildlife, and serenity that we have come to cherish. We also hope that any and all Chumash cultural sites receive full and adequate protections.
Sincerely,
Rebecca A. Manfredini
Cambria
