Title: Comment from Piffero , Laura
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Laura Piffero from the Te-Moak Bands of the Western Shoshone Nation.  I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Chandler, Arizona] and to me, the ocean is sacred to all Native People.

Water is life and death, strength, change, healing, dreaming, and unconditional love.

When I go to the west coast, me and my children find peace and serenity.  The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.
I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.

The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: [share what you want to see in the sanctuary designation, using the messaging guidance below]

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,
Laura Piffero
Western Shoshone
Elko, Nevada
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Jaffe, Matthew
Comment:
My name is Matthew Jaffe and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension.
This option would cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean and best protect biodiversity and fragile marine habitats.
Last year, I moved to Cambria, where I hike along the ocean on a daily basis. I am a writer and worked as a newspaper reporter in Lompoc during the 1980s and have written extensively about the Central Coast, both as a onetime staff writer at Sunset Magazine and as an independent journalist. I have also written a number of articles about California’s Indigenous peoples
My wife and I cherish the natural beauty and cultural heritage of the Central Coast and strongly support the full protection of this globally significant ecological area.
To best protect the coast, I ask that this sanctuary ban oil and gas development within these delicate waters. I also strongly encourage that Traditional Ecological Knowledge is employed as part of a collaborative management approach with the Indigenous peoples of this area.
Furthermore, I encourage far more comprehensive studies of the many potential impacts on air quality and wildlife within the sanctuary area from offshore wind power development, both during the construction and operational phases of the project. My fear is that a globally significant section of the coast could essentially be industrialized without a true and full understanding of what could turn out to be major impacts on this rare marine environment. And, that by leaving a large gap in the National Marine Sanctuary system along the California coast, the area between Cambria and Point Buchon will be vulnerable to a variety of harmful development activities that could severely degrade both marine and onshore environments.
In closing, I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, as originally envisioned, to best protect the area so that future generations can, like us, savor the natural beauty, abundant wildlife, and serenity that we have come to cherish. We also hope that any and all Chumash cultural sites receive full and adequate protections.
Sincerely,
Matthew Jaffe
Cambria

Title: Comment from May, Cybele

I moved to San Luis Obispo County only a year ago, but have been visiting here for more than 25 years, because of the unspoiled Pacific Coast which nurtures amazing kelp forests, the seagrass beds of the Morro Bay Estuary, migrating birds, whales, elephant seals and otters. This is a treasure that we have a responsibility to protect. Our other California marine sanctuaries have been shown to be economically and ecologically beneficial to our state, country and planet. Let's continue to be good stewards. 

I support the establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary using the largest possible contiguous sanctuary boundaries, as shown in the Initial Boundary Alternative combined with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alternative 5b). I think it's vitally important to link our marine sanctuaries. Our desire for wind power is to be respected, and permits can be created with greater oversight than if we left out that part of the coast of Morro Bay up to San Simeon.

Title: Comment from Moore, Lorna
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Lorna Moore and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Santa Barbara, California.  The ocean should not be a place to build things, it should remain untouched by man.  The ocean produces oxygen, provides fish to eat, and creates beautiful beaches and coastlines.  We need to protect it.

Title: Comment from Dominguez, Dinah
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is dinah dominguez and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Los Angeles, CA and to me, the ocean is an important part of our ecosystem in Southern California. We should follow the leadership and stewardship of indigenous communities like the Chumash who are telling us the best ways to care for the land and ocean.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
* Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
* Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
* Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
* Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
* Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
* Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,
Dinah Dominguez

Title: Comment from Won, Sabine
Comment:
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. The preservation of ocean life is vital for the preservation of humankind.

This national marine sanctuary will be the first Tribally Nominated Sanctuary, preserving marine and cultural resources along 156 miles of Central California Coastline. It will help address the global biodiversity crisis and accelerate nature-based solutions through inclusive partnerships and collaboration among federal, state and local governments, and California Native American Tribes.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with a prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries and the protection of Rodriguez Seamount. Thank you for taking care of the sea!

Sabine Won

Title: Comment from Merrill, James
Comment:
I enthusiastically support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, uniting marine sanctuaries and National Park designations up and down the coast. I also favor the innovative co-management plan with indigenous people who have been in that area since long before European contact.

My one reservation is the limitation on offshore wind generation. The ability of our planet to support life as we currently experience it is in a moment of existential crisis, and I believe that the ability to generate renewable energy to replace carbon-based energy should not be as restricted as currently planned.

Title: Comment from Whitaker, Regina
Comment:
I support the designation of the CHNMS with the largest possible contiguous boundaries, the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alt 5b), because it would provide the most protection to this important area. I do not support NOAA’s Alternatives 2, 3, and 4 because they would not protect a critical area of coastline that contains important Chumash cultural sites, marine habitat, and local communities.

I further support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary name. It is meant to recognize people that have lived on this coast for over 10,000 years; to protect the heritage of the Chumash, an ocean-going band among the First People of the Pacific Coast; and provide a timely and appropriate reminder of the cultural origins. I further support equitable inclusion of all Central Coast Tribes, both federally and non-federally recognized Tribes, in collaborative management. All sanctuary stakeholders will benefit from Indigenous input.

The CHNMS provides an exceptional opportunity to advance the first Tribal-nominated national marine sanctuary designation in the U.S., setting a precedent for elevating Indigenous perspectives, cultural values in ocean conservation, and Indigenous collaborative management that includes all Central Coast tribes equitably. 

I appreciate the designation of a marine sanctuary honoring the history and culture of Native Americans, specifically the Chumash people and their ancestors, known to have inhabited this region for more than 10,000 years. Thank you for providing me with the opportunity to contribute my thoughts on this important process.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from D, Rebecca
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Rebecca Delgado, and I wholeheartedly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. I believe it's of utmost importance to do so, and am excited that this could soon become a reality.

I live in Los Angeles, CA, and to me, the Chumash territory designation represents a crucial step forward both for the area's environment to thrive, as well as the designation area to thrive, recognizing the Chumash nation as an integral part of the area's past, present and future health. I also think it's an important example being set for other states to recognize and connect indigenous knowledge with the future health of our environment - the two are inseparable. 

When I go to the coast, I explore remote areas and observe the wildlife, get a welcome break from city life, and am always amazed by the wonder of nature and its resilience. Being in touch with nature in California has taught be about resilience, perseverance, spirituality, human life both past and present, and how similar we are to wildlife, plant life and the ocean. The ocean is important to be, and we depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Rebecca Delgado

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Maine Sanctuary. with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.  The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity.
I ask that this sanctuary include the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.”  Please include all tribal organizations in your decision making. Title: Comment from Zdenek, Bob
Comment:
Hello- My name is Bob Zdenek, and I am a resident of San Luis Obispo.  I am active in community development and sustainable development initiatives in both San Luis Obispo and the San Francisco Bay Area.  i am also a Docent for Friends of the Elephant Seals.
I want to applaud NOAA for striking the right balance with the proposed rules.  We need to balance the protection of the ocean and its creatures with the ability to generate more clean energy uses on the Central Coast.  I agree that Morro Bay and the surrounding area should not be part of the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary.  

Generating renewable wind energy is critical to addressing climate change.  We need the wind that can be generated from the Morro Bay area to enable us to benefit from wind energy as a primary renewable source of energy.  

We need both solar and wind for our future to reduce the devastating impact of a heated planet from fossil fuels.  Excessive heat disproportionally impacts low-income people of color, especially our farmworkers who are critical to our economy.  We have already seen a cutback on rooftop solar provisions led by the utility industry.  We need wind to offset the political challenges that the solar industry is facing. 

Again, I want to encourage NOAA to implement the proposed rules.  They are balanced on conversation and energy conversation.  Thank you for reviewing my comments.  Bob Zdenek

Title: Comment from Starkgraf, Valerie
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Valerie K. Starkgraf and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension (sub alternative 5b) to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Simi Valley, CA, and work in Ventura, CA and to me, the ocean is entirely vital to our lives on shore, and the kelp forest ecosystem is even more vital to preserve the health of our planet than the also vital protection of our terrestrial forests. It is the offshore equivalent of a rainforest. It is also vital for my personal spiritual health and well being. I’m a photographer, the Central Coast is my favorite place. I have pictures of this proposed sanctuary from shore that speak well of its beauty, sacredness, and vitality to Central Coast communities.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the biggest possible Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension. We need this sanctuary to be a true bridge between my local Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary and the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary to safeguard protections for Southern Sea Otter habitat, Northern Elephant Seal habitat, and other migratory species that use this corridor to breed and seasonally migrate between the two other sanctuaries. I ask that this sanctuary include the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary,” because without our tribal neighbors safeguarding this area of coast we would not have these resources to enjoy. I ask that there be an equitable approach to include all tribes in collaborative management, and that the outreach and education about this sanctuary include prioritization of Traditional Ecological Knowledge and access to local underserved communities. I ask for the protection of Rodriguez Seamount to protect regional biodiversity. It is a wildly unique geological feature and ecosystem feature we cannot afford to lose or mess up. I also ask for a ban on new oil and gas production within the sanctuary boundaries. This sanctuary should protect the area from harmful oil and gas development and reduce water pollution in Sanctuary waters by preventing excess runoff of sediments, oils, pesticides, nutrients, and pathogens.

I do support the wind farm, but I do not support taking scissors to the original proposed boundaries to cut a corridor for an end run around full environmental review for the cabling of that wind farm. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should ensure that Offshore Wind operations and construction are completed through the guidelines of the new Sanctuary. These projects should be planned and authorized in a way that avoids and mitigates impacts to sensitive marine areas, species, and important cultural areas.

We need the full bridge sanctuary, all of it, including Gaviota.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,

Valerie K. Starkgraf

Title: Comment from Carcovich, Andrea

Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Andrea Carcovich and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I am from Torrance, Ca and to me, the ocean is    the center of my universe. Because of the ocean there is a cool breeze at night that sweeps away the warmth of sunny days. Although my family does not have ancestry in California, my Croatian ancestors were fisherman and were able to survive for generations because of the oceans bounty.  My family are no longer fisherman but the ocean has always meant home to us. I have a son and I take him to the beach to enjoy the breeze and water and learn about the unique and precious California coast landscape, animals and environment.

A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 

I ask that this sanctuary includes:

-The Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension

-Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management

-The Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity 

-A Ban on Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries (of Most Importance)

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,

Andrea Carcovich

Title: Comment from Fellows, Jonathan
Comment:
I am an ex-scuba diver.  I have dived the central CA coast many times.  I'm not sure what restrictions on spear fishing and shell gathering will come with this sanctuary, but I feel there is a place for those activities.  

One concern of mine is that I've read restrictions on harassing marine life.  When I dived the coast at Cayucos, back when there were Abalone there, I was frequently bothered by sea otters who tried to get the Abalone out of my bag.  I was not harassing them - quite the opposite.  You need to be careful not to require no contact with marine life.  Its not always harmful or intentional.

Title: Comment from Hunt-Pierson, Lucy
Comment:
Dear NOAA,

We appreciate the opportunity to comment on the boundaries of the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary .

Mr. Paul Michels , NOAA's Regional Policy Coordinator for our area , commented that he "did not hear compelling arguments" regarding the inclusion of the coastline between Morro Bay and Cambria into the Sanctuary .  I find this confusing .  At the same time that this comment was made , NOAA has highlighted the fact that the industrialization of this zone "could increase ocean noise, change existing habitats, affect life cycles of fish , change species survival rates, and release contaminants that could be absorbed by marine life".  What we don't understand is how NOAA can substantiate these two conflicting statements ?

Title: Comment from Holkey, Sharon
Comment:
Sharon Holkey

October 21, 2023

Paul Michel
NOAA Sanctuaries
West Coast Regional Office
99 Pacific Street, 
Building 100F
Monterey, CA 93940

Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Sharon Holkey and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Los Angeles County in a beach town.  The ocean is my temple! I care deeply about it and all the sea life it inhabits as well as the benefits known and unknown it provides to us and Mother Earth as a whole.  I also believe in respecting our indigenous people’s ancestral lands and waters and to include them in the conversations as to how to properly maintain them for optimal health.  
I am also very concerned about the under water (wind mill) technology proposed to create green energy.  Do you know to what extent it will disrupt sea life?  I am all for developing green energy.  Are there better alternatives?
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes all listed below: 
1. The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.  
2. Tribal Collaborative Management- An equitable approach to include all Tribes in collaborative management. 
3. Outreach and Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge and access for local underserved communities. 
4. Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity.  
5. Ban oil and gas: A prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures. 


Sincerely yours,

Sharon Holkey

Title: Comment from Creation Justice Ministries
Comment:
Dear Regional Policy Coordinator Michel,

Our National Marine Sanctuaries need to be just that, sanctuaries. A space of care and comfort where all God’s creation can gather.  The ocean space nominated by the Northern Chumash Tribal Council to be a sanctuary, is just a formal acknowledgement of the care that the Northern Chumash and other tribes have given these waters for generations. We support the Northern Chumash in their continued care of God’s creation.

Specifically, we support the following recommendations of the Northern Chumash Tribal Council:

Sanctuary Boundary. It is vital that the sanctuary cover the largest possible contiguous boundaries. We support designation of the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alt 5b), including the waters offshore Point Buchon, Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria will close the California Central Coast’s biodiversity protection gap between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This will protect the only eelgrass bed in a 300-mile stretch of coast; many historic Chumash sites, including Lisamu’ (Morro Rock); numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds; the highest population of Southern sea otters on the California coast; several State Marine Conservation Areas; and the kelp forests and rocky intertidal habitats considered to be some of the most diverse and abundant in the world.

Sanctuary Name. Creation Justice Ministries specifically supports the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” to honor the cultural history and stewardship of California Tribal Peoples. The name will recognize Peoples that have lived on the California coast since time immemorial and protect the heritage of the Chumash, an ocean-going band among the First People of the Pacific Coast. We want to honor the late Chief Fred Collin’s nomination and vision for the sanctuary and the 10 years of work that the Northern Chumash Tribal Council did to campaign for the sanctuary.

Tribal Collaborative Management. The sanctuary is an opportunity to advance environmental justice efforts. Creation Justice Ministries asks that NOAA keep the sacred connection between ocean and community at the heart of this effort. The Sanctuary should teach the benefits of protecting our ocean and planet and promote the spirit of stewardship that is exemplified by the culture and history of the original Chumash caretakers.

We support equitable inclusion/representation of all Central Coast Tribes in the collaborative management of the sanctuary. By being equitable and inclusive, all sanctuary stakeholders will benefit from broad Indigenous input and TEK informing management.

Equitable collaborative management must be open to all Tribal groups interested in participating. This can best be accomplished with a Tribal Sanctuary Advisory Council made up of interested Tribal Groups. NOAA’s Tribal collaboration should be facilitated by a qualified Tribal Liaison.

Outreach and Education. Sanctuary education and community outreach should partner with area schools to increase education and access to the ocean for local communities. New educational programs should focus on both ocean ecology and Tribal history and culture. Outreach should be multilingual and multicultural, and should prioritize underserved communities, such as the inland communities of Guadalupe and Santa Maria. We also urge development of research programs that address the impacts of climate change, encourage community science, and elevate the use of TEK to enhance ecosystem-based management.

Rodriguez Seamount. We support regulations to protect Rodriguez Seamount. The seamount provides critical habitat for extremely biodiverse marine life, which needs strong and permanent protection. Once damaged, fragile seamount ecosystems may not recover in our lifetime.

Offshore Wind. While a source of renewable energy, Offshore Wind (OSW) farms will have environmental impacts on habitat, wildlife, and water quality. California’s first OSW projects should be planned and sited to avoid or mitigate impacts to sensitive marine areas and species and important cultural resources. The National Marine Sanctuary Program should work closely with state and federal partners, OSW companies, Tribes, and community members to ensure future OSW is developed in the most environmentally and culturally responsible manner.

Water Quality. The sanctuary should prohibit oil and gas exploration, development and production; phase out existing fossil fuel infrastructure and leases; reduce land and ocean-based pollution; and partner with the local communities to improve conservation of the Central Coast.

With gratitude and hope,

Creation Justice Ministries

Title: Comment from Fayram, Thomas
Comment:
Hello, thank you for allowing me to comment on the proposed Chumash Marine Sanctuary.  I urge you to NOT impliment this proposal as it is unnecessary and is simply a roadmap to expanded restrictions for public use and recreational fishing.  You have not clearly defined what will and will not happen as a result of this proposal and as such you leave the door open to do anything that you fell like restricting.  If you can guarantee that no resprtictions in public uses AND fishing regulations, then you should clearly state that and re-sumbit for comment, however I do not see anything that restricts you from further regulations.  As you know there are processes in place through the MPA's in place, and fishing regulations adopted by the State of California that are fully adequate to address fishing issues.  You have not said you will abide by that process which means you intend to restrict fishing further and I would say without, or ignoring, fishing interests.

Thank you again for allowing me to comment and again, please DO NOT approve this proposal without clear protections for public recreational uses.

Tom Fayram

Title: Comment from Fink, Katherine
Comment: How inspiring to designate these 156 miles of central California coastline to the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS)! The CHNMS is an exceptional opportunity to advance and elevate Indigenous perspectives and cultural values in ocean conservation and would help to address the biodiversity crisis and accelerate nature-based solutions through inclusive partnerships and collaboration among federal, state and local governments, and California Native American Tribes. Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Greening, Eric
Comment: I support the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Extension, and with inclusion of the Morro Bay Estuary within the boundaries of the Sanctuary.  For over four decades, local efforts have been based on contiguity with both the Channel Islands and Monterey sanctuaries, leaving no gaps.  The current proposal for a huge gap excluding 30 miles of coast and vast tracts of ocean are based on a vague notion that some sort of linear connection might, in the future, be made between a not yet approved, not yet formally proposed wind array, and the onshore electrical grid, coming onshore in Morro Bay.  While grandfathering of incompatible uses has many precedents, these precedents nearly always involve EXISTING infrastructure, not vague future possibilities.  We don't know whether the proposed wind array will pencil out or be approved, we don't know whether any associated infrastructure that might cross sanctuary waters would be incompatible with sanctuary management, and we don't know how the existence of a sanctuary might lead to conditions of approval that would minimize or eliminate compatibility issues.  What we can know is that the precedent of "grandfathering" not only a linear easement, but a 30-mile gap, based on vague possibilities about the future sets a horrifying precedent that could endanger all future conservation efforts anywhere, if all that is needed to eviscerate such a conservation effort is a vague notion that something incompatible might someday be proposed.  My reasons for supporting not only the complete sanctuary as long envisioned but also explicit inclusion of the Morro Bay Estuary include the importance of that estuary as a nursery for sea creatures who spend much of their lives in the sanctuary's outer waters, the enormous intrinsic biological and cultural value of the estuary, the estuary's calm waters (compared to the open ocean) that can welcome sanctuary visitors of all ages, including those without open ocean experience, to get ON the water in the estuary and to partake of such special features as the eelgrass beds, and the extension of the benefit of sanctuary-related water quality resources to the watersheds directly incident into the estuary, including the Los Osos and Chorro Creek watersheds and those of their tributaries.  I very much look forward to implementation of the most complete possible sanctuary, and thank you for the opportunity to comment

Title: Comment from Boicourt, Dave
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel,

My name is Dave Boicourt and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension.

I live in Atascadero, California.

I believe the primary reason for approving the sanctuary in its entirety is to honor the Chumash Tribe. Throughout our nation’s history lands belonging to its indigenous people have been seized. I believe this designation (in full) would go a long way in ameliorating those wrongs.

Another reason for keeping the sanctuary in its entirety is my belief the form follows function. The shape of the sanctuary should follow organic boundaries and should not be influenced by economic conveniences like wind power.

You and I have an opportunity to complete a virtuous act. I would be so proud of you, our local community and the nation if we were able to have the sanctuary approved as it was intended. Imagine the protection our coast would enjoy with both the Monterey and Chumash sanctuaries being contiguous and extending all the way to Gaviota. 

Of course, Morro Rock needs to be included as the sacred heart of the sanctuary.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension

The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”

An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.

Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities

The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity

A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,

Dave Boicourt

Title: Comment from Richards, Daniel
Comment:
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. With the vagaries of elected officials these days, I feel it is important to have layers of watchdogs and regulations to protect our natural resources. As a resident of the central coast I can attest to this area containing a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.
I feel the full area of the initial proposal should be used. Please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries.
Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.
Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Bradshaw, Justin
Comment:
Hello, my name is Justin Bradshaw. I'm a business owner in San Luis Obispo and have been a volunteer with the SLO Climate Coalition since its inception. My family and I visit many coastal areas on a regular basis to swim, paddleboard, surf and sail as a member of the Morro Bay Yacht Club. My son is a Junior Life Guard and a budding sailor who loves to frolic in the waves and often wonders about what’s under the surface. We moved here in large part because of our connection to the ocean. Protecting it like this is a rare generational opportunity. 

I support the CHNM designation with the extension along the southern coast to Gaviota. I also support the extension into Estero Bay and north to meet the MBNMS but only if it won’t cause significant delays to the creation of the wind energy area. The WEA is critically important to our climate goals in this state and the country. Ideally we could have our cake and eat it too. If that’s possible with a little extra work on your part, let’s do it! A contiguous area from Monterey down to the Channel Islands is the best possible outcome but again, not if it comes at the expense of several gigawatts of clean renewable wind energy. 

I also very much support the naming to include the Chumash and the planned collaboration with the tribe now and in the future. We have a long way to go to make things right with the indigenous people of this country. Every step we take in that direction makes a positive statement about who we are as a people because so many cultures in human history have just bowled over the “less powerful” cultures they found and took their land. We certainly aren’t the first to do so but maybe we can be the first to make peace with the “conquered” peoples and live in harmony and collaboration with them. 

Extend that metaphor to the wildlife in the ocean off our gorgeous California coast and you have my basic position: Let’s live in harmony with the wonderful gifts mother nature has given us. It’s our right and our duty, and in doing so we extend our moral authority to be the keeper of these lands.

Title: Comment from Beissel, Priscilla
Comment:
National Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary

It is a necessity for the approval of the National Chumash Heritage Sanctuary to become a reality. As a native Californian I have watched for too many decades as the Pacific Ocean has been used as a place to dispense waste; a source of business exploitation by both individuals, communities and greedy business entities! Every single California resident was given the precious Pacific Ocean to nurture; love; keep immaculate; clean; clear and thriving with all marine life created by God who has told us all---"CARE FOR MY CREATION" Thanks to the Chumash Tribal communities whose care and preservation of our Pacific Ocean has always and from the very beginning of the awesome beauty of a place that came to be known as California revered their home and the magnificent  Ocean on which they traveled and settled honoring the gift of life and sustenance found in the incredible Pacific Ocean! It is the prayer and eternal hope of every citizen who calls California their birthplace, their home and their sanctuary to defend, preserve and immaculately care for the greatest gift ever given----our Precious Pacific Ocean and ALL life forms which give birth and thrive within its waters -- a source of life to each and every citizen of the state of California..Sincerely,  Priscilla Beissel

Comment: Support for Designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary: please see attached

Title: Comment from Boicourt, Karen
Comment:
Paul Michel,
My name is Karen Boicourt. I am a California native and have lived in San Luis Obispo county for over 30 years. This past summer I heard an impassioned speech by Violet Sage Walker of the Chumash Tribal Council regarding the almost certain passage of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary after decades of work and the coordination and vision of numerous groups. At that time, the draft proposal included the coastal waters from Morro Bay north to the already designated Monterey Marine Sanctuary. It was a gut punch to many of us when the most recent draft plan excluded these coastal waters for the sole purpose of allowing a possible offshore wind energy project avoid the extra steps for approval that would be required through the sanctuary waters. It is stated in the NOAA proposal that "a core motivation in the nomination of the sanctuary was to raise public awareness of tribal and Indigenous cultures, incorporate Indigenous knowledge into sanctuary management, and protect resources essential to these cultures". The Chumash Tribe has an important voice in the stewardship of the sanctuary and should be heard. The small area excluded in the revised draft makes no sense when we want to protect a fluid corridor for whales, elephant seals, California sea lions, otters and other marine life that thrive in these waters. Also to be considered are the migratory birds that travel to the Morro Bay Estuary and others that live in this same area. It is imperative that to be the best stewards of our oceans and the rich biodiversity dependent on it that the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary be designated with the inclusion of the coastline and waters south of Morro Bay all the way to the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary without interruption.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from International Marine Mammal Project of Earth Island Institute
Organization Name: International Marine Mammal Project of Earth Island Institute
Comment:
The International Marine Mammal Project (IMMP) of Earth Island Institute submits the following comments for your consideration on the proposed establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  

IMMP strongly supports the proposed National Marine Sanctuary.  We emphasize the importance of this ocean area as both rich in biodiversity and relatively limited disturbance of the natural environment (compared to other areas of coastal California).  

We encourage NOAA to approve the largest possible boundaries, ensuring continuous protection with the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary and encompassing as much of the aquatic ecosystem as possible.

We commend the proposal for including the Chumash tribe and their interests in helping manage the sanctuary and restoring a part of their heritage.

We further urge all offshore oil drilling, exploration, and associated pipelines be banned in the Sanctuary borders, as is the case for California's other National Marine Sanctuaries.  Indeed, NOAA should take steps to end all offshore oil drilling off the California coast (and elsewhere) to address the threats posed by global warming from burning fossil fuels.

Thank you for your consideration of our views.  Please act soon to protect this Sanctuary.

Sincerely,
Mark J. Palmer
Associate Director
International Marine Mammal Project
Earth Island Institute
The Brower Center
2150 Allston Way, Suite 460, Berkeley, CA 94704
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Dunivant, Terre
Comment:
Hello,

I fully support designating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 

Specifically, I support the "Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension" that will protect habitats and biodiversity throughout 7,600 square miles of ocean. We know that it is very unwise to fragment ocean protection.

The science is clear: Marine Sanctuaries not only protect ocean species from those who would take and sell the last of a kind, damaging the ocean environment by dragging/trapping indiscriminately and dumping tackle and oil that regularly ensnares and kills citizens of the sea. Marine Sanctuaries are nurseries for species that go outside the boundaries where they can be harvested, so those who are looking to profit from killing wildlife actually benefit from ocean protection, despite their complaints. 

And while wind energy is important, the current state of the infrastructure is harmful to birds and therefore unacceptable. There are other forms that can capture the power of the wind that do not kill wildlife - sails, for example - which are currently not being considered by those wanting to build and install the deadly bladed wind turbines. The technology is evolving rapidly; the market MUST develop the means to capture wind energy that does not injure and kill birds following ancient flyways. 

I've lived in San Luis Obispo County for decades, in oceanside towns called Cayucos, Los Osos, and Morro Bay. The ocean is infinitely precious and must not be further damaged, specifically by the industries of fishing, farming, and energy. The whole point of a Marine Sanctuary is to protect that which will otherwise be ravaged. It is time.

Otherwise, I heartily agree with every point in the attached document, "NCTC (Northern Chumash Tribal Council) Messaging Guidance". 

Thank you for doing the right thing for the life of the ocean, and for the millions of us who regard the ocean as sacred and worthy of protection. 

Terre Dunivant
San Luis Obispo, CA
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Kershaw, C
Comment:
I am writing in support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  I support the original boundary joining with the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary’s southern border in Cambria.  This would fill the gap of Morro Bsy.  The argument that a wind farm and cables could be problematic Sanctuary waters is not valid.  It would simply mean that industry would need to respect the marine sanctuary and align its infrastructure to the standards of protected ocean marine sanctuary standards.  A win for all California!
Thank you, Cheryl Kershaw

Title: Comment from Wells Property Management
Comment:
Regarding the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary: We support the 7600 square mile proposal for protection of the marine biodiversity and habitat.
Our family lives in Oceano, and we often use the coastal areas defined by the proposed sanctuary for photography, boating, diving and general recreational use. 
We feel this is the minimum size required to provide adequate protection for protection of the diverse aquatic life.  We support the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension. As California's population grows and more population is felt thru-out California, more pressure will be put on these resources. The protection of the Rodriguez Seamount is essential to fully facilitate this proposal.  We need more educational  and research programs which will help us fully realize the immensity and importance of this act.  There is much we do not know or understand about our oceans.  A complete ban on oil and gas development is a must for adequate future protections.  We have several examples of tragic spills along our Central Coast.  The environmental destruction of these activities cannot be continued, and with the technology of EV cars, trucks and equipment of all types, oil and gas drilling will be less necessary in our future. This too, will be an acknowledgement to our Native American populations that we are finally taking the necessary steps to stop the destruction of our marine life and habitat.   We support the name of " Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary" in honoring their contributions to the betterment of of our environmental future.  All tribes should be included in a collective management program.  This is the least that we can do as a responsible population, in consideration of the future of our children, the Native Americans, and the spirit of pro-active environmental protections. Thank you very much, Gary & Suzanne Wells, 2445 Beach St., Oceano CA.

Comment: I fully support this effort and appreciate that the name highlights the indigenous heritage/importance in this region! Thank you all for the great work you have done in putting together this proposal, and working to include indigenous communities in the decision making process.

Title: Comment from DINIAKOS , Liza

Title: Comment from Bender, John
Comment:
The wind farms should not be visible from any part of the California shoreline. If this requires siting windmills further away from the shoreline then the lessees will have to absorb the additional costs involved with delivery and maintenance of the windmills. This just needs to be the cost of doing business for the lessees.

The windmill construction and servicing location(s) should be located where there is already significant industrial development and infrastructure to support such activities. Existing major ports and railroad hubs/terminuses should be utilized rather than creating new ones in relatively remote locations.

The proposed marine sanctuary should be contiguous along the central coast. Leaving a relatively small gap between the Monterey marine sanctuary and the proposed Chumash marine sanctuary is clearly only for the benefit of the wind farm lessees to install and service their equipment at the expense of the environmental health of our coastline.

If the final Chumash sanctuary is contiguous with the Monterey sanctuary, the issue of placing undersea transmission cables from the shoreline to the windmills through the sanctuary would need to be resolved. Numerous subsea communication cables presently exist and terminate in Morro Bay and Pismo Beach (Reference NOAA navigational chart 18700), but none of the cables transit the Monterey marine sanctuary to the north. The proposed Chumash marine sanctuary (even if there is a gap with the Monterey sanctuary) will contain some of these existing subsea cables, particularly the cables that terminate in Morro Bay within its boundaries.

Making a significant change to the proposed sanctuary boundaries as is currently being proposed constitutes a change in scope of the wind farm project for the advantage of the lessees and should require the process for awarding the leases to be redone.

I realize there are other legal, environmental, and economic issues to be considered and I admit I'm not an expert in any of them. However, I'm a native Californian born in the late 1950s and I've lived in Fresno, Humboldt, Mariposa, Stanislaus, Inyo, and now San Luis Obispo counties. I do know that I love my state and wish to see an unobstructed horizon from the central coast to remain unchanged in perpetuity for future generations to enjoy

Title: Comment from Spaulding , Jay
Comment: As a resident and a avid waterman as well as a major supporter of the Chumash heritage, culture the realization and importance as well as the vitality of our oceans mainly the 1 Great Pacific that we all reside and are a part of needs great attention as well as efforts to preserve what is left for the sake of nature and humanity the Chumash culture ultimately has to be protected living here in Morro Bay I have personally witnessed great change in our efforts and stances in our community to engage and protect for generations to come all this nonsensical thinking for unrealistic growth and power of expansion mainly in the quest for more and more and more is unbelievably disgusting.To think we would go out as humans and blow up the ocean floor to install major power grids and floating wind farms not even thinking for a moment the effects that us  humans the stewards of our all of our coastline that we can manipulate as humans and think we will never have any long-lasting effect in the generations to come is a big capitalistic joke people in charge of decision making really need to ask themselves one thing is what you are doing really benefiting?it's not all about you or them or they it's all about Us together making an impact of long-lasting decision making protecting the ocean, protect the marine life it is so fragile if we don't make this a sanctuary what will be left especially when the whale, the dolphin , the shearwater birds, the pelicans, the otters, the little sea shell that your kids pick up in excitement of learning what our ancestors mainly protected and mostly the Chumash they understand, why can't you? are you worried about your pocketbooks your purses whatever you put your greedy money into is that what this is all about ask yourself actually project ahead and think when you're dead and gone what your decisions leave behind the quest for more and more and more in the ways of destroying what is so much a gift to think we know more than nature itself is completely disgusting and disrespectful for the planet that us humans all reside.Without the protection of the Central Coast Waters this is all that's left we've already destroyed the rest of the Pacific coast you people can't see through preserving what is left if this is taken and destroyed there will absolutely be no hope of return so take your windmills take your big ships take your oil dumping toxic raw sewage and put it in your own backyard and then send your kids out to play and then maybe your grandchildren will have a thumb growing out of their eye better yet maybe won't even have an eye to enjoy and grow and give back to what is real people in decision making need to rethink and instead of being greedy how about giving back giving back to cultures and species mainly our ocean ,oceans that gave us all !life! Got a minute? Thanks for your time

Title: Comment from Schwartz, David
Comment:
I agree with the Agency Prefferred plan:
In accordance with NEPA (42 U.S.C. 4321 et seq. ), NOAA is identifying as its preferred alternative the combination of Alternative 2, “Cropped Bank to Coast,” and Sub-alternative 5b, “Gaviota Coast Extension.”

This maximizes the amint to protected space while avoiding the precedent of having infrastructure within protected space. This protection is required both for existing natural resources, and to allow recovery of degraded areas withing the region. Further, the indigenous cultural regions being incorporated is equally important since all to often those uses have not been completely integrated in protected natural space, since that use is not seen as "natural". This shift in perception is desirable. 

However, the agency needs to find ways to incorporate both accommodation of offshore wind power and marine protection in the same space since the interest and action for both is increasing.

Thank you.

Title: Comment from Mengebier, Clare
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Clare Mengebier and as a San Diego citizen I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover around 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

To me, the ocean a source of learning, growth, and life for me ever since I was a child visiting these beaches and looking out into the endless sea in awe. I want to be proud to bring the next generation to the same beaches and have these ecosystems in intact so we can continue learning from the abundant resources and life in the ocean. 

That is why I emphatically support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
•	The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
•	The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
•	Inclusion of all Tribes in Collaborative Management
•	Education and research programs that elevate Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
•	The protection of Rodriguez Seamount
•	A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to create long-term opportunities to continue to learn and benefit from our ocean.
 

Sincerely,

Clare

Title: Comment from Harns, Megan
Comment: As someone with a background in ecology, I support the creation of marine sanctuaries along California's Central Coast to preserve the unparalleled diversity of our marine habitats. And alternative energy creation is also critical to fight climate change destabilization. But leaving Morro Bay out of the Marine sanctuary-- a place that is so iconic and culturally sufficient-- which has already suffered exploitation and could see more if left unprotected -- baffles me. If alternatives for limited use and modification were in place or jointly proposed, perhaps leaving Morro Bay off the Marine Sanctuary plans would seem more reasonable, but as it stands, the situation seems to leave this valuable area as the only corridor for development. Off shore wind energy seems less necessary in California, considering our underutilized abundance of solar energy -- I would rather see our inland canals covered by solar panels than see wind farms in our oceans. NOAA would do well to include the priceless Morro Bay inside the proposed Marine Sanctuary and instead partner with other state and federal agencies to boost our alternative energy production in other ways and other locations which are of less cultural and ecological significance.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Kessinger, Ashli
Comment: I encourage you to create the largest marine sanctuary possible. Not only is this protecting wildlife, it’s also protecting the earth and humans. We have to think of the future and what we are leaving to our children. They are at our mercy with these policies and choices. I hope people in power realize that our future and earth is critical to human existence. We have to stop living in the now all the time and think of what our landscape will be when we are all gone. Please create a sanctuary that will benefit all of us in the future - the most possible area protected.

Preservation of the few remaining healthy areas off the southern central California coast for future generations must be prioritized while moving forward with clean energy solutions. We owe it to our grandchildren. Thank you.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Yes!  Indeed! We need to preserve our natural habitat, it is our life giving Mother Nature, 
    Please do the correct thing and make official the natural sanctuary of Morro Bay , Chumash sacred land. Let us show respect for our  Mother Nature. 
    I grew up in SoCal,near  Seal Beach, Huntington Beach, since 1966....where the water is brownish green and animals die from the pollution. There was a time when the so-cal beaches could have been preserved...but they weren't. Look at how Global Climate Change has affected our coastal wetlands( what is left of them). For every species that goes extinct,  including species from the vegetable kingdom, there is a detrimental cascade of death that follows.  A marine sanctuary of Morro bay is not a choice but the only place left for the endangered animals that live there.  They are indigenous to our California coast line. We, as humans, have to correct the mistakes of those who came before us. We have the choice and ability to preserve our natural lands and waters for the next seven generations to come. 
 Thank you. 
   May you be blessed with a good conscience and compassion, 
  Lidia I. Saworotnow

Title: Comment from Marine Applied Research and Exploration, a not-for-profit 501.c.3 organization
Organization Name: Marine Applied Research and Exploration, a not-for-profit 501.c.3 organization
Comment:
I support establishment of a Chumash National Marine Sanctuary, to be managed with full Chumash representation.  The Chumash people have lived, fished and hunted sustainably in the Channel Islands for at least 15,000 years.  They have also actively participated in the 10 year Decadal Review of the Statewide network of Marine Protected Areas.  The rest of us have lots to learn, and the sharing of Traditional Ecological Knowledge could assist in the management of California's 4 other National Marine Sanctuaries.
Dirk Rosen, Founder and President Marine Applied Research and Exploration

Title: Comment from San Luis Obispo County Democratic Party
Comment:
October 14, 2023 

Mr. Paul Michel, Regional Policy Coordinator 
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration 
99 Pacific Street, Suite 100F 
Monterey, CA 93940 

Dear Mr. Michel, 

We, the undersigned members of the San Luis Obispo County Democratic Party (SLOCDP) Central Committee, strongly support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) to protect ocean biodiversity and to advance environmental justice through collaborative ocean management. 

The objective of the CHNMS has always been to fill the gap between the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary by protecting 7,573 square miles of ocean. It is vital that the CHNMS cover the largest possible contiguous boundaries, including the waters off Point Buchon, Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria. 

We therefore support the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension. All other alternatives would reduce the significant beneficial effects on biological and cultural resources provided by the Initial Boundary Alternative. 

The SLOCDP supports the thoughtful development of Offshore Wind (OSW) energy and believes that such development can be compatible with a Sanctuary of maximum extent. The National Marine Sanctuary Program should work closely with state and federal partners, OSW companies, Tribes, and community members to ensure future OSW is developed in the most environmentally and culturally responsible manner that adheres to local, regional and state environmental standards, and regulations. 

The Sanctuary should be named the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in recognition of the history and culture of the Chumash and other Indigenous peoples of the region. Outreach, education, and research programs should elevate Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities. Outreach and education should be multilingual and multicultural. 
We support an equitable and inclusive approach to Tribal Collaborative Management that empowers all interested Tribal groups who are affiliated with the area. We also support the appointment of a qualified NOAA Tribal Liaison. 

The final management plan should ensure lasting protection of the Sanctuary’s unique and irreplaceable environmental and cultural resources. The CHNMS should prohibit oil and gas exploration, development and production; phase out existing fossil-fuel infrastructure and leases; reduce land- and ocean-based pollution; and partner with the local communities to improve conservation of the Central Coast’s enviable natural resources. We further support regulations to protect Rodriguez Seamount. 

Thank you for your consideration of these comments. 

Sincerely, 
Tom Fulks, Chair SLOCDP
Dona Hare Price, Vice Chair
Jamie Maraviglia, Recording Secretary
Barry A. Price, Corresponding Secretary
Debra Stakes, Treasurer
Deborah Scarborough 
Johnathan Lau
Benjamin Gildea
Mariam Shah 
Elena Garcia
Monica Schechter
Vita Miller
Lizabeth Horton
Geraldine Clemens

Title: Comment from Cayucos Citizens' Advisory Council
Comment: My name is John Carsel.  I am the current President of the Cayucos Citizens' Advisory Council.  The Council consists of 16 members elected by the citizens of Cayucos, California.  We are likely the last authentic little beach town in California located south of Cambria and north of Morro Bay.  The original designation of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary had the northern boundary adjacent to the southern boundary of the Monterey Marine Sanctuary and included Cayucos.  The northern boundary of the now proposed Agency-Preferred Alternative now EXCLUDES Cayucos, much to the potential detriment of we who live here and the countless visitors we entertain.  A Resolution was unanimously passed at our regular meeting on October 4, 2023, to ask that Cayucos be reinstated into the Marine Sanctuary boundary.  We exist in an unique area and must preserve it.  Please don't let short term economic interests destroy our fragile and precious coast.  Thank you for your consideration.  John M. Carsel, President, Cayucos Citizens' Advisory Council

Title: Comment from Futrell, Sherrill
Comment: As a Christian, I'm excited to see a proposed draft management plan for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. We need clear and meaningful management and implementation of the sanctuary. Given that the Chumash tribe, among other tribes, have been the primary keepers and sustainers of these waters and the lands that are along the coast, we must first look to them for comment and input on this draft management plan and future management plans. It is so important that we preserve God's unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. I ask that you respect the Northern Chumash Tribal Council requests regarding sanctuary boundary, the sanctuary name, tribal collaborative management, outreach and education, Rodriguez Seamount, offshore wind and water quality. Thank you for your work on this immediate need to preserve God's creation.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Colissimo, Cristina
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Cristina Colissimo and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Los Angeles, California and to me, the ocean is a place of bountiful life and rich diverse history. When I go to the coast, I enjoy kayaking with the family and we explore the beach, watching the wildlife on land and in the sea. 
The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.
I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,
Cristina Colissimo

Title: Comment from Thompson , Catherine
Comment:
It is so important that we preserve God's unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. I ask that you respect the Northern Chumash Tribal Council requests regarding sanctuary boundary, the sanctuary name, tribal collaborative management, outreach and education, Rodriguez Seamount, offshore wind and water quality. 

As a Christian, I'm excited to see a proposed draft management plan for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. We need clear and meaningful management and implementation of the sanctuary. Given that the Chumash tribe, among other tribes, have been the primary keepers and sustainers of these waters and the lands that are along the coast, we must first look to them for comment and input on this draft management plan and future management plans.

Thank you for your work on this immediate need to preserve God's creation.

Title: Comment from Elliott, Alexandra
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Alexandra Elliott and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in El Cerrito, CA and to me, the ocean is beautiful, wild, life-giving and sacred. The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

-Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
-Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
-Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
-Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
-Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
-Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,
Alexandra Elliott

Title: Comment from Prieto, Franky
Comment:
FINAL
Dear Paul Michel,

I am Franky Prieto. I am a Highschooler and I support the design of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
I live in Oxnard,California. The ocean is a very important part of Oxnard due to it being 20 minutes or less from wherever you are and especially the food supply from the ocean.

I support the sanctuary as almost anywhere in oxnard you will see something about the ocean because it is one of our biggest food suppliers disregarding the fields in oxnard. I believe that the sanctuary should be able to help monitor the ecosystem and help keep up with the populations of the animals in the area that is being monitored. I want to be ensured that majority of the times the environment will be looked out for to make sure the food chain does not go terribly wrong

There can be opposing views, such as fishermen who do not agree with the boundaries of the sanctuary because they believe that they should be able to fish wherever they want and that the area should not be monitored. However, the sanctuary will benefit everyone by preserving our unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguarding thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites.

In conclusion, the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary will help preserve the unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. It will also ensure that the environment is looked after to make sure the food chain does not go terribly wrong. Therefore, it is essential to support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Comment:
My name is Danielle Perez, I live in Berkeley, California, and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health. I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
The Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”.
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities.
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity.
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,
Danielle Perez

Title: Comment from Lezenby, Kathryn
Comment:
I strongly support creation of the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary using the original plan that would set aside the maximum area possible. Bestowed with healthy kelp forests and submarine canyons that shelter, feed, provide physical structures and hiding places for animals, and important  habitat for krill, this part of the ocean supports a wide diversity of lives, underwater and above. It also links the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary and the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary. Down-welling caused by its submarine canyons carries organic matter and pollutants into the bottom of the deep sea where they are buried or assimilated, helping to protect our climate and mitigate the effects of pollution. It makes sense to preserve this important place from the many man-made threats destroying ocean ecosystems around the globe. The Chumash National Marine Sanctuary should be off limits to bottom trawling, dredging, drilling, dumping, mining and other activities that could harm it. 

Our oceans are in crisis. Climate change is adding a further stress to the lives that depend on it. We need more ocean sanctuaries. The Chumash is an excellent place to establish one.
