Title: Comment from Nguyen, Kaylie
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Kaylie Nguyen, and I support the institution of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to offer a space of education, marine environmental protection, and preservation of the coast’s connections with the indigenous tribes of California.

I live in Oxnard, California and to me, the ocean is a place of recreation and community. When I go to the coast, I enjoy spending time with friends and family in the water or in the sand. I hope to protect this part of the ocean so my community can continue to enjoy an ocean that is clean and safe. I also hope that sanctuary will be an important development to learning the culture and history of the Chumash tribes and its interactions with the marine environment. 

Following the establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, I ask that this sanctuary includes outreach programs that contribute to the education of indigenous communities and their culture and communities, as well as the research of biodiversity and marine habitats. As a current high school student, these outreach programs can be instituted at schools, to be able to influence the younger generations. I believe that the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary will be able to prohibit the introduction of invasive species into the coast such as the Sargassum horneri.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I want the sanctuary to provide a center for the education and preservation of marine habitats, so current and future generations can enjoy the ocean for years to come. 

Sincerely, 
Kaylie Nguyen
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Gordillo , Niki
Comment:
Dear, Paul Michel

My name is Niki A. Gordillo and I support this swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. 

I live in Oxnard, California and to me, the ocean is an impressive place since life is different in the ocean rather than the land and it’s very impressive how animals survive with/without oxygen and how the ecosystems work. When I go to the coast, I walk around the shorelines and just watch the waves come back in and out and I see the wildlife that’s out there (at least what I can see). 

The first reason why I support this is because the ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, for the Chumash’s spiritual beliefs, for the community connections, and for the economy. The second reason I want to protest this part of the ocean is because it is sacred land for the Chumash and we should respect the native-american land of the Chumash and their personal/spiritual beliefs. We should keep the oceans clean in general so the ecosystems could continue to thrive. The third reason is that the ocean is a beautiful place and should be respected and clean so animals can thrive and the underwater plants can continue to grow. There is so much that we can learn about our own planet instead of learning about the vacuum of space. A sanctuary will be a very important part of ocean research and education for future generations instead of killing everything. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes a ban on oil/gas rigs because these rigs cause animals to die and it kills the animals' habitats in the process. If the oil/gas rigs aren’t gone, then there wouldn’t be any habitat for the animals to live in so they either die or migrate to another spot.  I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures. 
Sincerely,
Niki A. Gordillo

Title: Comment from Jones, Vicki
Comment:
I support the Chumash Marine Reserve proposal with the inclusion of Cambria and Morro Bay. I live near the beach and am out daily near “the rock.”  I appreciate that this is sacred to indigenous people. It is magical for me with wildlife that I remember all along the coast in my childhood but now found only here. 

I am deeply concerned that the very important push for alternative energy will overwhelm our small community - people and wildlife. Morro Bay is a town of about 14,000 people. Our only large companies are branches of pharmacy and grocery chains. The scale of companies required to build and run energy infrastructure at this early stage of development in the technology will destroy one of the few remaining seaside towns in California. Yes, I enthusiastically support alternative energy and argue that where is as important as what and when for the protection of the planet. If a popular tourist destination and precious marine resources are lost because of new energy development, this development will be a one off and the goal of extensive alternative energy will end in morro. 

 If the turbines won’t be visible from land then they should be placed in proximity of already industrialized coastline. The ocean impact will be the same and the additional shore impact will be marginal. 

For the people of my small town and our way of life, for the ocean life that has already been destroyed along the coast, and for the sustainable acceptance of alternative energy, for the sacred and magical of Morro Rock, approve the Chumash Marine Reserve to include Cambria and Morro Bay. 

Thank you.

Title: Comment from Mullin, John
Comment:
The extended southern boundary in the new “preferred” Chumash Marine Sanctuary is welcome. Unfortunately, the new northern boundary differs substantially from the “initially proposed” boundary. This new "preferred" boundary eliminates the important conservation area between Pt Buchon State Marine Reserve and Cambria State Marine Conservation Area. All benefits of sanctuary protection are eliminated between these two Marine Protected Areas.
 
Activity is heavy on the boundaries of these two existing marine protected areas (personal warden experience). Concentrated fishing activity and compliance difficulties at these locations will continue with acceptance of the “preferred” sanctuary. The “initially proposed” northern boundary of the Chumash Marine Sanctuary would eliminate these boundary enforcement issues and offer continuity of conservation.

Why is protection of this entire area being sacrificed? Why can't wind turbine cables, harbor dredging, etc. be addressed under the special permit process (Section 310 of the NMSA (16 U.S.C. § 1441)?

Title: Comment from Bauer, Jordyn
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel,
My name is Jordyn Bauer and I was born and raised along California’s beautiful coast. I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) with the Initial Boundary Alternative including Morro Bay and the Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I was born and raised in San Luis Obispo and frequently visit the coast to walk and boogie board. The ocean has always been a special place for me and my physical and emotional health. I studied environmental science in college and know the importance of protecting our oceans and all of the ecosystems within it. I would like to see future generations have the same opportunity to enjoy and benefit from our oceans. 

I support the designation of the CHNMS because it would help protect and keep our oceans and its species safe and healthy. I would like to see the initial boundary alternative including Morro Bay with the Gaviota Coast Extension. In addition, this is the first tribally led nominated sanctuary and would honor and respect tribal members who have stewarded the land and ocean for centuries. Please consider an equitable approach to include all Tribes in the Collaborative Management. 

I urge the Administration to designate the CHNMS to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 
Sincerely,

Jordyn Bauer
San Luis Obispo, CA

Title: Comment from Snook, Brad
Comment:
To: Paul Michel, West Coast Regional Policy Coordinator
      Office of National Marine Sanctuaries

Re: Comments on Draft Environmental Impact Statement for proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, (Docket: NOAA-NOS-2021-0080)

I would like to thank NOAA for their role in the ongoing designation process of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS). Per NOAA: “No significant adverse impacts are expected under any of the alternative'' plans shown in the CHNMS Draft Environmental Impact Statement (DEIS). Further, “Long term beneficial impacts are expected if the proposed action is implemented”. 

I whole-heartedly agree with the above assessments.

Also, per the Draft EIS, “The area contains unique and diverse ecosystems essential to the heritage of several tribal groups. The marine environment provides a special sense of place to coastal communities and visitors because of its significant historic, archaeological, cultural, aesthetic, and biological resources.” This statement is also true of many coastal areas around the United States (and the world). So, after formal recognition of the CHNMS, it will be vitally important for NOAA to show the federal government can be trusted to transparently carry out the sanctuary’s 11 action plans, and it’s up to local indigenous leaders and the public to work effectively with NOAA to measure, manage, and report meaningful protections of the CHNMS. The federal government has a brutal and destructive history when it comes to the rights of indigenous peoples, and a successful, transparent CHNMS could create beneficial opportunities to protect other ecosystems and people beyond the sanctuary’s boundaries.

Since a well-protected ocean is better for everyone, a larger well-protected area is also better. The CHNMS must include the waters off Cambria, Cayucos, and Morro Bay.I support the Initial Boundary alternative shown in the DEIS. Potential regulatory challenges, such as undersea cables coming onshore from the proposed Wind Energy Areas (WEA), can be permitted in a National Marine Sanctuary. I believe the additional oversight provided by the proposed CHNMS will be good for the offshore wind projects, and the sanctuary’s contributions to the offshore wind projects could help to improve clean energy projects elsewhere. 

Other possible actions will contribute to the sanctuary’s long term beneficial impacts: 
The DEIS mentions the City of Pismo Beach’s request for a 2 mile exclusion zone. I believe Pismo Beach leaders were previously misinformed about permissive exclusion zones within a sanctuary. The DEIS mention of an exclusion for Pismo’s pier is a more precise practice. Further, while studies on the Pismo Clam are ongoing, the proposed sanctuary might add meaningful support to helping the clam population rebound and Pismo Beach, like many other coastal areas in San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties, will significantly benefit from the sanctuary’s offerings.
The sanctuary could provide a meaningful contribution to the study of the impacts on upwelling downwind from wind energy projects. The sanctuary should begin baseline measurements for important elements within the sanctuary’s boundaries to be compared to findings after the WEA’s are installed. The waters off Cambria, Cayucos, and Morro Bay will be important contributors to these studies, only one of many reasons to include them within the sanctuary boundaries.

I had the great opportunity to share a friendship with Fred Collins, tribal leader of the Northern Chumash Tribal Council. Fred would speak about “Thrivability” and he would remind us how the failed concept of “Sustainability” is degrading the natural world around us. This is one lesson I learned from Fred: We must do better, and the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should be managed for thrivability and nothing less.

Title: Comment from Ellis , Lynn
Comment:
Morro Bay MUST be included in the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary!!! 

Morro Bay is NOT an industrial commercial wharf...it is a community fishing and tourist destination town with many seals, sea otters, beautiful beaches,  sand dunes, open areas! 

The proposed Vistra battery storage facility should not be built as it does not fit in our sleepy quiet natural harbor town. 

I read you don't plan to include Morro Bay in the marine sanctuary because the planned underwater cables, offshore windmills etc make it ineligible.  Please be reminded that we dont have those windmills yet! We don't have the underwater cables yet! Many many hurdles must be cleared before they are built. Please don't put the cart ahead of the horse!

And, other than massive Vistra and some politicians,  many of we,  the citizens of Morro Bay, do not want our town to have the commercial battery storage plant. Please dont listen to the politicians as they come and go...they may have financial or other Non Environmental reasons why they want Morro Bay changed into the largest battery storage facility in the world...

Please do the right thing and INCLUDE Morro Bay in the Marine Sanctuary!!! By you doing the right thing and not being influenced by politicians and big money corporations like Vistra, you will help preserve Morro Bay as a natural gem for generations to come! 

Just remember that trends like windmills and battery storage come and go just like nuclear plants and oil...So, if voting to include MB in the Marine Sanctuary hinders or prohibits the battery storage plant, then, good, as that's what is needed! 

Preservation takes guts! Preservation takes clear uninfluenced sight!! Thank you for your help with this matter!!

Title: Comment from Ripoyla, Jasmine
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Jasmine Ripoyla and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Sacramento, California and to me, the ocean is such an important source of life for all people. I feel called to be a careful steward of our coast by advocating for what will keep our lands healthy for generations to come. 

When I go to the coast, I love to explore the beach with my family and friends, learn more about marine wildlife, and keep it clean by picking up any trash or debris that I see. The ocean is personally very, very important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension

Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”

Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.

Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities

Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity

Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Jasmine Ripoyla
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Davis, David
Comment:
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary!
Please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries.
This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.
Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.
Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Greetings - 

I strongly support the creation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  

At the same time I vigorously oppose the creation of an Industrial Shipping Corridor cutting through the proposed Sanctuary.  

This last minute proposal strikes at the heart of the entire purpose of the marine sanctuary. In addition to being a sanctuary for animals and plants that live in the area, it will also serve as a wildlife corridor for animals traveling up and down the Pacific Coast.

Saying NO to the Industrial Shipping Corridor does not mean there will be no ships and heavy equipment…it means oversight of the development of the off-shore wind farm.  

It makes complete sense that there are strict governing rules that are rigorously enforced…versus a wild west approach to the offshore development.

YES to the creation of  Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

NO to the Industrial Shipping Corridor.

Thank you so much for your consideration.

Thank you!
R. Garthwait

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel,
I am writing today in support of the creation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
I am a filmmaker and have had the good luck to have done extensive filming of this unexpectedly wild and beautiful stretch of ocean and coastline.
I urge you to bring the sanctuary into existence with the full protections that a sanctuary would allow.

This would specifically not include the proposed Industrial Corridor.  This has the same feeling as putting a 6-lane highway through Yellowstone.
I do not argue with the wind energy slated off the coast of Morro Bay, but feel that this and other projects can be successfully built and coexist with the Sanctuary.

You have an amazing opportunity to help preserve the ocean and the California coastline for generations to come.
Thank you for your work!

Dan Griffin - Filmmaker

Title: Comment from T'epot'aha'l:  The Salinan Tribe of Monterey and San Luis Obispo Counties
Organization Name: The Salinan Tribe of Monterey and San Luis Obispo Counties
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Since the inception of the proposed Chumash Marine Sanctuary along the coast of California, the Salinan Tribe of Monterey and San Luis Obispo Counties (Salinan Tribe) has voiced our consistent and unwavering concerns to all governmental agencies and organizations involved in this process.  

At this point, the proposed name is not only historically inaccurate, but it also continues to perpetuate the false narrative that the central coast of California from the Channel Islands to the Monterey County border is the home to only one homogenized culture, the Chumash culture.  Educated historians and NOAA’s own research show that this is not the case.  California indigenous cultures throughout history have been a blend of overlapping languages and cultures.  As for Salinan culture, our culture is widely regarded as well traversed all throughout San Luis Obispo County and coastline.  

This is why we have consistently felt that a more appropriate name would be something that actually represents the historical accuracy of the known cultures represented in this proposed sanctuary.  

The gradual genocide of indigenous cultures, that began with the Spanish Mission Era along the coast of California in 1769, later pursued by the Mexican government with the theft of lands with their Mexican land grant policies from 1822 until 1850 and continuing after 1850 with California state and federal policies that both forced cultural genocide and funded the outright murder of the indigenous natives, continues today. 

Every generation claims they will right the wrongs of the past.  Yet every generation for the last 250 years has blindly repeated the sins of the past when it comes to native indigenous cultures.

Simply put, the Salinan culture deserves an equal seat at the table with equal respect, equal recognition, and equal dignity.  Anything less will not be acceptable to us as it will continue the narrative of systemic inequities that have permeated Spanish, Mexican, and American policy for over 250 years.  

This is why we continue to support an inclusive national marine sanctuary that includes a name that represent all indigenous cultures in the study area and simultaneously keeps the boundaries up to the Monterey Bay Marine Sanctuary throughout the northern part of San Luis Obispo County.  This simple proposal does more than rightfully preserve historical accuracy and cultural dignity.  It will also ensure the much needed protections of not only marine life, but of the indigenous cultures and traditions that are so important to everyone along the central coast.

From the onset of this proposed sanctuary, our solution has always been one that represents historical accuracy, equality, and respect for everyone.  And for this simple request, we have been marginalized, ridiculed, and routinely pushed aside.   

Our issue has never been with the Chumash culture and those who carry its legacy.  The Chumash culture is a vibrant story that needs to be preserved.  To those who are truly descended from this culture, we support you.  We are simply asking for the same respect in return.

For these reasons, the Salinan Tribe of San Luis Obispo and Monterey Counties will not support this marine sanctuary proposal until such time that both the name of the sanctuary is inclusionary representing historical accuracy, and that the boundaries equally protect all the lands up to the southern border of the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary.

We stand resolved on our position.

The Salinan Tribe of Monterey and San Luis Obispo Counties

Title: Comment from Gardener-Felix, Raine
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Raine Gardener-Félix, and I am writing to express my support for the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in San Luis Obispo, CA, and as someone born and raised on the Central Coast, the ocean is my home. Our local coastline supports a vibrant, diverse community of aquatic species, and getting to experience it has been one of the greatest joys of my life. In my professional life, I've had the privilege of assisting with biological monitoring and habitat restoration in Morro Bay, its estuary, and its tributaries. My work in these habitats has shown me firsthand the incredible interconnectedness of all life and how crucial marine sanctuaries are to supporting sustainable use of marine resources.

On a personal level, when life gets hard, the ocean is always able to bring me comfort. The constant, cyclical motion of the waves and the tides reminds me that whatever I'm feeling will pass. And the tide pools make me feel like a kid again, reminding me that even the smallest space on this planet is teeming with life if I just take the time to look.

I firmly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary include the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension to protect the greatest area possible. I also ask that this sanctuary honor this coastline's original Chumash stewards both in its name—"Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary"—and by including all Tribes in the Collaborative Management of the sanctuary. Finally, to preserve the integrity of the sanctuary, it is crucial that the Administration ban new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

The ocean is precious and irreplaceable. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to protect and preserve this one-of-a-kind place for generations to come.

Sincerely,
Raine Gardener-Félix

Title: Comment from James, Jenni
Comment:
I live in Cayucos, CA, and have called the Central Coast home for more than twenty years. I strongly support the designation the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) with the largest boundary possible. 
Only by combining the Initial Boundary Alternative plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) will you create a true sanctuary, providing contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources including submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.

I do NOT support NOAA’s Alternatives 2, 3, or 4, which create a dangerous carve out for industrial uses that the Agency recognizes are incompatible with the purpose of sanctuary. These Alternatives imperil crucial marine habitat and species, including the endangered Peregrine falcons that nest on Morro Rock and the threatened Southern sea otters that find refuge in Morro Bay’s harbor. Morro Rock also holds great cultural significance for the Chumash people. It should be the heart of the new CNHMS. 

Anticipating future offshore wind development is a reason to extend protection to this vulnerable habitat, NOT to leave the area exposed to bypass the special use permit process. Rather than fast track industry, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters. 

Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Friesen, Rachel
Comment:
My name is Rachel Friesen and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and the proposed Sub-Alternative 5b Boundary.

I live in San Luis Obispo and am a biology master's student at Cal Poly. As a biologist, I know the importance of protecting biodiversity and maintaining intact, continuous habitat. Full connectivity with the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary is essential in maintaining a healthy ecosystem. Patchwork reserve boundaries and therefore patchwork marine management policies have the potential to fragment habitat. 

As the climate is changing, the last thing we need is more oil and gas development. I firmly oppose any new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

I strongly support tribal co-management of the reserve and believe that decision-making power must be shared between NOAA and all tribes that want to be involved. I also support including Morro Rock/Lisamu’ as part of the sanctuary because it is an extremely important cultural site.

I regularly hike at Montana de Oro, Point Sal, and other spots along the coast. Whenever I'm along the coast I look for whales, dolphins and other marine mammals. I would like to see these waters and ecosystems protected for future generations.

Sincerely,

Rachel Friesen

Title: Comment from Wallace, Devin
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Devin Wallace and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Cayucos and the ocean is the reason I'm here. We are so fortunate to be close to the planet's lifeblood, so teeming with life.
Currently I volunteer doing water monitoring for the Morro Bay National Estuary Program. I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary holds to the initial boundary proposed with the Gaviota Coast Extension and the Rodriguez Seamount, which is essential to protect biodiversity.
 I realize that keeping the proposed boundaries will require some flexibility in considering the impacts of the windfarm infrastructure nearby, but to chop that section off seems extremely unwise, as the whole area needs protection at this critical point in our history.
I also believe the original proposed name, the Chumash Heritage Natonal Marine Sanctuary is the best choice, as the area contains so much Chumash history which must be preserved. Having the sanctuary under Tribal Collaborative Management will ensure that all tribes of the region have a voice. 
As a teacher I am particularly excited about the opportunities the sanctuary presents for Outreach & Education, includingresearch programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities.
One of the most important functions of the sanctuary will be to ban oil & gas development, which should have no place in these waters!
In summary, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
Sincerely,
Devin Wallace

Title: Comment from Sierra Club
Comment:
The Sierra Club is pleased to submit over 1400 signatures from 27 states and 300 cities in support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 
Thank you for proceeding with the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

We urge the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary within the borders of the Initial Boundary Alternative as originally proposed, along with the Gaviota Coast Extension.

Including the waters between Point Buchon and Cambria will close a biodiversity protection gap along the California coast. This will protect the only eel grass bed in a 300-mile stretch of coast, many historic Chumash sites, numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds, the area with the highest population of sea otters on the California coast, several State Marine Conservation Areas, the kelp forests of the Santa Barbara Channel, and rocky intertidal marine habitat considered to be one of the most diverse and abundant in the world.

Excluding any of these waters is unacceptable when multiple options are available that would allow for the permitting of the cables and infrastructure needed for the adjacent offshore wind area and would not require the permanent exclusion of 2,000 square miles of ocean from sanctuary protection. The National Marine Sanctuary Program should work closely with state and federal partners, OSW companies, Tribes, and community members to ensure off-shore wind is developed in the most environmentally and culturally responsible manner.

No other proposed alternative is adequate to this purpose. The Environmental Impact Statement acknowledges that all other alternatives would variously reduce the significant beneficial impacts on biological resources provided by the Initial Boundary Alternative to “moderate” or “minor” by comparison and increase the vulnerability of those resources to adverse impacts that the Initial Boundary Alternative would prohibit or mitigate. The alternatives that truncate the Initial Boundary Alternative would impact the many species that migrate through the unprotected areas, impacts that would go far beyond the wind farms' cable corridors.

We urge you to recognize your obligation to future generations and secure full protection for the irreplaceable ecosystem and cultural heritage of this vital marine region.

I fully support the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary that’s boundary’s stretch from Montana de Oro to Gaviota and feel it should be expanded to include the Morro Bay estuary as it’s waters flow in and out with the rhythm of the tides and should be protected as well. These flowing waters support marine life as well that includes the southern sea otters and their young offspring and the infrastructure furor the proposed massive floating windmills and undersea high voltage transmission along with passenger and commercial shipping are conflicting with the conservation and protection of the unique and natural environment that will be forever changed that’s irreplaceable with the developments proposed by corporate commercial gains. Not a word is mentioned about the Diablo Canyon twin reactors that’s scheduled closure in 2024+25=that due to lobbying efforts by PSG and was extended 5 years for commercial profits of the aged reactors while nuclear waste accumulates on site tucked away between Avila and Los Osos/ Morro Bay except to exclude its coastal marina and seawater discharge that continues to operate 24/7/365 with regulat testing local warning siren alarms intended to alert residents of imminent danger as Diablo Canyon ages with old technology that was constructed on an active earthquake fault. I strongly support this National Marine Sactuary and feel the boundaries should be extended to the sactuary to the north and include the living breathing essential flowing waters of Morro Bay as well. Many historic shell mounds left by indigenous remain on the sand spit uncovered then reburried by the shifting sand dunes blown by the prevailing westerly winds remaining shell mounds indigenous discarded as they consumed the meat within and discarded the clamshells. The local economies are supporting the residents employed by the people who visit to experience the charm of the small coastal towns that will undoubtably be negatively affected by this proposed massive system of floating wind turbine and the infrastructure supporting this unproven floating wind farm anchored to the deep underlying sea bed beneath.

Title: Comment from National Audubon Society
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern,

Please find attached an Excel spreadsheet (.xlsx) containing the comments of 18,757 supporters of the National Audubon Society asking the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to designate Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Many people submitted personalized comments, which can be found on the first worksheet; others sent the comments below: 
 
===================================
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, with boundaries that provide maximum protection from Cambria to Gaviota.  

With this sanctuary designation, we can create continuous ocean protection between the existing Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries.  

With the growing threats to our oceans and coasts, we cannot risk leaving this area open to harmful activities such as oil and gas extraction, seabed mining, and discharge into the ocean.  

Full protection will provide healthy habitats for seabirds and shorebirds that rely on this area. For example, 60% of the California Brown Pelican population is found within the proposed sanctuary. 

Morro Bay, an Important Bird Area, is one of the most significant wintering locations for migratory shorebirds on the Pacific Coast, with up to 20,000 birds feeding in the tidal mudflats. Sooty Shearwaters gather in the hundreds of thousands, relying on the open waters of the proposed sanctuary for food to make their annual migrations that span up to 40,000 miles.   

Offshore wind is essential in reaching our renewable energy goal, when wind turbines are sited in federal waters outside the proposed sanctuary and far from coastal resources and biologically rich state waters. I urge NOAA to work with the offshore wind industry and the state of California to site and permit only the necessary infrastructure, such as cables, to bring clean energy through the proposed sanctuary in locations that avoid or minimize ecological and cultural impacts.  

I urge NOAA to take bold actions and protect the largest area proposed for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
===================================
 
If you have any questions about the comments, prefer to receive them in a different format, or need additional information about the individuals submitting these comments, please do not hesitate to contact me.
 
Please accept our thanks for ensuring that the comments of these concerned individuals are considered.

Title: Comment from Chase, Johanna
Comment: We need your support and have just one key point to make regarding California’s Chumash Sanctuary.   California’s central coast is a bastion to California’s and our nation’s environmental, social, and cultural history.  Much like areas in the Hawaiian Islands and North Carolina’s Outer Banks,  California’s Central Coast is a unique place deserving of preservation without compromise.  Regulating use is key to preservation and this includes avoiding, preventing, and eliminating risks to our ecosystems and heritage.   Please ban petroleum and utility companies from further exploitation of California’s Central Coast.  Help us all respect and maintain our land and coastal waters for educational, cultural, and scientific purposes for generations to come.  Now is your opportunity to impact history!  Thank you,  Johanna Chase. Goleta CA

Title: Comment from Creation Justice Ministries
Comment:
Dear Regional Policy Coordinator Michel,

We, as faith leaders, are enthralled to witness the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, the first Tribal-nominated national marine sanctuary, now has a proposed draft management plan. We, the undersigned, recognize the importance of Indigenous-led resilience efforts. The Northern Chumash and other tribes in the area have been caring for these waters successfully for millenia. It is of the utmost importance that the recommendations made by the Northern Chumash are incorporated into the final management plan of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Our National Marine Sanctuaries need to be just that, sanctuaries. A space of care and comfort where all God’s creation can gather.  The ocean space nominated by the Northern Chumash Tribal Council to be a sanctuary, is just a formal acknowledgement of the care that the Northern Chumash and other tribes have given these waters for generations. We support the Northern Chumash in their continued care of God’s creation.

Specifically, we support the following recommendations of the Northern Chumash Tribal Council:

Sanctuary Boundary. It is vital that the sanctuary cover the largest possible contiguous boundaries. We support designation of the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alt 5b), including the waters offshore Point Buchon, Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria will close the California Central Coast’s biodiversity protection gap between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This will protect the only eelgrass bed in a 300-mile stretch of coast; many historic Chumash sites, including Lisamu’ (Morro Rock); numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds; the highest population of Southern sea otters on the California coast; several State Marine Conservation Areas; and the kelp forests and rocky intertidal habitats considered to be some of the most diverse and abundant in the world.

No other proposed sanctuary alternative is adequate. The Draft Environmental Impact Statement acknowledges that all other alternatives would reduce the significant beneficial effects on biological resources provided by the Initial Boundary Alternative. All other alternatives would increase the vulnerability of those resources to adverse impacts that the Initial Boundary Alternative would prohibit or mitigate.

We support the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” to honor the cultural history and stewardship of California Tribal Peoples, Equitable collaborative management must be open to all Tribal groups interested in participating, Outreach and Education, Rodriguez Seamount, Offshore Wind, and Water Quality.

We support equitable inclusion/representation of all Central Coast Tribes in the collaborative management of the sanctuary. By being equitable and inclusive, all sanctuary stakeholders will benefit from broad Indigenous input and TEK informing management. 

The sanctuary is an exceptional opportunity to advance the first Tribally-nominated national marine sanctuary designation in the United States, setting a precedent for elevating Indigenous perspectives, cultural values in ocean conservation, and collaborative management that includes all Central Coast Tribes. The designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary will be an unprecedented accomplishment, honoring the history and culture of Native Americans, the Chumash people, and their ancestors who inhabited this region for more than 10,000 years.

Each one of these asks is crucial to the continued successful sustenance and resilience of the ocean that will become the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. We thank you and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration for recognizing the importance of following Indigenous led resilience efforts and, more specifically, for creating the final management plan based on the points made above.

Sincerely, 

Eileen Gannon

Title: Comment from Brooks, Lynette
Comment: I support the establishment of the Chumash Marine Sanctuary. I am disappointed that the Morro Bay area has been left unprotected. Morro Bay provides shelter and calm water for otters, pelicans, herons, and other wildlife. This fall, pelicans were everywhere on the bay. Morro Bay also provides a calm place for residents and tourists to enjoy being on the water. On any given day, you can see kayaks, stand-up paddle boards, and dragon boats enjoying exercise and the wildlife. Leaving this area unprotected and allowing it to become an industrial corridor jeopardizes all of this.

Title: Comment from Smith, Jason
Comment:
The Chumash people, especially Violet Sage Walker and her organization were super pivotal for this this marine sanctuary moving forward. It seems very wrong for the Biden Adminstration to exclude the original designated area from their new draft proposal of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I understand that it has to do with energy and the underwater cables that transport the energy from offshore wind-- but I think it violates the original spirit of the movement to exclude the Chumash people now from this process. 
I ask that the NOAA strongly reconsider their draft proposal to more accurately reflect the original proposal that they described when collaborating with the Chumash people. They have the best authority, knowledge and stewardship of that land and thus it should be reflected in this process. 
I really value this project, and the emphasis on environmental protection that the administration. Not only that-- I HIGHLY value the open collaboration the administration has placed with indigenous people (the Tongva in San Gabriel, etc). It has a been a tremendous step of healing that I do not take lightly. For this reason, I ask that the Administration, through the NOAA, rise to their own bar that they have set previously. I know you can do it, and thank you for what you've done in the past.

Please extend the sanctuary back to the original area proposed by the Chumash people, it is fundamentally the right thing to do. 

Thank you so much, 
Jason Smith (Pasadena Resident)

Title: Comment from Nussbaum, Julia
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
I write to support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Campbell, California and frequently visit the coastal region within the proposed National Marine Sanctuary.  To me, the ocean contains the most important habitats to support life on earth and the emotional wellbeing of residents and visitors of this area.  Additionally, the following points are critical:
•	Habitats in the ocean are equipped to reduce the amount of carbon in the atmosphere, and when protected can be additionally beneficial.
•	With climate change, the sensitive habitats in the ocean need additional protections.
•	Many people that live in or visit California depend on the ocean for recreation, spiritual well-being, community connections, and economic health.
•	I want to protect this stretch of ocean so the community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
•	The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
•	Contiguous protections in the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension are necessary to protect migrating species, such as whales and dolphins.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
•	Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
•	Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
•	Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
•	Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
•	Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
•	Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,
Julia Nussbaum

Title: Comment from Roschen , Jane
Comment: Please consider the Initial Boundary, Alternative 1 Bank to Coast or at the very least the inclusion of the Sub-alternative 5a Morro Bay for the official designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The inflammatory and still widely unknown cost-benefit of the proposed offshore wind developments in this area create 1) uncertainty around the viability and affordability of project implementation and delivery and 2) risk of environmental degradation and ecological impact. A Marine Sanctuary designation will allow for the safe and timely evaluation of potential impacts of floating offshore wind at this scale and allow for a permitting process that meets the high standard an area with such biodiversity and ecological preservation deserves to have. Without a designated protection of the area, the local marine habitats, coastal economies, and utility ratepayers risk bearing the burden of overambitious and costly infrastructure for the greater benefit of major load centers in the State. Instead, please reconsider a Marine Sanctuary designation and offer a schedule of the offshore wind that accurately accounts for the preservation of local environments and economies. Meaningful collaboration and thoughtful development of the offshore wind will occur through the proper designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary that will foster stewardship equitably across California coastal environment and marine habitat. Without it, we risk the long-term costs of unknown and likely irreversible ecological damage and irresponsible industrialization of the coast. We also risk communities paying unjustly and unfairly high energy costs by encouraging ground-breaking energy development process that does not deliver the proper due diligence. As an energy professional myself, I ask you to provide the critical protection we must have for ocean environments in order to effectively mitigate climate change and realize the sustainable development of a clean energy system.

Title: Comment from Linsteadt, Sylvia
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Sylvia, I’m a 34-year old novelist and wildlife tracker. I was born and raised in Mill Valley, California and am devoted to our beautiful land and waters, and to traditions of the indigenous people of this state. I grew up going regularly to the beaches of the Point Reyes Peninsula, a National Seashore, and those memories are still guiding lights for me in my life. The ocean is personally my place of sanctuary and inspiration; a constant mystery that heals and uplifts and awes me. And our oceans are in turn precious natural resources in these times of climate chaos that deserve to be protected and preserved. 

I therefore support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I ask that this sanctuary includes the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension; the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary; an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management; outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities; the protection of Rodriguez Seamount, essential to the protection of biodiversity; and, very importantly, a prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,

Sylvia Linsteadt

Title: Comment from Gallerani, Erica
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Erica Gallerani and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Los Angeles CA and am a PhD candidate at UCLA studying endangered forest birds on Kauai. Despite my focus on terrestrial ecology in my research, I have gained an unbelievable love and appreciation for the California coast when I first went free diving in a kelp forest in the Chanel Islands. Many of my colleagues at UCLA study marine protected areas and the strong effect that these designations have on the ecology of California's coast. Without the protection of marine resources in collaboration with Indigenous communities, then California will lose a great deal of it's appeal, identity, and productivity. 

I therefore support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Erica Gallerani

Title: Comment from Williams, Michael

Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Micheal Williams.  I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension.  
I live in Morro Bay and to me, the ocean is where I start my day and end my day.  Each day begins with a walk south along the beach to Morro Rock and back.  At the end of the day I take my two dogs north to Dog Beach and we throw balls and retrieve to their Labrador’s delight.  
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. It should include the Initial Boundary with the Gaviota Coast Extension.  All of the local tribes should be involved in the management of the Sanctuary.  The Sanctuary should ban all wind turbines, oil and gas development.  If the Federal government insists on funding the Wind Farm project despite overwhelming evidence  from around the world that these ocean based wind farms will never be profitable, let them build outside the boundary.  
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,
Michael Williams

Title: Comment from EarthEcho International
Comment: On behalf of 130 young ocean advocates and 19 youth-led and youth-serving organizations, clubs, and groups we are submitting the attached letter of support for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Thank you!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Boeck, Eli
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Eli and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Vallejo, CA, and to me, the ocean has always been important in my life. 

I enjoy open water swimming along the coast and in the bays, so keeping it clean, safe, and publicly accessible is crucial in my life. Swimming significantly helps my chronic pain, and being in the cold open water of California's coast is perhaps the most rejuvenating feeling I get!
I also volunteered for years in public education and outreach about ocean ecology and health, and I worked in ocean conservation policy in Washington DC. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Eli Boeck
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Pizot, Toby
Comment:
As an engineer, clean energy is critical to the continued development of SLO County. At the same time, it is important to consider the effects of the development on marine life and the tradition of the Chumash. This is why I am totally in favor of Alternative 3, I believe it is the best way to compromise and chart the best path forward for all stakeholders. Alternative 3 provides that crucial clean energy to maintain California net zero targets (a net positive for the environment), while providing a significant area for marine sanctuary.

Thank you.

Title: Comment from Rosenau, Frances
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel,

My name is Rev. Dr. Frances Wattman Rosenau. I am a faith leader involved in my community, I am a parent and advocate for our planet. I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I have recently had the blessing of following my 11 year old son's lead to take up scuba diving. He loves the ocean, and I am in awe of his connection to our planet, our local eco systems, and the wildlife that lives just off our coast. I live in Culver City, but this summer we spent a lot of time in the Channel Islands hiking, snorkeling, and scuba diving. I learned more about the Chumash connection to that site and the way Santa Cruz particularly, almost saw several unique species go extinct. Preservation of both the ecology and the heritage was so crucial in designating the national park and protected areas of the surrounding ocean.

What's especially important to me is following the lead of indigenous people and tribes.  The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” is imperative. Conservation is not a new fad but one that my religious forefathers did not fully appreciate when they came to California. It is time to right the wrongs of the past through designated this protected area - with the initial boundary alternative - to preserve the tribal connection to these waters and coastline. 

This is a great opportunity to have more education of Traditional Ecological Knowledge and bring that knowledge to local under-served communities. This would also redress some of the harm done in the past by exploitative practices both towards people and towards the ecology.
    
And, of course, we need to prohibit any new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures. A sustainable relationship to the waters is possible and the time is now. 

Sincerely,

Rev. Dr. Frances Wattman Rosenau
Culver City Presbyterian Church

Title: Comment from Lancaster, Aubri
Comment:
My name is Aubri Lancaster and I am writing in support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension. I live in Simi Valley, CA and believe that my ability to live here is contingent on a healthy ecosystem of which the ocean is an inextricable part. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary needs full support to cover as much area as possible and to be cared for by the Chumash Tribes who have centuries of knowledge regarding this region. I support the protection of Rodriquez Seamount to support biodiversity and a ban on Oil and Gas development in this delicate environment.

Thank you for taking the time to read my letter and I have faith in your agency's ability to make this sanctuary possible for the benefit of all our citizens and our ocean.

Aubri Lancaster
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Collins, Ezra
Comment: I wholeheartedly support the proposed designation of a new marine sanctuary in California. As a college student studying biology, hoping to go into conservation work after I graduate later this year, I see this as a very strong step in the right direction. Conserving our oceans is key to the future of countless species, including humanity. This measure would stop the specter of offshore oil drilling, allowing us to do the key research needed to know what our effect on the things living there may be. In addition, the designation of this sanctuary is projected to create jobs, which is always a good thing for the economy and society. And finally, perhaps most importantly, by designating this sanctuary and consulting with the Chumash people while doing so, this act will allow indigenous Californians to finally have some say over the stewardship of their historical lands. This will also allow everyone to benefit from indigenous knowledge when it comes to conservation stewardship, hopefully creating a more effective plan for management overall.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Dolphin, Dobie
Comment:
Hi,
My name is Dobie Dolphin. I've lived on the Mendocino Coast for over 50 years. I fished for salmon in the 1980's, dove for sea urchins when the Chinese first started buying sea urchins in this area. I spent countless hours going out of Albion in my kayak, diving for abalone, spearing fish, and enjoying the rich undersea garden that was here - giant sea stars, nudibranchs, iridescent kelp, seals, fish, and so much more. I totally support the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, with the largest possible boundary. I think there should be a ban on new oil and gas development in the Sanctuary area. I'm concerned about the proposed wind farm in this area. It's too close to shore and too big. I'm in favor of wind farms but I think this one could be located in a less biodiverse area. 
I hope you will collaborate with the Chumash and other local tribes to make this Marine Sanctuary the biggest and best it can be.
Thank you,
Dobie Dolphin
volunteer Noyo Center for Marine Science

Title: Comment from Wyss, Leslie
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

I write in support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 

My husband and I have lived on the Central Coast for 25 years. I am a sailor, paddler, scuba diver, bird watcher. In short -  I have first hand knowledge of the area. But I don’t ask for the sanctuary designation for my own use, but so that it will be preserved in perpetuity. We do not know what secrets the sea hold for us, but we do know that we are capable of grave damage to the natural environment unless we create boundaries and laws to control our actions.

I ask that this sanctuary include:

• The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.
• Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity.
• Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

I do support exploration into development of wind energy solutions. However, I don't believe it is necessary to reduce the proposed NMS because this might be a possibility in the future. We should be able to find a way to develop wind in a manner compatible with the values of a marine sanctuary.

Thank you for your consideration.
Leslie Wyss
Morro Bay, CA

Title: Comment from Karoff, Deborah
Comment:
My name is Deborah Karoff and I am a resident of Santa Barbara. I want to applaud the Chumash bands throughout the Central Coast for proposing the Sanctuary and working so hard towards federal designation. I also want to applaud NOAA for their collective analysis and consideration of the many factors and issues involved in their recommendation. I am interested in protecting as much of the California coast as possible and I fully support the original designation as proposed by the Northern Chumash Tribal Council. 
I have read the revised designation proposed by NOAA and understand the reasons and rationale for reducing the protected coastline to allow for the development of undersea cables for off-shore energy development between Morro Bay and Monterey Bay. I have no technical background to asses the needs and impact of off-shore energy development but I would hope that some way could be found to develop wind energy in a way that allows for minimal environmental impact and protects more of the coastline as proposed by NOAA. 
It is challenging to balance the protection of coastline and marine life with the need for alternative energy sources. However, we need the ocean to be protected and the more we develop parts or sections of it, the higher the risk of more serious environmental impacts. The ocean is an eco system that can't be organized into compartments and ocean is not the only source for wind energy. I urge you to reconsider the NOAA designation and adopt the designation as originally proposed by the Chumash. Thank you.

Title: Comment from Bethel, Paul

It is so important that we preserve God's unique and irreplaceable coastal ecosystems and safeguard thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites.  I ask that you respect the Northern Chumash Tribal Council requests regarding sanctuary boundary, the sanctuary name and tribal collaborative management.  Thank you for your work on this immediate need to preserve God's creation.

Title: Comment from Ballesteros, Jennifer
Comment:
As a Surfrider member and/ or coastal recreation user, I strongly support the designation of a new national marine sanctuary off the central California coast.
This designation should be named Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in recognition of the history and culture of the Chumash people.
The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should be officially designated as soon as possible.
The sanctuary boundaries should include the full geographic extent reflected in the original proposal - i.e., the Initial Boundary Alternative - as well as the Gaviota Coast Extension (5B) boundary option. 
The management plan should ensure the lasting protection of the sanctuary’s outstanding ecological and cultural resources.
The sanctuary should prohibit any oil and gas exploration, development or production.
The sanctuary should prohibit seabed mining, ocean dumping and other activities damaging to the seafloor, cultural resources and marine ecosystem.
The sanctuary should protect water quality from pollution sources including cruise ships, commercial vessels and agricultural runoff.
Indigenous Collaborative Management should be applied in an equitable manner to empower the Chumash Nation and other Indigenous Peoples to steward these invaluable resources.
The sanctuary should support and promote marine research, education, stewardship, recreation and tourism. 
Protecting this biodiverse marine life is essential, as is supporting stewardship from the Chumash Nation and other Indigenous Peoples. We need more measures like this in order to keep our planet livable.

Title: Comment from Naegle, Erin
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Erin Naegle, and am the co-founder of the Gold Country Bat Project, and I support whole heartedly the  designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
This area of the coast is critical habit to so many species, as humans that have disrupted and destroyed habitat in so many places, providing this protected marine corridor is the very least we can do. And I am so very grateful for the designation of the Marine Sanctuary, thank you for all of your work and effort in this process. I also strongly plead that the entire Initial Boundary Alternative be used when making the sanctuary.
I live in Cambria CA, and have come to love this coast and ocean. My wife and I moved here because of the wild coast. Listening to the otters crack open shells and watching the pelicans dive for their lunch is heartening. There are places where life continues to be in abundance. This needs our thoughtful and committed protection.  
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the biggest possible boundary and a prohibition on new oil and gas development. I also ask that any windfarm development be done mindfully, and minimize impacts on birds, bats, marine mammals, and the great variety of fish. Wind turbines can be regulated so that they are not running during migrations or when bats are active. 
Furthermore, the protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity. It is undoubtedly home to species heretofore undocumented. Let us protect it rather than alter the habitat.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 With Gratitude for your time and attention,
Erin Naegle
Cambria CA resident, 
trained biologist and co-founder of Gold Country Bats,
 STEM Dean at Cuesta College in San Luis Obispo

Comment: Everyone that lives on the Central Coast has a responsibility to help protect our beautiful coastal waters.  We live in such a wonderful place. Let's keep it safe for generations to come . The deadline is Wednesday. Please sign and comment on the proposed Chumash National Marine Sanctuary.  Thank you.

Title: Comment from Murphy, Betty
Comment:
I love visiting my daughter in Cambria California.   We watch the sea otters  in the kelp, the harbor seals, elephant seals, dolphins and whales (a month ago we  seeing them breach as well as seeing their spouts from the shore at Fiscalinin Ranch.   The brown Pelicans fly up and down the coast, constantly it seems in the fall.  I love the ocean and the fresh air, and the amazing un-obscured sunsets.
My points for this coment letter 
1.  Sanctuary Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension Sanctuary
The contiguous nature of the sanctuaries along the California coast are is of the upmost importantce - creating a cotinuous protected marine wildlife corridor.  And so important to include the bulge - go out all the way to the edge of the continental shelf.  The marine life depends on the upwelling that happens there.
Also important to me is science - my daughter studies bats, and I am quite concerned that it sounds like very little research has been done offshore to understand the migration of insects, bats, and birds and how the proposed windfarms may effect them.  And I am very concerned about floating windfarms.  In my lifetime I have seen so many incidents of unintended negitive environmental consequences as a result of not doing proper science and studies before trying to create a new way of doing something.   Often slow and steady wins the race and fast and furious ends up upside down in the bleachers. 
I do not want to see any more development of oil and gas along the coast and certainly not in the NMSs.  And no sea floor mining.  My daughter told me about the permits for kelp harvesting and it seems like with all the stressors we are adding  to the ocean, we should really  think hard about our actions. 
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount - This needs to be a priority to protect, include in the new sanctuary, and have researchers begin to understand what is living there.  I have heard about the Davidson Sea Mound in Monterey Bay NMS (my daughter told me about all the new species that have been discovered there) these sea mounds are unique habitat -  Rodriguez sea mound needs to be in the sanctuary boundaries.   I would also like to see an education center for the school children and for tourists and locals.   We love going to the Monterey Bay Aquarium and always learn so much.  It would be nice to have a simpler, smaller version of that - perhaps in Morrow Bay area.
Thank you for reading my thoughts on the matter.
These are very important decisions you are making.  To protect the earth and it's inhabitants is what we are all called to do.  I wish we were doing a better job of it.   Please let your decisions move us towards better stewardship of the marine environment along the California Coast.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Stransky, Lynn
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Lynn "Jeong" Stransky, and I strongly support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. This move would not only protect wildlife, but it would be a small step towards reparations.

I live in Los Angeles, CA and to me, the ocean is one of our most precious landscapes and resources, and it must be protected. We know that Indigenous people have an intimate relationship with the land, and they will care for it better than any industrialized nation ever could. Protecting this area would do so much to protect wildlife!

Please, I urge you to support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary be as large as possible, named the "Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary," managed through tribal collaborative management, and encompass the Rodriguez Seamount too. I also demand that you prohibit new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries. There are so many incredible renewable energy sources that it is embarrassing to use anything else.

I whole-heatedly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge you to please, please, please designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary for our current and future generations.

Sincerely,

Lynn "Jeong" Stransky

Title: Comment from Swenson, Virginia
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Virginia Swenson and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Los Angeles. To me the ocean is a sacred place, a place we have to protect at all costs. I surf, swim, and play at the beach. I feel held and inspired by the ocean. I want everyone, humans, animals, and plants to be able to thrive and enjoy our beautiful stretch of coast. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes all the asks of the Chumash people; the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension, the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”, an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management, outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities, the protection of Rodriguez Seamount, and a prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,
Virginia Swenson
