Title: Comment from Rosen, Dorah
Comment:
Dear NOAA, 
As someone who lives on Monterey Bay in Santa Cruz CA, close to your offices there, I stand with the Chumash requests for the following important measures to truly protect the CHNMS. Having the Chumash themselves officially involved in stewarding and planning for its protection is of paramount importance. I volunteer with the Amah Mutsun, who have a State of California grant to protect part of our amazing coastline. I can see the dignity and care with which the tribal members discharge their responsibilities. 
Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

Sincerely, DR, Central Coast CA, PADI certified scuba diver
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Kamiel, Lauri
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern,

I just returned from a vacation in honor of my birthday in San Luis Obispo County (I am a resident of Ventura County, but go up north as much as possible to the Central Coast, most frequently to Santa Barbara). It was a magical weekend and highlights include climbing Black Hill and admiring the entire Morro Bay coastline, as well as a sunset at the beach at Morro Rock, with horses on the beach in the distance. This area inspires awe with its overwhelming beauty. Adding to the value of natural beauty is the history of the region as sacred land to the Chumash people. I have great respect for the history and ecology, and feel strongly all should be done to preserve this precious natural area. On my last trip to the region, I also enjoyed a stunning sunset over Montana de Oro. The gifts of the region are for locals and tourists alike, and the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary protects it for generations to come. I hope to experience the same pristine beauty for many more vacations, and the proposed rule protects a vulnerable environment, already struggling from Climate Change. Let's do the least we can do and make the Chumash Heritage Sanctuary a reality! Thank you, Lauri Kamiel
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Treeson, Emanuel
Comment:
I recently moved to San Luis Obispo County but have been visiting here for more than 25 years.  It is because of the unspoiled Pacific Coast which nurtures amazing kelp forests, the seagrass beds of the Morro Bay Estuary, migrating birds, whales, elephant seals and otters that I have been drawn to want to make a life here. This is a treasure that we have a responsibility to protect. Our other California marine sanctuaries have been shown to be economically and ecologically beneficial to our state, country and planet. Let's continue to be good stewards.

I support the establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary using the largest possible contiguous sanctuary boundaries, as shown in the Initial Boundary Alternative combined with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alternative 5b). I think it's vitally important to link our marine sanctuaries. I am also strongly in favor of a plan that allows for the best use of wind power off coastline.  I support any needed permits need to create the wind farm and believe this  can be created with greater oversight than if we left out that part of the coast of Morro Bay up to San Simeon.

Thank you for giving the public comments consideration. Thank you for your time and we hope for as much haste as possible for the completion of this sanctuary designation while we have the momentum of public and governmental support.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Thorp, Ashley
Comment: Living near the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary, I understand how important it is to protect our ocean environment and all the animals and organisms within. Last semester, earlier this year, I actually interned at the MBNMS Sanctuary Exploration Center in Santa Cruz. Within this internship I was tasked with aiding on field trips, to teach kids the importance of keeping our beaches and oceans clean, the health of our kelp forests, testing of oceanography, and much more. This internship taught me a lot of things I hadn't known before. I was learning, along with the kids, what a sanctuary was and why it was important. As we are dealing with increasing ocean temperatures, we are noticing negative effects that come with it. Which is why it is important to have a protected area that we are able to test and monitor; for both improvements or declines. A designated sanctuary will allow for regulations to keep everything inside safe and help diminish the wicked problems of pollution of all forms (fossil fuels, noise, light, trash, etc.). Traveling the coast of California from north down to south, there are clear differences in the ocean where you can tell which portion has regulations against pollution and which beaches don't. Protection of the ocean isn't only beneficial to aquatic organisms, but to the health of humans as well. If fish are eating microplastics, and we eat fish, we are eating microplastics too. Everything in this world is intertwined, a domino effect, one small thing can eventually cause catastrophe to all things, until nothing is habitable (talking on worst case scenario but still a likely possibility we’re headed towards). It takes small acts to ruin something, but it can take small acts to improve something as well. Which to some adding a sanctuary may seem useless but it’s not. Just like when the Monterey Bay National Marine Santuary was established after a large oil spill, we started seeing ocean animals populations increase again. Also with the otter populations, otters are mainly found along the west coast due to these protection (no longer allowed to hunt for them) and they are still slowly climbing out of their almost extinct phase. There is a lot to be fixed in this world, and establishing this sanctuary is one small step that will help towards a larger goal.

Title: Comment from WACHMAN, ROBERT
Comment: Please include Moro Bay and from there to Cambria within the boundary of the sanctuary.  It's very important that the wishes of the Chumash people, the longtime protectors of the area, are respected.  Sincerely, Robert Wachman

Title: Comment from Cecchi, Nicholas
Comment:
Hello,

My name is Nicholas Cecchi from Sacramento, California, and I want to express my support for this management plan (naming, protection, and area). It so happens I have stumbled upon this plan after a full day of thinking about my university's (Sacramento State University) indigenous land acknowledgement. This led me to read about the California native American genocide of the 1800s, and the newly appointed California truth and healing council. The past is out of reach, but we can both affect the future and appreciate the humanity that is around us here in the present. It is with that ethos/background that tribal co-management and naming of this sanctuary appeal to me, as well as the sanctuary status itself.

Furthermore, being this area of coastline has had a past with oil spills/leaks (eg: Avila beach) and will seemingly continue to feel non-native developmental pressures (ie: housing sprawl), this in my opinion lends the area as a good candidate for as much marine protection (and it's biodiverse areas like Rodriguez Seamount) as possible.

The California state government have long iterated energy commitments to the public that will decrease the reliance of fossil fuel sources as much as possible: any comment contrary to this sanctuary plan presented at the federal level would not be supportive, representative, or substantiated of the needs or goals at the local level. This is an especially important point of relevance in this plan as the tribal population concerned is concentrated right at this sanctuary area and nowhere else in the nation.

I hope this hastily written comment has provided some meaningful input. Thank you for reading,

-Nick

Title: Comment from Fernandez, Christian
Comment:
See attached file(s)

Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Christian Fernandez and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Watsonville, CA and to me, the ocean is Vital to myself and my community around me. 
When I go to the coast, I go with my friends, family, and dog. We all enjoy making memories together, watching the sunsets, feeling the breeze, and sharing smores together on summer nights.
I enjoy the sounds of the waves as they provide me with a sense of serenity, watching wildlife, and the beauty of mother nature.
The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, spiritual well-being, community connections, and economic health.
I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is both gorgeous and fascinating.  We've obtained a tremendous amount of knowledge from it, and there's still a lot more to discover. A marine sanctuary will be essential in ocean research and education for current and future generations.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” to recognize people that have lived on this coast since time immemorial, by Western estimates over 10,000 years and protect the heritage of the Chumash.
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management. To support the creation of a Tribal Sanctuary Advisory Council made up of all interested local Tribal groups as well as a NOAA Tribal Liaison.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education, and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities. We could include educational programs and efforts to protect and maintain historically significant sites.
Scientific Research: Marine sanctuaries frequently provide opportunities for scientific research to better understand and monitor marine ecosystems. This research can help to inform conservation efforts and increase our understanding of marine life.
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity because it provides a critical habitat for an extremely diverse and abundant array of marine life.
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
Conservation of Marine Ecosystems: To protect and conserve marine ecosystems, such as coral reefs, kelp forests, seafloor habitats, and various species that live in these areas. Involves regulations that prevent damage to at-risk habitats, such as restrictions on fishing, anchoring, or other potentially harmful activities.
Recreational Opportunities: We may allow for acceptable recreational activities such as diving, snorkeling, boating, and wildlife watching, as long as they are done responsibly.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,

Christian Fernandez

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: I would like to talk to you about a very interesting and important topic I learnt called " Keystone Species" in my Zoology class. Every ecosystem has one or few key stone species, these species play a greater role in maintaining the function and diversity of an ecosystem. In short, their absence or decline in their population will have a greater impact on the whole ecosystem. The Southern Sea Otters are one of species which would improve the Ocean ecosystem of our Central coast. Their existence and survival will define the ecosystem of the California current which starts from Alaska and continues to Baja Mexico. I truly support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary Proposal. It is our duty to correct the mistakes of our past or at least try for the better tomorrow.

Title: Comment from Crockett, Margaret
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Margaret Crockett, I do not speak for Pacific Wildlife Care, but I am a Past President of that organization, and current supporter of theirs, as such I support all sorts of environmental issues in San Luis Obispo County in which I have lived for over 17 years. I absolutely support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in San Luis Obispo and our Pacific Ocean which is within a few miles of me on 180 degrees land and sea around me.

I happened to be at a Pacific Wildlife Care event on Sunday October 22, 2023 and there met a lawyer who has been working on the National Marine Sanctuary.  I told her that I already favored the inclusion of the whole area off our coast, but learned from her that a whole swath of the coast from Cambria down to Morro Bay is being considered as dropped from the Santuary, even more than I had thought.  I asked why, of course. She told me because of the potential for the wind farm which may or may not even be built in our area.

I learned from her that if it even is approved to be built it will likely be 10 years from now, and there are questions about how likely it is given the amount of wind we receive.  Although the argument is often given that our site is perfect for a wind farm because of the electrical infrastructure we have in Morro Bay and off of Diablo Canyon.  The technology in these locations is decades old, very likely way too antiquated to be equal to the task.  A cable might be needed, ok this is far off in time, and the Chumash people have said over and over that they are willing to collaborate with any wind farm organizations which are engaged, if they ever are.  In the meantime, we need to connect the whole Pacific Coast between the Monterey Marine Sanctuary and the Channel Islands Marine Sanctuary.  Anything less is a very very sad partial solution to the protection our coast requires!

I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:
Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.  To do something less than all this would be a pitiful substitute from the whole solution we need in this area.

Thank you for your concern and your thoughtful consideration!
 
Sincerely,
Margaret R. Crockett

Title: Comment from Environment America and Environment California
Comment:
Paul Michel, Regional Policy Coordinator
NOAA Office of National Marine Sanctuaries
99 Pacific Street, Suite 100F
Monterey, CA 93940

Re: NOAA–NOS–2021–0080

Dear Mr. Michel,

Environment California is a non-profit environmental advocacy group with one mission: to build a greener, healthier world. Along with our national partner, Environment America, we are submitting 11,594 public comments on behalf of our members and followers. 

Our organizations wholeheartedly support the creation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. From warming waters to threatened species to pollution from oil drilling and more, our oceans are in need of additional conservation efforts. Sanctuaries and marine monuments can play an important role in providing healthier marine habitats and healthier oceans altogether. 

The proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary encompasses a diverse range of ecosystems teeming with marine life. Its habitats include coral reefs, kelp forests, coastal wetlands and more. It’s a feeding stop for migratory marine mammals and provides a home for 25 threatened or endangered species, including southern sea otters, leatherback sea turtles and humpback whales. Establishing the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary will protect the area from significant threats, including offshore oil and gas drilling, which can have devastating impacts on marine life, as evidenced by the 2021 oil spill off the coast of Orange County. 

The area also holds deep cultural significance to the Chumash people and is the first tribally nominated national marine sanctuary.

As you finalize the plan, we urge your agency to choose the most extensive and continuous sanctuary boundaries, as outlined in the Initial Boundary Alternative combined with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alternative 5b). This would bridge the unprotected gap between the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary to the north and the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary to the south, ensuring a connected stretch of coastline where oil drilling is prohibited, safeguarding these critical ecosystems. 

We understand that NOAA may have reduced the size of the sanctuary to accommodate offshore wind. Know that we write this letter as supporters of offshore wind. There’s no reason why responsibly placed offshore wind support infrastructure cannot coexist with a sanctuary. 

Additionally, we support the creation of a Research Activity Panel (RAP) with a designated NOAA Research Coordinator, similar to the structure in the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary. This will result in a comprehensive understanding of the marine environment.

Here is the specific language of the public comment that our 11,594 members and followers signed: 


Thank you for your swift action to create the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The region off the California coast is home to sea otters, kelp forests, and deep sea areas that are still unexplored.

We support Sub-Alternative 5b; the Initial Boundary Alternative combined with the Gaviota Coast Extension, the original boundary proposed by the Northern Chumash Tribe. This is the only proposal to create a contiguous series of sanctuaries from Monterey Bay to the Channel Islands.

It is vital that this incredibly biodiverse region receives permanent protection from oil drilling and mining as well as the opportunity for additional resources to manage and protect this ocean life.

By establishing the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the most extensive boundaries, NOAA will take the next step towards safeguarding California’s incredible ocean life for decades to come. 

Sincerely,


Laura Deehan					        Kelsey Lamp
Director, Environment California		Oceans Campaigns Director, Environment America

Title: Comment from Kaiser, Risa
Comment: Dear Mr. Michel, Thank you for the time and energy you give in the process of designating and managing marine sanctuaries on the central coast.    I have been telling people what a gracious and kind man I have seen you to be in the Grover Beach and San Luis Obispo public events.  My love for the ocean runs deep; two granddaughters are studying to be marine conservationists, I am a retired earth science teacher, and I lead a peace and earth care group for a local Friends (Quaker) meeting.  My personal goal these last two months has been to educate and activate 100 people about the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  The positive energy I have seen has gratified me.  The Central Coast Friends Meeting approved a minute in support unanimously.  I have tried to emphasize that NOAA was pressured by BOEM and the State of California to delete the area from Morro Bay to Cambria to make it easier for the projected wind farm to lay cables, but these cables need to have permits or they could harm sea life and the ocean floor inadvertantly.  I am certain that with all our voices begging NOAA to restore the initial boundaries to include Morro Bay to Cambria that NOAA will be able to stand up for the initial sanctuary boundaries.  I have also praised NOAA's addition of the Gaviota coast extension which shows sensitivity to tribal requests.  I am confident that you will honor the endless hours and effort of the Northern Chumash and designate the area they proposed.  Thank you so much.  Sincerely, Risa Kaiser, Arroyo Grande, CA

Title: Comment from Taylor, Elizabeth
Comment: I fully support the creation of additional marine sanctuaries but feel that much greater restrictions on fishing are needed within them. We’ve seen that large no take zones increase biodiversity and with climate change, provide additional safety nets for wildlife. Very few people need to eat ocean wildlife but marine mammals, sea birds and fish have limited options. We also need to strengthen scientific research and monitoring in MPAs/sanctuaries along with developing more recreational access that isn’t fishing - examples include small vessel ramps/hoists, scuba diving access, bird/whale watching, and tide pooling. What if monies currently allocated to underwriting fishing went to restoring our National Undersea Research Program instead? It would create more meaningful jobs while enhancing our knowledge about the ocean.

Title: Comment from Cheatham, Chas
Comment: I know this is just one persons' opinion, but I agree with the proposed carve-outs in the sanctuary area in order to support the needed commercial activities necessary to maintain a vibrant local economy and national interests.  Overall, there is sufficient area for the sanctuary to make a good environmental and cultural statement, while leaving enough area carved-out to also maintain a necessary commercial interest.

Title: Comment from Hemming, Brooke
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Brooke L. Hemming and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I am a native Californian, currently living in Durham, North Carolina.  To me, the California coastline is my spiritual home and a refuge that sustained me during my undergraduate and doctoral studies at UC Berkeley and Stanford University.  During those years, I learned about the critical role our oceans play in the stability of Earth's climate system as well as global ecosystems.  When life in the lab became overwhelming, I would get in my car and drive out to Monterey Bay and the surrounding coastal areas to remind myself of why I wanted to do work in environmental science and protection.  When I retire from my current civil service job, I hope to return to the area to live out the remainder of my life. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
            1)  Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
            2)  Named the “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
            3) Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
            4) Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local 
            underserved communities
            5) Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
            6)  ABSOLUTELY BAN further oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely, Brooke L. Hemming

Title: Comment from Akin, Rebecca
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel,

I am writing in strong support of the immediate designation of the entire proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, specifically one that excludes the NOAA proposed off shore wind energy project. 

I live in Novato California and actively involve myself in the Grater Farallones National Marine Sanctuary through my Beach Watch volunteer role. In this role I’ve learned so much about the importance of Marine Sanctuaries in general in terms of stewardship and education as well as the value they provide in protecting what is one of the most biologically diverse spots on earth. 

Having the addition of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would make California a model for Marine Sanctuary designation, situating the current Cordell Bank, the Greater Farallones, and the Channel Islands Sanctuaries in one long close to interconnected whole. What a magnificent and positive accomplishment that would be. 

I want to reiterate my support for the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, one that includes tribal collaboration, the largest possible boundary (the initial boundary alternative with the Gaviota Coast extension), and a prohibition on new oil and gas development. Again, I do not support the NOAA proposed off shore wind energy project and it’s resulting direct negative impact on the marine ecosystem structures and functions. 

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in order to honor our commitment as stewards of our precious California Eastern Pacific marine ecosystem. 

Best regards, 

Rebecca Akin, PhD 
804 Wilson Ave.
Novato, CA 94947
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Murphy, John
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel,

I am writing in vigorous support of designating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I was born and raised in Santa Barbara.  Not without some reluctance I left the area at age 23 to pursue a Ph.D. in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology. I now live in San Diego, CA--a close second, but not Santa Barbara.  I return to the central coat often.  I have been fortunate to travel to many other beautiful places as well.  None however captivate my heart and mind like the central coast of California.  I have heard many, many visitors say so as well.  When I learned today of the push to create the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary I was absolutely thrilled.  This is an amazing opportunity to protect a beautiful place in a way that the United States of America has done so well with many of its public lands.  Other countries look up to the US for this, and we certainly see the thrill in the faces of tourists when they see our public lands.  We must continue to protect our land and ocean. This is a fight that must be waged every day by every generation in the face of society's temptation for unmitigated extraction of resources from our planet.  There is a place for extraction of needed resources, but the central coast of California is not that place.  It is pristine in a way that will not come back in any reasonable time frame if we let the market determine how the land and sea is used.  I urge you in the unique role of being a government agency to be a proper steward of the land and sea by protecting this beautiful place for the long term.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.


Sincerely,

John Murphy

Title: Comment from Crawmer, Susan

Please support this Chumash  marine sanctuary and tell NOAA to find another windy place on the vast California coastline to put a wind farm. Find the alternative location & go back to the drawing board.

Title: Comment from Moore, Barrie
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Barrie Moore and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Redwood City, California and have lived in California all my life.  As a student at UCSB in the 1980’s, I lived with a view of the ocean marred by oil rigs. Those oil rigs will never go away. This is our chance to protect an important part of our central coast so the ocean can stay the way is has been for millennia. 
•	My husband and I often travel along the central coast, camping and hiking at Morro Bay State Park, walking the beaches in Cambria, and enjoying the views of the ocean along Highway 1.
•	The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.
•	I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my children, grandchildren and our entire community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
•	The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
•	The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
•	The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” to honor the Native Americans who have called this area home for thousands of years
•	An equitable approach to include local Tribes in Collaborative Management
•	Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
•	The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
•	A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Barrie Moore

Title: Comment from Smith, Jan
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Jan Smith and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Morro Bay, CA and to me, the ocean is paramount to my well being as well as the well being of my community. The ocean provides recreation (for me kayaking, whale watching and beachcombing) and spiritual solace as well as economic vitality to Morro Bay. Protecting the ocean protects life in Morro Bay.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the area from Cambria to Morro Bay as well as the Gaviota Extension. To exclude this area would be a travesty. I believe that management should include collaboration with all local tribals. I believe that the proposed wind farm and the marine sanctuary can coexist. The wind farm should not exclude Morro Bay from the sanctuary boundaries. Like national forests, responsible economic use within the boundaries is possible. But, all new oil and gas development should be banned. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Title: Comment from Hollywood, Jennifer
Comment:
The establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is a critical step in safeguarding the invaluable cultural and ecological resources of the California Central Coast. This sanctuary will not only honor the rich heritage and ancestral ties of the Chumash people but also serve as a beacon of conservation and stewardship for the entire community.

 By designating this sanctuary, we prioritize the sustainable use of ocean resources, thereby ensuring the resilience and health of our marine ecosystems for generations to come.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Gamez, Jairo
Comment:
The proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is a landmark proposal that requires immediate attention. With the impacts of the Climate Crisis, protected corridors are vital for preserving California’s marine environment. Kelp is a critical carbon sink that is a principal component of the marine environment along the coastline of the proposed site. The creation of the marine sanctuary will buffer the effects of the Climate Crisis, effectively maintaining the ecological resistance of the area. 
	In addition, the prohibition of activities maintains two types, allowing the potential for offshore development. The inclusion of these activity prohibitions creates an avenue for continual growth, which maintains the economic interests of the State and private sector. However, managing the proposed marine sanctuary creates a balance that promotes ecological resource sustainability, protecting the landscape from overuse and overdevelopment. 
	Finally, the creation of this proposed sanctuary Intergovernmental Policy Council, which explicitly includes Indigenous leadership and management. This action prioritizes indigenous ancestral knowledge in tandem with scientific research and conservation. The management of the proposed council creates a wider conversation and example for future conservation proposals. 
	Therefore, the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary actively protects and provides resource restoration and environmental resilience along the California coast and must be implemented immediately.

Title: Comment from R, Amanda
Comment:
I am writing to express my support for the establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The New York Times reported that Solomon Kaho’ohalahala, co-founder of the Maui Nui Makai Network (a conservation group), stated at a recent rally in support of the project: "We all live in the same ocean. Those resources are fluid; to think that we can draw a line through it and protect just one part is not true." As someone who has lived her entire life near the ocean, I could not agree with this sentiment more. 

I'm not going to preach to the choir -- the NOAA knows better than most the importance of ocean health in planetary health. The extreme weather of this summer served as a clear and frightening sign to many of us non-scientists that we are at a tipping point when it comes to the climate crisis. Now is the time for us to collectively take bold, decisive action to protect our planet. This project represents an opportunity for us to do just that.

Title: Comment from Pelican Cove Vacation Rental
Comment:
As a local business owner, Pelican Cove Vacation Rental, I have worked to ensure that travelers have access to a coastline that embodies the California that once was, and struggles to maintain a coastline that is as intact a habitat as possible.  When my daughter-in- law first visited Los Osos and Morro Bay, her comment was, "I didn't know that a place like this still existed in California".  She was raised in San Diego.  

I was raised in Carpinteria, and spent my childhood exploring the coast and streams that at that time were filled with abalone, pismo clams, and teaming with fish we caught off the Santa Barbara pier.  The 1969 oil spill and channelization of the creeks following the 1969 flooding by the army corp of engineers devastated the ecosystems that I treasured, and set me on a lifelong journey to do what I could to stop the devastation.  The factors that affected these species are complex, and not well understood.  I observed the changes from my childhood perspective.  One year you could reach your hand into the sand and pull out a pismo clam.  After 1969--I never again found a clam.  For the past 20 years, I have worked with conservation groups, state and tribal biologists, and individuals to conserve open space for endangered species (primarily salmon) with the Washington State Department of Fish & Wildlife and Snohomish County.  The impact of these conservation efforts have been vital, but fall far short of what should be done, what could be done.  In my experience, the tribal conservation efforts are often the key element in successful conservation efforts.  In my experience, the tribal focus and dedication exceeds that of federal, state and local jurisdictions because their focus and dedication and commitment to conservation efforts is unwavering.  I understand and empathize with the need to balance clean energy with conservation in California.  Taking a step back in decommissioning Diablo Canyon was such a personal blow to me I can hardly contain my grief.  But there has to be another way.  I ask you--as a local business owner and individual who has dedicated her life to habitat conservation.  Please let the Chumash lead the decision-making process.  

The 1969 flood devastated our family's avocado ranch in Carpinteria.  The trauma of that loss has haunted our family since then.  When I think about that loss, I think about the losses that the indigenous people have endured.  When I witness the Chumash rise from these losses and step up to conserve what still exists, it gives me hope.  I fully support their efforts, and lend my voice to their voices.  Please listen to them.  They have the deepest connection to this place that we all cherish.  We need to slow down and listen.  Our grandchildren will thank us for that.

Comment: I strongly support the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The area of the proposed sanctuary not only support the conservation efforts of the local Central California people but also support both the United States and global efforts to conserve and restore our oceans. Our oceans need help. These waters are home to hundreds if not thousands, of different ocean creatures and deserve a clean and inhabitable place to live.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Dear Paul Mitchel,

My name is Alyssa Medrano. I am in the 10th grade and I attend Pacifica High School in Oxnard, CA. I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.


I love spending time at the beach and visiting different parts of my state’s coast. I travel along the coast with my family to make new memories and enjoy the presence of marine life. It’s traditional to visit the coast, and I would love to have this sanctuary be extended to protect wildlife as well as preserve culture for others’ to enjoy. In protecting this region of land, I know that marine life would thrive and be protected so that my kids in the future could see this and enjoy it as much as I would.

The main reason that I support the designation of the sanctuary is because I believe that in preserving this area, people, as well as marine life would offer protection and connection with the indigenous groups of California. Students, as well as visitors of the area, would learn much of the Chumash culture when presented with the option of visiting. By reserving this ocean area, marine life would be protected by invasive species. If you think about it, protecting marine life is also protecting the species and further giving them more freedom to live free. With this preserved sanctuary, we will have a new space to learn about the culture of the Chumash and marine life. New and healthy perspectives of this region would be culturally engaging for me to visit the Sanctuary and further support it. On the other hand, people believe the area should be preserved for wind turbines for renewable energy. Yet, this plantation of wind turbines could be done in another area, and does not necessarily share culture or protection of marine life to California citizens. All in all, we should all support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Sincerely,

Alyssa Medrano

Title: Comment from Anonymous

Dear Paul Mitchell,

I live in Oxnard, California, right next to the coast. I enjoy spending time at the beach with family and friends. Title: Comment from Valdez, Vanessa
Comment: I  Vanessa, support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary designation. It will help protect and grow the sea life population of Sea kelp, sea otters, and migratory whales. Tribal Chumash members will stay and help run the island keeping it healthy and clean. “More than 7,000 square miles of ocean there could soon become the largest national marine sanctuary in the continental U.S. It could also make history as one of the first federal sanctuaries to be spearheaded by a Native American tribe, part of a growing movement to give tribes a say over the lands and waters that were once theirs.” I will be impacted because it's our planet. I would like to live in a world with a healthy environment. I will live in this world and want a healthy planet for me and my future kids. Even with the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary, there are some cons to it. The addition of sanctuary status would significantly disrupt local ocean-based industries and make activities such as harbor dredging much more costly and lengthy. Title: Comment from Lopez, Esmeralda
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel,
Hello, my name is Esmeralda Lopez. I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 

I’m currently living in Oxnard, CA near the area that is being suggested for designation. When I visit the beach it’s usually with family or for volunteer work with my club. Title: Comment from Open Space Real Estate, LLC
Comment:
As owner of Open Space Real Estate, I have retired from 20 years of public service in Washington state as a Real Property administrator conserving and managing public land for conservation and recreation.  I have started a business designed to fund the gaps so prevalent in land conservation efforts.  The place of conservation with our current system falls far short of what is needed in order to make significant strides toward meaningful conservation.  

This effort by the Chumash to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would achieve more benefit for the central coast ecosystem than I could claim in the past 20 years in western Washington. The initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast extension should be approved without removing Morro Rock and Morro Bay.  Morro Rock and Morro Bay are the most significant areas to include for all the reasons that have been outlined in the statements made by the Chumash Tribe.  I encourage and urge you not to be persuaded to cut out the most significant places slated for development--even for clean energy.  This is what we have done for hundreds of years.  It is time for a change.  Let the tribes lead this effort.

In my experience, the tribal conservation efforts are often the key element in successful conservation efforts.  In my experience, the tribal focus and dedication exceeds that of federal, state and local jurisdictions because their focus and dedication and commitment to conservation efforts is unwavering.  I understand and empathize with the need to balance  I ask you--as an individual and business owner who has dedicated her life to habitat conservation.  Please let the Chumash lead the decision-making process.  

I fully support the efforts by the Chumash, and lend my voice to their voices.  Please listen to them.  They have the deepest connection to this place that we all cherish.  We need to slow down and listen.  Our grandchildren will thank us for that.

Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
The inclusion of Rodriguez Seamount, the protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Emma Vail

Title: Comment from Gunn, Liam
Comment:
I know that maximum sustainable yield (MSY) has a lot of issues, but it's a reasonable bare minimum floor for regulatory protection. My understanding is that this proposed marine sanctuary is more about adding procedural protections than substantive policies. If NOAA is considering substantive protections at all, I would love to see MSY included as an absolute ceiling for any areas where fishing continues—basically as a permanent binding fallback in case agreements are ever not reached for a given year, and to make sure that agreements never exceed the MSY.

I've spent a lot of time in Morro Bay throughout my life. I've never formally studied the ecosystems or fishing industry there, so all I want to note is how much I love the sea otters there and that my anecdotal impression is that the wide variety of marine wildlife in SLO County is excellent for tourism!

Title: Comment from Kern-Jones, Sheryl
Comment:
Dear NOAA Administration, 
I write to you in strong support for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. This sanctuary is critically important to protect diverse species and preserve the land and waters they depend upon. It also serves as a rich area for recreation and time spent in nature for our region and country. The preservation of this area and guidance by the local Chumash people native to the area in concert with NOAA is also long overdue and a way to bring forth knowledge and respect for all species. This is a tremendous opportunity to learn from native traditions how to properly care for our earth, as is currently being done in the partnerships between native cultures and scientists in some of our forests devastated by fires, such as Santa Cruz. Please take all actions necessary to bring about the creation of this sanctuary. 

Thank you,
Sheryl Kern-Jones
Central coast resident

Title: Comment from Carroll, Paavo
Comment:
I am a commercial fisherman, and have fished all over the west coast from Alaska to Morro Bay. I have fished within the boundaries of the proposed sanctuary for the last eight or nine years. I have no issue with the proposed sanctuary, and would prefer it in the form and boundaries originally proposed, the better to protect the area from oil or mineral extraction, as well as ill conceived deep water wind turbines.  The fisheries management I am currently subjected to is little short of an abject failure. Incorporating indigenous voices can hardly make it worse, indeed I am hopeful it could be improved. All NOAA and western natural resource management seems to know how to do is privatize the fish in the sea, cut off huge swaths of the ocean for 20 years, only to reopen it and cut off the opposite swath, all the while putting out press releases touting the supposed miracle of the groundfish recovery. Salmon redds are intentionally dewatered, the fry boiled in their natal streams. Global warming goes unaddressed; the oil must flow. We are forced to listen to unceasing drivel from the likes of Wild Fish Conservation Network or Oceana in our fisheries management meetings. I would rather hear what the Chumash have to say and welcome their co-management of the proposed sanctuary. I think they have a valuable contribution to bring. Of course I am somewhat concerned by anything that has a potential to negatively affect my livelihood, but the status quo is unacceptable. It belongs to them; let's give it back. To the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary, I say, bring it on.
     I will make one more specific comment pertaining to ship speeds etc. I suspect ship strikes are a much more significant cause of whale mortality than anything else and I would like to see the ability to control and monitor ship traffic written into the draft management plan.

Title: Comment from Perez, John

Dear Paul Michel,
My name is John Perez and I support the establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary so that the local ecosystem and biodiversity along California’s coast can be sheltered and preserved.

I live in Oxnard, California and to me, the ocean is very therapeutic and calming. It gives me a place to hear the sounds of nature that my ancestors before me heard too. It’s a place where I can spend time with my friends, family, and myself.
Whenever I go to the beach, it's usually with my friends. We run around the beach, enjoy snacks together, entertain the family dog, and it’s always a time I can fondly look back on.
Another time I go to the beach is on field trips with my class. I get to enjoy the warm embrace of the beach away from the environment of my school. I get to analyze, research, and interact with the local environment there like the shy crabs along the rocks or watch dolphins effortlessly swim across the ocean when I’m on a boat. 
The ocean is where a lot of my favorite foods come from too. I love foods like ceviche with shrimp, shrimp alfredo and fish with rice. In my family, it’s a tradition to eat our Mexican dishes with sea foods so the ocean is very important to me.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, I ask that this sanctuary includes more tribes into this collaborative project. I see that tribes such as the Salinan tribes also have relation to the Channel Islands and so, I think it’d be fair to be more inclusive when in consideration of the Channel Islands protectors and inhabitants. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Sincerely,
John Perez

Title: Comment from knight , elizabeth
Comment:
Mr. Michel,
I am writing to express my wholehearted support for the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. As a sophomore and a passionate advocate for the environment, I believe that this sanctuary would not only benefit the Chumash people but also protect the region's important marine ecosystems and maritime heritage resources, support ocean-dependent economies, and highlight the cultural values and connections of Indigenous communities to the area.
Reasons for Support:
Preserving Indigenous Connection: The Chumash people have a strong religious and emotional connection to the ocean, and I believe that they should be supported and funded for the sanctuary to honor their heritage and traditions
Protecting Marine Life: The designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would benefit the animals and underwater species greatly by providing them with protection against anyone and anything that may harm them
Environmental Impact: Stopping oil drilling and other harmful activities in the sanctuary would have a positive impact on the surrounding areas, including the mass population who frequent the beach, like myself, and have a love for the ocean and marine life
Fishing Opportunities: While some people may be concerned about the impact on fishing opportunities, I believe that there are alternative fishing areas where it would not be hurting the wildlife and laws can be implemented to ensure sustainable fishing practices
I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and include measures to protect biodiversity, habitats, and the cultural values of the Chumash people. This sanctuary would be a valuable addition to the National Marine Sanctuary system, promoting collaboration, education, and community involvement in ocean management
Thank you for considering my comments in support of this important initiative. I look forward to the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and the positive impact it will have on the environment and the community.
Sincerely,
Liz Knight

Over 200 ship and aircraft wrecks have been reported with at least 20 in the sanctuary area. The nationally-significant natural resources, physical features and habitats, and the cultural and historical resources within the proposed sanctuary warrant long-term protection and management to reduce threats that would negatively affect their historical, cultural, archaeological, recreational, and educational value. For example, many threatened or endangered species, such as blue whales, snowy plovers, black abalone, white sharks, and leatherback sea turtles, rely on habitats, physical features, or prey found in the proposed sanctuary rely on habitats, physical features, or prey found in the proposed sanctuary. Many known or suspected shipwrecks of historical importance have also been found in the area and the proposed sanctuary would preserve them. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the initial boundary alternative with gaviota coast extension.

Title: Comment from Mora, Yoselin
Comment:
Dear NOAA,

     I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary because it will help sea life and for the area to be protected. For example it will help the 5,600 square miles be protected so as its history it beholds of the Chumash and Salinan tribes. It will be impacted by preserving the diverse and valuable resources of the area such as kelp forest, sea otters, and migratory whales. This will be a good idea because the area has deep history which is why it shouldn’t be damaged and be protected. 

     The area has been connected to the Chumash and Salina tribes for over 100,000 years. The region also saw the first meeting between indigenous people and Europeans in the mid-1500s. This area was shaped by settlers and explorers that were Spanish, Mexican, English, Russian, and American. The events that happened were the California gold rush, ranching, military activities, oil boom, experience missions, and recent renewable energy development. The coastal waters also have precious marine life, contain critical ocean ecosystems, which are connected to the past, present, and future of the Chumash people. 

     California’s coast has been focused on the wind industry to install the states first offshore wind farms. The state has been trying to get 100% of its electricity from renewable resources by 2045. The thing is that the marine sanctuary designation would prevent the wind turbines to be installed and the same goes for the offshore oil platforms. This could have an effect on how the world is trying to grow by trying out new things, but it wouldn’t be possible because of the NOAA. The good thing is that the country’s network of 15 other marine sanctuaries are monitored for their ecological health. This means it helps spot any possible impacts and the effects of climate change. 

     In the mid-1800s the Congress rejected the treaties made with California tribes. Then tribes were able to join the sanctuary’s advisory council that provides feedback for decisions and priorities. The NOAA is working with the Chumash which means they will recognize the tribes and advise decision making as collaboratively as an Intergovernmental Policy Council. People would probably oppose this because they would need more information or just need more convincing to support the NOAA. Such as the reason for not being able to build wind turbines and offshore oil platforms.  

     In conclusion I do support the NOAA for the reason that it can help preserve the area for history of the Chumash tribe and marine life. The area can be safe and also be protected for energy development. Although wind turbines can’t be built offshore, it's better to have a different solution to it and try to save history. It will also help to create a strong foundation to have a thriving coast for generations to come in the future. 

Sincerely,
Yoselin Mora

Title: Comment from Maldonado, Emma
Comment:
Paul Michel,

My name is Emma and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the initial boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Oxnard, California and to me, the ocean is one of the most important things in the world. There’s so much we’ve learned from it, which was only 5%. There is still so much to discover, and we need to keep the most of it as we can. We could lose so many opportunities for new knowledge if we lose it.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that the sanctuary includes:
Biggest possible boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.
Sanctuary name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
 Outreach & Education: Outreach, education, and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities.
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity.
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,
Emma

Title: Comment from K., Emily
Comment:
I write in support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, with proposed borders as outlined in the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension. The protection of a continuous stretch of coastal waters between the Monterey Marine Sanctuary and the Channel Islands Marine Sanctuary are of paramount importance to our Central Coast. I urge you to revise your recommendation to include all the coastal waters from Cambria to Morro Bay to Gaviota to preserve the vast biodiversity our Central Coast is known for. 
I also urge you to deny the request made on October 13, 2023 by Invenergy California Offshore LLC, Golden State Wind, and Equinor Wind US for a 60-day extension of the comment period on the DEIS and the Draft Management Plan.  The Leaseholders have had more than adequate time to formulate their maneuvers.  The sooner the CHNMS is designated, the better for our coastal waters, wildlife, and communities!
Thank you for doing the right thing.
Emily K., Los Osos

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

I, Janet Gregorio, am writing to express my support for the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. This designation would serve to protect the region's important marine ecosystems and maritime heritage resources, support ocean-dependent economies, and address issues such as climate change, offshore energy, water quality, and wildlife disturbance. 

As a resident of Oxnard, California, I believe that the ocean is a vital component of our existence and should be taken care of and revised as frequently as possible. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would provide a safe and healthy ocean for my community to benefit from and connect with. 

It is crucial to protect our natural habitat in a safe enclosure since, without it, we wouldn't have the benefits that it provides us through many existing resources. The environment, climate change, offshore energy, water quality, and wildlife gradually depend on us as a community to be protected. 

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our oceans' many features. I ask that this sanctuary include action plans that would address climate change, offshore energy, water quality, and wildlife disturbance, and be revised as frequently as possible to ensure that management is cautious about any unexpected circumstances that may arise.

Title: Comment from Dominguez, Angelina
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
I am writing to express my support for the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension, covering approximately 7,600 square miles of ocean. This designation is proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats, and I believe it is a crucial step towards preserving the ocean's wonders.

As a resident of Oxnard, California, I consider the ocean to be my home. Its breeze keeps the city cool even on the hottest days, and its thriving ecosystem holds deep significance in every individual's heart. The ocean not only holds thousands of species, but the balance it creates in the world protects our ability to live as human beings.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary because I want to see the ocean's treasures protected from harm. I believe that the sanctuary's area should be safeguarded from harmful institutions such as the mass extraction of oil, fish, and other acts of exploitation with little to no regard for the environment and our future.

While I understand that some resources are necessary for society to live a comfortable and efficient life, I believe that we must prioritize the protection of our environment. Therefore, I ask for the restriction of oil and gas development within the Sanctuary's boundaries, as well as fishing and other future experimentation.

Thank you for taking the time to consider my thoughts and the implementation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I hope that we can work together to preserve the ocean and its incredible treasures for current and future generations to enjoy and thrive in.

Sincerely,

Title: Comment from Lazcano, Jordan
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Jordan Lazcano and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of the Ocean proposed to protect the biodiversity and habitats. 

I live in Oxnard California and to me the ocean is a place of comfort and peace.

When my family and I go to the beach the last thing we want to be greeted with is large landfills and stained water. It is not fair to the ocean life and people who resonate deeply with the ocean. There is a much more spiritual bond between the ocean and  people like the Chumash who’s once clear ocean blue waves were turned into clouds of oil and darkness. My family and I love watching the sunset and the elegant fish that swim by, but I fear that this will not be possible in the years to come. The ocean is a place of comfort to not only us, but also the marine life that is affected by every single incident that happens with boats. The sanctuary will help solve these issues by the NOAA prohibiting harmful materials on grounded or deserted vessels. This will keep boats that sink, run aground, or discharge chemicals into the ocean from releasing anything that may harm the sanctuary or marine life. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary bans the use of oil and gas to prevent any pollution that could be let into the ocean. According to statista.com, In 2022 700 metric tons of oil were let into the ocean killing marine life. People that do not support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary fear that fishing will not be allowed. I respect the fear of losing something you enjoy, but there will be nothing to fish in the ocean if we allow incidents to recur and the abuse the ocean endures to continue. With the installment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary dozens of species of fish will be protected and the Chumash will have a piece of their home back that they once lost.

I support the designation of the Chumash National Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,
Jordan Lazcano

Title: Comment from Mount Tamalpais Circumambulation
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Gifford Hartman and I am the leader of the Mount Tamalpais Circumambulation, in the San Francisco Bay Area, a ritual that occurs around the time of each solstice and equinox and which began in 1965. I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Gifford Hartman

Title: Comment from Central Coast Friends Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends (Quakers)
Comment:
STATEMENT SUPPORTING CHUMASH HERITAGE NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY

The Central Coast Friends Meeting (Quakers) offers this statement of support for the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  Our principles of harmony with nature and of right relationships with Creation bring us to make this statement.

We support the establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary using the largest possible contiguous sanctuary boundaries, as shown in the Initial Boundary Alternative combined with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alternative 5b), because it would provide the most protection.   Our beloved coastal and offshore waters in San Luis Obispo County would be subjected to drilling, dumping, and desecration of sacred sites in alternative boundaries 2, 3, and 4 proposed by NOAA. We request that any cables laid in sanctuary waters have permits from the Office of National Marine Sanctuaries.

Migrating marine animals need safe passage through our waters.  Lisamu, which we call Morro Rock, needs protection so that never again will we take rocks from this sacred site. Our indigenous neighbors have wisdom to share based on 10,000 years of living in harmony with the land and waters. We support strong collaboration among local agencies and tribes in regulating and managing the sanctuary to include all interested local tribes.

Respectfully submitted,

Melissa Lovett-Adair
Presiding Clerk
Central Coast Friends Meeting (Quakers)
San Luis Obispo

Title: Comment from Lowe, Lucas
Comment:
Dear NOAA, 

My name is Lucas Lowe and I am an undergraduate student at UC Santa Barbara. I support the creation of a national marine sanctuary (NMS) aimed at preserving cultural heritage for indigenous communities and protecting biodiversity. I support the initial boundary alternative extending to Monterey Bay NMS and the portion of the Agency-Preferred Alternative extension of the Gaviota Coast. I also ask that this NMS reject any oil or gas developments within the sanctuary boundaries and extend out to protect the Rodriguez Seamount. 

I live in San Francisco, and while I will not be residing adjacent to the proposed NMS, I do support those who advocate for the establishment of an NMS for the communities that have deep cultural connections to the territory. 
	
Sincerely, 

Lucas Lowe
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Birch, Thayer
Comment:
I grew up in Morro Bay, and I was shocked and disappointed to see its exclusion in the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The proposed boundaries do not protect the Morro Bay estuary, a critical ecosystem home to dozens of endangered species[1].

The estuary has seen conservation efforts from local, state and federal programs including the NEP[2], however these efforts are focused on preserving the watershed. The magic of an estuary is the mixture of water and sediments coming from both inland and the ocean, and it is critical to protect the coastline outside the estuary to preserve this habitat. It has been shown that offshore industrial uses often have negative impacts on nearby estuaries [3][4], including NOAA's own research [5].

I fully support extending the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to the border of the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary.

[1] https://www.morrobay.org/listing/morro-bay-national-estuary/15560/
[2] https://www.mbnep.org/estuary/
[3] https://onepetro.org/JPT/article-abstract/24/04/385/164001/The-Petroleum-Industry-as-It-Affects-Marine-And
[4] https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s13131-012-0195-y
[5] https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/topic/offshore-wind-energy/protecting-marine-life

Title: Comment from Allen, Stephanie
Comment:
To the attention of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration,

My name is Stephanie Allen and I am a full-time resident of a beach town impacted by this decision on the Central Coast of California. I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

As mentioned above, I live in this specific beach town on in California and for one reason and one reason only - the opportunity it gave me to live in proximity to this amazing stretch of the Pacific Ocean along the Central Coast. I am a surfer, boogie boarder, beach walker, nature appreciator and observer.

I have been a homeowner in this area, one block from the beach since 2009.  This beach and ocean have saved my life -- while grieving the sudden and tragic deaths of beloveds, it gave me hope for the future during the pandemic lockdown and the protests of the summer of 2020 and even now while war is raging in Ukraine and Israel and Gaza.  When at the beach - watching surfers and dogs play, seeing families out in the waves or exploring the tide pools, feeling the serenity from the fisherpeople as they cast their rods I find glimmers of possibility for humanity.  I am awed by the migrations of birds and bait balls, the breaching whales and dolphin, the changeability and power of the wind, the glory of the sunsets, the ever presence and ever changing ocean; wave quality, color, texture, power and grace.  And - make no mistake - I am reminded of the harsh realities of the world - often - as I come upon dead birds, seals, sea otters and more, the bones of a whale or a cormorant.

It is imperative for us to protect and honor this stretch of ocean so we can all continue to connect with, find grace in and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.

The ocean is beautiful and mysterious and it provides infinite opportunities from which we can learn and connect peacefully.  

I fully, and wholehearted support this Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary - in the full designation as proposed by the Northern Chumash Tribal Council.  Think to the future generations.  Consider history and how many short termed decisions have put us at risk.  Let's not make those same mistakes.

The Sanctuary must include:
1) Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
2) Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
3) Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
4) Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
5) A Ban on Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

To reiterate in the strongest possible terms: I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Respectfully,
Stephanie Allen

 

Sincerely,

[Your Name]

Title: Comment from Schramm, Mary Jane
Comment:
Good day,

Thank you for the opportunity to support the INITIAL Boundary Alternative for the proposed Chumash Heritage NMS.

As a former employee of NOAA's Greater Farallones National Marine Sanctuary, now retired but continuing my involvement in marine conservation activities, I am familiar with many aspects of sanctuary management and policy, and therefore support only the INITIAL alternative originally published in the Federal Register that will create an uninterrupted corridor of legal protections for significant natural and cultural resources. No non-contiguous option is acceptable. 

These waters support a host of protected and endangered species and critical habitats for them, in one of the most significant upwelling regions on the planet. This alone merits the utmost effort to maintain, conserve and restore its biological resources and habitats. Its proximity to offshore oil development already compromise the health of these waters, and this must prompt an extra layer of protection for the proposed marine protected area. 

The INITIAL alternative ensures that offshore industrial development is subject to the same regulatory protections for habitat integrity and wildlife that apply to other national marine sanctuaries, and to other areas of this proposed sanctuary. While I support development of green energy alternatives, including potential offshore industrial installations for wind and wave energy if done responsibly, the most rigorous scrutiny is needed before issuance of permits or authorizations to ensure it is carried out with minimal environmental impact and impacts to fisheries. I'm a realist and know that trade-offs are a necessary evil. I further appreciate that NOAA is under the US Department of Commerce, and not the Interior. However, I believe that commerce and conservation are not incompatible. The inclusion of the Morro Bay and other areas missing from the agency-preferred option will provide a stronger framework for enforcing environmental protections as development proposals are initiated. The energy industry's track record - whether for carbon based fuels or otherwise - does not merit  special exemptions; indeed, it warrants extra caution. In our haste to meet state and federal goals, ref: the 30/30 objectives, we should not waive our obligation to minimize impacts in achieving those goals.

Please confirm the INITIAL Boundary Alternative for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,

Mary Jane Schramm
