Title: Comment from Lopez, German
Comment:
My support to the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is German Lopez and i support the idea that is soon to become true of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. It has gotten a immense grasp of my attention to see that this project will not only benefit marine life but the environment from climate change and for possible dangers, And i wish for you to keep thriving with the idea and make it true one day.
I live in the City of oxnard and seeing that the ocean is going to be hugely benefited from the soon to come project, I am quite happy and thankful to see the amazing change.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

I support it because The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would protect 5,600 square miles of ocean off the central California coast, an area known for its kelp forests, sea otters and migratory whales. 
Executive Order 12898 is a directive that requires Federal agencies to identify and address the disproportionately high and adverse effects of their actions on human health and the environment of minority or low-income populations. The goal of this order is to achieve environmental protection for all communities, including those that are often overlooked or underserved. The designation of national marine sanctuaries by NOAA helps to ensure the enhancement of environmental quality for all populations in the United States. The proposed sanctuary designation would not result in disproportionate negative impacts on any minority or low-income population. In fact, many of the potential impacts from designating the proposed sanctuary would result in long-term or permanent beneficial impacts by protecting sanctuary resources, which may have a positive impact on communities by providing employment and educational opportunities, and potentially result in improved ecosystem services. The Executive Order 12898 is an important tool for promoting environmental justice and ensuring that all communities have access to clean and healthy environments. It is important for Federal agencies to consider the potential impacts of their actions on minority and low-income populations and take steps to address any adverse effects.
NOAA is proposing to designate a national marine sanctuary off the coast of central California. The proposed sanctuary would include the coastline of central California from Hazard Canyon Reef at the north end of Montaña de Oro State Park, south along the San Luis Obispo County coast and a portion of Santa Barbara County to approximately two miles south of Dos Pueblos Creek near the township of Naples along the Gaviota Coast. The sanctuary's proposed boundaries also include the offshore marine waters from the western end of Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary (CINMS), northwards to within approximately 2.5 miles of the southern end of Morro Bay Wind Energy Area (WEA), and then east and southeast to the point of origin at Hazard Canyon Reef. The proposed sanctuary would cover roughly 134 miles of the mainland coast (163 miles if including the shoreline of offshore rocks and islands) and out to approximately 66 miles (50 nautical miles) from shore. The area includes numerous offshore features, such as the Santa Lucia Bank, portions of its escarpment, Rodriguez Seamount, Arguello Canyon, and other offshore features and resources. Coastal watersheds drain into this area via multiple outlets, including the Santa Maria and Santa Ynez river mouths and several other coastal streams and rivers. The area is known for its high biological productivity, which supports dense aggregations of marine life. The proposed sanctuary would balance protection with recreational use and would help conserve and manage coastal resources to protect them from potential threats.
It would help impact all people especially due to it being able to spot possible signs of effects and climate change.
The reason i do support the work and project going into this idea is due to it having a positive impact towards marine life and the plants but not only that but the positive impact that is going to bring towards climate change and possible detectable effects.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I support the Chumash marine sanctuary designation. I am a lifelong waterman and have surfed and swam in these waters responsibly since I was a child, and my children now do as well. I am a passionate environmentalist. I am a big wave surfer and much of my use of this area, now occurs when some of the largest waves of winter occur in our region.  Many of you may not know that the area covered under the proposed marine sanctuary  includes numerous surf spots with waves similar in size and ferocity to the famous Mavericks in half moon bay. These areas are exceptionally dangerous, with waves from 20-50 foot throughout most winters. Many of these waves are very far from shore and are often exceptionally difficult to access from shore. Many of them can only be accessed via PWC. There is a small number of big wave surfers who use this region for both paddle and tow in surfing in these types of conditions. Personal Watercraft are an absolutely integral portion of maintaining our safety in these situations and are used to rescue surfers after a fall, or to quickly get out of harms way. In the event of an emergency such as a shark attack, a drowning, or any other injury, PWC operators in conjunction with the other surfers in the water,  function as the first line of defense in providing advanced lifesaving care. We are trained to self rescue and we have first aid kits, tourniquets, and often defibrillator devices onboard our PWC’s. Many of us are trained in CPR and first aid. I am a private citizen, however I have trained with the half moon bay harbor patrol, the US coastguard, Cal Fire, and many other agencies in regards to PWC operation for Ocean Safety. Most other PWC assisted surfers have similar training.  All the Surfers I know are responsible environmentalists. We are cognizant of wildlife and marine mammals during these activities and give them a wide berth if ever encountered. We are far more agile than a boat and can turn on a dime. Strikes on wildlife by PWC operators like this are non existent.   

Surfers have died surfing big waves in Central California, when PWC’s are not able to be a part of the safety plan. At the end of the day we all want to come home safely to our families and having unfettered access to utilize PWC’s for safety makes the overall process much safer for us. While I understand there is currently no ban on PWC operation within the draft regulations, if the sanctuary were to follow in the footsteps of either the Channel Islands or Monterey marine National sanctuaries management plans, PWC use would be banned. While I understand they are not being banned now, the language in the action plan is concerning n (see draft management plan, Wildlife Disturbance Action Plan, Activity WD-1.2). I implore you to realize that it is a small number of conscious environmentally minded waterman who are actually utilizing these areas with these machines, and very often it truly is a matter of life and death to have one of these machines in an emergency. A second but no less important point is that regarding the Gaviota coastline extension as currently proposed, PWC’s offer one of the only ways to access this entire stretch of coastline, as all land access is currently prohibited due to the Hollister and Bixby ranch private regions. Please do not change this. The photo I have attached is of a location in the proposed sanctuary with these types of PWC assisted surfing activities. Thank you.

Title: Comment from Uebersax, Mary
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel

I am writing in support of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. This sanctuary would protect a rich and diverse marine ecosystem, including endangered species and important migration corridors, as well as culturally significant sites for the Chumash and other indigenous people.

**Rich biodiversity**

The proposed santuary encompasses a wide range of marine habitats, including kelp forests, rocky reefs, sandy beaches, and deep-sea canyons. These habitats support a diverse array of marine life, including fish, invertebrates, seabirds, and marine mammals. The sanctuary would protect important nursery and feeding grounds for many commercially and recreationally important species, such as salmon, tuna, and whales. Citizens of all ages recognize and value this proposed sanctuary and it is largely celebrated, explored by involved organizations, student groups, advocacy groups and local docents. 

**Indigenous historical legacy and input in management**

The Chumash people have inhabited the Central California coast for over 10,000 years. They have a deep understanding of the marine environment and its resources. The proposed sanctuary would be co-managed by the Chumash people (or a coalition of indigenous tribal representatives) and NOAA, ensuring that their traditional knowledge and values are incorporated into management decisions. The Marine Sanctuary designation is vital at this time to ensure that harmful and irreversable development would be mitigated including energy technologies such as oil and gas tec and the burgeoning space exploration managed through Vandenberg Air Force Base and Space Force.

**Influence and decision-making of local stewardship and environmental organizations**

Local stewardship and environmental organizations have played a key role in advocating for the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary. These organizations have provided valuable input into the sanctuary designation process and will continue to be involved in its management. Their engagement will help to ensure that the sanctuary is managed in a way that protects its natural and cultural resources for future generations. I was a young child as my Mother, an Anthropologist specializing in Chumash Heritage pointed out the importance of the cultuaral and environmental legacy. And 50 years later, the importance of this stewardship is more important than ever.  

**Precious habitats including endangered species and migration corridors for birds and marine animals**

As a local naturalist and volunteer of several organization and Google Guide, I chronicle the and write on the rich habitat. The proposed Sanctuary is home to a number of endangered species, including the blue whale, humpback whale, and southern sea otter. It is also an important migration corridor for many birds and marine mammals. The sanctuary would provide these species with protected habitat and help to ensure their long-term survival. Meanwhile, threats including poaching, aggressive treatment against otters and unchecked kelp harvesting needs enforcement and protection. 

**Geological position and seismic activity**

The proposed CHNMS is located in a geologically active region. This means that there is a risk of earthquakes, tsunamis, and other natural disasters. Offshore oil and gas development in this region would pose a significant risk to marine life and coastal communities. The CHNMS would prohibit offshore oil and gas development, helping to protect the marine environment and coastal communities from these risks.

**Exemptions to sanctuary boundaries**

I urge NOAA to minimize exemptions to the sanctuary boundaries. Exemptions would increase the risk of damage to the marine environment from activities such as offshore oil and gas development, seabed mining, and dumping. It is important to protect the entire marine ecosystem within the sanctuary boundaries, including its important habitats and endangered species.

**Scientific collaborative research**

I encourage NOAA to continue to support scientific collaborative research with local credible universities. This research will help us to better understand the marine environment and its resources. It will also help us to develop effective management strategies for the sanctuary.

Thank you for your time and consideration. I urge you to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Sincerely,
[Mary Uebersax]

In addition to the points above, I would like to add that the CHNMS would also provide a number of economic benefits to the Central Coast region. The sanctuary would attract tourists, recreational anglers, and other visitors to the region, supporting local businesses and jobs. The sanctuary would also help to protect the marine resources that are essential to the region's fishing and tourism industries.

The CHNMS is a win-win for the environment, the economy, and the Chumash people. I urge NOAA to designate the sanctuary as soon as possible.

Title: Comment from Hoover, Vicky
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michael:
I write to express my strong support for the prompt designation of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary off the central Californis coast.
I'm a longtime California resident, and longtime advocate for environmental protection, especially concerned now with the biodiversity crisis that is worldwide, and that is being addressed, in part, by California's new law making th "30 by 30" initiative truly law in our state.  I work with several environmental organizations, including Sierra CLub, Great Old Broads for Wilderness, and California Native Plant Society 
I urge the designation WITH the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension. This broad inclusive boundary is vital: Including the waters offshore Point Buchon, Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria will close the California Central Coast’s biodiversity protection gap between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This will protect the only eelgrass bed in a 300-mile stretch of coast; many historic Chumash sites, including Lisamu’ (Morro Rock); numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds; the highest population of Southern Sea otters on the California coast; several State Marine Conservation Areas; and the kelp forests and rocky intertidal habitat. The protection of Rodriguez Seamount should be included.
I also support using the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
I urge continuing Tribal Collaborative Management--this sanctuary is proposed first of all by tribes and they deserve a strong leadership voice in ongoing management.An inclusive approach to all Tribes in Collaborative Management & a NOAA Tribal Liaison.
While I emphatically support further focus on and use of offshore wind resources, the potential for harm to ocean life requires thoughtful planning of Offshore Wind farms to protect ocean life. Careful sitting is imperative.
Designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, spanning over 7,500 square miles of ocean and 156 miles of coastline, in addition to biodiversity protection, will also benefit local communities and the economy. 
The Draft Environmental Impact Statement acknowledges that all other alternatives than the Initial Alternative --all with reduced boundaries would reduce the significant beneficial effects on biological resources provided by the Initial Boundary Alternative. All other alternatives would increase the vulnerability of those resources to adverse impacts that the Initial Boundary Alternative would prohibit or mitigate. The Initial Boundary Alternative is expected to result in long-term beneficial impacts on local residents (including low-income and minority populations), as well as on the health and well-being of children.

I look forward eagerly to this new designation. Our oceans are the least publicized and most endangered ecosystems on earth. YOUr help can now work toward improving this global situation.
Thank you for considering these comments.
Vicky Hoover, Sierra ClubSenior Wilderness VolunteerSan Francisco CA
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Jasper, Jessica
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in California and to me, the ocean is a lifeline to health of the planet. 
I want to protect this stretch of ocean so we can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations. I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the following:
 -Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
- Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
- EXTREMELY IMPORTANT: Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
-Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
-Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
-ALSO EXTREMELY IMPORTANT: Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,
Jessica Jasper

Title: Comment from Ruiz Aquino, Anthony
Comment:
I am writing in support of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. It’s important to establish the Marine Sanctuary, it’s an important area for the Chumash people due to cultural significance, and also this area is ecologically significant.
The Chumash and other indigenous tribes have been in this area for thousands of years. They have knowledge of the area and also it’s culturally important to them due to them being connected to the ocean. They have lived off the resources the ocean provides.  With the government and indigenous people working together they’d be able to ensure a sustainable future for California's ocean.
Ecologically this area is high in biodiversity and a highly productive marine ecosystem. This area is made up of kelp forests, sandy beaches, rocky shorelines, shallow and deep reefs, and wetlands. These areas provide a important habitat to many sea birds, marine mammals, invertebrates, and fishes. This area also serves as a gathering point for whales and dolphins to feed.
There are also three major upwelling occur in this area, they bring nutrient rich water to the surface which feeds marine life and they also enhance the ecosystems of the two adjacent sanctuaries. If this is disturbed there would be a disruption in the ecosystem. 
Also while I do support wind power, we should not build a wind farm where whales and many other marine animals live. They habitat are likely to be disturbed with the building of these wind farms. Also the whales travel pattern is likely to be affected by these wind farms. The better alternative is to build these wind farms on land and not in the sanctuary area since it would not affect the habitats of marine organisms and travel patterns of whales.

Title: Comment from McCamant, Freya
Comment:
Public comments in support of the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary

To NOAA- 

I am writing today in support of the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and the Gaviota Coast Extension to cover 7,600 square miles of ocean biodiversity.

I was born and raised along the California coast.  I currently live on the California coast north of the proposed Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary, but I still feel that the designation is very important for all people in California and in our country.  As an environmental attorney, I understand the need to proactively work to keep resources protected, rather than try to address pollution, species or other issues in a piecemeal approach.  By designating this Sanctuary, and working in tandem with the Chumash tribe, the traditional ecological knowledge that has been used by the tribe to manage and care for the environment for thousands of years will be given a necessary and essential role in resource management. 

I urge NOAA to adopt the sanctuary with the following elements.

I support the Chumash Marine Sanctuary, specifically the largest possible designation of the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension.

I support the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”.

I support an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.

I support outreach and education to highlight Traditional Ecological Knowledge and to grant access to local underserved communities.

I support the protection of the Rodriguez Seamount.

The new Marine Sanctuary must prohibit the development of new oil and gas projects within the sanctuary boundaries.


The Chumash tribe has been living near and managing these resources for thousands of years.  When the Portola Expedition traveled through the area in 1769, they encountered numerous villages with a settled culture that utilized the marine resources providing the Spaniards with fresh and dried fish (among many other food sources.) See, The Discovery of San Francisco Bay: The Portola Expedition, The Diary of Miguel Costanso, Ed. By Peter Browning. The Chumash tribe has maintained a tribal identity and their traditional knowledge in the face of waves of attempted destruction beginning with the Spanish priests and military at the Missions and followed by the State of California’s aggressive attacks on the California native populations, and federal policies through the years. This sanctuary designation as a Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary will be a positive step to help counter some of this destructive history. It will be an opportunity for the Chumash tribe to continue to exercise their traditional knowledge and for other people to learn about their long history with the ocean in this area. We can all benefit from their knowledge and respect for the ocean environment. In Voices in the Ocean, Susan Casey summarizes the relationship between the Chumash and the ocean, drawing from her conversation with a Chumash activist regarding their creation story, and the relationship to dolphins and the whole area of the ocean.  This connection between resource management and spirituality is a necessary one for us to learn.  It is time to recognize that the California Native tribes who were here for thousands of years before this area was the State of California or the United States are still here and have a tremendous amount to teach all of us about the ocean and our connection to it. 

Please designate the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary with the largest possible are of the Initial Boundary Alternative and the Gaviota Coast Extension.  

Thank you for your time.

Sincerely, 

Freya McCamant
Environmental attorney, activist and writer

Title: Comment from Pick, Jennifer
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Jennifer Pick and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Columbus Ohio and to me, the ocean is not only a place of beauty and respite for those who can visit it, but the source of so much life, not just the fish and corals in the seas but the water that comes to us via the local cycles, where the run off from forests nourishes the underwater life and the water evaporates to provide the rain that nourishes us all on land.  It is also the home of so many sentient species whose existence brings us joy.  I will never forget sailing off the coast of Australia and being accompanied by dolphins swimming by the prow of the boat.  We have greedily emptied the oceans for profit and left many larger fish starving, think of the plight of the Orca's on the west coast.  However, there is hope.  Numerous examples exist of the way nature can rebound when protected from the ravages of overfishing and other insults such as trawl fishing. The Stellwagen Bank National Marine Sanctuary in the Gulf of Maine is a great example.  As we head into the fiery future of climate change, it is important to take every step we can to protect what we can, while we can.  If you are not aware of the global 30 by 30 project, it hopes to protect 30% of both land and water for its biodiversity as a way to stave off the growing extinction crisis.  This has been endorsed by President Biden, 100 nations and many conservation groups.  It was also endorsed by the COP15 meeting of the Convention on Biological Diversity.  The proposed sanctuary would be a wonderful contribution to this effort, provided that it imposes strict limits on or excludes completely commercial fishing.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

Jennifer Pick

Title: Comment from Katsaounis, Stephen
Comment: It is vital that the final designation of the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary cover the largest possible contiguous boundaries. Please support designation of the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alt 5b). Including the waters offshore Point Buchon, Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria that will close the California Central Coast’s biodiversity protection gap between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This will protect the only eelgrass bed in a 300-mile stretch of coast; many historic Chumash sites, including Lisamu’ (Morro Rock); numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds; the highest population of Southern sea otters on the California coast; several State Marine Conservation Areas; and the kelp forests and rocky intertidal habitats considered to be some of the most diverse and abundant in the world.  No other proposed sanctuary alternative is adequate. The Draft Environmental Impact Statement acknowledges that all other alternatives would reduce the significant beneficial effects on biological resources provided by the Initial Boundary Alternative. All other alternatives would increase the vulnerability of those resources to adverse impacts that the Initial Boundary Alternative would prohibit or mitigate.  Our all-important ocean upwelling and the Pacific Current Ecosystem will not be protected by the artificial and inadequate boundaries recently dictated by the offshore wind industry.

Title: Comment from James, Jessica
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Jessica James and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Richmond, California and went to school at Cal Poly in San Luis Obispo where I earned my degree in Landscape Architecture.  To me, the ocean is part of our cultural heritage and protecting it is an honor the Chumash should receive.

At Cal Poly I competed in the Solar Decathlon with a team of architecture students to design sustainable a home for Reggie, a member of the Chumash tribe in Santa Ynez, California. He had a vision of his whole community modernizing their homes to be sustainable to ease the burden on the earth.  He was serious about his commitment a sustainable future for the next generations and fighting climate change.

I know he would want this wind farm. But it's also important that the future of the coast at Morro Bay be in their hands.  We've had a chance to shape it already- adding a sand bar and power plant.  It's time to give others the opportunity to shape the outcome.  People who are serious about protecting the earth and have everything to lose because this is part of their community.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,

Jessica James

Title: Comment from Olivero, Layla
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel, 

My name is Layla Olivero, and I am a high school student currently attending Pacifica High School (in Oxnard). I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

I live in Oxnard, California and to me, the ocean is a place of significance. The memories alone I have of being by the water are close to my heart. Growing up in a city that’s significantly close to the water, it has always been a part of my life. Birthdays, weddings, field trips, etc, are all celebrated and take place on the coast and beaches. The ocean is deeply important to myself and my community. We all depend on the ocean for recreational purposes, our mental and spiritual well-being, and our community connections and health. I support protecting this stretch of the ocean so that my community can continue to connect with it and benefit from it under safe, clean, and healthy circumstances. A sanctuary that is a part of the ocean will help us not only bring to light the protectors of these waters, but also help educate our community on the significance of the waters. As well, a sanctuary can also be an aspect of research and education used for present and future generations. 

Since I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, there are some causes I strongly support and wish to be included within the building of this sanctuary. The ban on oil and gas idea: a prohibition on new oil and gas development within the sanctuary boundaries. I support this ban idea specifically because of how badly our planet alone has been affected by the oil and gas industry, and if one area can maybe change the way oil and gas is affecting them, then maybe the rest of the planet will follow. 

In conclusion, I do support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Based on my reasoning, I hope you agree with my statement.  I do urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow present and future generations to protect, enjoy, and benefit from our ocean’s many beautiful treasures. 

Sincerely, 
Layla Olivero <3

Title: Comment from Miya, Navarre
Comment:
Covering over 134 miles of coastline this designated protected area would help support the health of our oceans and preserve the rich biodiversity of these ecosystems. It is all of our responsibilities to do everything we can to advocate for our natural resources, which include the ocean and all of the biodiversity remaining there. I strongly support the designation of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I advocate for the full original boundaries of the proposed sanctuary with the Gaviota coast extension. I advocate for a name that is inclusive of all the indigenous people of the sanctuary area. Current alck of consensus should not be used as a justification to eliminate any regions from the sanctuary boundaries. Collaborative management should include all of the tribal groups that are indigenous to the area of the proposed sanctuary. No tribe can make a decision for other tribes. Each tribe speaks for itself. The diverse Chumash and Salinan tribes, regardless of federal recognition status, need to be on equal footing with regards to input and management decisions. 
I support well regulated greed energy alternatives within the boundaries of teh sanctuary that do not come at the cost of long term ocean protections. The proposed wind farm is not an appropriate justification for excluding the Morro Bay area from the sanctuary boundaries. An acceptable wind farm should be able to meet the regulatory requirements of the sanctuary. Excluding the Morro Bay area from the sanctuary leaves that sacred and ecologically essential area vulnerable, not only to the wind farm, but other industrial purposes such as sea floor mining, oil drilling, and increased ship traffic. 
Please protect these natural resources and ancestral waters.
Thank you,
Navarre Miya

Title: Comment from Tagudar, Brennan Kayne
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,     

    My name is Brennan Tagudar and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. As a Californian, I want to support anything that protects our environment for future generations, so some information I would need to know to make my decision is how and if this sanctuary helps with the environment for ocean life. 

The seabed is an important habitat in the ecosystem of the proposed sanctuary, and NOAA wants to prevent activities that would harm the habitat and species on or near the seafloor. Therefore, NOAA proposes to prohibit activities that would drill into, dredge, or otherwise alter or disturb the submerged lands of the sanctuary. This prohibition would include constructing, placing, or abandoning any structure, material, or other matter on the submerged lands. However, there are some exceptions to this prohibition, such as disturbance during the conduct of lawful fishing activities, kelp harvesting, or anchoring a vessel. NOAA also proposes to except from this prohibition the installation of an aid to navigation, as well as the repair, replacement, or other maintenance on existing structures, specifically docks, piers, breakwaters, or jetties. Additionally, maintenance dredging of the entrance channels for Port San Luis in existence at the time the sanctuary is designated is also exempted. Vandenberg Space Force Base periodically conducts dredging near its coastal loading dock, with onshore disposal of the sand, but that dredging disturbance would be exempted with the general exemption for existing Department of Defense activities. NOAA has also proposed an exception to allow for drilling, maintaining, and abandoning wells incidental and necessary to normal oil and gas production activities within or into existing reservoirs in production at the time of sanctuary designation from Platforms Irene or Heritage.

The sanctuary contains significant natural resources, physical features, habitats, and cultural and historical resources that need long-term protection and management to reduce threats that would adversely affect their historical, cultural, archaeological, recreational, and educational value. These natural resources can benefit me and others. The area is home to many threatened or endangered species, such as blue whales, snowy plovers, black abalone, white sharks, and leatherback sea turtles, that rely on habitats, physical features, or prey found in the proposed sanctuary and with a balanced ecosystem in the ocean, that benefits scientists and us people.

The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary has faced opposition from some individuals who are concerned about the impact of wind turbines, future renewable energy, and the regulation of introducing and releasing species into the sanctuary. However, it is important to consider the benefits of the sanctuary, which include protecting an internationally significant ecological transition zone that is home to a wide variety of wildlife, including many at-risk species, such as snowy plovers.  Additionally, the sanctuary would connect two existing sanctuaries, forming a network where ocean wildlife can roam, and would protect an offshore area along 140 miles of California coastline, which is a diverse hotspot with a range of habitat types from coastal estuaries to deep sea canyons, and migratory paths frequented by marine mammals such as dolphins and whales 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I support anything that protects our environment for future generations and for them to protect, benefit, and enjoy the ocean.

Sincerely,
Brennan Kayne Tagudar

Title: Comment from Lee, Cate
Comment: I recently wrote an essay for an anthropology class about Indigenous "World-making." The essay essentially gets at the idea that there are important ideological discontinuities between the NOAA and the Chumash people. However, as Marisol de la Cadena discusses in her book "Earth Beings," the sanctuary space can be framed as a place of "partial connections" in which two "worlds" are partially connected through a similar interest to protect the land. While the essay is rather long, I would like to submit it as a further explanation of the issue of the alternative boundaries proposed by the NOAA. I hope that the NOAA is able to take into consideration other perspectives and critically reconsider the cultural and larger-scale impacts of leaving the Morro Bay wind energy corridor open for development. I think that this project is more than just an environmental project but an important cultural project that, if succeeds, reestablishes indigenous agency and self-determination.

Title: Comment from Blankespoor, Sarah
Comment: I strongly support the establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension, including the Rodriguez Seamount to protect the biodiversity of the area. As a Central Coast resident, I have a deep appreciation for the natural beauty of the proposed sanctuary area. The Pacific Ocean has always inspired me to take care of our planet, and I love visiting the ocean to look for fascinating creatures like anemones and crabs. I love going down to the waterfront in Morro Bay and spotting otters! It brings me so much joy to see the sea otter population begin to recover from hunting; the whole ecosystem should get a chance to recover and thrive. I believe the sanctuary area should be protected to preserve its vital ecosystems and ensure future generations can continue to enjoy this area. In addition, all Tribes, as the oldest stewards of this land, should be equitably included in collaborative management of the sanctuary, as signified with the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.” Similarly, the sanctuary plan should involve education and outreach programs to connect with the community, particularly underserved populations, and elevate Traditional Ecological Knowledge. New oil and gas development should be prohibited within sanctuary boundaries; the negative impact of oil and gas development on both local marine ecosystems and the biosphere as a whole is clear.

Title: Comment from WhoPoo App
Comment:
This draft management plan is pointless without a plan to dismantle offshore wind turbines. Planned wind projects off the New England coast threaten to harm the region’s dwindling population of endangered right whales, according to a US government marine scientist.

The warning from a top National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration official, obtained by Bloomberg under a Freedom of Information Act request, underscores the potential legal and environmental perils of offshore wind development along the coast. President Joe Biden has a goal of deploying 30 gigawatts of offshore wind within the decade. his strong correlation is strong evidence of causation, especially since no other possible cause has appeared.

To begin with, offshore lease sales really geared up 2015-16, with nine big sales off New Jersey, New York, Delaware and Massachusetts. These sales must have generated a lot of activity, likely including potentially damaging sonar.

In fact 2016 also saw the beginning of what are called geotechnical and site characterization surveys. These surveys are actually licensed by NOAA Fisheries, under what are called Incidental Harassment Authorizations or IHA’s.

There is some seriously misleading jargon here. IHA’s are incidental to some other activity, in this case offshore wind development. They are not incidental to the whales. In fact the term “harassment” specifically includes injuring the whales. That is called “level A harassment”.

To date NOAA has issued an astounding 46 one-year IHA’s for offshore wind sites. Site characterization typically includes the protracted use of what I call “machine gun sonar”. This shipboard device emits an incredibly loud noise several times a second, often for hours at a time, as the ship slowly maps the sea floor.

Mapping often takes many days to complete. A blaster can log hundreds of miles surveying a 10-by-10 mile site. Each IHA is typically for an entire year.There are lots of ways this sonar blasting might cause whales to die. Simply fleeing the incredible noise could cause ship strikes or fish gear entanglements, the two leading causes of whale deaths. Of the whales could be deafened, increasing their chances of being struck by a ship later on. Direct bleeding injury, like getting their ears damaged, is another known risk, possibly leading to death from infection. So there can be a big time difference between blasting and death.

Note also that these deaths need not be in the immediate vicinity of the sonar blasting, so spatial correlation is unlikely. Humpbacks in particular are prodigious travelers. One group was tracked traveling 3,000 miles in just 28 days, over 100 miles a day on average. Another group routinely migrates 5,000 miles. Both are winter-summer migrations which can happen twice a year.

Thus a sonar blasting, site characterization in one place could easily lead to multiple whale deaths hundreds of miles away. If one of these blasters suddenly goes off near a group of whales they might go off in different directions, then slowly die.

The point is that the huge 2016 jump in annual humpback mortality coincides with the huge jump in NOAA Incidental Harassment Authorizations. It is that simple and surely NOAA Fisheries knows this.Nor is this just about humpbacks. Some of the dead whales off New Jersey are endangered sperm whales. And of course there are the severely endangered North Atlantic Right Whales, on the verge of extinction.

Even worse, the IHA’s are about to make a much bigger jump. There are eleven pending IHA applications and eight of these are for actually constructing 8 different monster wind “farms”.

Driving the hundreds of enormous monopiles that hold up the turbine towers and blades will be far louder than the sonic blasters approved to date, especially with eight sites going at once. These construction sites range from Virginia to Massachusetts, with a concentration off New Jersey and New York.

This animation is embarrassing and pathetic. It is not supported by evidence of whale movement which include flips and flipper movements getting caught in cable: https://www.boem.gov/about-boem/humpback-whales-and-floating-offshore-wind-farms

Title: Comment from Diaz, Andres
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel, 
       My name is Andres Diaz and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. As a Californian I would love to support anything that would help and protect our environment and would like to understand if future generations will be affected by being unable to expand.
        Executive Order 12898 is a law that requires federal agencies to identify and address any negative effects their actions may have on the environment and human health of minority or low-income populations. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) designates national marine sanctuaries to improve environmental quality for all populations in the United States. The proposed sanctuary designation would not have a negative impact on any minority or low-income population. In fact, it could have long-term or permanent beneficial impacts by protecting sanctuary resources, which may provide employment and educational opportunities and improve ecosystem services. This means that the proposed sanctuary designation would not harm any minority or low-income populations and could actually benefit them in the long run.
          The Sanctuary will protect our animals and natural habitats but they will be scared from having any buildings or expansions to the area and will affect us as in our oils and turbines built for renewable energy. As well, new species are said to not be welcomed to the sanctuary and future energy would be heavily affected.
         Even if this impacts on us humans as in future energy and not having any new species invited to the sanctuary on the other hand there are still benefits that can help us and are able to make us expand as humans. The future takeaway from this Sanctuary will have an effect on the future generations to have an historical place where culture of the Chumash on the coastline with stories that impact the Chumash and also me as a Californian to be informed and learn about our coastline history.
       I truly would love having Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary on the coastline that will be dedicated to the first people in our area. I am all for it if this Sanctuary is permitted with the intent to help, expand, and protect the environment. 

Sincerely,
        Andres Diaz

Title: Comment from Moran, Veronica

Dear Paul Michel,

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and the Gaviota Coast Extension in order to protect over 7,600 square miles of the ocean. Title: Comment from Howard, Astrid
Comment:
I am very happy that NOAA is proposing the creation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.
However, the original boundary of this project in Cambria, further norther of Montanan del Oro State Park, and touching the southern boundary of the Monterey Bay Marine Sanctuary should be maintained. The further development of the Morro Bay 399 Wind Energy Area could then be developed with greater ecologic control and regard for the marine environment. 
I also believe that it is extremely important that the Chumash people be involved in the stewardship of this National Marine Sanctuary. These were the waters their ancestors honored and fished. This would be a recognition of the Chumash People whose lands and waters have been stolen from them by the colonisers. The inclusion of the Chumash People in the stewardship of this marine sanctuary would show respect for the our indigenous communities and a regard for their different perspective on our relationship with the land and the water.

Title: Comment from Burke , Spencer
Comment:
To whom it may concern: 

I was born and raised on the central California coast, where residents overwhelmingly support the protection of our irreplaceable natural and cultural resources. As such, I am writing to express my family’s and community’s enthusiastic support for the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

 I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Spencer Burke

Title: Comment from Owens, Penelope
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel,
I am writing in strong support for the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary as it was originally proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), as well as the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b), so that there is protection for the waters between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Santa Barbara, CA and the waters and coastline proposed to be protected in the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary are some of California’s most beautiful, diverse, and abundant coast and ocean. 

Many of Californians, including myself, look to the ocean as a place of recreation, restoration, and connection. Protecting this stretch of coastline and ocean will allow our community to continue to foster a strong ocean connection and benefit from a clean, healthy, and safe ocean. It will also help to preserve it for future generations to enjoy and benefit from. 

The proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should include:
•	Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension;
•	Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management;
•	Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities;
•	Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity; and
•	Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

Thank you for this opportunity express my support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,

Title: Comment from Tomlinson, Melissa
Comment:
I am writing in to support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension (including the current military occupied land and waters) to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. 

I have been stuck living in Lafayette, CA for many years, but for the first 18 years of my life I was raised alongside the Pacific Ocean. To me, the ocean has always been an elder, a place of reverence and a place long needing our protection. 
I was at the shoreline as an infant and all throughout my childhood, I still go there to feel a sense of home.  It constantly breaks my heart to witness its pollution as the Bay Area is so wrought with devastation to maintain elitist agendas.  

When I go to the coast, I walk, observe, and appreciate while I can mostly because I can only even access it while I’m working on my lunch break.  Due to poverty getting there otherwise is not possible.  It has been made to be for those who are wealthy instead of for all who care for it, which particularly disgusts me.  Development of our coasts is absolutely in part responsible for the effects of the many climate catastrophes we are seeing today.  These are some of the most precious and vulnerable areas of our ecosystem.
The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, our spiritual well-being, our community connections, and our economic health.
I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I also suggest this be considered a place a refuge and that there not be allowed any military or police personnel allowed within in boundaries.  Allow the tribal nations to truly have authority over its territory. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures. 

 

Sincerely,

Melissa T.
Lafayette, CA

Title: Comment from Bodily, Nancy
Comment:
You can try, a friend said, but they don’t care. They’re going to do whatever they want. She talked about mining rights, how she thought she had a choice whether to allow fracking. She didn’t have a choice. They were fracking no matter what. Her only decision was get paid for her claims or not. 
Here I am anyway, writing to ask that you preserve the Morro Bay section of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, and that you adopt the entire proposal as a marine sanctuary. I’m not going to bore you with the reasons. You know what they are. 
How tragic this Wind Turbine project is the reason for the Morro Bay exclusion from the sanctuary. Tragic that in the name of clean, green energy, this project will turn Morro Bay’s intact and thriving marine life and its surrounding communities into an industrial site for surveying, construction, and ongoing maintenance.
Morro Bay was of course part of Marine Sanctuary corridor. It’s essential. It wasn’t until rights were sold for millions to build wind turbines. Only energy departments and city planners want these wind turbines, and unfortunately you and they hold all the power in these decisions.
People don’t want this. It seems inevitable that it will impact, if not devastate whale migrations and all the marine life that surrounds them. Pause please and look to mistakes we’ve made in the past. Please consider adopting the Marine Sanctuary with the Morro Bay section intact. Don’t risk destroying ocean life along the Pacific Coast.

What I have learned from the ample research on this topic, is that community-led environmental management is far more effective than management led by those outside of the community. For this reason, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary!

Title: Comment from Morton, Ted
Comment: I am a resident of Goleta, CA. I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the largest boundary that is contiguous with other National Marine Sancutaries. I support including the approximately 2,000 square miles that were part of the initial proposal, but eliminated as part of the latest agency proposal. Adding this area would connect the southern end of the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary with the northern border of the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary. Connecting these two important marine protected areas will maximize protections for wildlife, habitats, and waters that make the central coast of California so special. It would follow scientific studies that demonstrate the importance of marine wildlife corridors for migratory species. It would also add back in sensitive cultural sites. I also support including the "Gaviota extension" as proposed in the Draft EIS. As you finalize a management plan and regulations for the new sanctuary, I recommend and support preventing new offshore oil and gas development in the sanctuary, prohibiting fracking and acidizing activities in the sanctuary, including water quality programs to prevent land-based pollution into sanctuary waters, adding strong measures related to speed of large vessels transiting the sanctuary, reducing pollution from large vessels, and making sure proactive, collaborative management is undertaken with Indigenous peoples.

Title: Comment from Strong-Cvetich, Nik
Comment:
My name is Nik Strong-Cvetich and I serve as Chief Executive Officer of Save The Waves Coalition, and I am writing to express my support for the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative to cover nearly 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect ocean biodiversity and habitats. I may live in Santa Cruz, but to me the designation is crucial as it sets aside a large swath of the coast under indigenous leadership and helps protect some of California’s most important surf ecosystems.

I have known Violet Sage-Walker for a few years now and have witnessed her determination, grit and resolve to realize a multi-generational dream; to get the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary designated as the first indigenous-led marine sanctuary. I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) name is important. It is meant to recognize people that have lived on this coast for over 10,000 years; protect the heritage of the Chumash, an ocean-going band among the First People of the Pacific Coast; and provide a timely and appropriate reminder of the cultural origins. I support equitable inclusion of all Central Coast Tribes, both federally and non-federally recognized Tribes, in collaborative management.
It is vital that Sanctuary education and community outreach should partner with area schools to share information about sanctuary species and habitats and Chumash history and culture. Outreach should be multilingual, culturally relevant, and should focus on underserved communities.
I support regulations to protect Rodriguez Seamount. The seamount provides critical habitat for an extremely diverse and abundant array of marine life and deserves to be granted strong and permanent protection. The seamount has special national significance that warrants special protections through sanctuary designation. Once damaged, fragile seamount ecosystems may not recover in our lifetime.
The proposed CHNMS will help protect important surf and cultural sites in perpetuity, therefore I support the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension as advocated by the Tribal Council.

Again, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the CHNMS to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

Nik Strong-Cvetich
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Weeks, Maya
Comment: I am a geographer living and working on Northern Chumash land in San Luis Obispo County writing to encourage NOAA to set as the boundaries for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary the entire area initially proposed for the Sanctuary. I support the Sanctuary reaching from the boundaries of the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary to the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary. This would protect an area of crucial biodiversity (for both the nation and the globe) as well as cultural heritage that is so important to the Chumash who have proposed and guided the designation of this Sanctuary. To leave out an area around Morro Bay would miss the point of the Sanctuary and leave that area vulnerable to hazards from development and overfishing. This would also render an area of great cultural significance vulnerable, which the Sanctuary was designed to avoid doing. I strongly encourage listening to the priorities of the Chumash individuals and organizations at the helm of this Sanctuary's designation.

Title: Comment from Rodriguez , KC
Comment: As a Ventureno Chumash, I would like to ask for the project to come to a end. There's been clear evidence that those who claim to be "Northern Chumash" are in fact frauds. Protecting our land and water is in fact crucial but this care should be given to those who are authentically Chumash, rather federal or non federal recognized. In closing, I hope you allow us, authentic Chumash people,  do what our ancestors have done for over 14,000 years, care for our homeland.

* Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
* Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
* Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 
Sincerely,
Kelly Jo Hannon

Title: Comment from M Arrona, Karen
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My, name is Karen Arrona and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Santuary with the initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extention . This will include about 7,600 square miles of ocean intended to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in San Luis Obispo, CA and have lived here since I was a young child (64 years). My father was a marine biologist and a professor at Cal Poly. He led field trips for the community to the Hazard Canyon tide pools and participated in summer programs for elementary age students from the San Joaquin Valley as well as doing research. I remember going to various beaches in the county all during my childhood with my dad and learning about the marine environment. My own children enjoyed these activities as well.

We need to protect the ocean so the community can benefit from a clean, safe and healthy ocean and continue to have recreational activities such as wh, swimming, surfing, kayaking and  educational activities such as whale watching.

I request that the designation of the marine sanctuary include the initial boundary alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension and I would support adding the Salinan name to the Sanctuary since part of the proposed area includes territories inhabited by the Salinan native people. I feel that the name Chumash/Salinan Heritage National Sanctuary would be appropriate to provide an equitable approach in collaborative management. There should be outreach,education and research programs providing traditional ecological knowledge and access for underserved communities. The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity. New oil and gas development should be prohibited within sanctuary boundaries to prevent ecological disasters like we have had in the past.

I support the designation of this marine sanctuary as the best way to protect our coastal waters and diverse habitat and urge the Administration to designate this sanctuary for future generations to enjoy.

Sincerely, 

Karen Arrona

Title: Comment from Goldstein, Susan
Comment:
The area proposed for national marine sanctuary designation is an important and vibrant
ecological transition zone with high biological productivity that supports dense aggregations of
marine life, including a nationally significant biodiversity of seabirds, marine mammals,
invertebrates, and fishes. It serves as “headwaters” for upwelling that nourishes important
ecosystems down current of the proposed sanctuary; however, due to the myriad ongoing and
emerging threats to the area from consumptive and non-consumptive human uses and climate
change, additional protections are needed. Threats facing these increasingly vulnerable coastal
and offshore ecosystems specifically include direct and indirect impacts from offshore energy
development, pollution from offshore and onshore sources, increased vessel traffic and
transportation, increased coastal development, and other stressors to the ecosystem that
compromise its resiliency—especially acute and cumulative impacts from climate change.
Moreover, there is a need to recognize and promote Indigenous cultural heritage of this area,
including the bands of Salinan people and the Chumash people, one of the few ocean-going
bands among the First Peoples of the Pacific Coast. The marine environments of California’s
central coast provide a special sense of place to coastal communities and visitors.

My name is Katherine Carmichael and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, and I strongly urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Katherine Carmichael

Title: Comment from Schulman, Daniela
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel and NOAA Staff,

My name is Daniela Schulman, and I am a climate and clean energy policy advocate living in Santa Barbara, CA. Today I am writing in my individual capacity to support the swiftest possible designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension. Below I offer three suggestions for the final rule:

1. Establish a Tribal advisory council that includes all local Tribal groups, not just federally recognized Tribes, and extends membership and input opportunities to community members outside the governing bodies. Elevate Traditional Ecological Knowledge in the education and management of the Sanctuary. Respect Tribal rights to sovereignty and determination by pursuing as many genuine opportunities for collaborative management as possible.

2. Prohibit oil and gas infrastructure within Sanctuary boundaries to address the climate crisis and protect local cultural resources and marine biodiversity. To avoid the worst impacts of the climate crisis, NOAA should do everything in its power to facilitate a swift phaseout of fossil fuels and transition to a zero-carbon economy, consistent with our national and state climate and clean energy targets and based on the best available science.

3. Designate the largest possible boundary alternative that ensures an equitable and expeditious path forward for the development of floating offshore wind. I urge NOAA to approve the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Extension and immediately, proactively pursue a special use permit for undersea transmission cables to pass through the Sanctuary. Submarine cables already run through Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary and could serve as a model. NOAA and California state agencies should also make use of all available funds to research the marine biodiversity impacts of offshore wind and associated transmission off of the Central Coast to ensure responsible siting that avoids, minimizes, and mitigates impacts.

Thank you for your efforts to undertake this EIS, and for your review of these comments. Please consider designating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension.

Sincerely,
Daniela Schulman

Title: Comment from Sklar, Helen
Comment:
I don’t get to the ocean as much as I want to, and think I should. It is a healthy place to be.  The air is better than it is in inland Los Angeles.   It is often but not always cleaner than the sidewalks and parkways of my neighborhood, a mile from the ocean.  
Oil spills are catastrophic and as humans its out job to protect the ocean from them.  It is wrong to assume that the ocean’s ability to survive is infinite.  As Former Congressman Leon Panetta tells us in his LA Times piece,“we wrongly assume [the ocean’s] bounty and capacity to absorb waste are limitless.  And the recent oil spill off Huntington Beach is an alarm we cannot ignore — the health of our coast and the wildlife, people and economies that depend on it cannot continue to absorb these avoidable catastrophes.”  See https://www.latimes.com/opinion/story/2021-10-22/oil-spills-marine-sanctuary-northern-chumash.  Congressman Panetta has extensive background in policymaking related to ocean protection,  so when he expresses an opinion, I listen.  He has concluded that the time is right to create a new sanctuary in California, this time in partnership with tribal communities.  
Former Northern Chumash Tribal Council Chair Fred Collins, community members in San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties have fought a multiyear campaign to create a sanctuary. Tribal Council Chair Collins died before his dream could be realized.  Nonetheless the need for the sanctuary continues.  It would protect an area targeted for offshore oil and gas development.  It is an area that contains Chumash cultural and sacred sites as well as sensitive ocean habitats. “Sanctuary designation would advance ecosystem-based planning to protect fisheries, seabirds, marine mammals, estuaries and beaches and promote appropriately sited offshore wind energy.”  See LA Times Op-Ed, above.  
Consider the alternative: A significant oil spill in this area would threaten a major portion of California’s shoreline, putting at risk nearly half the state’s coastal waters and beaches. Id. 
Thank you for your consideration.  
Helen A. Sklar
12551 Barbara Avenue
Los Angeles, CA  90066
310-717-7279
hsklar@ca.rr.com
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Minky, Michael

Comment: I have been leading hikes along the California Coastal Trail in San Luis Obispo County for over 15 years. The pristine coastline with abundant sealife, sea mammals, and land animals has highlighted the California Coast at its best. It is crucial to preserve this unique marine ecosystem for the health of the nation. I have worked closely with the Northern Chumash Tribe and their fight for the Marine Sanctuary. To have the Tribe be appointed guardians is a fitting tribute and recognition of their struggles and to the memory of Freddie Collins, the late Tribal Administrator. As a member of the Board of Directors of Coastwalk, The California Coastal Trail Association, I whole heartedly support the creation of the CHNMS.

Title: Comment from naxsmash group productions
Comment:
RE: Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary designation (NOAA-NOS-2021-0080)

We strongly support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) to protect ocean biodiversity and to advance environmental justice through collaborative ocean management. We support the following actions:

Sanctuary Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An inclusive approach to all Tribes in Collaborative Management & a NOAA Tribal Liaison.
Outreach and Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities.
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount
Offshore Wind: Thoughtful planning of Offshore Wind farms to protect ocean life
Water Quality: A prohibition on new oil development within sanctuary boundaries.

The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, spanning over 7,500 square miles of ocean and 156 miles of coastline, will be both beneficial for the environment, local communities and the economy. 

It is vital that the CHNMS cover the largest possible contiguous boundaries. We support designation of the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alt 5b). Including the waters offshore Point Buchon, Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria will close the California Central Coast’s biodiversity protection gap between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This will protect the only eelgrass bed in a 300-mile stretch of coast; many historic Chumash sites, including Lisamu’ (Morro Rock); numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds; the highest population of Southern Sea otters on the California coast; several State Marine Conservation Areas; and the kelp forests and rocky intertidal habitats considered to be some of the most diverse and abundant in the world.

The Draft Environmental Impact Statement acknowledges that all other alternatives would reduce the significant beneficial effects on biological resources provided by the Initial Boundary Alternative. All other alternatives would increase the vulnerability of those resources to adverse impacts that the Initial Boundary Alternative would prohibit or mitigate. The Initial Boundary Alternative is expected to result in long-term beneficial impacts on local residents (including low-income and minority populations), as well as on the health and well-being of children.

We support equitable inclusion of all Central Coast Tribes in collaborative management. All sanctuary stakeholders will benefit from Indigenous input. The CHNMS is an opportunity to advance environmental justice efforts. Equitable collaborative management must be open to all Tribal groups interested in participating. This can best be accomplished with a Tribal Sanctuary Advisory Council made up of interested Tribal Groups. NOAA’s Tribal collaboration should be facilitated by a qualified Tribal Liaison.

Sanctuary education and community outreach should partner with area schools to increase education and access to the ocean for local communities. Programs should focus on both ocean ecology and Tribal history and culture. Outreach should be multilingual and multicultural, and prioritize underserved communities, such as the inland communities of Guadalupe and Santa Maria. We urge development of research programs that address the impacts of climate change, encourage community science, and elevate the use of Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) to enhance ecosystem-based management. The Sanctuary should teach the benefits of protecting our ocean and planet and promote the spirit of stewardship that is exemplified by the culture and history of the original Chumash caretakers.

We support regulations to protect Rodriguez Seamount. The seamount provides critical habitat for extremely biodiverse marine life that needs strong and permanent protection against damaging activities such as deep sea mining and other threats. The seamount has special national significance that warrants special protections through sanctuary designation. Once damaged, fragile seamount ecosystems may not recover in our lifetime.

While a source of renewable energy, Offshore Wind (OSW) farms will have environmental impacts on habitat, wildlife, and water quality. California’s first OSW projects adjacent to the sanctuary should be planned and sited to avoid or mitigate impacts to sensitive marine areas and species and important cultural resources. The National Marine Sanctuary Program should work closely with state and federal partners, OSW companies, Tribes, and community members to ensure future OSW is developed in the most environmentally and culturally responsible manner.

Please act to protect our coasts via the Initial Proposal for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Dixon, Richard
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Richard G. Dixon and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Cambria, California and to me, the ocean is my front yard and an essential element bof my life and my happiness.  This is also the opinion of my wife of 61 years, Margaret E. Dixon. We will have enjoyed that relationship for 24years.

When I walk two blocks to the waters edgeto the coast, I  wade in the surf, explore the beach, and watch the wildlife. We often see broaching whales during the migrations.  The ocean is personally important to me. We depend on the ocean for recreation, and our mentall well-being.
I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean.
The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

I ask that this sanctuary include:

*  LargestPossible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.

     * Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”

Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Education: Education and research programs that elevate both ecological knowledge and access for local underserved communities
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
