Title: Comment from Bakula, Marcelle
Comment:
My name is Marcelle Bakuls.  I do not speak for Pacific Wildlife Care (PWC), but I am a current President of that organization serving San Luis Obispo County, I also have been a volunteer since 2005 for the Hi Mountain Condor Lookout, helping to train Cal Poly interns for work with the CA Condor Recovery Program. I was in Santa Barbara during the '69 oil spill. PWC as an organization began by citizens involved responding to an oil spill in Avila Beach.  I have joined the Oiled Wildlife Care Network through PWC and received many response trainings.  I have supported many environmental issues in San Luis Obispo County since moving here in 1970, including the successful protests of a supertanker port in Estero Bay.

I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the original Boundary Alternative to protect biodiversity and habitats joined to the Monterey Sanctuary in the north. I live in Cambria and our Pacific Ocean which is within a  mile of me and I take my grandchildren to the beach whenever they visit.

 I understand the removal off Morro Bay is due to the leases for wind farms...I am just now learning that there is a growing number of SLO County folks who are beginning to organize and will rally our citizens to oppose this move.  The environmental impacts, the effectiveness of wind are unknowns at this point in time. I have recently attended two USGS talks about the MOTUS at Piedras Blancas and tracking along the coast (migratroy birds and bats) as they BEGIN to gather data (that is far from complete).  I was surprised to learn that none of the obvious environmental concerns for whales, marine mammals, pelagic birds, migratory birds has been considered prior to the granting of leases. To me this is an obvious cart before the horse situation!  In my lifetime, there have now been 3 major/catastrophic cart-before-horse events:  Thalidamide, Fen-Fen, Opioids.. It's always hard to put the genie back in the bottle, but our oceans are fragile, our marine life important and vital. We need to STOP and really analyze everything BEFORE we ruin more of our planet and resources. Morro Bay itself thrives on Tourism (as does my town and we already have the impacts of Highway One being closed for so long!)

 It's my opinion that we need to connect the whole Pacific Coast between the Monterey Marine Sanctuary and the Channel Islands Marine Sanctuary in order to maintain our natural beauty and reduce any harmful impacts to the ocean, the seashore, the communities along our coast. Anything less is not only risky but a shameful way to protect our CA Coast (a treasure)!

Title: Comment from O'Mahoney, Penny
Comment: I am writing to express my deep support for the designation of a Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, specifically the larger proposed boundary which would encompass 5,617 square miles. The Chumash people were the original occupants of this land and sea, and only under colonization has ecological disaster created the need for such natural sanctuaries. Returning this stretch of coastline to the care and guidance of the Chumash community is crucial to the central coast's long term ecological survival in a world increasingly marred by climate change. Since Spanish colonization, Chumash people have been oppressed, killed, driven from their land, and faced cultural erasure. Although we are far from a place of atonement, creation of this sanctuary would be a critical step toward restoring rightful agency to the original occupants of this land. I urge you profoundly to grant the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Gill, Lucy
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Lucy Gill, and I am a recent graduate of UC Berkeley’s doctoral program in Anthropology now living in Oakland, California. I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I am an archaeologist with experience working in cultural resource management throughout California. Archaeological research complements Indigenous oral records in demonstrating that Indigenous Californians have been sustainably managing California’s diverse marine ecosystems for millennia. Additionally, because of the state-sanctioned genocide experienced by Native Californians, which resulted in the destruction of many sacred places, the government has a responsibility to protect sacred places like Lisamu’ (Morro Rock) and the entirety of Morro Bay, which was the center of Chumash commerce and community and holds significance for many different Tribal communities. 

I ask that this sanctuary incorporates the largest possible boundary (the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension), the only plan sufficient for protecting one of the most biodiverse ecosystems in the world and protecting Chumash and other Tribal sacred places. It should be collaboratively and equitably managed by all Tribes, prioritizing Traditional Ecological Knowledge in outreach, education, and research, which is essential for sustainable management, especially in this time of anthropogenic climate change. I also support a complete prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries, which would be in direct opposition towards protecting this sensitive ecosystem and promoting a sustainable future for California.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

Dr. Lucy L. Gill
Killam Postdoctoral Research Fellow
Department of Anthropology
University of British Columbia

Title: Comment from Nguyen, Makayla
Comment:
My name is Makayla Nguyen and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600  square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. 

The designation can be very important and crucial. Not only in preserving, and protecting marine life, but also in preserving the historical site used by the Chumash. The proposed sanctuary would come with long-term protection and management to reduce threats that would adversely affect their historical, cultural, archaeological, recreational, and educational value. In the designation there are also possible historical sites within, mainly being shipwrecks. 

I live in Oxnard, California and the ocean is a big part of our society and identity. Especially being so close to the coast, I have a deep appreciation for the marine life here. I grew up fishing with my dad and he would always teach me about marine life in the Channel islands. I loved watching dolphins go by the boat, seeing sea lions laying on the docks. The certain occasions where we would hear whales. The things I have experienced I would want for other kids and younger generations to be able to experience as well. 

Not to mention, there are also oil rigs that are harming our ocean and risking endangered animals in the ocean. This designation would help protect all of these marine animals. Many threatened or endangered species, such as blue whales, snowy plovers, black abalone, white sharks, and leatherback sea turtles, rely on habitats, or prey found in the proposed sanctuary. Without these, the animals have a chance to go extinct. 

However, in the area of the designation, California is proposing an ambitious goal to get 100% of its electricity from renewable sources by 2045. To do this they have been wanting to build wind farms in the area of the designation. This is a good thing, increasing in more renewable sources, though it’s an ambitious plan. These wind turbines can be harmful to marine life and habitats in the area. I believe that it would be better to find a different area to build these turbines, and have the designation go through for scientific and preversing purposes. 

I fully support this designation, because it’s highly beneficial and important to our society.

Sincerely,
Makayla Nguyen

Title: Comment from Luccioni, Marina
Comment:
Support for the INITIAL boundary alternative

Dear NOAA,
I am a marine biologist PhD student at Stanford University and resident of Moss beach, California writing in strong support of the INITIAL boundary alternative.

The Initial Boundary Alternative represents the boundary option in the original sanctuary nomination and is the sole alternative that assures contiguous protections of our coastal and offshore waters. It also ensures that offshore development is subject to the same regulatory protections for wildlife and habitat that apply to other parts of the sanctuary. I support the responsible development of green energy alternatives, including potential offshore industrial installations for wind and wave energy, but feel that rigorous assessment is needed for permits or authorizations, to ensure that any activities carried out have a justified environmental impact and impact to fisheries. 

I also think it is important to keep in mind the funding mechanisms behind different agencies who have interest in developing the coastline. If a private interest requests a permit/authorization to work within the proposed boundary, it is important that the financial burden of denying this appeal or engaging in legal action is held by the corporation that is applying, not the marine sanctuary. The initial boundary alternative is the only alternative that gives full power and financial safety to the stewards and managers of the sanctuary to carry out necessary assessment and then approve or reject development proposals within its waters. 

The California coast has been meaningful to me and my family as a place of rest and harvesting and connection. This comment is for myself and for them, and for my future children and neighbors so that we can together ensure that power is concentrated in the right places, helping to enforce decisions to steward our coastline in a way that helps humans and non humans of the area to thrive together. 

Many thanks for your time,
Marina Luccioni

Title: Comment from McCartney, Kathleen
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel,
I am a lifelong Californian, and I support the full designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension. As a resident of the San Mateo County coast, I am exceptionally fortunate to have daily access to the Pacific Ocean. Each time we stroll our local beach, we look for - and collect - debris and trash, in an effort to keep our local state beach as clean as we can. 

I cannot think of a more important or relevant effort than to approve the full Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, with the boundary alternative and Gaviota Extension. The Sanctuary will undoubtedly be an important element of ocean research, and a truly unique opportunity for education and environmental awareness.

As part of my enthusiastic support for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, I ask that:
It is comprised of the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.
The sanctuary is named the “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”.
It reflects an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
It emphasizes outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge and access for local underserved communities.
It includes protection of Rodriguez Seamount, which is essential to protect biodiversity.
And that there is a prohibition on new oil and gas development within the sanctuary boundaries.

Thank you for taking my comments into consideration, and thank you and your team for making the right choice to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in the most robust and full capacity as possible. - Kathleen McCartney

Title: Comment from Dahms, Daphne
Comment:
I am a long time resident of the Monterey Peninsula/Marine Sanctuary, and supporter of the Monterey Bay Aquarium.  I STRONGLY OBJECT TO the NOAA proposal, STRONGLY preferring the INITIAL BOUNDARY ALTERNATIVE, and the addition of the 5a and 5b EXTENSIONS, to create a seamless continuum of marine protection.  I AM STRONGLY AGAINST THE INCLUSION OF WIND TURBINES and associated CABLES in Morro Bay.  The disruption of the seafloor and underlying seabed, in these LARGELY UNEXPLORED, AND UNKNOWN, FRAGILE MARINE ENVIRONMENTS, the long-term  effects of which
are unknown, are sufficient to prompt the Monterey Bay Aquarium to call for a 'pause' on undersea mining and exploration, until the impacts of such disruptions can be more fully elucidated.  Construction of these massive structures is similar in its destructive effects on the seafloor. THERE IS ALREADY KNOWN HARM BEING CAUSED TO MARINE MAMMALS BY THE PRESENCE OF OFFSHORE WIND FARMS, AND, AS SUCH THEY HAVE NO PLACE IN AN AREA THAT PURPORTS TO PRESERVE MARINE LIFE!!
I also object to the inclusion of such structures being 'permitted' in the event the Initial Boundary limits survive to implementation.  THE BLASTING, DRILLING AND CONSTANT MECHANICAL HUM OF THESE MASSIVE STRUCTURES, not to mention their EVENTUAL REMOVAL, HAVE NO PLACE IN A SANCTUARY.  The idea that the destructive effects and commotion will be restricted to the narrow corridor, in a marine environment, is ludicrous!!! 
IN ADDITION, THE HARM TO MIGRATING BIRDS AND OBSTRUCTION OF MARINE MAMMAL MIGRATION ROUTES, as well as the BLIGHT to the seascape makes wind turbines of MORE HARM THAN BENEFIT.  In contrast, the ongoing operation of the Diablo Nuclear Power Plant: "Unlike evaporative cooling systems used at other plants, Diablo Canyon's OTC is designed so all water can be recycled, and to assure minimal impact on ocean ecosystems. Reactors can be throttled back during heavy storm surges to prevent an excess of kelp from entering the cooling water intake, and power is limited during operation" (Wikipedia quote), the warmed water returned to the ocean SUPPORTS THRIVING MARINE LIFE, and Diablo's presence in the Sanctuary area
should prove to be of benefit, in contrast to the KNOWN HARMFUL EFFECTS OF OFFSHORE WIND FARMS!!!!!

Title: Comment from Lane, Kat
Comment:
Dear NOAA decision makers,
I first want to thank you for going through with the designation of the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary. As a guest and settler in Santa Barbara County, I have been welcomed with open arms by the Chumash bands that have thrived here for millennia and continue to do so. I know that this designation is a crucial step in affirming Chumash sovereignty and autonomy, creating a regenerative, healing, and accountable society, and also doing our part as allies and settlers in this space. I commend you for working on this effort, but also call on you to do so much more. I urge you to include the waters from Cambria south to Point Buchon and Montaña de Oro State Park, included in the original Sanctuary boundaries, in the actual Sanctuary. We must do this Marine Sanctuary correctly and authentically. Not including these waters is another example of settlers disregarding Indigenous voices and needs, and places us further away from equitable coexistence. I urge you to add these waters to do your part as an accountable ally and to set precedence for more amazing and healing designations like these. Thank you so much for your time and consideration; I greatly appreciate it!
-Kat Lane, Santa Barbara, CA resident.

Title: Comment from Martley, Suzanne Iudicello
Comment:
24 October 2023
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Suzanne Iudicello Martley and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
Although I now live as far away from either coast as can be — in Rapid City, South Dakota, about 50 miles from the North American pole of inaccessibility — my career of 50 years has been on the coasts, for the ocean, for fishers, for fish and all ocean species. Truth to tell, I’ve been a contractor to NOAA for technical support for decades, including projects related to marine reserves and national marine sanctuaries.*
My time on the coast is constrained these days to business trips, but I always take some extra time after the work to walk on the beach, watch wildlife, wade in the surf, and restore my well-being. 
This sanctuary will be an important part of those qualities, but also recreation, community connections, economic sustainability and new opportunities, ocean research and education for present and future generations. More than that, it can be an example of how to respect, integrate, and co-manage sacred sites.
In my current geography and work, the preservation of tribal access to plants, animals, and sacred sites in the Black Hills is actually relevant to your designation. Protection of the Rapid Creek Watershed that sustains our community and others in Western South Dakota is another tough bargain: how do we choose natural resources that provide clean energy when those activities conflict with sustaining and conserving clean water, healthy communities, economic activity in the outdoor recreation sector, and access to lands and resources by the indigenous people from whom these lands and waters were taken? We are currently fighting the unregulated, unpermitted exploration and proposed development of lithium for car batteries in the watershed that is Mní Wičóni: Water is Life.
Because of my career-long work to protect the ocean and its inhabitants, and because NOAA has this opportunity to show that co-management and restoration of tribal rights can work, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 
Please designate boundaries that include:
•	The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.
•	The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.”
•	An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
•	Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities.
•	The protection of Rodriguez to protect biodiversity.
•	A prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.
This area should be a sanctuary, “a place of refuge or safety” according to the dictionary, not a conflict zone of strife and threats to sea life. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
With respect,
Suzanne Iudicello Martley
*Bernstein, B., Iudicello, S., Stringer, C. Lessons Learned from Recent Marine Protected Area Designations in the United States. A Report to: The National Marine Protected Areas Center NOAA, June 11, 2004.

Bernstein & Iudicello (eds) Integrating Marine Reserve Science and Fisheries Management: Consensus Conference, June 7-9, 2004 Long Beach, CA. NFCC Consensus Statement (August 2004)

Title: Comment from Christensen, Kate
Comment: I am in full support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary! Thank you, NOAA, for a most incredible job of preparing the plans for the CHNMS This designation is incredibly important. It will do much to protect our ocean for the benefit of all. This designation will not only protect the environment, it will educate many people and future generations. It will protect Chumash Heritage and ensure that indigenous knowledge is passed forward. The benefits to the economy in terms of jobs and tourism is important. Protecting the environment is paramount. Mitigating the certainty of climate change effects is essential. I also hope that the original boundary in the North will be maintained to close the gap between the Monterey Sanctuary and the Channel Islands Sanctuary. Leaving no gap makes sense to me. I also support the Gaviota extension. Title: Comment from moffat, lorna
Comment:
I approve of this proposal provided it doesn't disallow people from living on their vessels in harbors because as a liveaboard, I have helped our Monterey Bay Marine Sanctuary from many impending disaster.
We are the eyes on the ocean when others are asleep. Many times I have called in loose vessels that might otherwise have crashed upon shore.
Our Monterey harbor depends on us liveaboards to alert them of loose vessels, illegal oil spills excreta. We are a valuable assets and save our Harbor office much money to hire full time employees to comb the harbor 24 hours a day looking for violations or loose vessels.
Also it is unreasonable to ask a person to die on their ship because it went aground and they cannot leave the ship. Sometimes you must desert due to whatever circumstances threaten your life. This must be clarified.
(7) Deserting a vessel aground, at anchor, or adrift in the Sanctuary or leaving harmful matter aboard a grounded or deserted vessel in the Sanctuary.
Wind farms on the ocean will kill millions of seabirds who also use the wind patterns that these wind farms seek. Therefore may I suggest only allowing wave energy farms be used such as VOIT Systems as depicted in this YouTube Video. There are many different wave energy systems to choose from but allowing wind farms on the surface of the ocean should not be allowed for the reasons mentioned.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gcStpg3i5V8&t=33s

Title: Comment from Levin, Allison
Comment:
I support the name, "Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” to recognize the First People of the Pacific Coast. I encourage this sanctuary to have the largest possible contiguous boundaries ( Initial Boundary Alternative combined with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alternative 5b); too much of our oceans are unprotected and overfished and abused. We must protect as much as we can!
Collaborative management among all local tribes will bring the best outcome possible.
I'm concerned about any pollution that might impact this sanctuary, so support strong water quality programs, and opposed the nearby Vandenberg projects that may negatively impact the sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Peterson, Briana
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel, 

My name is Briana Peterson, and I'm writing to express support for the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I am a native of SLO county, California and live in south county near the beach.  To me, this coast is a life source for thousands of animals and plants.  The ocean enriches them, and this unique ecosystem enriches us human residents with its profound beauty.  Every interaction with a sea otter, whale, dolphin or octopus is precious and fills me with an ineffable sense of joy.  Right now there are so many things threatening the vibrant ecosystems of our oceans, I think we should protect the national treasure off our own coast to preserve these joyful interactions for future generations as well.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension, The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”, an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management, Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities, the protection of Rodriguez Seamount as essential to protect biodiversity, and a prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,
Briana Peterson

Title: Comment from Lee, Sandra
Comment:
NOAA and BOEM, I support the Chumash Sanctuary protecting the entire stretch of the Central Coast, with Morro Bay at its heart.
This is vital to the economic and physical health of the coastline.  Not only have the Chumash protected this area for hundreds of years, but our current population relies on a healthy coastline for its survival as a working coastal town and the tourist dollars that support many of our local shop owners.  The Morro Bay community is home to a world renowned annual Bird Festival, natural history museum, and  whale watching industry.  The survival of our community depends on a coastline free of wind turbines, oil drilling, and deep sea mining.  Sanctuary status would protect the coastline's health for generations to come from willy-nilly decisions made by rotating officials.  I feel very strongly that we need to protect our marine life.  I realize the government wants to find ways to produce power and harvest resources, but there are less sensitive areas to do so that will not impact a local population dedicated to and dependent upon a healthy coastline.

Title: Comment from Thawley, Bob
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Bob Thawley and I support the rapid designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats, and create a lasting legacy of protection for our children.

I live in San Francisco, CA,  but have spent substantial time over the years on that coastline, diving and fishing in my youth and now just appreciating the natural beauty with family. 

This sanctuary should have biggest possible boundary and again, please support the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension to be named “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”, in honor of the original people of theses lands and  should include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
This stewardship would help support outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities. The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity, as is a prohibition on new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries. Additionally, please oppose the proposed offshore wind projects off of Vandenberg based on serious environmental, cultural and permitting-process issues. The projects are irresponsibly sited too close to the shore, in a uniquely biodiverse location, with highly significant fisheries and unacceptable impacts to critical cultural sites for the Chumash and other native peoples. We should be ensuring a contiguous buffer of ocean protection while directing Offshore Wind development to more suitable areas further offshore where wind energy is optimal and ecological and cultural impacts can be reduced.  Any
Offshore Wind transmission cables proposed for this area as part of future offshore wind
development should require permits from the National Marine Sanctuary Program to ensure that
they are planned and sited in a thoughtful, consolidated manner to reduce and mitigate impacts to
the ocean. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s bounty and healing power, as well as to honor and benefit from the traditional Indigenous knowledge that Chumash stewardship would bring to our future as Californians.

 

Sincerely,
Bob Thawley 
   retired UCSF researcher
   San Francisco,  CA

Title: Comment from Chacon, Ali Marie
Organization Name: Tribal member of the Gabrielino Band of Mission Indians, San Gabriel
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Ali Chacon and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. 
I live in Oxnard, CA and to me, the ocean is a wonderful place where ancestors traveled across to bring our people to new lands. Where most stories took place, and where they will continue to be told. The ocean is filled with creatures of the sea and land. It's a special place for me, and a special home for them. 

When I go to the coast,  I can hear the ocean waves crash onto the rocks. My family and I would go on trips to places far away, and so my dad would always take the route that's near the ocean on the other side of the mountains. I can see the big waves crash on the shore, seagulls flying over the sea, tides coming… Everything was beautiful to see. The smell too, it reminds me of my childhood so much of when I came in contact with the sand, water, shells.. Everything.

The ocean is personally important to me because this is where my native ancestors started. They lived near the ocean and came from islands. It brings back memories because I would always help my Native tribe with beach and ocean cleanups. It gave me a good connection with the ocean, and it had been a while since i've been in the ocean.
I want to protect the ocean for the sake of the ocean’s sea animals. They live in those waters and shouldn't have to leave or worse.. Die because of our causes. I want more people to realize that we are hurting our beautiful ocean, and that we should do something to protect our waters. We want this part of the ocean to be here for a long time, for future generations to see how far the world has come and what we did to save it. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: Native culture of the Chumash people. It would be nice since this would be a sanctuary in their name, and we can listen to the stories they would want to share dedicated to the ocean and animals. It also honors them and the land that we stand on. I would also hope to see Tribal Collaborative Management. It would mean the world to me knowing other tribes would want to help this good cause, and everyone coming together would create better bonding. Another is the banishment of Oil and gas near the sanctuary. I hope the sanctuary would prohibit any oils from spilling from offshore or from development areas. I did read that they will prohibit it, but with a cost of transferring pipelines and being a disturbance to the seafloor, so I'm hoping they would do something about that. Lastly, I’m hoping to see outreach and education. Seeing programs for kids to be part of or understanding the traditional ecological knowledge of the Chumash and the community. For example, elementary kids could learn about the plant life and animals of course living in the sanctuary. Highschoolers can learn the way these animals are living, what is keeping them safe, and how this affects us and the environment. But for people of all ages, they can learn the Chumash peoples' culture, traditions, and the land that we stand for. It can be an enjoyable experience for all people of different cultures, and gaining new knowledge to continue sharing.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely, Ali
(Tribal member of the Gabrielino Band of Mission Indians, San Gabriel)

Title: Comment from Castro, Alina
Comment:
Dear Mr. Paul Michel,

My name is Alina Castro and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. I live in Oxnard, California and to me, the ocean is beautiful, mysterious, and one of a kind. Healthier oceans and oceanic ecosystems means that we will also have a healthier human population. Establishing this sanctuary means that there will be reduced chances/effects of climate change which indicates there will be cleaner air and a cleaner Earth. Some say that the marine sanctuary will get in the way of the state’s plan to install wind farms (which is a plan/goal that California has to reach their bigger goal of getting 100% of our electricity from renewable sources by 2045.) Others believe that it will negatively affect fishing and other local manufacturing industries that are ocean based. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary will help improve and preserve local oceanic ecosystems, food webs, and rich marine life which is why I support the designation of this sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: tribal collaborative management, a ban on oil and gas development, and a name that includes the meaning/reason of the preservation such as “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”. I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s treasures.

Sincerely, 
Alina

Title: Comment from Clark, Gretchen
Comment:
Although the language of the proposed boundaries refers to the First Peoples of this area, the map leaving out Morro Rock and the coastline up to Cambria does not fully value the integrity of the tribal territories. Preserving a through-way for energy development, undersea cables and such, is a modern-day echo of the taking of resources that has occurred throughout the history of this land. I live here in Los Osos, I walk the beaches, and I am always conscious of the fact that we have built our homes on indigenous land. I urge NOAA to honor this debt by making the boundary totally inclusive, preserving the continuity of this area.
Sincerely, Gretchen Clark, Los Osos

Title: Comment from Bloom, Jeffrey
Comment: I support the approval of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  There should be no gap left between Cambria and Morro Bay to assure the protection of sensitive marine migration routes.  Leaving a gap for the purpose of supporting speculative future offshore energy cabling is shortsighted.  The need for alternative energy development may be high, but not at the expense of protecting an irreplaceable marine ecosystem.  The establishment of a future highly confined route for cables should be considered within the context of protecting the sensitive marine environment.  Not left out to make it easier.

Title: Comment from Saleh, Lina

Lina S.

Title: Comment from Gage, Faydra
Comment: I’m writing to request that you please revise the designation of the Sanctuary to be as it was originally proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), as well as the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b), so that there is protection for the waters between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. I am in support of the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary,   and want to urge the importance of the conservation of marine waters, wildlife, and habitats that this Sanctuary promotes. Furthermore, keeping the initially proposed area in the Sanctuary boundary does not prevent Offshore Wind Farms off of Morro Bay, but would lead to more careful planning to ensure these projects avoid and mitigate impacts to sensitive marine areas, species, and important cultural areas. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should ensure that Offshore Wind operations and construction are completed through the guidelines of the new Sanctuary. Thank you for considering my comment.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Flaniken, Stephanie
Comment:
I celebrate that the Biden-Harris Administration has proposed the Chumash Heritage NMS! This is a letter of support for the proposal with a request to extend it to meet the Monterey Bay NMS, the entry and wetlands of the entire Morro Bay, and Morro Rock.

I am thrilled that this area of the California coast is being put forward as a national marine sanctuary.  If we are going to take care of the planet and it’s life, we need to make it a priority to do so. The ocean and this area are worth protecting as a source of diversity, safe migratory paths and homes for a plethora of animals, food, oxygen, and as a carbon sink. The currents of the ocean protect and stabilize the climate of the planet, provide heat and carbon absorption, and help provide for the diversity of life critical for continued life on this planet.  

The Chumash have revered this coast line. It is important that we recognize their place here and celebrate their special connection to the ocean. I love that this sanctuary will be named to honor these people.

I do have complaints that the sanctuary does not complete a ocean highway for migrating animals, does not include ocean access to Morro Bay, does not include the Bay itself or Morro Rock.  These are aspects that should not be left out of the Sanctuary.  The fact that the area has commercial concerns and will be a necessary access point for off-short wind farms should not be an impediment to its inclusion in the sanctuary. By failing to include and protect the bay, Morro Rock, and connect this stretch of coast to the Monterey Bay NMS, NOAA is breaking up the migration highway of marine animals, leaving out a site sacred to the Chumash (Morro Rock), and failing to provide the bay the protections that will be necessary effectively protect the cultural heritage and the bird species that rely on the area. I think that’s wrong.

Please establish the Chumash Heritage NMS, connect it to the Monterey Bay NMS, and include the bay and the culturally important Morro Rock in the Sanctuary.

As a lover of the California coast, an active volunteer of the Monterey Bay Aquarium, and coastal recreation user, I am borrowing these words from the Surfrider Foundation and agree with the following points that they raise. 
“I strongly support the designation of a new national marine sanctuary off the central California coast, 
    • This designation should be named Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in recognition of the history and culture of the Chumash people.
    • The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should be officially designated as soon as possible.
    • The sanctuary boundaries should include the full geographic extent reflected in the original proposal - i.e., the Initial Boundary Alternative - as well as the Gaviota Coast Extension (5B) boundary option. 
    • The management plan should ensure the lasting protection of the sanctuary’s outstanding ecological and cultural resources.
    • The sanctuary should prohibit any oil and gas exploration, development or production.
    • The sanctuary should prohibit seabed mining, ocean dumping and other activities damaging to the seafloor, cultural resources and marine ecosystem.
    • The sanctuary should protect water quality from pollution sources including cruise ships, commercial vessels and agricultural runoff.
    • Indigenous Collaborative Management should be applied in an equitable manner to empower the Chumash Nation and other Indigenous Peoples to steward these invaluable resources.
    • The sanctuary should support and promote marine research, education, stewardship, recreation and tourism.”

Thank you,
Stephanie Flaniken

Title: Comment from M, Jessica
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
 My name is Jessica and I support The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is a collaborative effort led by the Northern Chumash Tribal Council. To fund a national marine sanctuary off the central California coast. The sanctuary would protect ocean biodiversity, and advance environmental justice through collaborative management. The sanctuary would protect thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. I live in Oxnard California and to me the beach is a sacred place and it means a different thing to everyone. The beach holds an ocean full of memories and history. I learn so much about the beach, and me every time I go. I see how every animal has its own space.  Everything that makes the beach up has a beautiful story yet to be told. The beach brings me to peace and grounds me from this hectic world. The background information of The Chumash National Sanctuary states “marine environment of the proposed sanctuary is significant for its historical, archaeological, cultural, aesthetic, and biological resources. Over 200 reported ship and aircraft wrecks, with at least 20 in the sanctuary area, reflect its maritime importance. Coastal tourism, recreation, and commercial fishing drive the local economy, especially in San Luis Obispo County, while Santa Barbara County sees more coastal and offshore energy and military activities. Public access is more available in San Luis Obispo County, with military bases and private land limiting access in Santa Barbara County. Marine research is an emerging sector in the region.” The opposing side argues that the Central Coast waterways do not need to add more federal oversight. The fear he might lose local control over the water. Might disturb the local businesses that are there. Some are concerned about the economic impact. I believe that we should take the risk and help persevere such an important part of history, culture, and marine life   


Sincerely, Jessica Michel

Title: Comment from Wilks, Kirah
Comment:
Dear Mr. Paul Michel,

My name is Kirah Wilks and I fully support the proposition to create the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary in order to protect biodiversity, habitats and the water quality. 

I live in Santa Cruz, CA and I cannot begin to describe my love for the ocean. It brings me to tears knowing that so many amazing marine species have gone extinct within recent years specifically due to human activity, but we can still restore what we've lost! The ocean is the most powerful place and can easily benefit us with spiritual well-being and community connections. I want to protect the proposed 7,600 square miles of coast to ensure our communities with a clean ocean and healthy marine life. 

There's so much we know (and so much more we don't know) about our oceans, moreover we have strong evidence proving that our actions 100% affect the overall health of our ocean. Without National Marine Sanctuaries, oil-drilling would be overpopulating our oceans and propelling even faster towards a mass extinction. The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary should include the biggest possible boundary, a ban on oil and gas development, collaborations to manage movements with Tribes, easy-to-understand educational resources/outreach programs, and finally to protect the Rodriguez Seamount to preserve biodiversity. 

The designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary has my full support, I strongly urge the Administration to appoint the possible Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to learn, benefit and protect the ocean's treasures and offerings. 

Thank you.

Sincerely, 

Kirah Wilks

I live by the Pacific Ocean and value the ability to walk along the beach and enjoy the natural environment. As a birder, I am very interested in the shorebirds and seabirds and want to support initiatives to protect the birds and their environment.


I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:
Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Lydia Bruno

Title: Comment from Hellier, Ruth
Comment:
Firstly, I want to offer my thanks to you for protecting the Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.  I believe that Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is incredibly important - because it recognizes the rightful native peoples and the importance of the ocean and the richness and diversity of life within the waters. 


I ask that you please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (known as the Initial Boundary Alternative), and also the Gaviota Extension (known as sub-alternative 5b). These two areas are crucial in order to provide continuous and contiguous protection between Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries and Monterey Bay.
The contiguous area is absolutely essential to ensure that the whole region can be protected, rather than fragmented, which will inevitably lead to degradation. 
This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment. it also contains cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages.

I suggest that offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit later in the process. In the meantime, it is crucial that the area and waters be permanently protected from harmful activities like the development of gas and oil; dredging,and seabed mining; and also from harmful polluting discharges to these precious and beautiful waters.

Please create and protect the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Boyer-White, Branden
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

As a resident of Los Angeles and former volunteer with the Marine Mammal Care Center in San Pedro (4 years), I know from firsthand experience the value of safe passageways, open, clean seas for feeding, and shoreline for breeding and raising of Elephant seal, Harbor seal, and California sea lion pups. And, in a time of huge ecological upheaval and coming devastation from human-born climate crisis, these animals (including birds, fish, and all other marine life) need even more support in the form of protections like this for their survival.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and ask that it include the Biggest Possible Boundary that was initially proposed with Gaviota Coast Extension, that it be called the “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” in recognition of the Chumash people who originally lived on and stewarded those waters and coastlines, and that it be managed equitably including all Tribes in Collaborative Management. I wish to see the protection of the Rodriguez Seamount for the sake of biodiversity and for a ban to be put in place prohibiting new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries.

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary because it is the right thing to do.

Title: Comment from Black, Kyra
Comment:
Four generations of my family have lived in Morro Bay. As such, words cannot describe my profound love for my community and investment in its future, but I will do my best:

To me, the future of Morro Bay is inherently entwined with the ocean's health. Every aspect of life here, in one way or another, is shaped by our beautiful marine surroundings. In my case, the time I spent kayaking, tide-pooling, swimming, and boogie boarding amongst Morro Bay's marine life during my childhood was critical in determining who I wanted to be in this world. This past June, I graduated from UC San Diego with a B.S. in Marine Biology. I spent most of my undergrad researching climate mitigation solutions at Scripps Institution of Oceanography. I now work at the UCSD Center on Global Justice teaching and developing climate science curricula for middle schools in San Diego. Long term, I want to use my skills to protect and conserve marine habitats back home - I owe my deepest gratitude and admiration to the Chumash leaders who already do so, and have been for thousands of years.  

I firmly believe that the only sustainable, just, and equitable way forward for Morro Bay - and the surrounding Central Coast - is to establish the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative. It is time that we learn from past mistakes, listen to community leaders with generational knowledge, and fully commit to protecting the health of our marine ecosystems. There is inevitable loss and transformation that will unfold in Morro Bay as a result of climate change - we cannot undo the past, but we can fight for the future. I urge the NOAA to do everything in its power to protect heritage and biodiversity for generations to come.

Title: Comment from Marin Audubon Society
Comment:
MARIN AUDUBON SOCIETY
P.O. BOX  599
MILL VALLEY, CA 94942

Good morning,

Thank you for the opportunity to support the INITIAL Boundary Alternative for the proposed Chumash Heritage NMS. As President of the Marin Audubon Society, a Mill Valley, California based chapter of the National  Audubon Society that has for over 67 years worked to conserve wildlife and wild habitats. I am writing to convey our support for the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary Boundary Alternative 1 (Initial) plus Gaviota addendum.

First, we endorse the extension of sanctuary protections to create a contiguous corridor in our country’s offshore waters. Having reviewed the boundary alternatives, Marin Audubon therefore supports the boundary alternative originally published in the Federal Register that will create an uninterrupted corridor of legal protections for significant natural and cultural resources. An automatic carve-out for offshore industrial development, including wind and wave energy installations as reflected in the “agency-preferred” alternative is not in keeping with NOAA’s Office of Marine Sanctuary’s mandate for environmental protection.

These waters support a host of protected and endangered species and their critical habitats in one of the most significant upwelling regions on the planet. This alone merits the utmost effort to maintain, conserve and restore its biological resources and habitats. Its existing proximity to offshore oil development already compromises the health of these waters, and this must prompt an extra layer of protection for the proposed marine protected area.

The  Initial/Alternative 1 Boundary ensures that offshore industrial development is subject to the same strict regulatory protections for habitat integrity and wildlife that apply to other national marine sanctuaries elsewhere and to other areas of this proposed sanctuary.  

We acknowledge that compromise is often a necessary part of achieving consensus. We also appreciate that NOAA is under the US Department of Commerce, however, we believe that commerce and conservation can work in partnership to achieve our nation’s clean energy goals. The inclusion of the Morro Bay and other areas missing from the agency-preferred option will provide a stronger framework for enforcing environmental protections as development proposals are fleshed out. The energy industry's track record - whether for carbon based fuels or otherwise - does not merit special exemptions; indeed, it warrants extra caution. In our haste to meet state and federal goals, ref: the 30/30 objectives, we should not waive our obligation to avoid, where possible, impacts in achieving them.

Please confirm the Initial Boundary Alternative for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Barbara Salzman, President
Marin Audubon Society

Title: Comment from Pico, Rom
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Rom Pico and I support the establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary so that it can protect these habitats and biodiversity. I live in Oxnard, California and to me, the ocean gives me so much. It gives me a place to bond with my family, it gives me food to eat, a place to practice soccer. Whenever I go to the beach, it’s always with my family. We play volleyball or just sit there and picnic. It's really fun. Another time I go to the beach is to practice with my team, I get to be more fit due to sand being harder to run on and I get to do chilenas a lot. The ocean is also where most of the food I love comes from. For example, I love sushi and fish and chips, they are so savory and my stomach growls when I think of them. I support this establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary but I ask what does this sanctuary provide? I want to see how the name of this sanctuary collaborates with the Salinian tribe, as it’s their land as well so how will you share this sanctuary with them? I want to know will this Sanctuary be involved with national parks? I want to know if this Sanctuary will cost a lot of money to establish and if it will harm or benefit the California economy How will biodiversity be protected? And what will happen if this sanctuary fails? For the last time, I support this Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I really hope this succeeds as I want to see a lot of unique animals in the ocean in the future. From, Rom Pico. can you make this college leveled
Sources
Proposed Designation of Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary

noaa
·
1
Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary

chumashsanctuary
·
2
About the Proposed Chumash Heritage Sanctuary

chumashsanctuary
·
3



Dear Paul Michel,
The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is a proposed marine sanctuary that would protect the region's important marine ecosystems and maritime heritage resources, support ocean-dependent economies, and preserve thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites. The sanctuary would stretch from Gaviota to Cambria, covering nearly 6,000 square miles of ocean. The sanctuary would prohibit oil development, seismic testing, dumping of agriculture wastewater, and other threats to the marine habitat.
Regarding the Salinian tribe, the sanctuary is a collaborative, grassroots effort led by the Northern Chumash Tribal Council, and it provides an exceptional opportunity to advance the first Tribal-nominated national marine sanctuary designation in the U.S., setting a precedent for elevating Indigenous perspectives and cultural values in ocean conservation.
The sanctuary will not be involved with national parks, as it is a separate designation.
The cost of establishing the sanctuary is not mentioned in the search results. However, the sanctuary would protect ocean biodiversity, including salmonids, and would advance environmental justice through collaborative management. The sanctuary would also support ocean-dependent economies.
Biodiversity would be protected through comprehensive ecosystem management, which would ensure the health of the marine habitat. If the sanctuary fails, it is not clear what would happen, but it is likely that the marine ecosystem and cultural heritage resources would continue to be threatened by human activities such as oil development and dumping of agricultural wastewater.
Overall, the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is a proposed marine sanctuary that would protect the region's important marine ecosystems and maritime heritage resources, support ocean-dependent economies, and preserve thousands of years of Chumash cultural heritage by protecting sacred sites.
From, Rom Pico.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Maruska, Don
Comment:
I have read and understand the proposed sanctuary designation and alternatives. I offer this comment based upon insights gained from the following experiences: 
(a)	My extensive work from 2003-2010 as an independent facilitator of the Marine Interests Group of San Luis Obispo County (MIG).  The MIG began at the request of then Congress member Lois Capps and San Luis Obispo County Supervisor Shirley Bianchi to engage a multi-stakeholder group of scientists, fishermen, businesspeople, environmentalists, and local government officials to evaluate the desirability of creating a National Marine Sanctuary for the area and other measures to enhance and sustain the marine resources off of the Central Coast. Although I served without advocating any position, I did have the opportunity to listen to much scientific information and public discussion.
(b)	Experience as a facilitator of the stakeholder discussions for the State of California’s formation of MPAs along the Central Coast.
(c)	Facilitator in the creation of the California Collaborative Fisheries Research Program, which remains active today, to engage scientists and fishermen in gathering valuable information to enhance the understanding of fish stocks on the Central Coast. 
(d)	Founding member of the Ecosystem Advisory Subpanel of the Pacific Fisheries Management Council 2010-2021.
(e)	Insights from serving as an independent facilitator on behalf of the City of Morro Bay for an early community discussion about offshore wind opportunities.
(f)	Continued information gained from attendance at public discussions of the proposed sanctuary, offshore wind, and Diablo re-use opportunities. 

I underscore, however, that the following recommendations are entirely my own and do not represent the perspectives of any other persons or organizations identified above.

Recommendations for the Sanctuary

1.	Use the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.
a.	There are many scientific and management rationales that support continuity of marine ecosystems for optimal performance.
b.	Continuous sanctuary boundaries will enhance public understanding and ease in communication of sanctuary activities.
c.	Inclusion of Morro Bay and Estero Bay will provide important opportunities for interpretation and public participation in the sanctuary.
d.	While concerns about interfering with offshore wind or Diablo re-use are important, those can be addressed in other ways (see below). If developments in those projects don’t proceed, it’s important that the full sanctuary boundaries remain intact.

2.	Include in the designation a carve-out for offshore wind permits.
a.	Offshore wind offers many potential benefits for local communities, state, and national interests.
b.	The combination of BOEM and State regulatory authorities create extensive requirements for evaluation of potential impacts and opportunities for public comment to determine whether offshore wind is in the public interest.
c.	Adding uncharted sanctuary processes and approvals for offshore wind would create concerns for duplication of efforts. With the rise in interest rates and increase in supply chain costs, an unknown sanctuary review process for offshore wind would add a level of project risk that would delay, add unnecessary costs to ratepayers, or potentially scuttle what might otherwise be a desirable project to meet local, state, and federal objectives.

3.	Include in the designation a carve-out for Diablo use/re-use.
a.	There has been relatively little public discussion about any ramifications of sanctuary designation upon the use and re-use of the Diablo Canyon Power Plant property. 
b.	There are extensive regulatory processes already underway with public engagement opportunities regarding current and future uses of the property. 
c.	Since the impacts of Diablo activities are largely within California State-managed water, the sanctuary designation will be well-served to allow existing state and federal processes to proceed without adding uncertainty about potentially duplicative and complex involvement of a newly formed sanctuary.

I am pleased to continue to listen, learn, and share insights with others about these important issues.

Title: Comment from Marketos, Cassandra
Comment:
Hi Paul Michel,

I'm Cassandra Marketos, a community composter and certified Naturalist local to the Echo Park region of Los Angeles, CA, and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I previously worked in government, serving at the White House under Barack Obama, and focused on climate and conservation—working on the project to designate Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument, and I'm very familiar with and dedicated to the idea of "preserving our oceans" (as you can imagine!). Not only is protecting our oceans important for marine life and the ongoing health of our oceans and planet, it's essential for preserving HUMAN health and well-being. And we all know that we are running out of time to take these critical actions and try to reverse course on decades of climate abuse. 

I ask that this sanctuary includes:  

A ban on any oil & gas drilling. ANY. And funding for outreach, education, and research programs. It is wonderful to protect our oceans, but a critical part of ensuring these initiatives last (and can expand) is public education. 

Thank you for reading!

Sincerely, 
Cassandra Marketos

Title: Comment from Devlin, Trieste
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Trieste Devlin, and I support the swift designation of the CHNMS to protect ocean biodiversity and environmental justice. I support designating the largest possible contiguous boundaries, including the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension, as shown in the Draft Environmental Impact Statement. I support the sanctuary being named the "Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary", and for it to include Tribal Collective Management with equitable and inclusive representation of all Central Coast Tribes, facilitated by a qualified Tribal Liason.

I am from Moss Beach, and went to college in Santa Cruz, although I live in PA now. Growing up on the coastside, the beach and the ocean were cornerstones for community, recreation, exercise, and (for me) spirituality and a connection to nature. I watched the tidepools change as overfishing, pollution, and holes in the food web took their toll - the dyeback of the seastars, then years where the beach would stink with masses of dead seals and sea lions after algal blooms and overfishing caused them to starve, then the unbalanced surge in purple sea urchins, since we didn't have many otters left to eat them or sea stars to cover the rocks. These changes were visible even to me as a small child! They were scary, they hurt my soul, and as a kid I wondered why we weren't doing more to protect our oceans.

There is no one I would trust more to steward our California coastside than the native peoples of the land. In elementary school I learned about the coastal tribes in the past tense - as if they were gone and their connection to the land as family was over. I recognize that they are still here, and still fighting for their rights and for the continued health and safety of the ocean. I am SO grateful to native people all over the world who have protected so much land even as they continue to be disenfranchised, and specifically to the Chumash and other CA Tribes. It is important to me that there is funding for the Sanctuary to partner with local schools, so that kids can be educated about Tribal history and culture (especially those in underserved communities), marine biology, and land stewardship. 

I further ask that the Sanctuary includes:
- The protection of Rodriguez Seamount, as I understand reports have indicated it will serve an important role in protecting biodiversity in the region.
- Language drafted with the input of the CA Tribes to regulate Offshore Wind to ensure ocean safety
- A prohibition on oil and gas exploration/extraction within the Sanctuary, and policy intended to reduce overall pollution in the region

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures. I trust the CA Tribes and I believe in my heart that generations of Californians to come will truly benefit from as much of our coast as possible being protected.

Thank you to everyone working on this project.

Sincerely,

Trieste Devlin

Title: Comment from Wayman, Rick
Comment:
As a resident of the California Central Coast who spends time in the ocean every day, I bring a special passion for the conservation of our ocean areas. You have an incredible opportunity with the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to protect and preserve a meaningful swath of our ocean. I fully support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. To maximize the benefit of protecting ocean areas, a contiguous area makes the most sense. Therefore, I support the Initial Boundary Alternative plus sub-alternative 5b in order to provide such contiguous protection. 

The diverse, rich marine life that currently exists in this area deserves to be protected. With such protection in place, the ecosystem will have the ability to repair and restore itself in an uninterrupted way.

As someone who has been diving extensively in the Marine Protected Areas off of the Channel Islands, I know how robust and beautiful these pristine ecosystems can be if we let them. Designating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the aforementioned boundaries will not only bring great benefit to our local area, but will also serve as a model for others around the world to emulate.

I would like to add that, in principle, I support the development of offshore wind. I believe that offshore wind transmission lines can be accommodated at a later date through a special use permit. My immediate request is that this Sanctuary be approved to protect the environment from harmful activities like oil and gas drilling, dredging, and other disruptive and polluting actions.

Title: Comment from Cervantes, Avery
Comment:
My name is Avery Cervantes and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I was born and raised in Los Angeles, CA. My parents are from a coastal town in México, and they have taught me to love and respect the ocean. They nurtured a deep care for wildlife in me, and I have been lucky to find work in wildlife conservation. Protecting marine habitats and supporting the biodiversity present in our oceans means preserving human life and wildlife everywhere. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,
Avery Cervantes

It would be a shame to destroy this ecosysem in the name of green energy, especially wind energy, which will kill/maim the plethora of birds as well as whales and dolphins that richly inhabit the ocean environment. Title: Comment from Trujillo, Lauren
Comment:
To Whom it May Concern,

My name is Lauren Trujillo and I am a resident of Santa Barbara. I am writing in support of the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary!

I request that you please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries.This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.
Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.

Now is the time! We must protect this region now and into the future. 

Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Preheim, Grant
Comment:
Peace,

My name is Grant Preheim and I have been living in the central coast community my entire life. I strongly support the preservation and restoration of our marine wildlife. This especially means protecting the water entering our ocean and keeping our ocean as minimally polluted as possible. As an Electrical Engineering Technology student at Cuesta College, I have learned the immediate life threatening hazards that energy production will pose. As we have seen time and time again with oil drilling and recourse collection careless “mistakes” happen. How will wind energy production be any different? Electrical current creates a magnetic field that is harmful to all of us in the form of radiation. The amount of human activity along our coastline to build and set up a wind energy farm alone is destructive to our proposed sanctuary. A wind energy farm under any circumstances directly cause our waters to be radioactive. After years of studying electricity in Cuesta College’s state-of-the-art power laboratory, harvesting wind energy from our central coast is not a worthwhile plan for the longevity and health of anyone. All other protections for our coast described in the sanctuary proposition are necessary for our survival as living beings. Thank you for the opportunity. I am looking forward to seeing that this time of change will be great and not abused by the decision makers. 

-Grant Preheim

Title: Comment from Harness, Brooke
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Brooke Harness and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Visalia, California and the central coast is my beach. I want to protect the sea animals so that the people who were turned into sea animals (referencing the Chumash story of the Rainbow Bridge) are safe because I don’t want them to get hurt. I also want turtles and dolphins and orcas to be safe. We need to take out the trash in the water and keep the water clean to protect them and not throw any nets at them. We need to not do anything to hurt them. Except not sharks very much because I don’t like them. I want to have the marine sanctuary so that the little animals can all stay safe and be happy and feed them if we can. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes covering as much of the coast as possible by using the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension, that it should be called Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, that it should have Tribal Collaborative Management, that there should be educational programs to teach me and my family traditional ecological knowledge to better take care of our beautiful ocean, that it should be protected by the Rodriguez Seamount to protect the many different types of animal life that live there, and that new oil and gas development should not happen here.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures and gifts.
 
Sincerely,
Brooke Harness

Title: Comment from W, S
Comment:
I agree with proposed action to designate Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary 
CHNMS) in the waters along and offshore of the coast of central California to recognize the national significance of the area's ecological, historical, archaeological, and cultural resources and to manage this special place as part of the National Marine Sanctuary System.

Title: Comment from DICKASON, Tina
Comment:
I would like to preface my comments by saying how thrilled I am to know that the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is moving forward.  I have been following the unfolding of this possibility since its inception.

I am in support of NOAA's ORIGINAL Initial Boundary Alternative map. By so doing, the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would incorporate a contiguous area, beginning at the southern point of the Monterey Bay Marine Sanctuary, in the waters offshore of Cambria.  The proposed sanctuary, in my opinion, must begin at that point--from Cambria to Point Concepcion, incorporating 7,600 square miles. To choose any other map, not only greatly lessens the area for the sanctuary, but it also excludes a large area that Central Coastal Indigenous peoples lived in.  In honoring the Chumash, Salinan and all Indigenous peoples who deserve recognition in proclaiming this sanctuary, ALL areas of their habitation along the Central Coast must be included--to do otherwise, would dishonor the very people the proposed Sanctuary plans to recognize and honor. 
  
From NOAA's website, describing a marine sanctuary: "National marine sanctuaries are special areas that protect important marine ecosystems around the nation. Some sanctuaries are breeding and feeding grounds for endangered whales, others contain thriving coral reefs or kelp forests, and many are home to historic shipwrecks and other archaeological treasures."  Protecting a National Marine Sanctuary should not exclude 2,000 square miles from the proposed sanctuary, where no protections would be given -- in fact, just the opposite, to include the area from Cambria to Montana de Oro.  NOAA's description explains the reason for the exclusion of 2,000 square miles, thusly:  "Second, the preferred boundary excludes a wide area that could serve as a corridor for the industrial development associated with offshore wind energy production (specifically subsea electrical transmission cables and substations from the Morro Bay Wind Energy Area to shore), given that certain concentrations of this infrastructure may not be compatible with a national marine sanctuary depending on the number of cables and disturbance that could occur."  This would hardly seem to fit with the protections NOAA cites in the quote I referred to above, or in its Initial Boundary Alternative (Map #1), which would provide more protections.

I urge NOAA to reconsider the first map it initially selected: The Initial Boundary Alternative Map, and NOT the Agency Preferred Map.  Please maintain the integrity of your own words, the integrity of the ocean and the safety of the creatures who dwell within and who soar above.  May this Marine Sanctuary be given ALL the protections it deserves, honoring the Indigenous peoples who inhabited the lands along California's Central Coast and the ocean's precious ecosystem and marine habitat.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the historic significance of a Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, not only for the Central Coast of California, but for the entire nation. 

Respectfully, 
Tina Dickason
Cambria, CA
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from BLACK, MIMI
Comment:
I am a long time resident of Morro Bay, CA.  My family moved to Morro Bay in the '70's, attracted by it's natural beauty and majestic coastline.  I am in full support of establishing the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with it's Initial Boundary Alternative.  It has been well documented what harm off-shore wind farms can do to sea life and migrating whales.  Also, what is not mentioned, along with the implementation of a wind farm is the actual construction involved.  Which means that the harbor of Morro Bay, which is the home to sea otters, seals, and other marine wildlife, would be turned into an industrial port.  A place where locals, and visitors like to kayak and sail would be turned into an port where large ships and barges bring materials out for construction.  This would entail large scale dredging to accommodate larger ships, the loss of Coleman Beach to where a proposed large commercial dock would be constructed, and the absolute beauty of our harbor would be ravaged. Marine life would loose their natural habitats to this construction as well.
I firmly believe that the only sustainable, just, and equitable way forward for Morro Bay - and the surrounding Central Coast - is to establish the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative. It is time that we learn from past mistakes, listen to community leaders with generational knowledge, and fully commit to protecting the health of our marine ecosystems. There is inevitable loss and transformation that will unfold in Morro Bay as a result of climate change - we cannot undo the past, but we can fight for the future. I urge the NOAA to do everything in its power to protect heritage and biodiversity for generations to come."
