Title: Comment from Morro Bay Leaseholders (Golden State Wind LLC, Equinor Wind US LLC, Invenergy California Offshore LLC)
Organization Name: Morro Bay Leaseholders (Golden State Wind LLC, Equinor Wind US LLC, Invenergy California Offshore LLC)
Comment:
Equinor Wind US LLC, Golden State Wind LLC, and Invenergy California Offshore LLC (known as Even Keel Wind), Leaseholders of Lease Areas OCS-P 0563, OCS-P 0564, and OCS-P 0565 (together, the Leaseholders) in the Morro Bay Wind Energy Area, respectively, appreciate the opportunity to provide comment on the proposed designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS or Sanctuary) by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Office of National Marine Sanctuary (NOAA ONMS).  

The Leaseholders acknowledge the effort, time, and thoughtfulness of NOAA ONMS in development of the proposed CHNMS Draft Environmental Impact Statement, Draft Management Plan, and Notice of Proposed Rulemaking, which reflect the agency’s effort to balance multiple uses, stakeholder requests for conservation, and other considerations in the Central Coast of California.  

These comments represent our collective commitments to responsible offshore wind development, environmental stewardship, and as neighbors of the future CHNMS committed to fighting climate change, which is one of the most significant threats to the marine resources the CHNMS seeks to protect. We offer these recommendations as potential solutions that will support coexistence of the CHNMS and offshore wind in Central California.

Title: Comment from SeaWell LLC
Comment:
I am writing to express my concern for lack of consideration of future desalination projects in the definition of the Sanctuary.  Although I deeply respect the initiative behind CHNMS to preserve the ocean environment, I believe NOAA’s draft rules are shortsighted with respect to a potentially critical need to support water supply onshore.  As written in the current draft, all of the current State and Federal permitting safeguards would continue to be in place, as well as new regulations imposed by the Sanctuary as an overlaying jurisdiction; this extensive permitting hurdle will substantially reduce the odds the new desalination projects could be brought to bear to support basic water needs during extended drought.  

Meanwhile new offshore desalination technologies such as SeaWell’s continue to reduce impacts and improve energy efficiency, and promise to be among the least environmentally impactful means of obtaining freshwater of any system currently utilized, including the State Water Project.  Without compromising any existing permitting requirements, having desalination recognized as a potential future need would go a long way to enabling a path for permitting, which would still be subject to CEQA and NEPA, as well as the Coastal Commission’s Coastal Development Permit.

I URGE YOU TO PLEASE INCLUDE DESALINATION AS A RECOGNIZED, POTENTIAL ACTIVITY WITHIN THE CHNMS.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Lueker, Andrea
Comment: So I am pretty sure you don't pay any attention to these comments, that has been my experience with NOAA for the last 20 years, but just in case here is the story - The sanctuary should have never gotten this far as there was not widespread community support, but NOAA decided they would move the designation ahead anyway.  Now we have documentation that the Chumash Tribe that has spearheaded this through does not have any standing in the native american world and in fact are hispanic, not native american..... so will you make any changes?  This designation is not necessary and while I am sure that it won't matter at all about the comments against - you are doing the wrong thing!  While I am commenting as an individual, I am the former City Manger of Morro Bay and retired Harbor Manager of Port San Luis.

Title: Comment from Californians for Western Wilderness
Comment:
Dear Mr. Michel:

I am submitting comments from Californians for Western Wilderness (CalUWild), a citizens organization with nearly 900 members and supporters. We are dedicated to encouraging and facilitating participation in legislative and administrative actions affecting wilderness and other public lands in the West. Our members use and enjoy the public lands and coastal waters all over the West.

CalUWild appreciates this opportunity to comment on the Draft Environmental Impact Statement and Draft Management Plan for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, proposed by the Biden Administration and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), and nominated by the Northern Chumash Tribal Council.

First, and most importantly, we are in favor of this establishment wholeheartedly. Three significant reasons stand behind our support: 1) Protection of the ocean itself and the myriad forms of life that live in it and that it nourishes; 2) Protection of the coastline that forms the boundary, particularly from local oil spills; and 3) The opportunity it provides for the Chumash and Salinan Tribes to reclaim some of their traditional heritage through collaborative management and stewardship with NOAA.

CalUWild fully supports the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.” This name honors the Indigenous Tribes who have called the area home for many, many years and who nominated the Sanctuary.

To further that recognition, we support formalized structures of Tribal collaborative management with NOAA, allowing as many interested Tribes as practical to be full partners in the planning and stewardship of the Sanctuary’s resources. The management should include full use of traditional ecological knowledge and practices.

CalUWild supports the “Initial Boundary Alternative” with the addition of the Gaviota Coast Extension from Sub-Alternative 5-b. These boundaries would protect the largest area and the most biodiversity. The largest area also makes the largest contribution to the Administration’s goal of protecting 30% of America’s waters by 2030.

As part of this protection, we support a ban on all new oil & gas development, including exploration, with the Sanctuary’s boundaries. The risk of environmental damage from such activities is simply too high. (Additionally, we have a goal of reducing our consumption of petroleum products, so in theory we won’t need to be conducting so much exploration anyway.)

We support the inclusion of the Rodriguez Seamount. Its wonderful biodiversity requires its protection.

Finally, CalUWild supports NOAA’s proposed efforts to develop robust research educational programs, stressing both the best of “Western” science and traditional knowledge and history, with results made easily accessible to all who might be interested.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment. Please inform us of your decision in this matter and please also inform us of further opportunities to be involved in your public decision-making processes.


Respectfully submitted,
Michael J. Painter
Coordinator

Title: Comment from Committees for Land, Air, Water and Species (CLAWS)
Organization Name: Committees for Land, Air, Water and Species (CLAWS)
Comment:
I’m commenting as a native of this region, a local small business owner, a board member for the Gaviota Coast Conservancy and Board President of Committees for Land, Air, Water and Species, and Vice President of the Equity Advisory and Outreach Committee of the Central Coast Regional Climate Collaborative. Wearing all of those hats, I strongly support this marine sanctuary. Thoughtful planning and preparation has developed a dream into reality and we would be foolish not to protect this sacred and unique treasure of marine biodiversity. 

I applaud the planners, agencies, legislators, tribal leaders and policy makers who have prepared for this sanctuary. 

Thank you, 
Nancy Black
nancy@mercurypress.com
nancy.black@gaviotacoastconservancy.org

Title: Comment from Zelman, Alice
Comment:
I am a plant scientist, and citizen marine scientist, and I support immediately designating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover ~7,600 square miles of ocean, to protect biodiversity and marine and shore habitats.



I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary: 

I support the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.
While I don't have an indigenous background I support an equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.

I also think the protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity!
To protect the ecosystem and human health, there should be a prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I passionately believe the Administration should designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures. As a plant scientist and diver I am acutely aware of the importance of eelgrass to ecosystem health, and the benefits it provides. It needs to be protected.

Title: Comment from Harness, Lexy
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Lexy Alari Harness and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Visalia, California and the central coast is one of my favorite places. I’ve been going there with my family since I was a child and now I bring my daughters there whenever I can. It’s become a special and sacred place for me, even more so after finding out through DNA testing that my ancestors were indigenous to the California coast. The coast is in my blood. Every person deserves a clean ocean and to look out across the sea to the horizon without seeing oil rigs and pollution. I want this place and every life form lucky enough to be there to be protected; for myself, for my children, for my children’s children, and many more generations of Californians. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes covering as much of the coast as possible by using the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension, that it should be called Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, that it should have Tribal Collaborative Management, that there should be educational programs to teach me and my family traditional ecological knowledge to better take care of our beautiful ocean, that it should be protected by the Rodriguez Seamount to protect the many different types of animal life that live there, and that new oil and gas development should not happen here.
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures and gifts.
 
Sincerely,
Lexy Alari Harness

Title: Comment from Yang, Heidi
Comment: I agree with and advocate for the creation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The Indigenous peoples of California have been excluded from their own land and sea for too long; with climate change, resource extraction, and pollution threatening these essential marine ecosystems, the creation of this sanctuary is a huge step in the right direction for true Indigenous stewardship to nurture marine ecosystems. If the sanctuary is not approved, the health of the coasts and oceans that provide for all of us will continue to be threatened and significantly altered by the various anthropogenic threats they have been facing since the start of Spanish colonization in what is now California. Their plan is comprehensive and shows deep knowledge of and compassion for the local marine communities they aim to manage and conserve. I wholeheartedly support the formation of the Chumash National Heritage Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Sanchez, Lupita
Comment:
To whom it may concern,

I am writing to convey to you the support of the designation of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, the first tribal-lead designation effort in the history of the national marine sanctuary system. We know well the area, love it and need to protect it for future generations. 

Named after the local native American tribes, the new sanctuary would reflect the contribution of the coastal Chumash tribes and the First Nation to the health of the ocean. Indeed, their rich maritime heritage underscores the deep significance of the ocean to humanity. The ocean is a living part of their mythology, and they continue honoring their ancestors through a “pilgrimage” to the Island of Santa Cruz in their traditional redwood canoe (Tomol). The AC recognizes the value of diversity in stakeholders and values diverse stakeholder representation supporting this designation, in particular with regard to maritime and Native American heritage. In light of dramatic climactic and cultural shifts occurring now, there is an urgent need for tribal entities and federal agencies to take a cooperative stewardship role.
The CHNMS is designed to include the continental shelf as well as the escarpment rich with deep underwater canyons. It is influenced by the California Current and subjected to the yearly upwelling that yields some of the most productive waters on Earth. It provides a link between its three sister sanctuaries to the north (Monterey Bay, Greater Farallones, and Cordell Bank national marine sanctuaries) and the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary to the south, from Point Arena to Santa Barbara. Furthermore, it sets aside a stretch of ocean that would help science better assess the biological productivity of this system and enhance its understanding of ocean dynamics in the context of climate change.
By virtue of its designation as a sanctuary, CHNMS would be protected from oil and gas exploration as well as seafloor ocean mining, restrictions which would help protect local fisheries and the clean coast economy. Both of these industrial activities now pose an increased threat to the region. CHNMS would also be able to implement regulations against large ship discharges which has been identified as an environmental problem.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both indigenous Knowledge and indigenous science and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries!!!!

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures. This is an opportunity to make for the nation to be a leader in conservation projects that only protect our plant but also through partnerships with native peoples.

Sincerely,
Lupita Sanchez

Title: Comment from Wallace, Matt
Comment:
I’m writing in support of the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary off the central coast of California.

I am also asking that you designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b).  Doing this would provide contiguous protection between the Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries.

The proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.

Looking towards the future, offshore wind transmission cables could be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date.  In the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging (a huge possibility for Lithium Ion battery production), and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.

Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from O'Driscoll, Anna
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Anna O'Driscoll and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Cambria, California, and work as an environmental educator. I want to protect this stretch of ocean so my community can continue to connect with and benefit from a clean, safe, and healthy ocean. The ocean is beautiful and mysterious. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes the largest possible boundary, which is the initial boundary alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension. I ask that the sanctuary be named the "Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary," and that it include tribal collaborative management. The sanctuary should include components of outreach, education, and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities. The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity, and the sanctuary must include a prohibition on new oil and Gas development within the sanctuary boundaries. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

Anna O'Driscoll

Title: Comment from Lees, Dennis
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
My name is Dennis Lees, Littoral Ecological & Environmental Services, and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
I live in Encinitas, CA, and to me, the ocean has been, for all my adult life, a major focus of my professional and recreational activities.
I recently read the CalMatters report on the proposed wind farms off California and became particularly concerned about potential impacts of the proposed farm off Lompoc on infaunal resources in that area. I am an infaunal ecologist with a strong interest and expertise in the composition and secondary production of these sedimentary ecosystems. First, I know the infauna on that continental shelf off Lompoc/Vandenberg Space Force Base has been little studied, if at all, since the sparse collections (seven stations, in all) by Velero IV, Allan Hancock Foundation, U. S. C., in 1957. That lack of knowledge extends to most of the nearshore habitats within the boundaries of the entire proposed sanctuary.

Second, I suspect the assemblages on the shelf off Lompoc and Vandenberg are very productive, especially because of their location just north of Point Conception. It is highly likely they provide considerable nutrition to a variety of valuable commercial fisheries species, to sea otters, and possibly to migrating gray whales. 

Third, I know that methods currently used to sample those types of assemblage greatly underestimate the biomass and secondary production of those assemblages. Thus, they greatly undervalue them; this is the topic of my recently published paper and of a manuscript currently in a late stage of preparation. One reason these ecosystems are so poorly known is that current methods do not sample most of the "trees", i.e., the non-migratory megainfauna, which bury too deeply in the sediments (often more than a meter) to be sampled by conventional methodologies, which generally do not sample deeper than 10 cm into the sediment. They also are too uncommon, relatively, to be given consideration by the current cohort of numbers-fixated infaunal investigators, who do not consider biomass. The importance of the “trees” is based primarily on their much greater biomass and the contributions through predation to other trophic levels. Another reason they are so poorly known is there has been very little funding to study these rich productive habits, even in estuaries.

Fourth, a manuscript I am currently preparing, a follow-on to the earlier “weeds and trees” paper, demonstrates, with solid hard data, that current approaches (grab or box-core sampling) underestimate biomass by a factor of about 300, i.e., the biomass of the "trees" can be about 300 times that of the "weeds", or macrofauna, which is generally sampled by current inadequate sampling techniques. Based on analyses in my current manuscript, the "trees" likely conservatively contribute 30 times more energy to other trophic levels than the "weeds", excluding contributions of reproductive and excretory products.

Bottom lines: 1) The proposed areas for wind farms off Lompoc/Vandenberg and nearshore areas of the proposed sanctuary need to be carefully sampled to determine the nature of the overall infaunal ecosystems and how much energy these likely very rich assemblages contribute to associated trophic levels and fisheries.  The value of these assemblages must be determined. 2) This sampling cannot be accomplished by standard contemporary methods as these cannot sample the non-migratory megafauna adequately. These form the major basis for the benthic-related food webs for many important, some endangered, species that could be affected by installation and operation of the Lompoc/Vandenberg proposed wind farms and other activities that may take place in the sanctuary. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
•	Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
•	Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
•	Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
•	Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
•	Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
•	Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
 Sincerely,
Dennis Lees

Title: Comment from Merrill, Michelle
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Dr. Michelle Merrill. I'm the founder of an ecospiritual and ecoactivist organization called Novasutras. I live in Santa Clara, California. I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

To me, the ocean is sacred. In Novasutras, we believe that all life is connected and must be treated with reverence. Connecting with the ocean is essential for our spiritual well-being, and the coasts are vital spaces for reconnecting with community, human and more-than-human. 

I also have the deepest respect for the original people who cared for this coast, its lands and waters. As aware beings, we all have an obligation to care for our amazing, beautiful ocean planet.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes: 
The widest possible boundary, with the Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension, including the Rodriguez Seamount, and a ban on fossil fuel projects. Prohibition of new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries will best honor our responsibility to care for the lands and waters, to stabilize the climate, and to protect biodiversity, so that all ocean and coastal beings have a better chance to thrive.
The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” and Tribal Collaborative Management. An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management will best honor those original peoples who have cared for this coastal area and ocean for millennia. Outreach, education and research programs that elevate Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) are also required for respectful relationship.
Access for local underserved communities is another vital component of the sanctuary. Those who most need nature, yet are often least able to access it, should be a major focus of outreach and education.

I wholeheartedly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Dr. Michelle Merrill
Founder and Community Organizer
Novasutras

Title: Comment from Brown, Ellen
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Ellen Brown and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in San Diego, California and to me, the ocean is an essential habitat to protect. There is so much we’ve learned from it and much more to be learned. A sanctuary will be an important part of ocean research and education for present and future generations.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes all of these components:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Ellen Brown

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: I support the proposed Marine Sanctuary but am concerned about the proposed version (the Agency-Preferred Alternative that carves out an area from Cambria to south of Morro Bay. It is indicated that this version would carve out an area right between two sanctuaries to allow for a wind farm or other offshore developments in that carved out area. It seems excluding those areas from the sanctuary would negatively impact marine life as well as coastal communities in those carved out areas. It is indicated that the "preferred Alternative," while allowing offshore development, nonetheless would "limit adverse impacts on offshore wind development and would lessen adverse impacts on marine transportation compared to the Initial Boundary Alternative analyzed in the draft EIS." It is not specified in detail how it would do so, but I would support an alternative that does not negatively impact marine life or the shoreline, noise, and ocean view in and around Cambria.

Title: Comment from Hutchins, Venessa
Comment:
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection. Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters. Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

In addition to the above comments of support, on a more personal level, I support the designation of the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary because just in the short 35 years of my life, I have seen a dramatic decline in the amount of open space and pristine environments, as well as a marked decline in the number of animals I see in the wild. I am so appalled at how quickly we are destroying our planet. Nature does tend to be resilient but if we keep going as we are, we will hit a threshold that will lead to our demise and to irreversible damage to the planet as we know it. Species come and go, but through more natural causes. We are wreaking havoc with so little regard for the consequences. Please, take this one step in the right direction, towards environmental stewardship and the protection of our planet. This sanctuary will mean more legal protection, less damaging activities to ecosystems, and preservation of cultural resources.

Title: Comment from Friends of the Earth US
Comment:
Please find the attached 41,094 from Friends of the Earth members and activists. 

I am writing to support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. The designation of the CHNMS should include the largest possible contiguous boundaries, the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alt 5b), because it would provide the most protection to this important area. We do not support NOAA’s Alternatives 2, 3, and 4 because they would not protect a critical area of coastline that contains important Chumash cultural sites, marine habitat, and local communities. First, please support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary name. It is meant to recognize people who have lived on this coast for over 10,000 years; protect the heritage of the Chumash, an ocean-going band among the First People of the Pacific Coast; and provide a timely and appropriate reminder of the cultural origins. We support equitable inclusion of all Central Coast Tribes, both federally and non-federally recognized Tribes, in collaborative management. All sanctuary stakeholders will benefit from Indigenous input.  It is vital that Sanctuary education and community outreach partner with area schools to share information about sanctuary species and habitats and Chumash history and culture. Outreach should be multilingual, culturally relevant, and should focus on underserved communities. In addition, regulations to protect Rodriguez Seamount should move forward. The seamount provides critical habitat for an extremely diverse and abundant array of marine life and deserves to be granted strong and permanent protection. The seamount has special national significance that warrants special protections through sanctuary designation. Once damaged, fragile seamount ecosystems may not recover in our lifetime. The proposed CHNMS will protect our beloved ocean now that Offshore Wind (OSW) farms are being established off the Central California Coast. Sanctuary designation is needed before OSW and other environmental impacts affect the habitat, wildlife, and water quality. California’s first offshore wind projects must reflect leasing, siting, and permitting decisions that are guided by planning and comprehensive scientific research on the potential impacts to sensitive marine areas and species and coastal resources, including cumulative impacts. I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Michele Whiteaker. I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I grew up in Santa Barbara and Ventura, California. My entire childhood was spent on boats in the Pacific Ocean off Santa Barbara and Ventura. My family cruised on our sailboat and later powerboat to the anchorages of Santa Cruz Island. I learned about the Chumash: at Vieja Valley Elementary School, reading Island of the Blue Dolphins in 3rd grade (and imagining myself as the main character when we were out at the islands), on visits to the Santa Barbara Natural History Museum, and at 6th grade environmental education camp at Lake Cachuma. My schooling did a great job of weaving what's now known and promoted as TEK (traditional environmental knowledge) to the point where I felt -- and still feel -- a true connection to the environment around me and appreciated the stewardship of the Chumash people.

I'm a 1990 graduate of Ventura High School. My parents still live in Ventura County. I am just a few hours away in Laguna Hills, CA. When I go to the coast, I am sad that the tidepools of my youth are not in existence anymore. In my 50 year lifetime, I've noticed the sea creatures dwindle as the population and demands on the fragile ocean ecosystem increase. I think the MPAs and designations such as this are the only way to preserve what we have and it's honestly my only hope that we can turn things around - by turning towards the original stewardship which protected it and made it thrive.

I want my kids and future grandkids to be able to be drawn to the ocean like I have been. To find peace here and connection that I can't find anywhere else. I work hard in my community of Orange County promoting play and empowering OC families to prioritize outside time. If I still lived in Santa Barbara or Ventura, the waters off the coast would be a big part of that.

The ocean is a sanctuary to so many living things. I've chronicled a central coast summer which I call the "Summer of Humpbacks" where we watched the whales feeding from the pier at San Simeon and the bluffs of Cambria. I want this to not be a fleeting thing. I want more generations to experience these natural wonders. 

I emphatically support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:

Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”.
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities (like the kind I got throughout my childhood, but for ALL).
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity.
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries. This is KEY!

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Thank you for your time and I hope you consider this letter as a very personal plea,
Michele Whiteaker

Title: Comment from Cohen, Michael
Organization Name: Chairman - Port San Luis Commercial Fisherman's Association and the Whale Working Group
Comment:
To whom this may concern:

I have worked as a commercial fishermen for over several decades. I am a chairman on the Port San Luis Commercial Fisherman's Association and the Whale Working Group. I am writing to express my complete opposition to the proposed sanctuary. The CHNMS poses a significant threat to the future of fishermen culture and it will disrupt the current delicate balance between man and the ocean in the area identified for CHNMS creations.  Despite claims, existing marine protected sanctuaries show no scientifically proven benefits to the ocean. The scope of the management plan declares policies of protection already in place by the current conservation regulation and enforced by CDFW/ PFMC. This is a waste of government resources. Further the general public and cultural organizations such as the PSLCFA  repeatedly opposed the formation of sanctuaries within this area multiple times but NOAA keeps changing the sanctuary name and reproposong it. Lastly, the neo-indigenous Chumash are being used as a politic pawn, a poster child of for a political agenda. This concludes my reasoning for rejecting the CHNMS. Thank you for your time and consideration!

Warm regards,
Michael Cohen
Captainmikec@gmail.com

Title: Comment from briggs, shaunie
Organization Name: Member - The Salinan Tribe of Monterey and San Luis Obispo Counties
Comment:
I am a member of The Salinan Tribe of Monterey and San Luis Obispo Counties, an Indigenous community deeply connected to the land and ocean encompassing the proposed National Marine Sanctuary (Sanctuary). This region represents our ancestral homeland, which includes the area under consideration for the new national marine sanctuary. While I acknowledge the historical presence of the Chumash in this land, it's crucial to recognize that The Salinan name should not be omitted in this context.

Various groups without clear tribal affiliations have attempted to establish cultural boundaries based on landmarks such as Morro Rock, Diablo Canyon, and Point Conception. It's worth noting that the United States only began surveying and defining territorial rights during European exploration in the 1700s, and this concept was not applied to California until it became a state in 1850. The ongoing division of indigenous cultures through territorial lines is inaccurate and misleading.

1. I wholeheartedly endorse the creation of a new national sanctuary along the Central Coast of California and fully support the approval of the Initial Boundary Alternative as the ultimate boundary for this sanctuary.

2. I vehemently oppose any reduction in the protected area from the originally proposed sanctuary boundary, as outlined in the Initial Boundary Alternative.

3. The sanctuary's name should follow established practice, using geographical features as a basis, just as previously established sanctuaries have been named.

4. I suggest that NOAA (National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration) establish a collaborative relationship with the California Native American Heritage Commission to develop a process ensuring that tribal representatives participating in the sanctuary management process have a validated ancestral and cultural affiliation with the Central Coast.

5. I recommend that NOAA extend the same advisory capacity and input opportunities to non-federally recognized tribes as they do to federally recognized tribes. Additionally, culturally affiliated tribes should be appropriately represented on the advisory council.

6. I propose that the primary designated consultation entities for any matters related to this sanctuary be the Salinan and Chumash people.

I sincerely appreciate your attention to our concerns and issues.

Title: Comment from Cyra, Tom
Comment:
I support the establishment of the national marine sanctuary utilizing the initial or alternative 1 boundaries, along with the subunits 5a and 5b.

The concern over the disturbance due to undersea cables from offshore wind facilities can be moderated and  better controlled through the use of the permitting process under the NMS designation, as is already done elsewhere (and the exemptions granted to DoD make these cables a minor distubance). This also  creates protections for the area in general, which would not happen if excluded.

The name dispute is unfortunate. I'd suggest a combined name, and if that is not acceptable then something culturally significant but with neither tribal name included.
A footnote states that the Monterey  Bay sanctuary could at some point be extended. If the preferred alternative is chosen, I would hope it would be with the stated NOAA goal of completing this addition in the near-term,  with the boundary adjoining this one.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Throughout humanity’s time, we have attempted to better our living standard and its connected issues. Towards this objective, we have made countless sacrifices, sometimes at the expense of nature. We have abandoned a sustainable balance with the one from which we came, which we owe our very existence to. Now we seek to correct wrongs and make amends by again tarnishing and interfering with the fragile tapestry of nature. The NOAA revised area of the Chumash heritage National Marine Sanctuary, has done just this. It has excluded, area around and in Morro bay which it has leased to Trident Winds and TotalEnergies Renewables USA. They seek to alter the landscape dramatically, transforming miles of wild ocean into forests of metal trunks and canopies of aluminum blades. Supporters of this Castle Wind project, argue that it provides high-paying job opportunities and satisfies the states requirements toward Net Zero carbon. While all of this is true, it establishes the precedent for further exploitation and commercialization of the open oceans, which could have disastrous consequences similar to the establishment of offshore oil rigs. Perhaps this is an unstoppable force, yet arguing against every decision could potentially save one mile from pollution and allows the sea otters, kelp, and fishes to flourish is a victory. As a cautionary note, the Brazilian government has permitted portions of the mighty Amazon rainforest to be destroyed for the soy meal which feeds their large beef industry. I view this dispute as a microcosm of that, the effect of which could determine the landscape and ecosystem for hundreds if not thousands of years. Something which could be amplified in further contracts and development, under the raised banner of a better future. Again we arrive at the question I posed at the beginning, do we open the floodgates and allow our precious reservoir to be drained and continue our lives as usual or do we release only small amounts of water and improve our water catchment systems. My preference is the latter. Alas, if we chose the former, I seek to build a bulwark of the preservation of the marine ecosystem. To be a breakwater for the imminent flood of humanity’s wealth and influence flowing into the deep sea which will be surely brought by this ruling.

Thank you for considering this perspective.

Title: Comment from Amaroli, Thomas

National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration,

I wish to express support for either the Initial Boundary Alternative or Alternative 1 –“Bank to Coast” for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  I do not favor an alternative the excludes Morro Bay from the sanctuary.

As a lifelong Californian, and a one-time resident of San Luis Obispo County, the fact that the Pacific Ocean has remained free from the desecration of wind farms and offshore drilling, thus far, fills me with gratitude.

For future generations we should ensure that the Central Coast of California remains henceforward and forever free of such desecration.  Declaring the area of Morro Bay a national marine sanctuary would go far to ensure that protection.

I also see advantages to Alternatives 5a – Morro Bay Estuary protection, and 5b – Gaviota Coastal Extension, and I support those additional protections.

Please select one of the alternatives that protects Morro Bay as part of the marine sanctuary.  Thank you for your good work.

Thomas Amaroli

Title: Comment from San Luis Obispo Coastkeeper at Environment in the Public Interest
Organization Name: San Luis Obispo Coastkeeper at Environment in the Public Interest
Comment:
San Luis Obispo Coastkeeper supports the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary!

Nominated by the Northern Chumash Tribal Council in 2015, the proposed sanctuary stretches along 134 miles of coastline from Montaña de Oro State Park in San Luis Obispo County to Naples, along the Gaviota Coast in Santa Barbara County and encompasses nearly 6,000 square miles of water. The federal government is proposing this area for permanent protection as a sanctuary to preserve its rich marine ecosystem - a biological hotspot for sea birds, marine mammals including migratory whales, sea turtles, and other marine life - important offshore features like the Rodriguez Seamount and Santa Lucia Bank, and cultural resources and connections of Indigenous communities to the area.

Please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.

Potential offshore wind transmission cable corridors can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, permanently protecting the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.
    
Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

Gordon Hensley, San Luis Obispo Coastkeeper at Environment in the Public Interest

Title: Comment from Ricard, Jean-Michel
Comment:
Good afternoon,

I am writing as a concerned citizen of Santa Barbara County in regard to the apparent exclusion of Morro Bay and Morro Rock from the proposed boundaries of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I am very much in favor of the cultural, educational, and environmental benefits to be derived from co-managing this sanctuary with Chumash nations, so the exclusion of that sacred area undermines the full potential of the sanctuary. Since there is no proposed prohibition on fishing rights within the sanctuary, I cannot see any reasonable objection to linking up the proposed sanctuary with the pre-existing Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary. Certainly it may complicate the permitting process for the cabling necessary to enable offshore wind development, but it by no means prohibits it. I fully believe that enhanced protections for our natural and cultural treasures is fully worth the added difficulty to the permitting process. What's more, I agree on principal that Chumash and other concerned Indigenous peoples should have the right to weigh in on developments in their homelands. Bringing in these stakeholders would be a positive development for democracy and promoting reconciliation with Indigenous Californian nations, who are an indispensable part of our state's social fabric. In sum, I entreat you to include the areas of Morro Bay and Morro Rock in the proposed sanctuary; it is a winning proposition for all parties.

Sincerely,
Jean-Michel Ricard

Title: Comment from Castello, Erica
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Erica Castello and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.


My name is Erica Castello. I live in Nipomo, California. I recognize and hold sacred the great and non-negotiable vitality of the ocean, whose well-being is the centerpiece of our survival as a species.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:



Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension
Sanctuary Name: The name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”
Tribal Collaborative Management: An equitable approach to include all Tribes in Collaborative Management.
Outreach & Education: Outreach, education and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount is essential to protect biodiversity
Ban Oil & Gas: A prohibition on new oil and Gas development within sanctuary boundaries


I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Con respeto,
Erica M. Castello

Title: Comment from Kennel, Ted
Comment:
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration,

We have only one California marine environment and we need to protect as much of it as possible.  Regardless of the benefits of offshore wind farms, the Pacific Ocean offshore from our Golden State is not the place for them.

Therefore, regarding the creation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, I support either the Initial Boundary Alternative or Alternative 1 – “Bank to Coast”.  Morro Bay must be included within the boundaries of the Sanctuary.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Sincerely, 
Ted Kennel

Title: Comment from Corley, Leo
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel, 

My name is Leo Corley and I am reaching out to you to express my support of the true and complete designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover approx. 7600 sq. miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity, including people, and habitats.  
      I live in Paso Robles, Ca and I grew up here.  My family is a part of the original Californianos and we have always had a presence here along this sacred stretch of coast, from Santa Barbara and continuing up the Hwy coast towards Monterey.  My dad is the founder of the Black Surfing Association, learned to surf in Cayucos with Morro Bay being his home break.  The ocean means everything to our family and so does our relationship with other indigenous people.  These are the things our lives are built around.  
	I grew up around the ocean and the ocean is a sanctuary to our family and for many.  We have enjoyed and treasured our wild coastline and I wish to see that protected.  The issue I see with many modern environmental movements is the exclusion of the indigenous people as a part of the native flora and fauna and part of what needs to be protected and acknowledged when considering the environment.  I urge you to respect and honor the leadership and vision of the indigenous people of this land and coastline and to prioritize this over prospects for development.  Morro Bay, Lisamu’, is the heart of the people and this designation proposal and must be included in the sanctuary designation as well as Cayucos and Cambria. Furthermore, it seems like the environmental impacts of creating a giant wind farm off the coast of Morro Bay are unknown which also feels very negligent and irresponsible as well as disrespect to the local indigenous tribes and people who believed the sanctuary designation would have also protected these waters, coast and ecosystems.  
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.  I insist that it includes the following:  The Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension, the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”, there must be Tribal Collaborative Management using an equitable approach and respect and reverence to the Indigenous people of this land and coast, Education, outreach and access centering Traditional Ecological Knowledge and access for local marginalized communities, the protection of the Rodriguez Seamount and a permanent ban on new oil and gas development. 
	Please honor the Chumash People and the work they have put into creating the marine sanctuary designation and those who see and support their vision of the benefit of all of us including the non-human life the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would protect.  This coast needs to be protected from development.  I urge the Administration to designate the CHNMS for the safety and future of all who originated here, those here and those who are yet to come.
Sincerely, Leo Corley

Ps. My Mother and Father will send there letters postmarked for today. They are not people of the internet. Please keep an eye on your mailbox and consider and include their comments as well. Thank you

Title: Comment from Bushman, Jennifer
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Jennifer Bushman and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats. I am a board member for the Marine Mammal Center and the founder of Fed by Blue. An organization that believes in the importance of foods from water that are responsibly caught or raised. At the core, we believe that an MPA, overseen by the Chumash Tribe is not only important to our state but as an urgently needed example of the role that Indigenous communities can play in ocean conservation. Left alone, with the oversight of the tribe, this designation will the result in abundance that will eventually spill over into unprotected zones, stocking new areas with fish that can be harvested for human consumption. There are many opportunity zones already designated along our California coastline. The trust, the education opportunities and the impact that this will designation create is tremendous. 

I have worked closely with Michael Rubino is the Senior Advisor for Seafood Strategy  and Dr. Paul Doremus, Former Deputy Assistant Administrator of Operations for NOAA.  We have developed many discussions that align the conservation community, the fish and seafood community and the role that our waters play in contribution to our food system. There is no doubt that the trust and stewardship that this group will bring is vitally needed. There are other distinct regions where wind energy can be developed. Places where we can align ocean protection with ocean production. But this is not the place nor the time.  

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. 

 

Sincerely,

Jennifer Bushman

Title: Comment from Chong, Kristi
Comment: I recently visited Morro Bay and Montana de Oro State park for the first time this summer and was instantly captivated. I live in Los Angeles, and while I frequent the beach, the beaches in this area were vastly different. It was cleaner, much more free of trash/litter. I instantly felt my blood pressure dropping as I took in landscape and the views of marine life. I came back to the are in late Sept and hiked the Point Buchon trail in the state park, and my goodness the views are amazing. This area and all the way down the coast needs to be protected. I've seen way too many LA beaches become dirty from the effects of civilization. This area is more pristine and untouched and you can tell the different. It should be protected.

Title: Comment from Sanders, Mary
Comment:
I am writing in support of the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the largest proposed parameters as originally envisioned:  from Cambria extending down into Gaviota and into the deep sea preserving critical seamounts.  I am a lifelong Californian having lived in Southern California for over 20 years, then on the coast of southern and central California for close to 50 years.  My family lived in Santa Barbara for 35 years and we are currently residents of Cambria, California. It is our most cherished place on the planet, the place that we call home.  Our neighbors are magnificently more than human, and beyond wondrous and unexpected! Otters, elephant seals, condors, whales, kelp beds…marine and birdlife, migrators in air and water and land, constant residents of forest or meadow or tidelands, beaches, deep sea. All are cherished!

My engagement with the coast is deep and eternal.  My background is as a choreographer, dance ethnologist (ethnochoreologist), and artist/educator.  I am an advocate and activist for wildlife, and support with all of my being the Rights of Nature. (I am a member of GARN, the Global Alliance for the Rights of Nature which recognizes the intrinsic rights of Nature.)  In the arts I am a site specific choreographer and an environmental choreographer.  This means that my career has centered on exploring the natural coastline and environs, observing and connecting in a spiritual and respectful way with the sentient beings that we share this paradise with, performing in and for Nature while developing creative, sensitized multi-generational and cross cultural community.  In passionately adopting this life’s work, I continue to spend a great deal of time in Nature, as an observer, experiencer, and storyteller.  It is my life’s blood.  Not only do I bring professional dancers into Nature, but I introduce children, their families, and those new to artistic expression or natural environment into an immersion with the Extraordinary that is all around them. 
As a Dance Ethnologist I value deepfelt respect for place memory, and sacred space, and life-affirming, compassion- driven rituals and ceremonies. Our Earth desperately needs to regenerate this reverence, this healing! This world view continually reconnects and transforms a community’s connection to the rest of the natural world…all that is seen and unseen.  I support the protection of indigenous sacred space, input, and education to underserved/under-represented communities.  From our earliest childhood we should all be immersed in a reverence for the natural environment, so that we will protect it until the end of time.

The community of Cambria, in San Luis Obispo County,  is considered to be a “Blue Zone” where people live healthy lives due to outdoor engagement, the healing quality of Nature and other restorative practices.  This area is also a place that is working towards a Green way of life.  When you meet someone out for a walk, they look at the ocean or sunset and say that this is why they live here (without most of the conveniences of a city.). Residents feel that it is unfortunate if they miss the sunset on the ocean at the end of the day.  We socialize during walks on the bluffs by the ocean, and connect with our neighbors there.
Cambria is also trying to be certified as a Dark Skies community, which has significant impacts on wildlife and all of the natural processes that requires the dark night!  Imagine seeing and celebrating the starry night and constellations.  Imagine Quiet!  I hope that we attain that rare certification.

The Windfarm off the coast and the shrinking of the parameters of the Chumash Marine Sanctuary are at odds with what is most precious and extraordinary about this place.  The infrastructure required of these windfarms will industrialize this coast.  The wind farm itself will have unbearable consequences for sensitive wildlife who are much more sensitive than humans to their surroundings and impacts.  The construction periods, the anchoring to the seafloor , the pipes from sea to land, the cacophony of workers, the effect of piers and human activity, the maintenance…all with good intentions for clean energy will decimate paradise.  If I can hear Space X launches in Vandenberg rattling and shaking my Cambria home, how is the sensitive Marine Life not affected? What about earthquakes off the coast, Tsunami activity?
Marine mammals, marine life, seabirds come to this area for its cooler waters in the midst of climate crisis,  They need sanctuary!!!  Humans also need a place to restore and heal. Visitors need places they can come to in order to see what harmony with the natural environment could look and feel like…so that their own places of residence and communities might also be restored. Let our relationship to Harmony and life-giving co-existence with the rest of Nature not be reduced to nostalgia.Let it be our living legacy to this planet.

Title: Comment from Abbott, Grace
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

My name is Grace Abbott and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I live in Goleta, California, and I grew up in Freeport, Maine. I've always had a deep connection to the ocean. Spending any time on or near the sea is healing and reinvigorating. Submerging myself in the ocean is incredibly powerful for when I'm facing personal struggles—it's an incredibly spiritual experience that reminds me that I am not separate from the ocean and all that she holds. I'm so grateful to the sea and all its beings. I grew up eating from the ocean. My favorite tradition is gathering Quohogs where my dad grew up on Waquoit Bay, Massachusetts. This is a small part of my personal history, yet Chumash communities have been tending these waters for thousands of years. Many have been torn away from their traditional lifeways and reciprocal relations with ocean entities. However, many are still practicing and reclaiming these traditions. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary include the largest possible contiguous boundaries, as seen in the Initial Boundary Alternative combined with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alternative 5b). I don't support NOAA’s Alternatives 2, 3, and 4, because they reduce the size and protection of the sanctuary by some 2,000 square miles. This would eliminate connectivity
with the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary, leaving out important cultural sites, including Morro Rock/Lisamu’, and removing critical protections for marine habitat and species, including the threatened Southern sea otters.

I also support the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary” to recognize the people who've lived on this coast since time immemorial; protect the heritage of the Chumash people, an ocean-going band among the First People of the Pacific Coast; recognize people who have been denied recognition in so many other ways; and honor the late Chief Fred Collin’s nomination and vision for the Sanctuary and the 10 years of work that the Northern Chumash Tribal Council did to campaign for the Sanctuary.


I support equitable collaborative management that includes all local Tribal groups who would like to be involved, and Indigenous peoples who are not tribally-affiliated. I support the creation of a Tribal Sanctuary Advisory Council made up of all interested local Tribal groups and Indigenous peoples, as well as a NOAA Tribal Liaison.

I support the largest proposed boundary, the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alternative 5b), to ensure a contiguous buffer of ocean protection while directing offshore Wind development to more suitable areas further offshore where wind energy is optimal
and ecological and cultural impacts can be reduced. The sanctuary will also allow for robust monitoring and research needed to understand the long-term impacts of Offshore Wind. Any offshore Wind transmission cables proposed for this area as part of future offshore wind development should require permits from the National Marine Sanctuary Program to ensure that they are planned and sited in a thoughtful, consolidated manner to reduce and mitigate impacts to the ocean. We ask for meaningful and long-lasting collaboration with conservation and marine protection.

I oppose the proposed projects off of Vandenberg based on serious environmental, cultural, and permitting-process issues. The projects are irresponsibly sited too close to the shore, in a uniquely biodiverse location, with highly significant fisheries and unacceptable impacts on critical cultural sites.

I support Sanctuary water quality programs and regulations that reduce pollution, by preventing harmful discharges and excessive runoff of sediments, oils, nutrients, pesticides, and pathogens.

I support multilingual and multicultural education and outreach for the Sanctuary that centers engagement with local underserved communities. Support partnering with Tribal and community groups, local area schools, and educators to share information about local marine science, conservation, and Chumash history and culture.

I support strong and permanent regulations to protect the Rodriguez Seamount because it provides a critical habitat for an extremely diverse and abundant array of marine life.

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

 

Sincerely,

Grace Abbott

Title: Comment from Yanagihara, Wendy
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
As a lifelong resident of California’s central coast, I strongly support the designation of the new Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary as proposed by the Northern Chumash Tribal Council and submitted to NOAA in 2015. 

I was born and raised in Carpinteria, California and returned to live here 20 years later as local who has traveled the world and now appreciates more fully the biodiversity and fragility of the marine ecosystem, as well as the rich cultural and historical heritage of the ocean-going Chumash People. 

As a child, I grew up boogie-boarding, tide-pooling, dolphin-spotting, and swimming at Santa Barbara County beaches. As an adult, I now paddle offshore and have encountered incredible marine life, ranging from juvenile white sharks to dolphins to rays. I now understand more deeply the biological richness of our kelp forests, reef systems, and ocean currents. 

Not only does our community depend on the ocean for food, recreation, well-being, and a thriving tourism economy, but we also bear the responsibility to steward our local waters for the greater global good. Establishing the sanctuary will facilitate the health of the marine environment, scientific research, and the maritime culture of the Chumash People. 

For these reasons, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary encompasses the most extensive possible boundary; that it be named the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to honor the local First People; that the Chumash Nation be fundamental to the sanctuary’s collaborative management; and that any new oil and gas development be banned within the sanctuary’s boundaries. 

I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our spectacular ocean heritage.
 
Thank you very much.

Title: Comment from Zeiss, Katherine
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
Thank you for agreeing to receive and review comments on the pending decisions regarding the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. This is an issue that I’ve been following for at least one year. I’ve reviewed the documents on your website that relate with this. 

I myself of an avid ocean swimmer, and beach walker,  and have lived both in Santa Barbara county, and in San Luis Obispo County, swimming at various points along the Morro Bay coast, including the Strand, and Montana De Oro . Morro Bay itself is a very unique ecosystem unparalleled along our coast line.  There I have kayaked and painted some of the natural beauty. Additionally the Santa Barbara channel, connecting with our coast line and Channel Islands, holds its own value in preserving ecosystems for so many marine creatures including our migratory whale and bird populations. 

It is of supreme value to me that not only our generation, but the generations to follow, will be able to rely on the fertility of our coastal waters, and know that they are protected for posterity from historically harmful impacts of over-commercialization, waste and chemical dumping, drilling, and over-fishing. 

I am writing to express my individual views on the importance of acting now to protect and preserve, not only the cultural value of our coast in respect of the Chumash peoples’ heritage, but also protecting the variety of the marine life species which depend on these coastal regions.

I encourage you to utilize the opportunity we have before us now to link this Marine sanctuary to the Goleta  area, to extend the protection to the widest area possible. I also request you to regulate applications for transmission of generated energy, from wind turbines, via special use permit, which will allow specific review of impact, thus assuring that the water quality, marine mammal habitats, and added technology would be held in harmony. We cannot afford any more of our precious Natural world‘s balance to be permanently disrupted; your responsive actions are critical now to avoid  later wish that we had taken greater care. This is the time when we can designate a valuable and significant protection which will have a lasting positive affect, while still allowing for human needs to be met sustainably. 

Thank you for considering the health of our Oceans, recognizing that our  health is intimately intertwined with that of the ocean. This knowledge has been embraced by the Chumash people even us it is felt, known and respected by people of all heritages. Please act no to extend them Marine sanctuary to the widest possible length and breadth. Thank you.

Title: Comment from Piatti, Robert
Organization Name: Member - Salinan Tribe of Monterey & San Luis Obispo Counties Council (Cultural Protection & Preservation Lead)
Comment:
Oct. 1, 2023

I’d like to submit my public comment for inclusion into the discussion about a proposed marine sanctuary off the coast of Central California.

While initially I was hesitant to support a marine sanctuary in the Morro Bay region, I’ve come to see it as a positive, to possibly help establish some localized control over what uses this area may serve.  It is our traditional fishing zone, and home to many important species and habitats.

To attempt to name the sanctuary after one cultural of indigenous people, the Chumash, without including the other primary indigenous culture, the people now know as Salinans, is not only a serious act of disrespect, it is actually a direct effort to make a claim on a territory by a splinter group of a non-profit organization that doesn’t hold any proven cultural affiliation to the pre-contact territory..

The original peoples of this coast didn’t identify themselves by today’s cultural names.  They didn’t own the land, but belonged to it, and associated with others who shared the ability to communicate through shared languages.  Living in smaller family groups, or tribelets, rather than villages, the three groups of different Salinan people  known today as the Antonio, the Migeulino, and the coastal Playano  lived for thousand of years and hundreds of generations, off the resources that were abundant and varies.  The greater Pacific Ocean was and remains a primary source of existence for these people, and we honor our ancestors by remaining its active children.  We belong to this land, this coast, this ocean, and ask that if a marine sanctuary is installed with the intent of protecting this region, that it is named so as to not disrespect the original people that still belong to it, and is managed in partnership to see that it serves the purpose on which it is established.

Sincerely,
Robert Piatti
Salinan Tribe of Monterey & San Luis Obispo Counties Council Member
Cultural Protection & Preservation Lead

Title: Comment from Woodman, Lorraine
Comment:
I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, an important step in protecting the valuable cultural and environmental resources of our Central Coast.

I think it is important to designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries.
This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.
Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.
Thank you for considering these comments.

Title: Comment from Leavitt, Camden
Comment: My name is Camden Leavitt. I have lived near the Pacific Coast for my entire life and regard it as my true “second home.” The ocean and all the physical features and creatures that line within and around are truly the life blooms of the planet and by extension us as a species. We, the planet, our ocean are at a precipice in time. If we are to continue onward into a safe and sustainable future, we must take action now and we must take as strong and extreme actions as we can possibly make. That is why I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the full Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension. This will cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean and will be invaluable to the protection of biodiversity and both aquatic and terrestrial habitats. I implore you to approve this sanctuary with the largest possible boundaries, to approve the name “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary,” to approve the equitable approach that directly involves Tribal Management, to approve outreach and ediactaional programs and opportunities about the CHNMS particularly for underserved and low-income communities, to approve the protection of the Rodriguez Seamount, and to BAN any oil, gas, or other related drilling construction/development projects from EVER being allowed to take place within the sanctuary’s borders. I implore you to be on the right side of history, for if we do not act now and act correctly, we will have no future to live in and no history to reflect upon. Thank you.

Title: Comment from Miller, Vita
Comment: I am writing today in addition to having signed at least two petitions to support the designation of the Chumash Heritage Marine Sanctuary as originally proposed. I am in support of a collaborative joint management for ocean protection. The Chumash and other private and non-profit organizations should all have a voice in the protection of this immense resource on the Central Coast of California. We must do all we can to thwart the rapidly advancing effects of climate change and the establishment of a marine sanctuary is just one avenue to that end. This proposed sanctuary is a unique method to protect this rich marine environment home to diverse ecosystems and abundant wildlife including the beloved marine mammals that make the estuary located in Morro Bay their home. I am urging and encouraging you to include the entire coastline as originally proposed from the Channel Islands Marine Sanctuary to the south and the Monterey Bay Marine Sanctuary to the north. It makes no sense to exclude a huge amount of coastline from Morro Bay to Cambria and expect his sanctuary to fulfill the expected advantages proposed. That vast amount of coastline must be kept safe from oil drilling and other means to bring polluting industries to the area. I support the designation of the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension including the waters offshore of Point Buchon, Morro Bay, Cayucos and Cambria. This will protect the only eelgrass bed in a 300 mile stretch of coast including many historic Chumash sites. No other proposed sanctuary alternative is adequate to provide this protection. I also support the name "Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary" to honor the cultural history and stewardship of California Tribal peoples. I am also in favor of a Tribal Collaborative Management; please keep the sacred connection between our ocean and the community at the heart of this effort. In short please protect our magnificent coastline for generations to come with "no Carve-Out" Thank you.

Title: Comment from O’Reilly, Siobhan
Comment:
To whom it may concern,
I strongly support the designation of and the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and the asks of the Chumash people. I urge you to approve the biggest possible boundary including Rodriguez Seamount, the sanctuary name’s inclusion of the Chumash people who have tended the coast for 20,000 years, tribal collaborative management, and outreach and education programming. It is also  imperative to ban new oil and gas development within sanctuary boundaries. It is well documented that while Indigenous people comprise less than 5% of the population, they protect 80% of the world’s biodiversity. With these provisions in place, the sanctuary can safeguard California and the ocean’s resilience and biodiversity for generations to come. Such protection is more important now than at any other point in history.
Thank you for your consideration. I hope you will take action to change this world for the better.

Dear Paul Michell, 
My name is Sarah Boyles-Muehleck and I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.
