I believe that all life along in our oceans has a right to a healthy environment and the right to reproduce and thrive as they did when these coasts sustained Chumash Communities for 20,000 years. I write to you not only as a citizen who loves the ocean, but as a medical student who knows that the health of all humans, particularly Indigenous communities, is inextricably tied to the health of our environment. The environmental impacts of colonization now threaten all life on earth and returning management of land to Indigenous Communities is not only the right thing to do, it is the best way to protect our environment for generations to come. 
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes:
Biggest Possible Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension

Title: Comment from Peters, V
Comment:
Please designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. 

These areas contain a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving and worthy of protection.

Offshore wind power transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.

Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Mintzer, Carole
Comment:
Thank you so much for moving forward on the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. Please use the Initial Boundary Alternative as proposed in 2021. Migratory marine life need protection throughout their path. They would have no idea that there is a gap in protection from Montana de Oro State Park to Cambria. So the best thing is for there to be no gap. 

Also, the management plan needs to include input from all the Chumash tribes, regardless of whether they are federally recognized. Without the efforts of the Northern Chumash Tribal Council, there would not be a marine sanctuary. They have more than earned a place in the co-management of the sanctuary.

Finally, just from a very selfish perspective - and back to the gap - I have a view from my house of the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Cayucos, Morro Bay, and Los Osos. I expected to someday be able to look out and know that those waters are protected by a national marine sanctuary designation. There is no reason for these waters to be excluded, so please, make my day and include them in the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

Hello,

I am a commercial fisherwoman active in the area selected for the CHNMS. I adamantly opposed the proposed sanctuary. Sanctuary benefits to the ecosystem are unproven and the additional regulations are unnecessary as they already exist under multiple federal, state, and local laws. Removing the local influence over this area and placing decisions solely in the hands of the Sanctuaries management division of the federal government will be detrimental to the local culture especially the commercial fishermen as priority will be given to neo-Chumash cultural practices. Neo-Chumash culture misrepresents historical and factually proven evidence. The neo-Chumash are claiming ownership of areas in the sanctuary where their tribes do not have history. Title: Comment from Hackney, Lauren
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment. I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, with the largest contiguous boundaries: the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension, including Morro Rock/Lisamu’, and connecting to the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary.  I live in San Luis Obispo, California, where I and many others view this beautiful and important coastline and ocean as central to our lives. Protecting the Central Coast’s unique marine ecosystem is vital to the human and non-human species who depend on it. 

This designation is occurring in a time of rapid change and uncertainty. Much of the language in the regulatory documents focuses on codifying current conditions or reference those as a baseline, but our ecosystems are already at a crisis point and are evolving quickly. Novel problems and solutions that cannot be easily addressed or predicted - changes to the shoreline, erosion and sedimentation, species migration, the especially accelerated acidification of California’s coastal waters, and cascading impacts on rare and endangered species - are already in progress, and will profoundly impact the health of the ocean and our relationship to it. 

Collaborative and creative management to address these wicked challenges will be essential. To this end, I support the name Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to recognize the Indigenous peoples who have lived on this coast since time immemorial, and who are the best-suited to take a long, holistic view at the challenges the ocean faces now and in the future. I urge NOAA to sincerely engage in equitable collaborative management by creating a Tribal Sanctuary Advisory Council, including all local Tribal groups who would like to be involved, as well as a NOAA Tribal Liaison. Collaborative management will also be key for evaluating the complexity of offshore energy resources. Protecting biodiversity and habitats should be paramount in this process. I support the exploration of offshore wind energy and believe it need not be mutually exclusive with the Sanctuary: the monitoring and research possible through the Sanctuary designation will help ensure the reduction of adverse long-term impacts of such projects. Transmission cables proposed as part of future offshore wind developments should require permits from the National Marine Sanctuary Program to ensure they are sited with care to reduce these impacts. New oil and gas development within Sanctuary boundaries is environmentally irresponsible and should be prohibited. 

Finally, as a landscape architecture professional and educator, I strongly support multilingual and multicultural education and outreach for the Sanctuary that elevates both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities, to share information about local marine science, conservation, Indigenous history and culture, and human impacts and connections to marine and terrestrial ecosystems. Protecting the ocean for future generations requires the education, participation and stewardship of current generations. 

I offer deep gratitude to the Northern Chumash Tribal Council for their inspiring leadership in this effort; to their local partners the Marine Sanctuary Alliance, Santa Lucia Chapter of Sierra Club, SLO Chapter of Surfrider Foundation, COAST; to NOAA staff and leadership; and the many others who have worked tirelessly to bring the Sanctuary designation to this point. I strongly support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary and urge the Administration to immediately act to protect and honor this vital, special marine ecosystem of highest value for past, current and future generations.

Title: Comment from n/a, n/a
Comment: Hello, I am writing to express my strong support of the designation of the Chumash National Marine Sanctuary. As a Chumash person and a conservation biologist, I am happy to see this marine sanctuary being discussed. I am, however, very concerned and upset at NOAA's preferred alternative that removes Lisamu' (Morro Rock) and leaves it as a sacrifice zone to offshore wind development. NOAA recognizes that such activities will have large impacts to the marine environment and uses this as the reason for removing this area from the sanctuary, when in fact the opposite should be true. The fact that offshore wind development and the installation of cables will have such a large impact that it wouldn't be compatible with a marine sanctuary is all the more reason why this entire area needs the full protection of a sanctuary. Permitting processes exist for a reason, and any development should have to go through that process, rather than choosing to leave a large area vulnerable and lacking protections. I attended the virtual public comment meeting and saw the overwhelming support for the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to have the full original boundary with the addition of the Gaviota Coast Extension, with the only opposition coming from a few who stand to lose money from the designation. This sanctuary MUST cover the largest expanse possible to protect our ocean and the creatures living in it. In addition, I urge NOAA to follow through with Indigenous-led management where coastal Indigenous people have real decision making capabilities. Thank you.

Title: Comment from Zou, Jason
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

I am writing in strong support of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, designated with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

The ocean plays a critical role in our ecosystem, and thus in all of humanity's wellbeing by extension. Since the industrial revolution, we have been throwing caution to the wind by overfishing it, polluting it, and disrupting it through human-caused global warming, which we are now more commonly beginning to understand the dire impacts of on our collective lives. I believe it is about time to finally change course and start treating it with the respect that it deserves. 

As such, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary:

1. Incorporates the biggest possible contiguous boundary, such that as much area is protected as possible. The Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension is the only option which accomplishes this, while also including benefits such as connecting it to the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary and including crucial cultural heritage sites.
2. Is named the “Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary”, which properly acknowledges the peoples who have watched over these waters and surrounding lands for most of our human history and who have been denied recognition in virtually every other way. 
3. Is managed collaboratively and equitably with local Tribal groups, who understand this area the best, and often in ways that the scientific lens historically is slow to agree with. 
4. Prohibits new oil and gas development within the sanctuary boundaries. Needless to say that global society cannot afford to burn more fossil fuels if we want to curb the worst effects of the climate crisis, and adding to our existing supply is at odds with that goal.
5. Pushes back against proposals to develop offshore wind within the sanctuary bounds when there are more suitable and optimal areas for such projects. The impacts of offshore wind on marine life and ecosystem health are not yet understood, so it does not make sense to experiment with such projects in locations where marine ecosystem health is crucial. 
6. Protects the Rodriguez Seamount, as it is a critical habitat for an abundant and diverse array of life. 
7. Supports outreach, education, and research programs that elevate both Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) and access for local underserved communities. While honoring Tribal knowledge via the sanctuary name is important, so is actively engaging US citizens with real tribal community members to center their voices, share in their wisdom, and better understand their culture. Too long have indigenous communities suffered from erasure, othering, and violence; through our joined intention to protect and heal the Earth, we may be able to find ways to improve our nation's long-strained relationship with indigenous communities.

In short, I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, and I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from our ocean’s many treasures.

Sincerely,

Jason Zou

Title: Comment from Gonzalez Castañeda , Alyssa

Title: Comment from Kluck , Aimee
Comment:
I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary!
Please designate the sanctuary using the initial boundaries proposed (Initial Boundary Alternative), plus the Gaviota Extension (sub-alternative 5b) in order to provide contiguous protection between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries.
This area contains a rich, diverse marine environment, cultural resources such as submerged historic Chumash villages, and shipwrecks, all of which are deserving of protection.
Offshore wind transmission cables can be accommodated through a special use permit at a later date, but in the meantime, we must permanently protect the area from harmful activities like oil and gas development, seabed mining and dredging, and harmful polluting discharges to our waters.
Thank you for protecting our Central Coast with this National Marine Sanctuary.

Title: Comment from Hamma, Christopher
Comment:
Dear NOAA, 

I am a longtime resident of San Luis Obispo County, California, who works as an Environmental Scientist at the California Department of Transportation. I have lived less than 2 miles from Pismo State Beach for approximately 20 years. My family and I place tremendous value on our local coastal and marine resources. I am writing to express my strong support for a Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary for the Pacific Ocean waters off the coasts of San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara Counties. I believe that you hold in your hands a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to extend permanent, meaningful protection to some of this nation's priceless natural resources on the West Coast. As you undoubtedly know, nationwide, National Marine Sanctuaries contribute roughly $8 billion a year to local coastal and ocean dependent economies across multiple sectors (NOAA, 2016). In San Luis Obispo County, ocean-based tourism and recreation are significant contributors to the local economy, employ many residents, and play a huge part in the general health and happiness of the population. There has been much discussion on whether it would be appropriate to designate a National Marine Sanctuary in an area planned for offshore wind energy development. I've participated in this discussion on a casual basis with friends and colleagues, and my take is that with strict controls/regulation, it would not be a dealkiller to include the potential wind energy area west of Morro Bay in the Sanctuary. On the contrary, I believe over the long term the benefits would outweigh any negatives and it would be a risk worth taking. I respectfully and explicitly ask that NOAA include that area in the proposed Sanctuary. Furthermore, I am aware there are disagreements between local tribal governments over the naming of the Sanctuary. Again, I believe that this Sanctuary designation would be overwhelmingly positive and beneficial for every stakeholder. It would be an absolutely foolish tragedy to let the opportunity slip away over prideful quibbling. Please work hard to bring the involved stakeholders to the table and hammer out a fair solution that honors and respects everyone. I am certain that this outcome is within reach. I'm not exaggerating when I say a very large proportion of Central Coast residents are depending on you to make the right decision for all our futures. Respectfully yours, (redacted).
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Rodgers, Jessica
Comment:
RE: NOAA - National Historic Preservation Act (NHPA) Section 106. - CHMS Designation


Dear NOAA Officials,

I hope this letter finds you well. I would like to extend my sincere gratitude to you for considering my thoughts and concerns regarding the proposed National Marine Sanctuary along the Central Coast of California. Your willingness to engage with community input and your endorsement of the Initial Boundary Alternative are greatly appreciated.

I support the formation of a new national sanctuary along the Central Coast of California. Although, as we navigate the establishment and management process of this sanctuary, it is of paramount importance that we do so with the utmost respect for the historical and cultural significance of the Salinan Tribe in the region. I would like to reiterate some key points summarizing my suggestions and concerns:

Recognition of Salinan Tribe's Significance: The ancestral bond that the Salinan Tribe shares with the proposed National Marine Sanctuary is profound. It is my fervent request that the significance of our tribe be recognized and celebrated alongside the historical presence of the Chumash in the region. Acknowledging both tribes' contributions is essential for an inclusive approach.

Boundary Establishment: I would like to express my strong opposition to any reduction in the sanctuary boundary, as proposed in the Initial Boundary Alternative. I believe that the initial  boundaries appropriately represent the cultural and historical landscape of the region, and any alterations would undermine the sanctity of the sanctuary.

Naming Tradition: I encourage the sanctuary's name to adhere to the tradition of using geographical features as its foundation. This approach preserves a deep connection to the region's natural and cultural heritage, which is essential for the preservation of our traditions and history.

Vetting Process for Tribal Representatives: To ensure authenticity in representation, I recommend that NOAA establish a vetting process for tribal representatives. Collaboration with the California Native American Heritage Commission would be a valuable step towards verifying ancestral and cultural connections to the Central Coast.

Consultation with Salinan and Chumash Peoples: I strongly advocate for the primary entities consulted regarding the sanctuary to be the Salinan and Chumash peoples. Recognizing our unique ties to the region is imperative in shaping a sanctuary that respects and celebrates our cultural heritage.

Representation for Non-Federally Recognized Tribes: It is crucial that non-federally recognized tribes are provided advisory capacity and opportunities for input. Additionally, culturally affiliated tribes should be adequately represented on the advisory council, taking into account the diverse tribal affiliations in the area.

In conclusion, I urge NOAA and all relevant authorities to give serious consideration to these recommendations. Inclusivity, respect for tribal heritage, and a fair representation of all stakeholders are fundamental principles that should guide the establishment and management of the National Marine Sanctuary along the Central Coast of California.

Thank you once again for your receptiveness to community input and for taking these concerns into account during the decision-making process. I look forward to seeing a sanctuary that reflects the rich tapestry of our cultural and natural history while ensuring its long-term preservation for generations to come.

Sincerely,
Jessica Rodgers

Title: Comment from Handman, Nick
Comment:
Michel,

My name is Nick Handman and I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension. 

I live in the San Fernando Valley and grew up in Ojai, CA. I have a strong personal connection to the ocean and our natural lands in southern CA and the central coast. I’m an avid lover of the outdoors as so many others are locally.

A healthy, thriving ocean is vital to our local communities as well as the health of our local ecology. Protection for this particular part of the coast is especially important due to all of the potential threats that face it. 

I feel very strongly that the largest area possible for the sanctuary is needed to preserve this area, without compromise. I also feel very strongly that the Chumash and local indigenous peoples wishes be honored and that they are involved at all levels, as they are the rightful stewards of this land and know how best to manage it.

Please designate the Chumash Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension in place.

Sincerely,

Nick Handman

Title: Comment from Fields, Jennifer
Comment:
Paul Michel, Regional Policy Coordinator
NOAA Office of National Marine Sanctuaries
99 Pacific Street, Suite 100F
Monterey, CA 93940

RE: Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary designation (NOAA-NOS-2021-0080)

Dear Mr. Michel:

I, Jennifer Fields, strongly support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary (CHNMS) to protect ocean biodiversity and to advance environmental justice through collaborative ocean management. 

I am a marine ecologist with over 10 years of experience studying the impacts of climate on marine and near-shore ecosystems. I believe that designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, spanning over 7,500 square miles of ocean and 156 miles of coastline, will be both beneficial for the environment, local communities and the economy. 

It is vital that the CHNMS cover the largest possible contiguous boundaries. I support designation of the Initial Boundary Alternative with the Gaviota Coast Extension (Sub-Alt 5b). Including the waters offshore Point Buchon, Morro Bay, Cayucos, and Cambria will close the California Central Coast’s biodiversity protection gap between Monterey Bay and Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuaries. This will protect the only eelgrass bed in a 300-mile stretch of coast; many historic Chumash sites, including Lisamu’ (Morro Rock); numerous protected marine mammals and shorebirds; the highest population of Southern Sea otters on the California coast; several State Marine Conservation Areas; and the kelp forests and rocky intertidal habitats considered to be some of the most diverse and abundant in the world.

In addition I support:
Equitable inclusion of all Central Coast Tribes in collaborative management. All sanctuary stakeholders will benefit from Indigenous input. The CHNMS is an opportunity to advance environmental justice efforts. Equitable collaborative management must be open to all Tribal groups interested in participating. This can best be accomplished with a Tribal Sanctuary Advisory Council made up of interested Tribal Groups. NOAA’s Tribal collaboration should be facilitated by a qualified Tribal Liaison. 
Compensation and resource support (e.g. childcare resources, flexible meeting times, accessibility accommodations, etc.) for Tribal and Indigenous community members for participation in engagement and collaborative management. Official designation will ensure the full benefits and expertise of NOAA and the Indigenous community are available to steward this important habitat, but equity and principles of co-management must be included in the process from designation onward.
Sanctuary education and community outreach programs should operate in partnership with area schools to increase education and access to the ocean for local communities. Programs should focus on both ocean ecology and Tribal history and culture. Outreach should be multilingual and multicultural, and prioritize underserved communities, such as the inland communities of Guadalupe and Santa Maria. This component is especially important as Indigenous communities on the Central Coast and throughout California have been forced away from their traditional lands along the coastline and onto inland reservations. Promoting access and education to traditional Indigenous lands, waters, and ways of knowing is a critical social component of sanctuary designation and education. 
Prioritize nature-based solutions within the Climate Action Plan and meaningful community engagement
Development of research programs that address the impacts of climate change, encourage community science, and elevate the use of Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) to enhance ecosystem-based management. The Sanctuary should teach the benefits of protecting our ocean and planet and promote the spirit of stewardship that is exemplified by the culture and history of the original Chumash caretakers. 
The National Marine Sanctuary Program should work closely with state and federal partners, Offshore wind (OSW) companies, Tribes, and community members to ensure future OSW is developed in the most environmentally and culturally responsible manner.
The CHNMS is an exceptional opportunity to advance the first Tribally-nominated national marine sanctuary designation in the United States, setting a precedent for elevating Indigenous perspectives, cultural values in ocean conservation, and collaborative management that includes all Central Coast Tribes. The designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary will be an unprecedented accomplishment, honoring the history and culture of Native Americans, the Chumash people, and their ancestors who inhabited this region for more than 10,000 years. Indigenous co-management is a key climate solution for addressing and adapting to the impacts of climate change.

Thank you for moving the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary forward in this process and for reviewing these comments.

Sincerely,
Jennifer Fields

Title: Comment from Miernik, Diana
Comment:
Greetings, I'm Diana, and I'm here to voice my strong support for the designation of the Chumash marine sanctuary. I've always had a profound connection to the ocean, and I'd like to share my perspective on a critical issue that often goes unnoticed. I consider myself a passionate environmentalist and an avid surfer, while my partner is a daring big wave surfer. Together, we're also parents to two young children, and it's important for us to emphasize the role of personal watercraft (PWC) in ensuring our safety, a factor that has become increasingly significant in our lives.

My own experiences as a surfer have deepened my appreciation for the ocean, and the Chumash sanctuary encompasses several perilous winter big wave surfing locations, known for their challenging and remote conditions. In these demanding and dangerous areas, PWCs have become indispensable tools for the safety of surfers. They not only play a vital role in rescuing surfers after falls but also in swiftly navigating through potentially hazardous situations. In emergencies such as shark encounters, drownings, or injuries, PWC operators serve as the first responders, making them absolutely essential to our safety. This concern resonates with many local surfers, big wave surfers like my partner, and families like ours who cherish both the thrill of the waves and the well-being of our loved ones.

It's also important to highlight that most surfers in our community share a deep commitment to environmental conservation. We're acutely aware of the rich wildlife and marine mammals in these waters, and we are wholeheartedly dedicated to preserving the natural beauty of the ocean and all its inhabitants. As a passionate water enthusiast, surfer, environmentalist, and parent, I firmly believe it's crucial for decision-makers to take into account the safety needs of our community and the responsible use of this area while discussing the sanctuary designation.

Thank you for providing me with the opportunity to share my viewpoint, one that reflects the perspective of a surfer, an advocate for environmental conservation, and a parent who believes in the importance of safeguarding our ocean while enjoying its wonders safely.

Title: Comment from Wright, Adrian
Comment: Hello my name is Adrian  Wright. I am in support of the Chumash marine sanctuary designation. I've always had a deep connection to the ocean, and shared my love of the ocean with my two sons, who have become big wave surfers and jet ski operators. We are a family of wilderness lovers, environmentalists, and conservationists. The Chumash sanctuary covers several very dangerous winter big wave surfing locations. In these remote and dangerous areas, personal watercraft become indispensable for the safety of surfers. PWCs are used not only for rescuing surfers after falls but also for quickly navigating out of potentially hazardous situations. Title: Comment from Houston, Ernest
Comment: My name is Ernest R. Houston and I am a person of Chumash descent. I have lived here on the central California coast all my life as has my mother and her ancestors. In the course of my lifetime I have watched as this area has become increasingly developed, and have noticed that the pressure to develop has increased with the increasing population and the demands of the population. I fully endorse the establishment of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, especially the original proposal which includes Morro Bay and environs. By excluding the Morro Bay component of this proposed sanctuary the preservation of this critical and unique marine environment is threatened by future development. I urge NOAA to reverse their decision to exclude the Morro Bay component of the Sanctuary. To paraphrase John Muir, every victory is temporary, every loss is permanent. Our marine environment is constantly threatened not only by development, but also by overfishing and climate change induced environmental degradation. If this environment is not set aside now, the future may be too late given the rate of change we are currently experiencing.

Title: Comment from Campbell, Bruce
Comment:
To NOAA and to whom it may concern:

First for some basic background, I remind you all that it was a clear scientifically-based conclusion that it would be best for natural biological resources for there to be NO INTERRUPTION between the Monterey Bay NMS and the Channel Islands NMS.  Thus to meet this criteria, the northern portion of the proposed Chumash Heritage NMS should be included within the designated NMS boundaries – whatever the debate about tribal naming disagreements.

It is my understanding that the initial proposed map for marine sanctuary designation extended all the way through Santa Barbara County coastal areas.  Yet apparently the nominating map submitted did not extend (southeast) beyond the mouth area of Gaviota Creek.  I applaud the agencies for realizing the wisdom of the inclusion of the Gaviota Coastal Extension in the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary proposal and for submitting that essentially preferred alternative.  This is important due to the incredible marine diversity of that South Coast region including in the greater Naples area, as well as due to the significance to the Chumash tribe of some important historic villages and sacred sites in that area.  (I would hope that various oil operations including an onshore pipeline which has leaked in recent years would not be grandfathered in upon establishment of the Chumash (or whatever it shall be named) Heritage National Marine Sanctuary.

I am pleased that all alternatives (except for the No Action Alternative) include the greater Rodriguez Seamount area for some protections under a NMS designation.

I want to point out a key area north of the Rodriguez Seamount which is the Arguello Canyon / Arguello Terrace area.  I pointed out in earlier comments in this NMS process that it is important to protect natural and indigenous artifacts in this area not only because the Chumash used to live in this region before the ocean rose, but also because this is the area where the 2000 km Murray Fracture Zone meets the North American continent in the Santa Barbara County area.  Note that Point Arguello juts furthest west of the North American land mass, and (obviously due to the name alone) there is the notable Arguello Terrace and then Arguello Canyon.  I support an alternative which includes more rather than less of Arguello Canyon partly because it is the mapped region to my knowledge which is most related to the grander seismic perspective of the less-studied east-west oceanic fracture zone – the Murray Fracture Zone.

I am extremely disappointed in Alternatives 3 and 4 since they clearly do not realize (or care about) the significant biological and aesthetic resources in the Montana de Oro State Park and Diablo Canyon area.  How dare they want to turn the loveliest coastal park south of Big Sur into a mere electronic cable transmission route!  Surely the relatively undisturbed (except for increased carcinogenic threat from radioactivity and heavy metal releases in the Diablo Cove / Diablo Canyon area) and astoundingly beautiful Montana de Oro and Diablo Canyon should not become further sacrifice zones!  Do not route electric cables related to wind energy to this area!  

I am happy that more sane alternatives do include Montana de Oro and Diablo Canyon within the NMS zone offering certain protections.  While on one hand because (when they can keep the old creaker running) Diablo Canyon does generate energy and those power lines run toward the San Joaquin Valley, I can see how some got the idea to route it through that area despite its largely pristine nature.  However, the spent fuel rod assemblies at Diablo Canyon are overstuffed into thin untransportable canisters, and will pose a major threat at least until they may possibly be able to moved sometime perhaps early in the 22nd century.  I respect workers more than to have more contaminated because they are trying to route more alternatively-generated energy through electric cables at Diablo Canyon.  Have you examined various theorized Diablo Canyon reactor potential shutdown dates to gauge which might work best if wind energy did come into Diablo Canyon to use those cables?

I am pleased with Alt. 5 b with the exception of a few activities which may be grandfathered in during the establishment of this NMS.  I also support Alt. 5 a.  Just because some want to mess a lot with Morro Bay to have it become one of two main wind energy hubs in California does not mean its tidal-influenced estuary could not be included within the Chumash Heritage NMS boundaries.


Thanks for your attention, and protect a good amount including Gaviota Coast Extension.

Sincerely yours,

Bruce Campbell
Los Angeles

Title: Comment from Dallmann, Allyson
Comment:
I am Dr. Allyson Dallmann and live in Cambria. It is short-sighted and offensive that you would consider excluding the area between my home and Point Buchon. Our area is vital for biodiversity and provides essential connectivity for many species. It is a sanctuary not only for the animals who live here but for all of us who appreciate nature in her purest form. I love walking this area with my dogs and bring friends and family here so they can appreciate the serenity and wildlife.  We are deeply connected to this area BECAUSE OF THE WILDLIFE AND because it is unadulterated.  This plan would hurt the animals, habitat and all of us. Our oceans are warming, becoming more toxic from human activity and we have fewer animals here than we used to, so I feel you are directly targeting marine life, me and my wellbeing along with so many others including indigenous people in leaving this precious area out.   
We know how destructive oil and gas are so they must be banned from this area as well as cables for wind. (1)
As noted in “Oil in the Sea III: Inputs, Fates, and Effects.”
“Oil in the sea from anthropogenic sources, whether from spills or chronic releases, is perceived as a major environmental problem. Major oil spills occur occasionally and receive considerable public attention because of the obvious attendant environmental damage, including oil-coated shorelines and dead or moribund wildlife, especially oiled seabirds and marine mammals. Acute effects may be of short duration and limited impact, or they may have long-term population- or community-level impacts depending on the timing and duration of the spill and the numbers and types of organisms affected. Oil also enters the sea when small amounts are released over long periods, thus creating chronic exposure of organisms to oil and its component chemical species. Sources of chronic exposures include point sources, such as natural seeps, leaking pipelines, offshore production discharges, and non-point runoff from land-based facilities. In these cases, there may be a strong gradient from a high to a low oil concentration as a function of distance from the source. In other cases, such as with land-based runoff and atmospheric inputs, the origin of the oil is a nonpoint source, and environmental concentration gradients of oil compounds may be weak. Chronic exposures may also result from the incorporation of spilled oil into sediments in which weathering of oil is retarded, and from which nearly-fresh oil may be released to the water column over extended periods. In recent years, it is the long-term effects of acute and chronic pollution that have received increasing attention (Boesch et al., 1987).” (2)
Wind farms would disrupt migrating whales and other species, detrimentally alter habitats, decrease species survival, discharge contaminants further harming wildlife and their homes and they’re noisy. Would you want this to happen in your home? 
Sea mining is detrimental to the wildlife and environment as well (3). 
The Rodriguez Seamount must be protected for biodiversity.  

 Please designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative including the Gaviota Coast Extension- 7,600 square miles -to protect our wildlife already struggling due to anthropogenic causes as well as our living ocean and sanctuary in the broadest sense of the word. 
“Above all, do no harm.” I learned this credo in veterinary medicine, and it is apropos in any situation where coexistence, the environment, land, air and water are affected.  It is your responsibility to “do no harm” especially when we are in the sixth extinction crisis, and it is anthropogenic!  We must accept responsibility for our actions and prevent further harm to our wildlife, ecosystems and ourselves as we all share this one planet. 
1.	Long-term ecological impacts from oil spills: comparison of Exxon Valdez, Hebei Spirit and Deepwater Horizon - PMC (nih.gov)

Oil in the Sea III: Inputs, Fates, and Effects.
2.	https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK220710/
3.	Extent of impact of deep-sea nodule mining midwater plumes is influenced by sediment loading, turbulence and thresholds | Communications Earth & Environment (nature.com)

Title: Comment from Dalforno, Ryan
Organization Name: Doctoral Candidate Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,

I support the swift designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary with the Initial Boundary Alternative and Gaviota Coast Extension to cover about 7,600 square miles of ocean proposed to protect biodiversity and habitats.

I am a doctoral candidate at Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, where I research the direct role that healthy ecosystems have in preventing asthma and allergies in kids. My decision to pursue this subject is inextricably tied to the fact that I grew up in Goleta and was so incredibly fortunate to benefit from the many nature preserves that surround Santa Barbara. Interacting with the vibrant natural space of the central coast is fundamental to my decision to pursue research of the relationship between human and ecological health, and is why I am proud to wholeheartedly support the designation of the Chumash Hertiage National Marine Sanctuary. 

Not only does safeguarding these ecosystems protect the beauty and biodiversity of our coast, this preservation of biodiversity in turn has cascading effects that protect the health of human populations that live nearby and spend time in natural environments. Our individual microbiomes - which are increasingly recognized as a critical supporter of our bodies' ability to fight disease and reduce the impact of poor diet, exposure to air pollution, and mental stress - are directly connected to the bacterial composition of the external biosphere around our bodies. As we eat, breathe, and move through our environment, the microbiome in our gut, lungs, and on our skin is engaged in a constant process of exchange with the broader environment. A healthy environment provides us with mircoorganisms that our bodies can incorporate into our healthy functioning, draw upon in the event of disease, and (especially when we're young) use to help our bodies determing which things are dangerous (e.g. germs) and which things are not (e.g. pollen). Without microbial diversity in the larger environment, as is common in many urbanized settings, kids are placed at higher risk of developing allergies and asthma because their bodies do not get enough "training" to differentiate between germs and allergens. 

Safeguarding biodiversity at the macro-level (think algae, kelp, dolphins, seals, starfish, whales - everything we can see with our eyes unassisted) is critical to make sure that our own microbiomes remain diverse and functional, in turn helping the body develop strong immune systems (especially for kids). This understanding of how humans' health and microbiome is linked to the macro-level biodiversity is just barely emerging, but has immense implications for the economic cost of health systems and disease that are not yet accounted for (to my knowledge) as possible benefits of safeguarding these biological reserves. 

From my position as a researcher and someone who spent the first 20 years of my life in the Central Coast, I cannot underscore emphatically enough how important it is to take drastic measures to preserve the wider network of life in California. It is not just a question of preserving beauty, or dollars from tourists, or cultural heritage (although those things are important) - it is also a question of safeguarding the health of humans, which depends on the land-sea biosphere's stability in ways which we are just beginning to understand. 

I support the designation of the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary. I ask that this sanctuary includes all the aspects as proposed by the Chumash Sanctuary campaign, including the largest possible boundaries (including, critically, the Gaviota Coast Extension), the proposed name of "Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary," a equitable approach to include all Tribes in a collaborative management process, elevation of vital traditional ecological knowledge and access to the reserve for all along the central coast, the protection of Rodriguez Seamount, and a strict prohibition of new oil and gas developments within the boundaries of the sanctuary. 
    
I urge the Administration to designate the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to allow current and future generations to enjoy, protect, and benefit from the stunning beauty of the marine environment along the Central Coast. 

 
Sincerely,

Ryan Dalforno

Title: Comment from Wang, Cathelyn
Comment: I wholeheartedly support designating the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary to include the areas from Montaña de Oro State Park in San Luis Obispo County to Naples along the Gaviota Coast in Santa Barbara County. This designation will not only support a healthier marine ecosystem for people to recreate and connect with, but it will continue to better mitigate climate change through marine diversity and increased biomass. Additionally, this sanctuary recognizes the cultural and historical significance of the Chumash people and honors the heritage and wisdom of indigenous communities who have lived harmoniously with nature for centuries. As a San Luis Obispo resident, I have the privilege to frequent these areas and have developed a fond connection through diving, surfing, and just spending beach days by the ocean. I want to see this place to be protected for generations to come.

Title: Comment from Parks, Noreen
Comment:
As a former resident of the California Central Coast and a professional environmental writer specializing in marine issues, I heartily support the proposed Chumash Heritage NMS and urge that a decision to establish it be implemented swiftly. 
There is abundant scientific evidence that marine protected areas with robust protections, such as federal sanctuaries, have multiple benefits, including: 1) safeguarding biodiversity and protecting at-risk species and habitats; 2) increasing the resilience of marine ecosystems to climate change; 3) increasing the commercial and recreational fishing catches in surrounding areas; and 4) providing economic benefits that support healthy coastal communities. 
Furthermore, creating networks of marine protected areas leverages their individual benefits. Thus, in bridging the gap between the marine reserves to its north and south (offshore of San Luis Obispo County and Santa Barbara County, respectively) the proposed sanctuary will strengthen and build on their benefits.
The draft EIS does an exemplary job of listing and describing the rich and abundant ecological and other qualifications for the proposed area. Arguably the area's most unique feature is that it includes the meeting place of currents from relatively cold northern waters meet with warmer southern offshore waters. The resulting intermingling produces an altogether unique and valuable asset to our national marine biodiversity. 
Finally, the wholesale recognition and respect of tribal and Indigenous cultures of communities across our country is long overdue, and sanctuary-related collaborations with these peoples would begin to redress the harm done. 
It is widely acknowledged that less than 3% of the ocean is effectively protected. Experts from diverse disciplines believe that humans need to protect at least 30% of the ocean to safeguard marine biodiversity and build ocean resilience. A Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary is a superb addition to the world ocean's official "family jewels." 
I want to extend my deep appreciation for NOAA's contributions to making President Biden's America the Beautiful agenda a reality. Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this significant issue.

Title: Comment from Claffey, Maureen
Organization Name: Vista Del Mar School - Student Letters
Comment: Dear NOAA Office of Marine Sanctuaries and Mr. Michel, I am a fifth and sixth grade teacher at a small, single-site school (and school district) in Gaviota, California, on the coastline that is at the far southern end of the proposed NOAA Chumash Heritage National Sanctuary (CHMNS). Our students and their families live, play, work and learn on land that overlooks this proposed protected waterway. My students surf, swim, "beach," and fish in the coastal waters of the proposed CHMNS. In fact, the October 12 information meeting was held at our school site. Because my students care deeply about the ocean they see everyday and will be affected by any changes to the coastal waters, I decided to use the call for comments as an assignment for my students, asking them to share their opinions in a letter to the NOAA. We read the press release and watched the video on the project and they wrote responses. I've attached their letters here, as I promised them I would. Please note that for their privacy, I did not include their last names or identifying information. Also, please note that the opinions stated are theirs alone and do not represent the school, myself or the district. Last, I have unfortunately been recovering from a medical issue for the last two weeks and nearly missed the submission deadline completely. Upon realizing it was due today, I scrambled to find my students' letters and realized that I left their final drafts at school. So, the letters you are reading are their rough drafts, with editing ideas and marks from each other. While I'm sad you don't see their best, polished work, their ideas and points of view are clear here, regardless. Please ignore the editing marks. We look forward to hearing about any future updates on the project. Thank you for your time!

Title: Comment from Kaplan, Leah
Comment:
Dear Paul Michel,
I support the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary because it is imperative to protect our wildlife and marine ecosystems.

My whole life I have loved the ocean and I can’t imagine a world where the ocean doesn’t hold the depth of wonder and life that it has nurtured since before our time as humans. The life within the ocean is worth protecting and worth protecting well. 

I think there should be the biggest possible boundary, including the Gaviota Coast Extension, because animals should be protected anywhere that they may be existing or migrating. There should absolutely be an equitable approach to include all Tribes in collaborative management and those Tribes should also be involved in Outreach and Education. Oil and gas should be banned within sanctuary boundaries after numerous spills that reveal the harm and damage these practices can inflict on marine life. 

Thank you for listening to our voices. I have included a sample of the voluntarily written letters from my third grade students, who adore the ocean and all its life. They were not told what to write, just that there was a question about whether we should protect the ocean and that there was the idea to have a sanctuary in order to do that. I hope the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary does become a reality so we can protect the ocean and continue to experience its wonders. 

Sincerely,
Leah Kaplan
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Murphy, Lisa
Comment:
I live in Cambria now, but lived in Santa Cruz for many years. I taught students about the ocean and tidal ecosystems, lead tours in elk horn slough and out into the open ocean, as well as participating in many beach clean ups.  I surf, boogie board, snorkel and kayak.  I also walk the cliffs and beaches, volunteered at the marine mammal centre in Marin, and have spend countless hours observing marine mammals.

Sanctuary Boundary: The Initial Boundary Alternative with Gaviota Coast Extension.   
	This is absolutely imperative for a contiguous NMS band along our Ca Coast, as well as protection to the edge of the continental plate - which in turn will offer protection to the upwelling process.
Outreach and Education: Outreach, education and research programs that help our locals, our children, our visitors understand the importance of our oceans and our actions to protect them.  As well as the problems we are causing for the oceans and all that live there.
Rodriguez Seamount: The protection of Rodriguez Seamount - this is an unique habitat that likely holds many new species for us to discover
Offshore Wind: Thoughtful planning of Offshore Wind farms to protect ocean life and migrating birds, bats, and insects (as we are seeing the numbers of all of there categories and species decline.). I am a supporter of the transition to sustainable.  But we need to know how to do so in an environmentally sound way.  Humans have an amazing history of significantly significant unintended consequences that negatively effect our environment.  It is much easier to protect  than it is to restore habitat and ecosystems.  
Also, I feel there has not been full transparency re other BOEM leases in the original proposed NMS boundaries - that have clearly driven the development of other boundary alternatives.   I have attached the BOEM maps that clearly shows this secondary lease area .
Water Quality: A prohibition on new oil development within sanctuary boundaries.  Also a prohibition on mining of minerals.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Blaney, Carol
Comment:
Addendum to comment submitted by Carol Blaney on 18 October 2023:

Thank you again for the opportunity to comment on the proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, which I urge you to designate as soon as possible with the largest possible boundaries (the Initial Boundary Alternative plus the Gaviota Coast Extension and the Morro Bay Estuary). 

A 2018 BOEM map of Central California call areas (attached) indicates that, over time, there could be an even larger development of wind energy in the Diablo Canyon call area. The potential effects of such a large development, especially if combined with the Morro Bay call area, are unknown. 

Such developments have the potential to damage the marine upwelling itself, the source of the biodiversity that makes this entire area worthy of protection as a national marine sanctuary. This potential makes designating the widest possible area as a national marine sanctuary even more crucial. As a nation, we must engage in wind-energy development in a way that addresses environmental issues and concerns thoughtfully and thoroughly. 

Thank you for your efforts to protect our irreplaceable natural and cultural heritage.

Sincerely,

Carol Blaney, MS, MS
25 October 2023
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment from Wiegand, Jim
Comment:
The proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, while a good idea on the surface, is really not such good idea at all. I say this because it will only extend northwards to within approximately 2.5 miles of the southern end of Morro Bay Wind Energy Area.  Yet, the destruction from this wind project to regional fisheries, marine life and avian species will extend for hundreds of miles.  The public would know this if wind energy developers and our government hadn’t been hiding catastrophic impacts associated with wind energy projects for decades. 
The Channel Islands, miles away and critically important to seabirds, will not be protected by the Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary from Morro Bay Wind. These colonies of seabirds will be decimated like the seabird colonies in the UK have from offshore wind. Migrating species, will also not be protected.
